headline: Four Dead in Shootings in Colorado Springs
text: A shooting rampage in Colorado Springs on Saturday left four people dead, including the assailant, who was gunned down after the authorities said the person fired at officers.

headline: 17-Year-Old Is Charged With Murder in Downtown Brooklyn Shooting
text: A 17-year-old has been arrested and charged with murder after a shooting on a busy commercial street in Brooklyn left one teenager dead and another injured, the police said late Friday.

headline: Mets’ Ruben Tejada Speaks, Convinced the Slide Was Dirty
text: As the Mets took batting practice Saturday before Game 3 of the World Series, Ruben Tejada emerged into the dugout in full uniform, wearing a boot on his right foot and moving gingerly, using a cane adorned with the Mets logo, a gift from the Wilpon family.

headline: Noah Syndergaard’s Bold Statement Adds Spice to Series
text: Dickie Noles was watching the third game of the World Series on television Friday night when he saw a fastball sail up and in to a Kansas City Royals hitter. Like that, Noles had company among pitchers who had done this, to great effect, on baseball’s brightest stage.

headline: American Pharoah’s Final Triumph Wipes Away Effects of an Earlier Loss
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The defeat in the Travers Stakes in August sucked the air out of the air-conditioned V.I.P. room at Saratoga Race Course. Television cameras recorded every emotion, from shock to horror to devastation, after the Triple Crown champion American Pharoah had lost his first race in more than a year.

headline: Royals Are Still Stewing Over Noah Syndergaard’s Knockdown Pitch
text: The intrigue surrounding Noah Syndergaard’s high first offering in Game 3 did not fade before Game 4 on Saturday, although it did not affect the way Game 4 was played, either, with the Kansas City Royals winning, 5-3, and moving one step from a championship.

headline: 3 Dead, 4 Injured After Car Crashes Into Trick-or-Treaters in the Bronx
text: Three people were killed on Saturday, including a 10-year-old girl, after a car swerved off a road in the Bronx and ran onto a sidewalk, crashing into a group of children and adults who were trick-or-treating, the police said.

headline: Royals Defeat the Mets to Take a 3-1 Lead in the World Series
text: The Mets were five outs from winning a pivotal Game 4 of the World Series on Saturday night when they called on their closer, Jeurys Familia, to protect a 3-2 lead.

headline: A Crushing Error, and Now a Daunting Hole
text: History is often told in thumbnails. Bill Buckner. Mitch Williams. Steve Bartman. Grady Little. They are goats of October, never mind the context or the more complicated stories that contributed to their infamy.

text: Rebecca Jill Koenig, the daughter of Rita G. Koenig and Philip J. Koenig of Stamford, Conn., was married Saturday to Michael Neil Rosen, a son of Harriet B. Rosen of Bridgewater, N.J., and the late Eugene W. Rosen. Jeffrey Rosen, the groom’s brother, who became a minister through American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated at the Metropolitan Building, a former factory in Long Island City, Queens.

text: Janelle Burrell and Derricke Dennis were married Friday at the Liberty House, an events space in Liberty State Park in Jersey City. The Rev. Keith C. Treadwell, a Baptist minister, officiated.

text: Lindsay Barrett Shelton and David Jeremy Pashman were married Saturday evening at Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts, an event space and former synagogue in New York. headline: Mets Let Game 4 Slip Away
text: An eighth-inning error by Daniel Murphy helped the Kansas City Royals rally to a victory that gave them a commanding lead in the World Series.

text: “Ominously, business has a good chance of opting out of the legal system altogether and misbehaving without reproach.”

headline: Al Qaeda Claims Responsibility for Attacks on 2 Publishers in Bangladesh
text: NEW DELHI — Statements attributed to a regional division of Al Qaeda late on Saturday claimed responsibility for attacks on two publishers in Bangladesh who put out works critical of fundamentalist Islam, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors radical Islamic propaganda.

headline: Royals Aren’t Perfect, but Opportunistic Does Just Fine
text: As Alex Rios stood in front of his locker and patiently explained how on baseball’s biggest stage, despite being surrounded by several scoreboards and nearby teammates, he forgot how many outs there were, he could at least shrug.

headline: Erdogan’s Party in Turkey Regains Parliamentary Majority
text: ISTANBUL — In a stunning electoral comeback, the Islamist party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan regained its majority in Parliament on Sunday, ensuring Mr. Erdogan’s continued dominance of Turkish politics after months of political turmoil and violence.

headline: China, Japan and South Korea Pledge to Expand Trade at Joint Meeting
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Meeting for the first time in three years, leaders from China, Japan and South Korea agreed on Sunday that they would meet annually and work toward greater trade ties, even as they continued to wrangle over territorial and historical disputes.

headline: SAP Chief Bill McDermott Embarks on Health Care Mission After Losing His Eye
text: On July 6, Bill McDermott, the chief executive of one of the world’s largest software companies, fell down the stairs at his brother’s house. He awoke in a pool of blood.

headline: Guinea President’s Re-election Confirmed Despite Fraud Complaints
text: CONAKRY, Guinea — After a presidential vote that prompted a spate of violence and complaints of fraud, election results were validated in Guinea late Saturday, confirming the incumbent, Alpha Condé, as the winner.

headline: Popular Hotel in Somalia Is Bombed by Militants
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Islamist militants stormed a popular hotel in the heart of Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, on Sunday, blowing up the front gate with a car bomb, shooting guests and hotel workers, and then battling with security forces from the hotel’s rooftop for several hours.

headline: Amid Vigils and Debris, Officials Seek Cause of Sinai Peninsula Crash
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — As Russia mourned the 224 victims of a charter flight that crashed over the weekend on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt, investigators on Sunday began the difficult process of trying to determine whether the plane, which they said had broken up in midair, was brought down by an act of terrorism or a tragic accident.

headline: Why Consumers Often Err in Choosing Health Plans
text: It’s open enrollment season for almost every kind of health insurance in America. Millions of Americans using Medicare plans, employer-sponsored health insurance or Affordable Care Act marketplaces select health plans each fall. Many consumers face numerous options, and research shows that they make many mistakes, often paying more than they need to.

headline: Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Grow Apart as Their Ambitions Expand
text: WASHINGTON — When he ran for the Senate from Texas in 2012, Ted Cruz welcomed the comparisons on Capitol Hill and in the news media to Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, another 41-year-old Cuban-American and oratorically gifted conservative, who had ridden a wave of Tea Party support two years earlier to victory over his state’s Republican establishment.

headline: Running While Juggling Is Banned by Marathon Organizers
text: As an elite joggler — that is, someone who runs while juggling — Michal Kapral of Canada is used to doing things the hard way. But at this year’s New York City Marathon, that meant something different: settling for an ordinary 26.2 miles, empty-handed. Marathon organizers banned joggling from the course, ruling that beanbags filled with millet seed, like Kapral’s, count as “Prohibited Items.”

headline: 1915: Sarah Bernhardt Says War Took Most Leading Men
text: Mme. Sarah Bernhardt, who recently arrived in Paris to rehearse her new play, has announced that she will leave on December 25 for her postponed American tour. Though the great artist had just come from the theatre fatigued from the daily rehearsals, she received a Herald correspondent at her home on boulevard Pereire, and talked at length of her trip to America.

headline: Evgeny Kissin to Take a Break in U.S., But Not Europe
text: American fans of the pianist Evgeny Kissin are about to go from feast to famine. This season Mr. Kissin seems ubiquitous at some of the country’s leading concert halls, but after May he does not plan to perform in the United States again until 2018, his representatives said.

headline: On Ballot, Ohio Grapples With Specter of Marijuana Monopoly
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As a member of the International Cannabinoid Research Society, a collector of antique marijuana apothecary jars, the founder of an industrial hemp business and “a pot smoker consistently for 47 years,” Don Wirtshafter, an Ohio lawyer, has fought for decades to make marijuana legal, calling it “my life’s work.”

headline: Scenes From the New York City Marathon
text: Images from Sunday’s New York City Marathon, which got underway at 8:30 a.m., when the wheelchair athletes took off.

headline: Daniel Murphy Hit Them High and Far, but Couldn’t Reach Down Low
text: When the helium begins to leak from the balloon and the descent turns pell-mell, the earth can soar up to greet you with startling speed.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Airing His First Ad of the Campaign
text: Senator Bernie Sanders is airing the first television ad of his campaign, a biographical spot that describes his up-by-the-bootstraps childhood in Brooklyn, incorporates imagery of the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and paints him as “an honest leader.”

headline: Job-Killing Obama
text: Source.

headline: Inside the Trial of Sheldon Silver
text: The list of people who may testify or be mentioned at the corruption trial of Assemblyman Sheldon Silver is a who’s who of Albany politics and New York City real estate.

headline: Report on Bella Vista Health Center
text: A woman with Alzheimer’s was sexually assaulted by other residents at the Bella Vista Health Center, a nursing home in Lemon Grove, Calif., according to an investigation by the state’s department of public health.

headline: Plastic Boat Sinks Off Greece, Killing 11 Migrants
text: ATHENS — A week of drownings in the Aegean Sea was capped on Sunday by more tragedy when a plastic boat carrying migrants from Turkey capsized and sank off the Greek island of Samos in high winds, killing 11 people including six children, according to Greek officials.

headline: Beware the Fine Print
text: When she bought her car, Tinker Martin-Bowen signed a contract with an arbitration clause that took away her right to a jury trial. Only later did she realize just what she had given up.

headline: In Arbitration, a ‘Privatization of the Justice System’
text: Deborah L. Pierce, an emergency room doctor in Philadelphia, was optimistic when she brought a sex discrimination claim against the medical group that had dismissed her. Respected by colleagues, she said she had a stack of glowing evaluations and evidence that the practice had a pattern of denying women partnerships.

headline: Paul Ryan Says He Won’t Work With Obama on Immigration Reform
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan said in a series of televised interviews on Sunday that he would not work with the Obama administration on changing immigration policy, effectively pushing off the issue to at least 2017.

headline: Elaine May to Direct Mike Nichols Documentary for PBS
text: Roughly six decades after she teamed with Mike Nichols to form one of comedy’s most influential duos, Elaine May has again signed on for a Nichols project. Ms. May will direct an “American Masters” documentary about the acclaimed director, who died in November 2014 at 83. The film will debut on PBS on Jan. 29 to kick off the 30th season of “American Masters.”

headline: G.O.P. Debates Fail to Give Voters Basic Details
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican presidential candidates’ three debates have been sometimes compelling, often contentious and always amusing.

headline: In Two Corruption Cases, the Culture of Albany Will Go on Trial
text: In separate federal courthouses in Lower Manhattan this month, two of the most powerful men in New York are about to go on trial, an extraordinary spectacle centering on allegations of corruption, bribery and nepotism in the state’s highest chambers of political power.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 4:20 P.M. THE LUNCHBOX (2014) Food from (and for) the heart: A neglected Mumbai housewife sends a home-cooked meal to her husband — and ends up pen pals with a widowed office worker after it goes astray. The great Irrfan Khan stars. It’s not a new conceit, but “the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. (Starz Cinema) (Image: Mr. Khan)

headline: Alex Rodriguez Is an October Surprise
text: Alex Rodriguez, the Fox pregame-show version of himself, was sitting on a black couch in a trailer outside Citi Field on Friday night talking about the World Series. This is a new role for Rodriguez, an unexpected diversion in a journey of athletic greatness tainted by performance-enhancing drugs, and one he is excelling at. So he looked happy to be talking about baseball as he peered into his interviewer’s eyes, answered some questions, avoided some others and posed a few of his own. He discussed his love of preparation, his note-taking, his working with Pete Rose (“When it comes to baseball, he has an Ivy League mind”) and his admiration of Keith Hernandez.

headline: A Dazzling Encore for Mary Keitany, and a Promising Debut for Laura Thweatt
text: Running a marathon for the first time is hard enough, especially when your debut involves vying for the top American slot in the largest race in the world. So before she took off with the other professional women Sunday in the New York City Marathon, Laura Thweatt faced a special set of concerns.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Elections in Myanmar
text: Voting will take place on on Nov. 8 in what is expected to be a major test for the country’s military establishment.

headline: Natural Confusion
text: Brad DeLong is bemused by the way Tyler Cowen makes very heavy going of the simple concept of the natural rate of interest. I will say that this kind of gratuitous complexification is somewhat characteristic.

headline: Stanley Biwott of Kenya Wins New York City Marathon Men’s Race
text: The New York City Marathon had not been forgiving for Stanley Biwott of Kenya. He was among the favorites in 2012, but the race was canceled in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. In 2013, Biwott hung near the front for about 23 of 26.2 miles, then faded to fifth place.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Press Operation Gets an Overhaul
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s press shop, the focal point of her campaign over the summer as she tried to grapple with questions about her use of private email while at the State Department, is adding staff members and reshuffling existing personnel as it prepares for the final months of the nominating contest and the general election.

headline: 1965: Gemini Astronauts to Fly in Long Johns
text: WASHINGTON — There’s no other way to phrase it: the Gemini-7 astronauts plan to spend ten days in orbit in GI underwear. If their funnel-shaped Gemini spacecraft doesn’t spring a leak, Air Force Maj. Frank Borman and his co-pilot, Navy Lt. Cmdr. James Lovell, intend to doff their silver spacesuits and continue the 14-day flight in regulation Air Force long johns. Long practiced by Russian cosmonauts, the so-called ‘‘shirt-sleeve’’ flight was not to become a part of the U.S. space program until the three-man Apollo spacecraft begin flying in 1967. Behind the change in plans is the absolute confidence that Gemini’s pressure hull will not expose the astronauts to the vacuum of space. If it did collide with a meteoroid or suffered explosive decompression for some other reason, the astronauts would pass out in less than a minute. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 2, 1965

headline: Fatal Crash in the Bronx Unites Two Families in Grief
text: Two groups of children trick-or-treating with their older relatives on Saturday briefly crossed paths on a Bronx sidewalk. They were strangers to one another when an out-of-control car veered off the avenue and over the curb.

headline: Patricia Canning Todd, 93, Dies; Tennis Champion Refused to Play on Side Court
text: Patricia Canning Todd, who won four Grand Slam tennis tournaments in 1947 and 1948 but lost the chance for another title when she refused to play on a side court at the 1948 French singles championships, died on Sept. 5 in Encinitas, Calif. She was 93.

headline: ‘Our Brand Is Crisis’ Finds Little Love at Box Office, Where ‘The Martian’ Is No. 1
text: LOS ANGELES — Another one bites the dust: “Our Brand Is Crisis” collected a dismal $3.4 million at North American theaters over the weekend, extending a cold streak for Warner Bros. and exacerbating concerns in Hollywood about the recent failure of high-profile dramas, including “Steve Jobs” and “The Walk,” to find audiences.

headline: A.C.C. Suspends Miami-Duke Officiating Crew for Allowing Final Play
text: It was one of the wildest finishes you will ever see. Using lateral after lateral, Miami managed a 97-yard kickoff return as time expired to beat Duke.

headline: Willis Carto, Far-Right Figure and Holocaust Denier, Dies at 89
text: Willis Carto, a reclusive behind-the-scenes wizard of the far-right fringe of American politics who used lobbying and publishing to denigrate Jews and other minorities and galvanize the movement to deny the Holocaust, died last Monday at his home in Virginia. He was 89.

headline: Le’Veon Bell Carted Off After Injuring Knee in Steelers’ Loss
text: The Pittsburgh Steelers barely got a chance to welcome Ben Roethlisberger back from a knee injury before Le’Veon Bell went down with what appeared to be a major injury to his right knee in a game against the Cincinnati Bengals. Bell was taken to the locker room on the back of a cart, and he did not return.

headline: Fantastic Finishes, and a Domino Effect on the Rankings
text: Saturday would have seemed like a good day for a cocktail party if you were a college football fan, and not just because it included the actual World’s Largest Outdoor Cocktail Party, the annual Florida-Georgia game, which the No. 11 Gators (7-1, 5-1 Southeastern Conference) dominated, 27-3.

headline: For Royals’ Edinson Volquez, a Bittersweet Start in His Father’s Memory
text: As Edinson Volquez went from pitch to pitch, with the game on the line for every one of them, it was impossible to tell what was churning in his mind and his heart.

headline: Jeb Bush Says He Was Unaware of Rubio PowerPoint Deck
text: In an interview that aired on Sunday, Jeb Bush said that he was unaware of a PowerPoint presentation his aides put together raising questions about his rival, Senator Marco Rubio, volunteered that he’d “kill” for his father, and said he has questions about the use of the death penalty.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Thunder at Rockets
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Leo P. Kadanoff, Physicist Who Explored How Matter Changes, Dies at 78
text: Leo P. Kadanoff, a physicist who provided critical insights into the transformations of matter from one state to another, died on Oct. 26 in Chicago. He was 78.

headline: In Fight to Save Young People, Brooklyn Doctor Treats Violence as a Public Health Issue
text: Dr. Robert Gore was stirred awake one morning in July by an urgent phone call from work. That was not unusual, given his job in the emergency department at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, a level-one trauma center that provides the highest level of care. Still, his years of skillful, coolheaded practice, of stopping bleeding and saving lives, had not prepared him for what he heard.

headline: Lightweight Blankets With a Big Footprint at the Marathon
text: Sixty-five volunteers for New York Road Runners gathered early Sunday on the west side of Central Park to tackle an unusual job: stripping 52,000 metalized blankets from industrial-size rolls several hours before the start of the New York City Marathon.

headline: Getting to the Start on Time: The Race Before the Race
text: For hundreds of New York City Marathon runners, the first line they encounter on the day of the race is along the orange rails on the outer deck of the Staten Island Ferry, where they jostle for space to photograph the Statue of Liberty, illuminated in an otherwise dark, predawn sky.

headline: Adulation Aplenty as American Pharoah Heads for the Stud Farm
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — A perky American Pharoah greeted visitors at Barn 62 on Sunday morning, a day after he won the Breeders’ Cup Classic to punctuate a competitive career in which he won nine of 11 races and captured the first Triple Crown in 37 years. His trainer, Bob Baffert, led him out of the barn at around 10 as his jubilant owner, Ahmed Zayat, stood guard.

headline: In Pro Sports, the Fan Becomes Part of the Action
text: When Jeff Vinik bought the Tampa Bay Lightning in 2010, he wanted to connect with his new community. Born in New Jersey, he had lived most of his adult life in Massachusetts, not Florida, and as an owner, Mr. Vinik said he believed that helping the local community was not just the right thing to do but would also be helpful to his team.

headline: Retiree Giving Becomes a Force of Philanthropy
text: When Carol Nash retired four years ago from Dimensions Healthcare System in Maryland after a long career in nursing, she had no inkling that she would soon be working harder than she ever did before.

headline: Spotting a Thief in a Room Full of Masks at ‘Sleep No More’
text: They arrived at their appointed time, about 8 p.m. on Monday, and showed their tickets to the doorman.

headline: In Bid to Counter Iran, Ayatollah in Iraq May End Up Emulating It
text: NAJAF, Iraq — In the struggle to transform Iraq from a dictatorship to a democracy after the American-led invasion in 2003, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the highest spiritual authority for many of the world’s Shiite Muslims, stood out as a singular champion of the effort to hold direct elections and ensure that politicians, and not clerics, rule the country.

headline: Patrick Modiano, an Author of Paris Mysteries, Keeps His Own
text: PARIS — It’s often said that Patrick Modiano, who won last year’s Nobel Prize in Literature, keeps writing the same book. That is partly true, but only in the way that Cézanne kept painting the same apples. Most of this novelist’s 30-odd atmospheric books, set in the murky waters and demimonde of occupied or newly liberated Paris, resemble and build on the others, yet each is completely distinct.

headline: Zanzibar Bombings May Be Related to a Disputed Election
text: ARUSHA, Tanzania — A string of small bombings on the island of Zanzibar has residents there fearing that the explosions could be related to last month’s disputed election and that more trouble could be coming.

headline: Your Asia Briefing: Turkey’s Election, Russian Plane Crash, Asian Leaders
text: Good morning, Asia.

headline: In Lee Mingwei’s ‘Sonic Blossom’ at the Met, Schubert Is Intimate Installation Art
text: Ahead to the left on Friday morning was Yvonne Jacquette’s painting “Little River Farm”; to the right, Chuck Close’s “Lucas I,” a portrait of the artist Lucas Samaras. Straight ahead, some dozen yards away, a young soprano, Beibei Guan, having politely inquired, “May I offer you the gift of a song?” and seated me in the lone chair, sang Schubert’s “Nacht und Träume” (“Night and Dreams”) directly to me.

headline: A Lonely End for South Koreans Who Cannot Afford to Live, or Die
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a culture in which funerals are often lavish three-day affairs with hundreds of guests, the recent funeral for Song In-sik was modest at best. It had only one guest — an activist who volunteered to hold a ritual for a person he had never met.

headline: Review: Lionel Popkin’s ‘Ruth Doesn’t Live Here Anymore’
text: What do a leaf blower and the modern-dance pioneer Ruth St. Denis have in common? For starters, both featured prominently in “Ruth Doesn’t Live Here Anymore,” a multimedia work by the Los Angeles choreographer Lionel Popkin performed at Abrons Arts Center in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Chucho Valdés, the Pianist, Reflects on Irakere and His Career
text: Chucho Valdés, the eminent Cuban pianist, bandleader and composer, carries himself with a sly balance of statesmanlike deliberation and youthful gusto. One day last month, not long before his 74th birthday, he folded his big frame onto a couch in a Midtown hotel and spoke animatedly about the last 40 years of musical exchange between the United States and Cuba — a dialogue that has largely defined his career, and one that he in turn has helped define.

headline: Review: Andras Schiff Deconstructs Sonatas
text: Deep in the second movement of Beethoven’s last piano sonata there’s a passage that’s become known as the boogie-woogie variation. The music, written in the early 1820s, suddenly breaks into a syncopated, showy dance that seems to anticipate the ragtime that would come almost a century later. A swinging riff repeats again and again, punctuated each time by two bold chords.

headline: Review: ‘Black Work,’ a Mystery and Drama with Sheridan Smith
text: Sheridan Smith is one of the busiest and most popular actresses in Britain, but very little of her work has made it to the United States. She won a Bafta award for playing a famous criminal’s wife (in “Mrs. Biggs”) and was nominated for another for playing a famous singer (“Cilla”). If she’s known here at all, though, it’s for one role — Rudi, the foul-mouthed, fiercely loyal younger sister of James Corden’s Smithy in “Gavin & Stacey.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 2
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘The Diplomat,’ a Son’s Documentary on Richard C. Holbrooke
text: In January 2011, seated alongside presidents and dignitaries at the Kennedy Center memorial service for Richard C. Holbrooke, his son David finally came to see his father as a historical figure.

headline: Review: ‘Pacific’ Is Simon Winchester’s Latest Big-Picture Book
text: In the prologue to “Pacific: Silicon Chips and Surfboards, Coral Reefs and Atom Bombs, Brutal Dictators, Fading Empires, and the Coming Collision of the World’s Superpowers,” Simon Winchester does such a virtuoso job of conveying the roiling enormity of his subject that readers may feel a kind of existential terror, wondering whether the vacant sky or the open sea will swallow them first.

headline: Republican Campaigns Meet in an Effort to Alter Debates
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — The presidential candidates in the crowded Republican field finally can agree on at least one thing: just how frustrated they are with the debate process so far.

I can’t tell you what it says because it would spoil the puzzle, but trust the emus: you’ll have a much better experience if you read it.

text: A half an hour or so after Stanley Biwott of Kenya won the New York City Marathon, he was followed by a grinning man nearly old enough to be his grandfather: David Walters, the first sexagenarian to cross the finish line Sunday.

text: One of the spookiest events this Halloween weekend may have been the dance concert presented by the Construction Company at University Settlement. There were no vampires or zombies, yet on Friday there was more than a suggestion of communication with the spirit world.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Is Injured and the Jets Are Routed by the Raiders

headline: Police Investigating Colorado Springs Shooting That Left 4 Dead

headline: Review: In Piotr Beczala’s Recital, Melancholy Mixes With Defiance
text: The Polish tenor Piotr Beczala has developed an ardent fan base in recent years. That much was evident from the adoring capacity crowd that turned out for his recital debut at Zankel Hall on Friday with the pianist Martin Katz. The program of songs by Schumann, Rachmaninoff, Dvorak and the fin-de-siècle Polish composer Mieczyslaw Karlowicz beautifully showcased his rich, virile voice, with its appealingly dark undertow.

headline: Washington State Weighs Far-Reaching Law on Animal Trafficking
text: SEATTLE — Wildlife poachers in Africa slaughter rhinos for their horns and elephants for their tusks, and organized crime gangs from Ireland to Mexico have in recent years expanded into the trade of endangered animal parts that can command more money, pound for pound, than even gold.

headline: Officers’ Boycott of Quentin Tarantino Films Grows

headline: Thousands Start Life Anew With Early Prison Releases
text: Michael Keating’s 11-year prison sentence for methamphetamine production was supposed to end next June. But he is one of thousands of federal prisoners who are benefiting from a reduction in drug sentences, and on Friday he became an ex-prisoner more than seven months earlier than he ever had reason to expect.

headline: BMG Expected to Announce Deal With the Pop Label S-Curve

headline: If Cancer Becomes Biden’s Cause, a Bold but Polarizing Doctor Is On Call
text: WASHINGTON — One day last winter, desperate as his son fought for his life against a killer brain cancer, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his family reached out to one of America’s most famous, and controversial, doctors for help.

headline: After Relenting to His Ace, Terry Collins Opens Door to More Scrutiny
text: In the eighth inning of Game 5 of the World Series, with the Mets facing elimination, Matt Harvey rushed over to Manager Terry Collins in the dugout, looking angry and shaking his head. Collins had tried removing Harvey from the game, in which he had held the Royals scoreless. The crowd was chanting Harvey’s name, urging Collins to keep him in.

headline: John Kerry Is Cautious on Human Rights During Uzbekistan Visit
text: SAMARKAND, Uzbekistan — Secretary of State John Kerry prides himself on his willingness to deal directly with some of the world’s most repressive governments, and his insistence on “engagement” has yielded results this year from Iran to Cuba. But even the State Department had a hard time explaining the strategy for transforming the behavior of President Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, a ruler whose human rights record is frequently compared to North Korea’s.

headline: San Francisco Ballots Turn Up Anger Over the Technical Divide
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Bruce Bennett is 52 and has a bum knee in need of surgery. But two Sundays ago he put on a knee brace and huffed his way up steep hills and dozens of stairs to implore residents to vote against a city measure called Proposition F.

headline: Media Earnings, Yellen’s Testimony and the Jobs Report

headline: Debris Suggests Russian Airliner Disintegrated While Aloft, Officials Say
text: PARIS — The Airbus A321-200 had just reached a cruising altitude of about 33,000 feet when, around 20 minutes after taking off from the Egyptian resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh, it suddenly plummeted by some 6,000 feet.

headline: When Royals’ Wade Davis Comes In, the Game Is as Good as Over
text: A popular talking point before this postseason was guessing which pitcher would be the next Madison Bumgarner. The answer, of course, was nobody — his dominance last fall, in toppling the Kansas City Royals, was nearly unparalleled in the annals of autumn.

headline: F.B.I. Tool to Identify Extremists Is Criticized
text: The F.B.I. is about to introduce an interactive program it developed for teachers and students, aimed at training them to prevent young people from being drawn into violent extremism. But Muslim, Arab and other religious and civil rights leaders who were invited to preview the program have raised strong objections, saying it focuses almost entirely on Islamic extremism, which they say has not been a factor in the epidemic of school shootings and attacks in the United States.

headline: Owner of The Orange County Register Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: Burdened by debt and struggling to meet its financial obligations, Freedom Communications, the media company that owns The Orange County Register, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday with an eye toward selling the company to the publisher and a group of local investors.

headline: The Best of Week 8 in the N.F.L.
text: Even with linebacker Jadeveon Clowney sidelined — he injured his back in the first quarter and left for good in the second — the Texans turned in a dominating defensive performance, forcing three Titans turnovers and tying a franchise record with seven sacks to rebound from a 44-26 loss to the Dolphins last week. Whitney Mercilus accounted for three and a half of those sacks, a career high, and J. J. Watt had two and a half, forcing a fumble on one early in the fourth quarter. Watt, who tied a career high with nine quarterback hits, said, “That’s the type of defense we expect to be.”

headline: Battles in San Francisco, but Not in Mayoral Race

With its gleaming new buildings and influx of Silicon Valley wealth, San Francisco has the fastest-growing income inequality gap in the nation.

They’re never going to be good enough. But when we finally heard bits and pieces of Noah Solloway’s “Descent” on “The Affair” on Sunday night, it was hard to have much sympathy for the screenwriter (in this case the playwright Sharr White).

Her colleagues expect her to mind her own business. But when sinister secrets surface, as you know they inevitably will (like how her husband was spying on her and probably knew about the affair she was almost having), she sets out to uncover the killer. Matt Charman, a writer on Steven Spielberg’s “Bridge of Spies,” created this three-part thriller, which stars Sheridan Smith. (Acorn TV) (Image: Ms. Smith and Matthew McNulty)

headline: Royals Rally Past Mets for First World Series Title Since 1985

It is his sanctuary, a place where he is at peace, jettisoning the scrutiny and sleepless nights that accompany him during the season.

headline: A Rooftop View of Insect Migration in a Warming Climate
text: The Natural History Museum of Denmark has studied the insect population on its rooftop for 18 years, tracking 1,543 species of moths and beetles and more than 250,000 individuals. In a study appearing in The Journal of Animal Ecology, museum researchers conclude that warming temperatures are affecting specialized insects that rely on a single food source. The nut weevil, for example, feeds only on hazelnuts; it appeared on the roof during the first half of the study but not the second. Scientists at the museum suspect that the nut weevil and other specialists are moving north, where the climate is cooler.

headline: How to Live a Lie

For the sake of enjoying a movie like “Back to the Future,” I may accept that time travel is possible even though I do not believe it. There seems no harm in that, and it does some good to the extent that it entertains and edifies me.

headline: More Stand Your Ground Mischief in Florida
text: The Florida Legislature, never one to leave bad enough alone when it comes to gun safety, is returning to the state’s notorious Stand Your Ground law to make it even easier for defendants to use it as a shield for intimidating and shooting people. Senate committees approved legislation this month that would relieve defendants of the need to prove that they were in fear for their lives. Instead, prosecutors would be required to disprove the self-defense claim in a pretrial evidentiary hearing.

headline: Amartya Sen: Women’s Progress Outdid China’s One-Child Policy

But we need to recognize that the big fall in fertility in China over the decades, for which the one-child policy is often credited, has, in fact, been less related to compulsion and much more to reasoned family decisions in favor of a new norm of smaller families.

text: MOSCOW — In Russia, where monkey chants directed at black players and Nazi salutes by fans have been persistent problems at soccer matches, local organizers of the 2018 World Cup have created a job that sets their preparations apart from those of previous hosts: antiracism inspector.

headline: Halsman, Jump on It
text: Any portrait photographer knows how hard it can be to get beyond a subject’s facade, especially in a studio setting. Irving Penn famously positioned celebrities into a narrow corner. Yousuf Karsh sometimes left his subjects alone for a few minutes between exposures. Richard Avedon is said to have told the Duke and Duchess of Windsor a made-up story about a dog being run over by his taxi in order to move past the royal pretense and evoke a sympathetic expression (it worked).

headline: Former Editor of Xinjiang Newspaper in China Is Ousted From Communist Party
text: BEIJING — The Communist Party has expelled the recent editor in chief of the official newspaper of the volatile western region of Xinjiang for openly discussing party policy and for corruption, according to an online announcement on Monday by the regional party anticorruption agency. The former editor is expected to face criminal prosecution on related charges.

headline: Ad Helped Chris Christie Win a New Jersey Race, but Then He Had to Apologize
text: In his Williamstown, N.J., home, tucked away among family ephemera, Christopher Laureys keeps that rarest of New Jersey treasures: an apology from Chris Christie.

headline: ‘Winter Is Coming,’ by Garry Kasparov
text: Russians in positions of power tend to measure their country’s standing in the world against the United States, longing to be recognized as equally important and powerful and getting very angry when they’re not so treated. President Vladimir Putin has made victimhood at America’s hands a leitmotif of his reign, and many Russians have bought into his claim that Washington tirelessly seeks ways to weaken, impoverish and otherwise humiliate their country. Many critics of Putin, in Russia and in the West, similarly hold that Washington’s treatment of Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union was disdainful and thus undermined embryonic moves toward democracy, contributing to the rise of Putinism.

headline: ‘The New Tsar: The Rise and Reign of Vladimir Putin,’ by Steven Lee Myers
text: Vladimir Putin has an origin story. It takes place in Dresden in the fall of 1989, in the dying days of East Germany, on the night that thousands of protesters stormed the city’s Stasi headquarters. Once they were done ransacking the offices that had inspired so much terror, they directed their anger down the street toward the K.G.B. residence where Lieutenant Colonel Putin, a young intelligence officer, stood looking out the window. Watching the approaching mob, Putin called the local Soviet military command and asked for reinforcements. But no higher authority would approve it. “Moscow is silent,” he was told.

headline: Michel Houellebecq’s ‘Submission’
text: Before I begin this review, I have to make a small confession. I have never read Michel Houellebecq’s books. This is odd, I concede, since Houellebecq is considered a great contemporary author, and one cannot be said to be keeping abreast of contemporary literature without reading his work. His books have been recommended to me ever since 1998, most often “The Elementary Particles,” by one friend in particular, who says the same thing every time I see him. You have to read “The Elementary Particles,” he tells me, it’s awesome, the best book I’ve ever read. Several times I’ve been on the verge of heeding his advice, plucking “The Elementary Particles” from its place on my shelf and considering it for a while, though always returning it unread. The resistance to starting a book by Houellebecq is too great. I’m not entirely sure where it comes from, though I do have a suspicion, because the same thing goes for the films of Lars von Trier: When “Antichrist” came out I couldn’t bring myself to see it, neither in the cinema nor at home on the DVD I eventually bought, which remains in its box unwatched. They’re simply too good. What prevents me from reading Houellebecq and watching von Trier is a kind of envy — not that I begrudge them success, but by reading the books and watching the films I would be reminded of how excellent a work of art can be, and of how far beneath that level my own work is. Such a reminder, which can be crushing, is something I shield myself from by ignoring Houellebecq’s books and von Trier’s films. That may sound strange, and yet it can hardly be unusual. If you’re a carpenter, for instance, and you keep hearing about the amazing work of another carpenter, you’re not necessarily going to seek it out, because what would be the good of having it confirmed that there is a level of excellence to which you may never aspire? Better to close your eyes and carry on with your own work, pretending the master carpenter doesn’t exist.

headline: Know Your Risks, but Meat Still Isn’t the Enemy
text: Smoking tobacco causes cancer. So does eating salted fish, drinking alcohol, breathing polluted air and being exposed to the sun. All of these things are classified as cancer-causing by the World Health Organization.

headline: Mystery Deepens Over Russian Plane Crash in Egypt

headline: Mary Gaitskill and the Life Unseen
text: When the writer Mary Gaitskill was a child in the 1950s, she was once taken to a roller-skating rink. She looked around and burst into tears. She didn’t understand why everybody was wearing the same thing, those poodle skirts and poodle hairdos.

headline: Wireless Start-up Artemis Reaches Deal With Nokia
text: A little over a year ago, a start-up in San Francisco called Artemis Networks announced a new technology that it said could enable much faster Internet access speeds over wireless networks, which often slow dramatically when too many people use their smartphones in busy locations.

headline: Visa to Buy Back Former Europe Unit for Up to $23.3 Billion
text: LONDON — Visa said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to pay as much as 21.2 billion euros, or about $23.3 billion, to acquire its former unit Visa Europe Ltd.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Season 2, Episode 5: Laughing With God
text: Sunday’s “The Leftovers” was the most compelling hour so far of season two, and that’s a bold statement considering how outstanding the second season has been. “No Room at the Inn” — which, like season one’s third episode, focused on the seemingly boundless bad luck that befalls Matt Jamison — was a pulse-pounder: intense, semi-violent, and surprising in scene after scene. It also continued to lock in on the themes of spirituality and faith that are central to “The Leftovers,” in ways overt (the conversation between John Murphy and Matt) and more subtle (the use of that Regina Spektor song that declares, “We’re all laughing with God”).

headline: Protecting Underage Models Becomes a Federal Issue
text: Paul D. Ryan, the new speaker of the House of Representatives, has another potential issue on his hands. For the first time since Brooke Shields donned her Calvins in the ’80s, spurring a national conversation, the question of underage models has reached the white dome of the Capitol.

headline: Heavy Fog Envelops Parts of Europe, Canceling Flights
text: LONDON — Dense fog caused scores of flights to be delayed or canceled early Monday across three of the world’s busiest aviation hubs — London, Amsterdam and Frankfurt — and shrouded London landmarks like St. Paul’s Cathedral and the Houses of Parliament in a thick mist that was remarkable even by the capital’s standards.

headline: Iran Begins Deactivating Centrifuges Under Nuclear Deal’s Terms
text: TEHRAN — Iran has started decommissioning the first of thousands of centrifuges used for enriching uranium as part of its commitments under the nuclear deal reached with global powers, the head of Iran’s nuclear energy program was quoted as saying on a visit to Japan on Monday.

headline: Irish Drug Maker Shire Agrees to Buy Dyax in Deal Worth Up to $6.5 Billion
text: LONDON — The Irish drug maker Shire said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the American biotechnology company Dyax Corporation in a deal that could be worth as much as $6.5 billion.

headline: Peyton Manning of Old Shows Up, and the Broncos Stay Undefeated

headline: A Quiet Swiss Town’s Unlikely Treasure: Shoes
text: ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT collections of footwear in Europe — and arguably the world — is not housed in a grand museum in Rome or Paris but in a remote 18th-century manor high north of the Swiss Alps owned by Bally, the 164-year-old fashion and leather goods brand best known for its shoes. In a storybook town between Zurich and Basel is Zum Felsengarten, home to the Bally Shoe Museum in Schönenwerd. Inside, more than 1,000 pairs of footwear represent 3,000 years of history: French court heels from the 17th century, Venetian platforms from the 16th, Queen Elizabeth II’s gold coronation shoes.

headline: How Donald Trump Leverages America’s Fault Lines
text: Anyone who has spent any time analyzing public opinion and voting data from the last 20 or so years has seen the fault lines that Donald Trump is leveraging. The data is clear: Anxiety about those who are different, support for traditional American values and a resistance toward openness all play a role in how people make up their minds in presidential elections.

headline: When Free Speech Disappears From Campus
text: The willingness to discuss uncomfortable ideas is under threat at American universities. What does this say about millennials as future leaders of this country?

headline: 1890: Prince Bismarck as a Brewer
text: BERLIN — It is announced that Prince Bismarck, together with a syndicate of Hamburg financiers, will establish a large brewery at Friedrichsruhe, with a capital of 600,000 marks. The brewery will, it is estimated, produce about 25,000 hectoliters of beer yearly. The Hamburg Association will own the brewery for fifty years, paying the ex-Chancellor and his heirs during that time the sum of 3,000 marks for the rent, Prince Bismarck reserving the right for his heirs to buy up the concern at the termination of the fifty years. The promoters are confident that the export trade will be large, owing in a great measure to the Prince’s popularity abroad. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 3, 1890

headline: Daily Report: San Francisco Voters Have Their Say on Tech Boom

headline: Party Victory in Turkey Bolsters Erdogan’s Pursuit of Power

headline: Nuremberg Nazi Site Crumbles, but Tricky Questions on Its Future Persist

headline: Bird Eggs Are Fertilized by More Than One Sperm
text: Bird eggs are fertilized by more than one sperm, a process called polyspermy. Penetration by multiple sperm may be unusual in the animal kingdom, but it is somehow crucial to the development of the bird embryo, a new study finds.

headline: Gaining Insight Into Some Itches

headline: For Statins, Cholesterol Care May Be Just the Start
text: Shortly after my 60th birthday, my cholesterol level inexplicably began to rise despite daily exercise, a healthy weight and a diet low in saturated fats. I tried to bring it down by cutting cheese, eggs and most meat from my diet as well as taking a daily fiber supplement, fish oils and plant sterols. Yet at every three-month checkup, my total cholesterol — and especially artery-damaging LDL cholesterol — was higher than the one before.

headline: Telemundo, With Its Republican Debate Put Off, Seeks a Democratic One

headline: 1940: Italians Bomb Crete
text: ROME — Italian planes have bombed and machine-gunned troops landing on the island of Crete, the high command said today [Nov. 2], and Italian troops were reported proceeding along the Kalamas (Thymais) River valley toward Janina, twenty-five miles within Greek territory. The attack on Crete, the high command said, had visible results, and ‘‘some steamships were struck and docks and material were damaged.’’ Informed quarters believed the troops landing to have been British. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 3, 1940

headline: Questions and Answers about Veteran Suicides
text: Since coming back from Afghanistan in 2008, the hard-hit Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment has struggled to adjust. The battalion, known as the 2/7, lost 20 men in war. In the years since, it has lost 13 more to suicide. The battalion now has a suicide rate 14 times that for all Americans.

headline: Bien Cuit Offers a Seasonal Danish
text: A new seasonal pastry in Zachary Golper’s line of Danish (or what the French call viennoiserie) at Bien Cuit has a suave center of yam seasoned with maple. I could see serving this treasure, warmed, with a scoop of vanilla ice cream alongside, one per person, as dessert at Thanksgiving dinner. It joins the raisin and apple varieties the bakery has been selling. And starting Wednesday, the pastries will also be available at 32 Whole Foods markets in the Northeast: Danish, $2 each, Bien Cuit, 120 Smith Street (Dean Street), Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, 718-852-0200, biencuit.com.

headline: Mumbai’s Lavish New Palace of Jewels
text: The Gem Palace, the famous ninth-generation purveyor of exquisite Mughal-inspired jewelry, is opening a lavish new shop this month in Mumbai — its first that can be visited without an appointment. The interiors by the Dutch-born, Jaipur-based designer Marie-Anne Oudejans recall traditional Rajasthan colonial décor: checkerboard marble floors, emerald walls, salmon silk sofas. Upstairs, a private salon and showroom boasts backlit carved panels painted with elaborate floral motifs — and a canopied bed for when the burden of choice takes its toll.

headline: An Artful Rebound From the Mets’ Big Loss
text: Driven out of the park, rebounded off a kneecap or ricocheted from a shattered bat into the stands — there are lots of ways to lose a ball, as evidenced by the last game of the 111th World Series on Sunday. On average, the series requires about 500 baseballs, all assembled by hand in much the same way they were a century ago: Each cork and rubber center is wrapped in yarn, encased in white cowhide and stitched together with waxed red thread. The same details inspire the Brooklyn-born and Mets-raised artist Elissa Goldstone’s work, which pays tribute to the days of knee-highs and chewing tobacco with highlight-reel scenes embroidered in bright, erratic lines; cotton sculptures of the four bases; and paper drawings done in familiar red double-stitch. For Goldstone, appreciating the minutiae of the game is the best way to cope with the inevitable heartbreak of being a baseball fan.

headline: 1852: Abraham Lincoln’s Other Party
text: The Republican Party is famously “the party of Lincoln” (the phrase has turned up in The Times six times since Aug. 1). But Lincoln actually spent a majority of his political career in another party — the Whigs, who were born in opposition to Andrew Jackson and his Democrats.

headline: Putin Calls for Objective Investigation
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia asked investigators to work with Egyptian and other authorities in determining what caused the plane crash on the Sinai Peninsula that killed 224 people.

headline: Special Delivery
text: Starship Technologies, an Estonian start-up, wants its robot to solve the “last mile” problem — getting goods like groceries, drug store items and most small packages to suburban homes.

headline: Skype Founders Build a Robot for Suburban Streets
text: Menlo Park, Calif. — Almost half a century ago, the first autonomous robot project, dubbed Shakey, was started here at a laboratory that is now called SRI International. Shakey was the first machine used to pursue a range of artificial intelligence technologies such as planning, navigation, machine vision and even speech recognition. Funded by the Pentagon, it was originally modeled on the idea of an autonomous sentry for a military base.

headline: Review: ‘Fortuna Desperata,’ in Which David Hallberg Explores the Beginnings of Ballet
text: It hasn’t really been forever, though it feels that way. David Hallberg, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater and the Bolshoi Ballet, has been missing in action since 2014, after an ankle injury forced him to cancel performances at both companies.

headline: When Adele Says ‘Hello,’ Fans Listen
text: The numbers are in for Adele’s “Hello,” her first single in three years, and they are stunning.

headline: 15 Years of Living in Space
text: Astronauts reflect on 15 years of humans inhabiting the International Space Station.

headline: Intimate Snapshots of Madonna, Warhol and More
text: Paige Powell, Interview magazine’s former associate publisher and the ex-girlfriend of Jean-Michel Basquiat, shares photos from her personal archive.

headline: In Performance | 'Sylvia'
text: Annaleigh Ashford plays a stray dog with Matthew Broderick as her new owner in A.R. Gurney’s comedy "Sylvia," which ran on Broadway in 2015.

headline: Never-Before-Seen Photos of Madonna, Warhol, Basquiat and More
text: Some It-girls of the ’80s may regret that their youthful glory predated social media, but Interview magazine’s former associate publisher Paige Powell doesn’t have to. Powell arrived in New York in 1980 from the Pacific Northwest, looking like a granola version of Edie Sedgwick and armed with the work ethic of Mary Tyler Moore. She was soon swept up in Interview’s bid to be a more serious publication — “At first it was more for friends, like, Fran Lebowitz drove the delivery truck to drop off issues at different newsstands,” she remembers — and Andy Warhol’s select social whirlwind of downtown clubbing, midtown shopping and uptown lunches. “Andy always said, ‘Work is fun and fun is work,’” Powell says. “It was just the way I thought New York City was, all the time, for everyone — exuberant.”

headline: In Performance: Matthew Broderick and Annaleigh Ashford of ‘Sylvia’
text: The latest In Performance video features the Tony Award-winning actors Matthew Broderick and Annaleigh Ashford in a scene from A. R. Gurney’s comedy “Sylvia,” which opened last week on Broadway at the Cort Theater. In the play, Greg (Mr. Broderick), hoping to curtail a downer of a midlife crisis, takes home a dog (Ms. Ashford) he finds wandering around Central Park one day. An unconventional love triangle — among Greg, his wife (played by Julie White) and the dog,named Sylvia — ensues.

headline: WeWork Said to Seek $750 Million Credit Facility
text: WeWork, which rents out offices and desks to freelancers and budding companies, has been on a fund-raising tear.

headline: Review: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ in Isango Ensemble’s South African Setting
text: Benjamin Britten fussed over the details of his operas, working hard to get every vocal line, pungent chord and instrumental color exactly as he wanted. What might he have thought of the very freely adapted production of his 1960 opera, “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” by the South African company Isango Ensemble, which opened on Friday at the New Victory Theater?

headline: Support Houston’s Equal Rights Ordinance
text: On Tuesday, Houston voters will be asked if they want to keep or repeal the city’s strong and enlightened equal rights ordinance, which was approved by the City Council last year and put on hold pending this week’s vote. Opponents of the law have perversely turned a broad, sensible measure  that protects people from discrimination in employment, city services, housing and public accommodations, among other things, into a debate about sexual predators in women’s restrooms.

headline: Review: ‘Theodora,’ Once a Handel Flop, Is Celebrated Anew
text: A long line of people waited outside Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening, hoping to get returned tickets for a performance of Handel’s “Theodora.” Handel would have felt vindicated. The 1750 premiere in London of this dramatic oratorio, a score of more than three hours, was a major flop for that celebrated composer. But of Handel’s 17 English oratorios, this was his favorite.

headline: Husband Charged in Wife’s 2009 Killing on Upper West Side
text: On the last morning of 2009, a 9-year-old girl went into a bathroom in her family apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and found her mother lying lifeless in the tub. At first, it looked to investigators as if it might have been an accident — Shele Danishefsky Covlin, a 47-year-old finance executive, had died after a hard fall, they thought.

headline: Judge Rules Bill Cosby Can Be Deposed in Janice Dickinson Case
text: Bill Cosby and his former lawyer can be questioned under oath in a defamation lawsuit filed against Mr. Cosby by the onetime supermodel Janice Dickinson, a judge ruled on Monday.

headline: Review: In John Irving’s ‘Avenue of Mysteries,’ a Blur of Aphorisms and Magical Events
text: Juan Diego Guerrero, the hero of John Irving’s 14th novel, “Avenue of Mysteries,” is a middle-aged Mexican-American novelist who, when he travels, carries two types of prescription pills in his Dopp kit.

headline: Serial Gems Are Painstakingly Restored for the Screen
text: Master villains and mysterious avengers stalked the serial films that gripped audiences in cinema’s silent years. But in the thick of World War I, another twist on these shadowy figures appeared in the Kaiser’s Germany in 1916. Its hero was the Homunculus, and he was, in the impassioned words of the film’s title cards, a lab-created superhuman “not conceived by love but through science.”

text: President Obama announced a series of small initiatives to help former inmates find jobs and live in subsidized housing, part of his broader effort to remake the criminal justice system.

headline: Jets Explore Quarterback Options After Injuries to Ryan Fitzpatrick and Geno Smith

headline: Suzanne Farrell and Kyra Nichols Carry On Balanchine’s Spirit
text: WASHINGTON — Since the death of the choreographer George Balanchine (1904-83), his legacy has both receded and grown. The last of Balanchine’s own dancers have retired. Certain aspects of Balanchine technique have lost their gleaming edge (as he himself often predicted). Yet there’s been a vast posthumous Balanchine surge. I’ve seen more than 60 of his ballets in the last 10 years; Balanchine Without Balanchine is a growth industry.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in Sheldon Silver Corruption Trial
text: Assemblyman Sheldon Silver got his first good look on Monday at the prospective jurors who will hear his case and decide his fate. He did not seem to know or recognize any of them, yet many were already familiar with him.

headline: African Biennale of Photography Returns to Mali Amid Unrest
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Faceless health workers in biohazard suits representing the fear of Ebola. Preachers with black spheres for heads showing the dark effects of religious obscurantism. Images conjuring a political leader’s life had he not been assassinated.

text: Despite the release of recorded comments in which he said he preferred to avoid Jews and homosexuals, the president of the Italian Soccer Federation, Carlo Tavecchio, insisted on Monday that he was neither anti-Semitic nor homophobic.

headline: New U.S.-Backed Alliance to Counter ISIS in Syria Falters
text: EIN EISSA, Syria — Weeks after the Obama administration canceled a failed Pentagon program to train and arm Syrian rebels to combat the Islamic State, American officials announced a new effort to equip ground forces in Syria to fight the jihadists.

headline: Illinois District Violated Transgender Student’s Rights, U.S. Says
text: CHICAGO — Federal education authorities, staking out their firmest position yet on an increasingly contentious issue, found Monday that an Illinois school district violated anti-discrimination laws when it did not allow a transgender student who identifies as a girl and participates on a girls’ sports team to change and shower in the girls’ locker room without restrictions.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Thoughts on the Joys and Pains of Baseball, Outsourced to an Aide

headline: Unofficially 49,467th, but First Among the New York City Marathon’s ‘Almost’ Crew
text: The finish line for the New York City Marathon, so orderly and secure throughout the morning and afternoon, resembled a carcass by Sunday evening as workers began to strip away its decorative features. A red truck slowly backed over the line, and employees hopped out to disassemble signs.

headline: Yemen: Powerful Storm Strikes Island
text: A powerful cyclone struck an island off the coast of Yemen on Monday, washing away the island’s main seaport and displacing more than 2,000 families, according to Saeed Bahegeba, the governor of the island, Socotra. The storm, known as Chapala, then threatened the Yemeni mainland. By Monday evening, the cyclone was bearing down on Al Mukalla, the country’s fifth-largest city, which has been under the control of the Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen since April.

headline: Speaker Paul Ryan Moves Fast to ‘Detoxify’ Boehner’s Smoky Suite
text: WASHINGTON — There are many things Americans cannot yet know about Speaker Paul D. Ryan’s plans for his fancy new digs on Capitol Hill. Dark curtains or sheers? Memorabilia from the 2012 presidential campaign or his first House race in 1998? Will he hang a poster of his favorite band, Rage Against the Machine?

headline: Soros Takes Back $490 Million From Bill Gross at Janus Capital
text: The billionaire hedge fund investor George Soros has withdrawn $490 million from a new investment fund set up by William H. Gross, according to investment filings.

headline: World Series Television Ratings Up Over Comparable Games From Last Year
text: The Kansas City Royals’ victory over the Mets on Sunday night in the fifth and deciding game of the World Series was seen by an average of 17.2 million viewers on Fox, nearly 37 percent better than the average for Game 5 of last year’s Series, between the Royals and the San Francisco Giants.

headline: Ben Carson Leads Donald Trump in New NBC Poll
text: For the second time in a week, Ben Carson took the lead in a national poll, drawing 29 percent support in an NBC/Wall Street Journal survey released on Monday evening and eclipsing Donald J. Trump, who had 23 percent.

headline: Russia: Librarian Is Accused of Allowing Access to Banned Ukrainian Books
text: The director of a Ukrainian-language library in Moscow was placed under house arrest on Monday by a Russian court that accused her of allowing public access to banned literature. The director, Natalia Sharina, could face as much as five years in prison for what Russian law enforcement agencies said was the dissemination of books by a Ukrainian nationalist writer, Dmytro Korchynsky, that are banned in Russia for promoting anti-Russian propaganda. Ms. Sharina denied the charges, saying the banned books were “planted during the searches,” a claim that was repeated by staff members. “Books cannot constitute extremism, because in my opinion extremism is an action,” she said in the courtroom, the Kommersant newspaper reported. Ms. Sharina’s lawyers have appealed the decision, the Interfax news agency said, and Human Rights Watch called for her immediate release in a statement.

headline: New York City F.C. Fires Coach Jason Kreis
text: New York City F.C. fired Coach Jason Kreis on Monday, laying the blame for a forgettable inaugural season in Major League Soccer on him and his staff.

headline: Entergy to Close Nuclear Plant on Lake Ontario, Angering Cuomo
text: The Entergy Corporation said on Monday that it had decided to close a 40-year-old nuclear power plant on the shore of Lake Ontario, disappointing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who said the company showed a “callous disregard” for more than 600 employees.

headline: Republicans’ Talk of Taxes Leaves Much Unsaid

text: Sales of organic and natural products are soaring — but you would never know it from the share price of Whole Foods Market, the premier purveyor of such merchandise.

text: CASTILE, N.Y. — The Genesee River flows through Letchworth State Park, forming a luminous ribbon at the bottom of 600-foot cliffs of shale and sandstone, and earning the park the nickname “Grand Canyon of the East.”

headline: Thomas Blatt, Who Escaped Death Camp During Revolt, Dies at 88

headline: A City Offers a World Series Title as Proof of Its Resurgence
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — All October, this city had been crazy for its baseball team. Locals ended their conversations with “Go, Royals.” The water in the famed J. C. Nichols Memorial Fountain was dyed blue. And jubilant masses turned out for viewing parties in the downtown Power and Light District, a booming shopping and entertainment area that not so long ago was a portrait of urban decline.

text: Iran suggested on Monday that it might withdraw from the new peace talks on Syria because of what Iranian officials described as the unconstructive role of Saudi Arabia, Iran’s rival for dominance in the Middle East.

headline: A New Look, and Label, for American Eagle Outfitters
text: The teenage-fashion retailer American Eagle Outfitters is set to acquire the high-end men’s wear label Todd Snyder for $11 million in cash and stock, shifting away from the “fast fashion” wars that have upended the teenage apparel market, and aiming to gain a foothold with an older age group.

headline: To Help Alex Ovechkin, Capitals Add Proven Scorers and Winners
text: WASHINGTON — The Washington Capitals have elevated losing Game 7s in the N.H.L. playoffs into a masochistic art form. They have been eliminated in a Game 7 six times in the past eight years, including three straight by the Rangers.

headline: Colorado: Suspect Killed in Rampage Is Identified
text: The authorities in Colorado Springs have identified the man they say killed three people in a shooting rampage on Saturday before being shot to death in a gunfight with the police. The El Paso County Sheriff’s Office said Monday that the assailant was Noah Jacob Harpham, 32, left, a local resident. The Colorado Springs Gazette reported that witnesses had said the assailant had a rifle in one hand and a revolver in the other when he killed a bicyclist on Saturday. He then walked less than a mile and fatally shot two women who were chatting on a porch. The victims were identified as Andrew Alan Myers, 35; Jennifer Michelle Vasquez, 42; and Christina Rose Baccus-Gallela, 34. Four Colorado Springs police officers were placed on administrative leave while the shooting is investigated.

headline: U.S.G.A. Plans Five-Year Study on Challenges Facing Golf
text: Facing concerns about participation levels and sustainability of golf, the United States Golf Association announced a five-year research partnership with the University of Minnesota to study the challenges facing the sport. headline: What to Watch Tonight
text: TALK TO HER (2002) 6:05 p.m. E.S.T. on Starz Cinema. Talk to her; just don’t expect her to talk back: Two men (a nurse and a journalist) share an unusual friendship while they care for their girlfriends (a dancer and a matador) who are both comatose. But not all devotion is what it seems, and suddenly romance is tinged with horror. Like all great doomed affairs, Pedro Almodóvar’s tragic comedy “is full of lovely, sweet suffering,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. (Image: Leonor Watling, left, and Geraldine Chaplin)

headline: G.O.P.: Save Your Candidates From Themselves

headline: The Evolution of Simplicity
text: In this country we’re raised to go for the gusto, to try new things and savor the smorgasbord of life’s possibilities. As Oliver Wendell Holmes put it, “The chief work of civilization is just that it makes the means of living more complex. Because more complex and intense intellectual efforts mean a fuller and richer life. That means more life. Life is an end to itself and the only question as to whether it is worth living is whether you have enough of it.”

headline: France, Paradise Lost
text: Paris — WHEN I moved to France 12 years ago, it was like arriving in an unfriendly paradise. Sure, hardly anyone spoke to me. But there was national paid maternity leave and free preschool. Practically everyone seemed to agree on the need for strict gun laws, and access to birth control and abortion. Not only did the whole country have health insurance; most undocumented immigrants could get medical and dental care free. (Cruelly, their thermal bath cures weren’t covered.)

headline: The Facebook Intifada
text: TEL AVIV — THREE weeks ago, my father was riding on a public bus in Jerusalem’s Armon Hanatziv neighborhood when terrorists from East Jerusalem shot him in the head and stabbed him multiple times. Afterward, as he lay unconscious in the intensive care unit of Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, fighting for his life, one question was on my mind: What inspired the two young Palestinian men to savagely attack my father and a busload of passengers?

headline: A Last-Minute Breakthrough
text: Julia returned after the August vacation that we New York psychoanalysts customarily take. Well, not right after. She missed the first session. A family obligation, she said. Were I a traditional analyst, I might have wondered to myself: “Is there ambivalence here? Perhaps she doesn’t want to come back?”

headline: Nigel Cabourn’s Old-School Workout
text: When Nigel Cabourn travels, he usually takes along several medicine balls, weighing a cumulative 33 pounds.

headline: Tom Brady, the New Face of TAG Heuer
text: One floor above a thumping party at Spring Studios in TriBeCa, where dozens of 40-something executives in Euro-cut suits sipped absinthe-infused cocktails, the man of the hour sat quietly on a director’s chair, behind a door guarded by a phalanx of publicists in black cocktail dresses.

headline: G.O.P. Fears Losing an Opportunity in Kentucky Governor’s Race
text: SHELBYVILLE, Ky. — A close contest for governor of Kentucky, where Republicans hope to win an office that Democrats have held for 40 of the last 44 years, highlights an off-year election Tuesday that also features several mayoral races and contentious ballot issues including an anti-discrimination ordinance in Houston and a marijuana legalization proposal in Ohio.

headline: Avoiding Taxes, Legally, Offshore
text: The collapse of Enron, with its web of offshore companies, got Paolo Woods talking with a photo editor. As big as the story was, the editor told him, he was hard pressed to figure out just how to illustrate something rooted in a thicket of secretive corporations that — on paper, at least — were based in tax havens. Nondescript post office boxes were not exactly the stuff of great images.

headline: Are You a Fair-Weather Fan?
text: Both the New York Mets and the Kansas City Royals picked up many new fans this postseason. That makes sense. People like to root for winning teams — or, at least, teams that have a chance to win a championship. If next season doesn’t go as well, those fans might find a different team to root for.

headline: Bowties and Arrows
text: Rugged men of style in their finest houndstooth and tweed at BDDW’s annual Weenie Roast in Dutchess County, N.Y.

text: The men at BDDW’s annual Weenie Roast show off their archery skills and finest tweed.

headline: ‘Islam and the Future of Tolerance’ and ‘Not in God’s Name’
text: Civilization has a civility problem. This I learned long before Donald Trump. In 2005, the prominent “new atheist” Richard Dawkins shouted his disapproval at me — from the audience — during my TED talk at Oxford University. More recently, the novelist Salman Rushdie chastised me on Twitter for suggesting that even atheists worship something. Many of Rushdie’s followers, worshiping their own wisdom, responded to my tweet with vitriol. Defending the value of doubt through crude certitude is a sign of our times.

Activision Blizzard plans to buy King Digital Entertainment, the maker of Candy Crush Saga, for about $5.9 billion,Michael J. de la Merced and Nick Wingfield report in DealBook.

headline: U.S. Admiral, in Beijing, Defends Patrols in South China Sea
text: BEIJING — The head of the United States Pacific Command, Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr., said in Beijing on Tuesday that the Navy would continue to conduct freedom of navigation operations similar to one in the South China Sea last week that China criticized.

headline: With First Campaign Book, Donald Trump Throws His Hat Into the Race’s Literary Ring
text: As book titles go, it’s not exactly a beacon of optimism. But like the presidential campaign of its author, “Crippled America,” a new book by Donald J. Trump, is deliberately defying convention. (Its subtitle is less doomsday: “How to Make America Great Again.”)

headline: Senate Republicans Seek End to E.P.A. Water Provision
text: Senate Republicans on Tuesday will take aim at an Obama administration rule on the environment that has become a leading target of conservatives who see it as the latest example of the administration’s executive overreach.

headline: Neuropolitics, Where Campaigns Try to Read Your Mind
text: In the lobby of a Mexico City office building, people scurrying to and fro gazed briefly at the digital billboard backing a candidate for Congress in June.

headline: Steve Deace and the Power of Conservative Media
text: Talk of alpha and beta males is common in the suburban Des Moines studio of the nationally syndicated conservative talk-show host Steve Deace. Almost daily, he assails the wimpy betas purporting to rule today’s Republican Party — the feckless politicians who, under siege, are giving ground to alpha fighters like him. Such chatter includes references to ‘‘manginas’’ and ‘‘growing a pair,’’ yet does not seem to put off the women in Deace’s audience; after all, being politically incorrect has become a conservative badge of honor in 2015.

headline: Mary Karr Thinks You Shouldn’t Google Yourself
text: In your book ‘‘The Art of Memoir,’’ you write that one of the side effects of being a memoirist is that strangers ‘‘skip the small talk and confide the most turbulent patches of their lives,’’ which to me wasn’t so surprising, but what you wrote about it was: ‘‘I have never not been moved by such a tale.’’ Small talk is boring. Politics are boring. The weather is boring. The minute somebody says to you, ‘‘I’ve never told anybody this before,’’ they’ve got your attention. I’m not a particularly nice person, but I’ve got to say, it makes me feel less lonely in the world when people confide in me.

headline: Poll Watch: Republicans Diverge on Religious Liberties and Guns
text: A New York Times/CBS News poll published last week revealed deep divisions in the Republican Party not only over potential presidential nominees but also over the federal budget, immigration and whether Republicans in Congress should compromise to get things done or dig in their heels over matters of principle.

headline: Shell to Focus on Liquefied Natural Gas in Deal for BG Group
text: LONDON — Seeking to reassure investors, Royal Dutch Shell on Tuesday said its $70 billion acquisition of the BG Group would allow it to realize $3.5 billion in savings, shed $30 billion in uncompetitive assets, and expand its operations in the fast-growing liquefied natural gas industry.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 27-Nov. 2, 2015
text: Have you been following the news?

headline: Hamptons’ True Colors Show in Autumn Off-Season
text: On a windswept morning in late October, a dozen wild turkeys crashed through the oak trees and landed unceremoniously on the patch of moss, grass and leaves that my husband and I call a lawn. I was on my way out the door, looking forward to a drive on the back roads near our house in Springs, a wooded hamlet in the town of East Hampton. The sight of the birds stopped me in my tracks. The screen door slipped from my hand. The slam rang out like a gunshot. A cloud of crows burst from the trees, and the turkeys, like the fantastical airships in a Philip Pullman novel, sailed across the fence and were gone.

headline: Travel Tips From the Well-Traveled Jamie Colby
text: As a television journalist specializing in news, Jamie Colby, 54, has traveled the world covering major events like the tsunami in Asia and the papal conclave at the Vatican, but nothing prepared her for being the host of “Strange Inheritance” on Fox Business Network. The second season of the series, debuting on Nov. 11, took her from her home in New York City to 20 states and one country, Britain, to speak with people saddled with unusual inheritances like a military tank collection in California, a frontier fort in Texas and a 17th-century shipwreck in Florida.

headline: China Aims for 6.5% Economic Growth Over Next 5 Years, Xi Says
text: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China announced on Tuesday that the Communist Party and the national government had set a 6.5 percent target for annual economic growth from 2016 to 2020.

headline: A Triumphant De Keersmaeker Takes Paris Opera by Storm
text: PARIS — Four musicians, dressed in black, walk on to the stage and sit with their instruments. Four female dancers, dressed in black, walk on to the stage and stand at the periphery in a rough semi-circle. The dancers look at each other, look at the musicians. Nothing happens. Then the dancers suddenly whip into quick turns toward the center of the stage, stand in a close line, and do little slinky, side-to-side walks. The music starts — Bartok’s String Quartet No. 4 — and they flop unceremoniously to the floor, legs splayed gracelessly, white underwear revealed.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This is a vivid indication that something is awry in these American households.”

headline: Is Legitimate Satire Necessarily Directed at the Powerful?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Siddhartha Deb and James Parker debate whether legitimate satire has to punch upward at its subject.

headline: Classical Music This Week: ‘Lulu’ and a Museum’s Taste of Schubert
text: Happy November! It was a gruelingly busy but immensely rewarding October for those of us riding the surge of the fall season. Things have quieted down ever so slightly, but there is still a great deal to see and hear.

headline: How the F.B.I. Can Detain, Render and Threaten Without Risk

headline: Bright Passages
text: For a brief respite from nitpicking, here’s a small sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions.

headline: 1915: State Rejects Women’s Suffrage
text: Woman suffrage was defeated yesterday in New Jersey by a majority of about fifty thousand. Despite President Wilson’s recent declaration in favor of the women and his trip to his old home, Princeton, to cast his vote for their cause, every county in the State cast a majority against the suffrage amendment. The defeat was overwhelming. The women conceded it early in the evening, but they stuck boldly to their battle flag and said they would carry the fight into another campaign, in which they felt confident they would drive their foes to cover. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 4, 1915
