headline: Heartland of Darkness
text: This new paper by Angus Deaton and Anne Case on mortality among middle-aged whites has been getting a lot of attention, and rightly so. As a number of people have pointed out, the closest parallel to America’s rising death rates — driven by poisonings, suicide, and chronic liver diseases — is the collapse in Russian life expectancy after the fall of Communism. (No, we’re not doing as badly as that, but still.) What the data look like is a society gripped by despair, with a surge of unhealthy behaviors and an epidemic of drugs, very much including alcohol.

headline: An Easy Way to Use WhatsApp
text: Q. My daughter has been living in South America for the last year and we communicate daily via WhatsApp on our iPhones. Our text history is a wonderful diary of her experiences there and I would like to be able to save them to my computer and print them out for us to enjoy in the future. Is there a simple way to do this?

headline: Punk Is Beautiful: Dickie Hammond (1965-2015)
text: Dickie Hammond, one of British punk rock’s most gifted and revered guitarists, died last week. He was 50. Facebook and British and European blogs are filling up with tributes to Dickie — a “legend,” a “lord” and a “lovely bloke” — some of them calling him the best punk guitarist of all time. None of this is likely to make the obit pages outside North England.

headline: Forty-Two Minutes With Jeb Bush on the Campaign Bus
text: RYE, N.H. — Jeb Bush needs a boost. He’s getting a bus.

headline: Bevin’s Victory Speech in Kentucky
text: Matt Bevin of Kentucky spoke Tuesday night after he beat his Democratic opponent in the state’s gubernatorial race.

headline: IoT and Cassandra: Topic Wildcards in Retained Storage
text: I recently presented at the 2015 Cassandra Summit on the Internet of Things (IoT) and our work at The New York Times, drawing on over fifty years of experience in computing.

headline: Bonuses for Bank Executives Should Be Tied to Gender Diversity, Review Says
text: LONDON — The annual bonuses of financial services executives in Britain should be tied to targets to bring more women into senior roles, according to the preliminary findings of a government commission’s review of gender diversity in the sector.

headline: Angelina Jolie Pitt Is Behind Closed Doors in ‘By the Sea’
text: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF. — During the filming of “By the Sea,” Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt — who play a depressed former dancer and her blocked novelist husband — had a go-to method for lightening an often somber mood on the set. “There were a lot of jokes about how nobody is ever going to want to be our neighbor again,” said Ms. Jolie Pitt, referring to how their characters often spy through a peephole on two lovers in the hotel room next door.

headline: Stressed, Tired, Rushed: A Portrait of the Modern Family
text: Children are much more likely than not to grow up in a household in which their parents work, and in nearly half of all two-parent families today, both parents work full time, a sharp increase from previous decades.

headline: In Honda’s Rebuke of Takata, a Rare Move for Business Partners in Japan
text: TOKYO — When a car manufacturer publicly questions the honesty of a business partner that supplies it with vital safety equipment, it is a sure sign that the relationship is in trouble.

headline: New N.B.A. Faces Among Those Off to Fast Starts
text: N.B.A. teams have played only three to five games so far. But that has been plenty of time for the best players to assert themselves.

headline: France to Lift Ban on Gay Men Donating Blood
text: PARIS — France will lift a ban on blood donations by gay and bisexual men starting next year, officials announced Wednesday, joining a growing list of countries that have loosened or scrapped such restrictions, which many see as outdated vestiges of the 1980s AIDS crisis.

headline: Reaction to Houston's Vote on Anti-Discrimination Ordinance
text: Mayor Annise D. Parker of Houston and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick of Texas spoke on Tuesday after the rejection of an ordinance that would establish protections for gay and transgender people.

headline: Public Companies Trying to Mimic Private Firms
text: It was one of the biggest rebukes of the public markets in recent memory — and it may not be the last.

headline: What to Watch in New York’s Fall Art Auctions
text: It has been a banner year for the international art auction houses. Last November, the big fall auctions in New York saw sales at Christie’s and Sotheby’s top $2 billion in two weeks. In May, Christie’s sold $1 billion worth of art in just three days. Included in that total was a 1955 Picasso, “Les Femmes d’Alger (Version ‘O’),” which went for $179.4 million with fees — a record for any artwork at auction.

headline: Reader Contest: The Best Parenting Advice in Six Words
text: Made a threat? Carry it through.

headline: 1940: Vichy Gives Assurances to U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The chances of early American intervention in Martinique were discounted today [Nov. 4] by Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador, after he had delivered a note from the Vichy government to the State Department denying any intention of turning over French possessions and bases to the Germans.

headline: Digital Transformation Going Mainstream in 2016, IDC Predicts
text: It is the time of year when the big technology research shops gaze into the near future to identify trends that will have the most impact on corporate America and the tech industry over the next few years.

headline: Patricia Riggen, Director of ‘The 33,’ on Shooting in a Mine
text: On the first day of shooting “The 33,” the Mexican director Patricia Riggen sat in her chair in the cave that served as the movie’s set. “And bicckk! A stone falls on top of my head,” she recalled. “Fortunately, I had my hard hat on. But it makes me realize where I am and what it means to be there.”

headline: In ‘The Hot Rock,’ Gems on View Before Their Time
text: It’s never been clear why “The Hot Rock,” the New York caper comedy directed by Peter Yates, didn’t get more love at its 1972 release. (Maybe because the city was simply an unfunny tableau of urban decline, not yet the object of nostalgic affection it would become.) Even so, the film, about unpolished jewel thieves trying to snatch a spectacular diamond for an interested buyer, is an embarrassment of riches: It featured William Goldman’s script, adapted from the Donald E. Westlake novel, as well as a top-shelf cast — Robert Redford playing straight man to George Segal, Paul Sand and Ron Leibman, all eclipsed by vintage late-period Zero Mostel. And the city was virtually a featured character itself.

headline: Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba Blends Dance Traditions
text: It’s always a hot night in Havana wherever and whenever Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba performs. In her “Cuba Vibra!,” Ms. Alfonso’s Havana-based company, in only 95 minutes, will celebrate the development of Cuban music and dance from the 1950s to the present with the aid of 18 dancers and an onstage big band. The troupe, founded by Ms. Alfonso in 1991 as an all-female group, now includes men.

headline: A Beloved Bakery in Midwood
text: Isaac’s Bake Shop is famous in Midwood’s Jewish community, but also picks up customers tired of waiting at a celebrated pizza place nearby.

headline: Q. & A. Why Are More Companies Passing on Going Public?
text: The United States stock market is thought to have played a heroic role in the country’s history. Over the decades, thousands of public companies have raised many billions of dollars in the markets — money that has propelled economic growth, innovation and employment. Without the public markets, corporate America would not have had a vast, cheap and powerful pool of capital.

headline: Classical Playlist: Vaughan Williams and a Piano ‘Nutcracker’
text: VAUGHAN WILLIAMS: ‘A Sea Symphony’Katherine Broderick, soprano; Roderick Williams, baritone; Hallé Choir, Hallé Youth Choir, Schola Cantorum of Oxford, Ad Solem; Hallé Orchestra; Mark Elder, conductor(Hallé)Manchester’s Hallé Orchestra continues its unbroken streak of valuable releases with this towering account of Ralph Vaughan Williams’s first symphony. Written at the crest of the fashion for seafaring works that swept Britain at the start of the 20th century, and given its premiere just a month after Mahler’s Eighth, it’s a full choral symphony lasting over an hour, a work that astonishes with ambition both compositional and (with texts by Walt Whitman) literary and philosophical. Mark Elder makes clear Vaughan Williams’s debts to Charles Stanford and Elgar, Wagner and Ravel, carrying them along in a reading of tidal power, patient yet inexorable. (David Allen)

headline: ‘Secret Space Escapes’ Re-enacts Near Disasters on Past Missions
text: We’re all familiar with America’s worst spacecraft moments, those that took a disastrous, fatal turn. But less well known are the “almosts,” the difficulties astronauts faced that could have been catastrophic.

headline: Britain Announces Plan to Update Surveillance Laws
text: LONDON — Stirring a fraught debate about the balance between security and privacy, the British government on Wednesday proposed tougher scrutiny over snooping by spy agencies, but also said it wanted technology companies to store data about every Briton’s Internet use for a year.

headline: Bali Travelers Stranded as Volcano Grounds Flights
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A volcanic eruption has stranded thousands of airline passengers on the Indonesian island of Bali and led to the cancellation of hundreds of flights in and out of the popular resort destination, with no relief in sight until at least Thursday.

headline: Statins May Dampen Response to Flu Vaccine
text: Statins, the cholesterol lowering drugs, may weaken the effect of the flu vaccine, two new studies suggest.

headline: A Brooklyn Bakery Appeals to Observant Jews and Pizza Fans
text: Isaac’s Bake Shop knows firsthand the power of the adage “location, location, location.” The humble kosher bakery happens to be directly across the street from Di Fara Pizza, one of the few destinations in Midwood that draws international tour guides. Di Fara is also known for its interminable waiting times. Thanks to the influx of hungry customers roaming up and down Avenue J looking for an in-the-meantime nibble, Isaac’s has developed an unexpected following among those unaware of or indifferent to the laws of kashrut.

headline: Christian Gerhaher at Park Avenue Armory, and Julia Bullock at the Met
text: Among chamber music fans, the baritone Christian Gerhaher is considered the uncontested heir to Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau at the helm of the German lied tradition. On Tuesday, Nov. 10, he and his longtime pianist, Gerold Huber, return to the elegant Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, which they inaugurated with an all-Schumann recital two years ago. This time, they bring their probing musicianship to the Viennese tradition with a program spanning songs by Haydn, Beethoven, Schoenberg and Berg. (7:30 p.m., parkavenuearmory.org.)

headline: Cargo Plane Crashes in South Sudan
text: Shortly after takeoff from Juba's airport, a cargo plane crashed into the banks of the White Nile River. Officials said three survived, but at least 25 have been reported killed.

headline: ‘Procession: The Art of Norman Lewis’ Is a Full Retrospective of This Artist’s Career
text: Last year, the art of Norman Lewis (1909-79) shared an exhibition at the Jewish Museum with that of another marginalized Abstract Expressionist, Lee Krasner (1908-84). Now the first full retrospective of Lewis’s art since his death opens on Friday, Nov. 13, at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: Takeaways from Tuesday’s Election
text: It was a big night for Republicans, turnout matters, and other things you need to know.

headline: House Tour | Thomas Flohr
text: The VistaJet chairman built a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps — fit for James Bond, and complete with a hidden grotto.

headline: The Man Who Hates E.T.F.s
text: Bearded and tanned, Peter S. Kraus, the chief executive of AllianceBernstein, strode with assurance into a Midtown Manhattan conference room full of financial advisers from a large investment bank.

headline: New Music From Nate Wooley, Alicia Hall Moran and Adam Larson
text: (DANCE TO) THE EARLY MUSIC

headline: Prime Minister Ponta of Romania Resigns
text: Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania said he is resigning in the wake of public discontent after a fire killed 32 people in a Bucharest nightclub.

headline: Britons Perturbed by a Troubling Shortage of Curry Chefs
text: LONDON — William Makepeace Thackeray, a 19th-century English satirist, was born in Calcutta and once penned an ode to curry. “ ’Tis, when done,” he wrote, “a dish for Emperors to feed upon.”

headline: Officer’s Death Stuns Illinois Town a Second Time
text: The shooting death of a police lieutenant made national news and brought a stretch of northern Illinois to a tense standstill with roadblocks, thudding helicopters and officers tramping with dogs through woods and over farmland, searching for the killers. The lieutenant, Charles J. Gliniewicz, was hailed as a hero, and some conservatives seized on this and other shootings as evidence that critics of the police were fueling a wave of violence against law enforcement.

headline: The Beatles’ Video Collection ‘1’: Baby, You Can Film My Song
text: On Nov. 23, 1965, the Beatles entered Twickenham Film Studios, on the outskirts of London, for a marathon session. But the biggest band in the world wasn’t recording music — it was making promotional films for five of its singles.

headline: A Jim Henson Thanksgiving, 47 Years in the Making
text: In 1968, a pre-famous Jim Henson and his frequent writing partner, Jerry Juhl, collaborated on a treatment for a one-hour Thanksgiving special called “The Musical Monsters of Turkey Hollow.” The outline called for Mr. Henson’s puppets to exist in real-world environs, shot on location in and around an unspecified New England town. The title characters, “small, shaggy monsters” of extraterrestrial origin, would communicate via “a rather unique musical sound” — to be created on an electronic synthesizer by the pioneering musician Raymond Scott.

headline: December Interest Rate Increase Is ‘a Live Possibility,’ Janet Yellen Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve could raise its benchmark interest rate in December as long as economic growth continues, two senior Fed officials said on Wednesday, hammering that message in repeated public remarks.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Fall-Themed Veggie Burger
text: Bailey Rae, a food writer in Nashville, created a fall-themed veggie burger to star on her Thanksgiving table. The dish requires some prep time to bake, scoop and, well, squash, the acorn squash and caramelize the onions, but once those steps are out of the way, this is an easy dish to add to your Thanksgiving menu.

headline: Enlisting Veterans to Remedy the Shortage of Farmers
text: American military veterans need work, and American agriculture needs farmers. So why not, figuratively, convert those who wielded swords into those guiding plowshares?

headline: A Flawed Marijuana Legalization Effort Fails in Ohio [Updated]
text: Ohio voters did the right thing on Tuesday by overwhelmingly rejecting a deeply flawed marijuana legalization ballot initiative. The proposal would have amended the state’s constitution to grant a monopoly on commercial cultivation of cannabis to a small group of investors, which is a terrible idea.

headline: Roosting Chickens and Fed-Bashing
text: So I look at Business Insider and see that Stanley Druckenmiller is issuing dire warnings that terrible things will happen unless the Fed hikes rates now now now. I guess this is supposed to be news. But wait; haven’t I heard this before? Why, yes: two and half years ago he warned that a crash worse than 2008 was coming unless we slash Social Security now now now.

headline: Another Setback for World Trade Center Transit Hub: Leaking Water
text: Everywhere, the shopping season is about to begin. Everywhere, that is, except at “the most complete retail destination in New York City, the most alluring retail landmark in the world,” as the luxury Westfield World Trade Center mall describes itself.

headline: Afghan Businessman Convicted in Kabul Bank Fraud Is Still Free to Make Money
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a big day for development here, a notable Afghan businessman stood with top government officials on Wednesday as he signed the contract for a new township: 8,800 homes across 33 acres of prime real estate in the heart of the capital, with an initial investment of at least $95 million.

headline: Migrants Rescued Near Greece
text: Greek authorities reported a deadly boating accident near the island of Lesbos involving migrants from Turkey, The Associated Press said. Rescue workers were able to save most on board.

headline: Expectations Mount for Trustees in Higher Education
text: Rick White is a financial consultant in Boulder, Colo., but his heart is often 2,000 miles to the east, at Haverford College, the school on the Main Line outside Philadelphia that he graduated from in 1981. When he was tapped to be on its governing board, he was like a sub coming off the bench in a crucial game, ready to go all in.

headline: Eight Edgy, Elegant Enamel Earrings
text: A bit Memphis, a touch mod, these graphic combinations of color and shape feel totally on the mark.

headline: Trudeau Becomes Prime Minister of Canada
text: Justin Trudeau, the leader of the majority Liberal Party, was sworn in on Wednesday as the 23rd prime minister of Canada.

headline: Navigating the Tax Rules on Charitable Gifts
text: Congress has been tightening the rules on charitable gifts for more than a decade, and following those rules is critical to getting the maximum deduction for gifts. Below, in time for year-end tax planning, are some common charitable giving pitfalls and how to navigate around them.

headline: Margaret Cho Wants to Talk About Sex Work
text: It was the tweet heard round the sex-worker world. At 6:12 p.m. on Oct. 29, Margaret Cho, the 46-year-old comedian, disturbed the Twittersphere with an economical 109 characters: “Sex work is simply work. For me it was honest work. I was a sex worker when I was young. It was hard but well paid. There’s no shame in it.”

headline: Steve Coleman, Toward a Sound That Defies Walls
text: The saxophonist and bandleader Steve Coleman is fascinated by tradition but doesn’t seem to believe that any tradition is self-contained. Starting from his early training in the Chicago and New York jazz scenes during the late ’70s and early ’80s, he eventually created a music that could encompass everything he learned: Charlie Parker and James Brown; rhythmic practices from Africa and India and Brazil; ancient or esoteric theories about numbers, form, symmetry and multiplicity. He’s played and taught all over the world but never led a band at the Village Vanguard. That soon changes. On the first two nights of his engagement, he’ll play with a new chamber-like group, Natal Eclipse: horns, bass, piano (Craig Taborn), voice (Jen Shyu) and no drums. Then he’ll present the standard version of his long-running band, Five Elements — a great evolving machine — and through the weekend he’ll add a second drummer, the great Marcus Gilmore, to that group. Don’t miss it. (8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Tuesday, Nov. 10, through Sunday, Nov. 15, villagevanguard.com.)

headline: Justin Trudeau Is Sworn In as Prime Minister of Canada
text: OTTAWA — Justin Trudeau, the leader of the Liberal Party, was sworn in as prime minister of Canada on Wednesday morning, ending nearly a decade of Conservative dominance.

headline: Lumber Liquidators Names John M. Presley as Chief
text: The discount flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators selected a new chief executive on Wednesday as the company struggled to recover from a major safety scandal that has badly damaged its stock price and sales.

headline: Terry Collins Gets a Reward, and Sandy Alderson Gets a Scare
text: The Mets held a postseason news conference Wednesday that, for the first time in years, was celebratory in nature. Manager Terry Collins wore a teal dress shirt and black slacks and a satisfied expression. Sitting next to him, General Manager Sandy Alderson announced that the Mets had agreed to give Collins a two-year contract extension, a reward for leading the team to its first pennant in 15 years.

headline: A $1,000 Day in New York City for $100
text: A budget doesn’t hamper our Frugal Traveler on a romp through downtown, from a beloved West Village cheese shop to the top of the city’s tallest tower.

headline: Honda and Takata Officials React
text: Executives gave statements regarding Honda's decision not to use Takata's technology in its vehicles after the United States fined Takata for faulty airbags.

headline: Activist Investors Get a Welcome Seat at the Table
text: For decades, corporate America rejected activist investors, accusing them of being corporate raiders out to make a quick buck. But these days, some of America’s biggest companies are trying to think more like them.

headline: Risking Your Neck to Run With the Unicorns
text: In the world of Wall Street, where numbers are everything, one number is especially coveted: one billion. Technology start-ups that achieve $1 billion in valuation before going public — so-called unicorns — can attract the attention of prominent venture capital firms and draw résumés from top talent across the country.

headline: An Anticorruption Plea in Kenya: ‘Please, Just Steal a Little’
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — When it comes to honesty, politicians here don’t usually win many awards.

headline: Britain, Concerned About Russian Crash, Halts Sinai Flights
text: LONDON — The British government on Wednesday suspended flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh over concerns that a chartered Russian jetliner might have been brought down in the Sinai Peninsula by a bomb on board.

headline: Review: Christian Tetzlaff Sharpens Mendelssohn’s Edge
text: A moment arose on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall when I thought that Christian Tetzlaff was going to play the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto straight.

headline: Thomas Flohr’s Fortress in St. Moritz
text: With a business that caters to modern-day 007 aspirants, the VistaJet chairman Thomas Flohr has created a house to match: a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps.

headline: One Man’s Mountaintop Fortress — and Playground
text: High above the Swiss ski resort of St. Moritz, where the royal and the merely rich break for caviar and champagne between downhill runs, is Thomas Flohr’s James Bond-inspired home, Ches’Aivla (Eagle’s Nest in the local language, Romansh). A seven-story, 35,000-square-foot structure built into the Suvretta mountainside, it has a cinema, library, wine cellar, spa, squash court, billiard room, bowling alley and pizzeria and is filled with important contemporary art and a stream of mostly female staff. Parked in the ‘‘garage gallery’’ is a pristine silver Aston Martin DB5 (‘‘like the one in ‘Goldfinger,’ ’’ Flohr says, brightly). Part of the home office is leather-padded like M’s at the MI6 headquarters in London, and there’s a midcentury rosewood and chrome desk that was used in ‘‘From Russia With Love’’ and ‘‘You Only Live Twice.’’ On the wall hangs a rusted steel map of the world with the capitals and major cities identified by tiny lights, ‘‘like when you have Dr. No in those meetings and they divide the world and look at the map,’’ he says.

headline: Saying No to a Cash Buffet in Start-Up World
text: SAN FRANCISCO — To fashion cognoscenti, Everlane is perhaps best known for its almost monastically plain button-down shirts and pants, stripped of excess.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Pay $258 Million and Fire 6 in Settlement
text: Deutsche Bank agreed on Wednesday to pay $258 million and fire six employees to resolve investigations by state and federal banking regulators into its dealings with countries like Iran and Syria in violation of United States sanctions laws.

headline: Marco Rubio Confronts New Scrutiny Over Use of Party Credit Card
text: A decade after he began using a Republican Party credit card for personal purchases like paving stones at his home, Senator Marco Rubio on Wednesday pledged to disclose new spending records from that account as he sought to inoculate himself against what could be his biggest liability as a presidential candidate: how he manages his finances.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Gun Control
text: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton discussed gun violence during a speech in Iowa on Tuesday.

headline: Modern Tintypes of the American West
text: A look at Ian Ruhter’s stunning landscape photographs.

headline: The Executive Paycheck Myth
text: Every religion has a creation myth.

headline: ‘The Bloggess’ Conjures Thousands of Cringes With One Tweet
text: After a decade of blogging, writing a best-selling memoir and dispatching clever tweets, the author Jenny Lawson is skilled in the art of self-deprecating humor.

headline: Details on Police Officer’s Suicide
text: Police officials in Lake County, Ill., said that Charles J. Gliniewicz’s death was a “carefully staged suicide” meant to cover up the lieutenant’s years of stealing and laundering money.

headline: France Ending Ban on Gay Blood Donors
text: Marisol Touraine, France's health minister, says the country will end a taboo and a form of discrimination as it prepares to allow gay men to donate blood.

headline: Readers React to Rising Death Rates of Middle-Aged White Americans
text: A front-page report on a study that found death rates rising among white, middle-aged Americans, tapped into deep roots of angst, compassion and frustration among readers. The article shot to the top of the most-emailed list, and attracted nearly 1,900 comments.

headline: Quentin Tarantino Says ‘All Cops Are Not Murderers’
text: LOS ANGELES — Quentin Tarantino has broken his silence regarding a growing police boycott of his coming film, “The Hateful Eight,” telling The Los Angeles Times that his public remarks about police violence had been misinterpreted.

headline: Police Kill California Student After Campus Stabbing of 4
text: A student wielding a hunting knife stabbed four people at the start of a class on Wednesday on the campus of the University of California, Merced, before he was shot and killed by university police officers, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Holocaust Film That Roiled Cannes Gets First DVD Release in Germany
text: “Night and Fog,” a 1955 Holocaust documentary that caused an uproar at the Cannes Film Festival in 1956, has been released for the first time on DVD in Germany.

headline: As Doors Close, Syrian Refugees Despair
text: Propelled by fear and desperation, Syrian refugees have faced one hurdle after another.

headline: Yellen Speaks to Legislators
text: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told the House Financial Services Committee that the economy was “performing well” and suggested that the Fed could raise interest rates.

headline: Making a Picky Eater Project Last a Lifetime
text: Six weeks ago we started the Picky Eater Project, introducing a few key ideas we thought could change the eating preferences of Brooke, a sixth grader, and Hunter, a third grader, whose meal requirements (along with their parents Marlo and Corey’s willingness to cater to them) were taking over the family dinner hour.

headline: When a Photographer Is His Own Camera
text: For the photographer Ian Ruhter, whose first New York show opens tomorrow at Danziger Gallery, success has come from climbing into his work. “The game-changing moment came when I realized I could be the camera. I could be the mechanics of it,” Ruhter says. From inside the lens of a delivery truck converted into a camera, Ruhter becomes the machine’s very manual settings: the shutter and the processor, and also the “film,” which he makes from scratch on sheets of aluminum up to five feet wide. (Light-sensitive collodion plates, once wet, need to be exposed and developed in a matter of minutes, but the whole set-up takes about a day for a single image.) “It takes so much time,” he says, of choosing not to “jump out of a car and take a selfie” at a lookout. “It really makes me sit there and be part of the environment, and suck it up and enjoy.”

headline: One Downside of an Up Economy: Employee Turnover
text: Most employees — no matter how many years they have been with a company or how much talent and hard work they bring to the table — feel disposable. And most employers do little to discourage that feeling.

headline: Graying Firms Wrestle With Making Room for Younger Lawyers
text: Even the law firms nimble enough to overcome the economic turbulence in recent years are not feeling invincible these days. The revenue looks good because costly litigation and specialized legal work are flourishing. But a generational divide is percolating just under the surface.

headline: Ted Cruz Has a Chance to Win. Here’s the Path.
text: When Ted Cruz announced his run for the presidency, the big question was whether he had only a small chance to win or no chance at all. Since then, a lot has gone right for him.

headline: Sylvie Guillem Prepares to End Her Ballet Career
text: MILAN — “I am not nice,” the ballerina Sylvie Guillem said. Seated in her dressing room in the Teatro Arcimboldi here, Ms. Guillem burst out laughing. “That has gotten me into a lot of trouble.”

headline: Performa 15 Kicks Off With Katy Perry, Miuccia Prada and Others
text: Performance art is sometimes associated with malnourished artists suffering inside a sterile white gallery.

headline: Plant Collapse Kills at Least 16 People in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 16 people were killed and dozens wounded when a factory undergoing expansion collapsed into rubble Wednesday evening in an industrial park in eastern Pakistan, rescue workers and government officials said.

headline: Shareholders Vote With Their Dollars to Have Less of a Say
text: In today’s world of public companies, there are the haves and have-nots of corporate governance. How long can this last?

headline: Rebel Wilson’s Red Carpet Looks
text: On the advice of her stylist, Rebel Wilson gave up her red-carpet tracksuits for plunging V-necks and skimpy sleeves.

headline: Rebel Wilson Goes From ‘Fat Amy’ to Fashion Brand
text: LOS ANGELES — Inside Milk Studios, a marble building here on North Cahuenga Boulevard, waiters passed sushi rolls amid racks of dresses, bags and T-shirts. Outside, a starlet posed on a red carpet by a reflecting pool, wearing a crimson scuba dress overlaid with black lace. It had all the trappings of a Hollywood branding soiree, announced by a neon sign hovering overhead: “Welcome to the Rebelution.”

headline: Long Lives and Rocky Markets Have Some Pension Systems Recalibrating
text: For decades, state and local pension systems thought of themselves as America’s ultimate long-term investors.

headline: Review: A High-Energy St. Lawrence String Quartet at Zankel Hall
text: In 1826, Beethoven sent the score of a new string quartet to his publisher with a flippant annotation: “Patched together from various bits filched here and there.” This work, the sprawling Opus 131, would come to be considered one of his boldest contributions to chamber music.

headline: Time Warner May Have Left Door Ajar for a Fox Return
text: Time Warner may have left its henhouse gate open to Fox. Its chief executive, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, last year thwarted an $80 billion takeover bid from Rupert Murdoch’s rival media company with some bold projections. Mr. Bewkes is now backing down from those claims and could be vulnerable to a fresh approach.

headline: Ruling in Mexico Sets Into Motion Legal Marijuana
text: The Mexican Supreme Court opened the door to legalizing marijuana on Wednesday, delivering a pointed challenge to the nation’s strict substance abuse laws and adding its weight to the growing debate in Latin America over the costs and consequences of the war against drugs.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 9: Browns at Bengals
text: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday night’s game between the Cleveland Browns and the Cincinnati Bengals. Check back Friday for analysis on Sunday’s games and Monday’s matchup between the Chicago Bears and the San Diego Chargers. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Reviews: Amazon Pilots Include a Revolt and the Supernatural
text: Since 2013, Amazon has released a batch of original TV pilots several times a year for the public to review and vote on. Our TV critics take a look at the latest crop, which will be available beginning on Thursday.

headline: Defining Diversity in Silicon Valley and on Wall Street
text: Jana Rich, an executive recruiter who specializes in consumer technology companies, estimates that 80 percent of the searches she has done over the last 18 months in Silicon Valley, San Francisco and New York have been for candidates lumped under the rubric of “diversity.”

headline: British Official on Halted Flights
text: Britain's transport secretary, Patrick McLoughlin, said the government was suspending flights from the Egyptian resort city of Sharm el Sheikh after a Russian airliner crashed on Saturday.

headline: Activists May Be Less Myopic Than Their Reputation Suggests
text: Are activist investors short-term traders or in it for the long term? It is the question of the moment as nearly $200 billion has poured into the coffers of activists with names like Icahn, Ackman and Peltz, among others. Last year, as a group they put some 200 companies in their cross hairs and replaced 19 chief executives, according to the law firm Sidley Austin, putting pressure on virtually every board in the country to pay attention to this vocal class of shareholders.

headline: Time Warner Cuts Profit Expectations, and Media Stocks Dip
text: Media giants have fallen back into a ring of fire.

headline: Amy Winehouse Documentary Team Tackling Oasis in Upcoming Film
text: London — The pair behind “Amy,” the highly successful documentary film about the singer Amy Winehouse, have signed on to make a feature-length documentary about the British pop group Oasis, which disbanded in 2009. Asif Kapadia, the director of “Amy,” and James Gay-Rees, the producer, will be producers on the Oasis project, which doesn’t yet have a title or release date.

headline: Obama’s Unfulfilled Pledge to Close Guantánamo
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pedestrian Fast Lanes. Why the Heck Not?
text: This is (possibly) brilliant: a fast lane for walkers in downtown Liverpool. Nimble people, keep to the left. Dawdlers, get out of the way.

headline: Supreme Court Justices Fear Loss of Control Over Redistricting Cases
text: WASHINGTON — At a Supreme Court  argument on Wednesday about procedures in redistricting cases, the justices appeared to be trying to reconcile two conflicting impulses. They did not want to close the door entirely on challenges to gerrymandering, but they also did not want to be required to rule on them.

headline: In Heat of August 1945, Mao and Chiang Met for the Last Time
text: BEIJING — In August 1945, Mao Zedong flew from his mountain redoubt in Yan’an to Chongqing, the headquarters of Chiang Kai-shek’s Nationalists and China’s sweltering wartime capital. It was to be the last meeting between leaders of the Communists and the Nationalists, the rival factions then contending for control of China.

headline: Why Buffett’s Salad Oil Magic May Not Repeat for Ackman
text: Jeff Gramm is the author of the forthcoming book “Dear Chairman: Boardroom Battles and the Rise of Shareholder Activism” (HarperBusiness), which has a chapter about the Great Salad Oil Swindle. He is a hedge fund manager who teaches value investing at Columbia Business School.

headline: Eruption Strands Passengers in Bali
text: Airline passengers were stranded at airports on the Indonesian island of Bali because of volcanic ash from the eruption of Mount Rinjani on the neighboring island of Lombok.

headline: Houellebecq’s Islam, Houellebecq’s West
text: Like many people who pretend to parle a little francais but get tired after reading a page, I’ve only just now read the newly-translated “Submission,” Michel Houellebecq’s dystopian vision of a near-future French republic that succumbs willingly to a vaguely Tariq Ramadan-esque form of political Islam. When I say “dystopian,” the casual reader may infer — as many people did when the book first appeared, literally at the same moment as the “Charlie Hebdo” massacre — that the dystopia is the Islamicized France, that Houellebecq is trying to do for Islamism or “Eurabia” what Orwell once did for Stalinism. But if you’ve read the keener reviews (or Houellebecq’s previous novels) you probably understand that no, actually, the dystopia is the contemporary West, and the Islamified future that Houellebecq’s story ushers in is portrayed as a kind of civilizational step forward, or if you prefer a necessary regression back to health.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Missouri City of Fining Homeowners to Raise Revenue
text: PAGEDALE, Mo. — This spring, officials in this tiny city near St. Louis ordered Valarie Whitner to replace her siding; repaint her gutters, downspout and foundation; and put up screens or storm covers outside every window and blinds or curtains on the inside.

headline: The Lessons of Stanford’s Sex-Assault-Case Reversal
text: Last February, I wrote a long article for this magazine about the relationship between Ellie Clougherty, a recent Stanford graduate, and Joe Lonsdale, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur and alumnus of the school. The couple started dating in 2012, after Lonsdale was assigned to be Clougherty’s mentor for an engineering course called Technology Entrepreneurship, which combined academics with business skills and access to Silicon Valley. After the relationship ended, Clougherty accused Lonsdale of sexual assault.

headline: App Smart | Home Away From Home
text: A selection of short-term rental apps for those seeking alternatives to Airbnb.

headline: Video Feature: Home-Rental Apps as Alternatives to Airbnb
text: To some people, Airbnb is an innovative service that is shaking up the hotel industry by offering interesting alternative places to stay. To others, Airbnb is viewed as a tax-dodging scourge that lets tenants violate their leases’ subletting rules in return for a quick buck.

headline: Opponents of Houston Rights Measure Focused on Bathrooms, and Won
text: HOUSTON — The predominantly black Third Ward here, a historic and struggling community, seemed like the kind of precinct that would be sympathetic to a broad ordinance outlawing discrimination based on factors such as race, religion and sexual orientation.

headline: Why Parents Should Have the ‘Sex Talk’ With Their Children
text: The “sex talk” isn’t easy for parents, but new research shows that adolescents who have talked to their parents about sex are more likely to use condoms and birth control.

headline: Jets’ Ryan Fitzpatrick Will Start Despite Thumb Injury
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets’ quarterback woes do not appear as severe as the team had feared.

headline: Guinness Is Going Vegan
text: Guinness, the Irish stout that once famously advertised itself under the slogan “Guinness is good for you,” took a step this week to inject 21st-century food culture into its 256-year-old product. Guinness is going vegan.

headline: Jeb Bush Apologizes to France for Workweek Remark in Debate
text: LONDON — Accused of French-bashing, the Republican presidential hopeful Jeb Bush apologized this week for making fun of France’s work ethic, saying he was sorry for insulting America’s oldest ally.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Brooklyn’
text: John Crowley narrates a sequence from “Brooklyn.”

headline: Whitney Names Curators for Next Biennial, in 2017
text: The Whitney Museum of American Art’s first biennial exhibition in its new home — which goes on view in Spring 2017 — will be organized by Christopher Y. Lew, an associate curator at the museum, and Mia Locks, until recently an assistant curator at MoMA P.S.1, the Whitney announced Wednesday.

headline: Market Changes May Prompt New Definition of Insider Trading
text: The law of insider trading has not changed much since important Supreme Court rulings in the 1980s established a high bar for convictions.

headline: For Start-Ups, Altruism as an Alternative to Acquisition or I.P.O.
text: For most private companies backed by venture capital or financial sponsors, there are two obvious paths to an exit: sell, or go public as a traditional for-profit corporation.

headline: Human Rights Campaign’s Letter to the N.F.L.
text: With Houston set to host the Super Bowl in 2017, Chad Griffin, the president of the Human Rights Campaign, wrote Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, to discuss “nondiscrimination protections” for attendees.

headline: Work Force Culture Is Buffeted by Swift Changes in Technology
text: Companies from Wall Street to Silicon Valley have been forced to adapt to technological and regulatory changes in the last seven years, but have their work force cultures adapted quickly enough?

headline: Seijun Suzuki, a Symbol of ‘Japanese Cool’ in Film, Is Reconsidered
text: It’s rare in this country for an actual political fight to break out over a filmmaker. The current squabble over Quentin Tarantino’s remarks about police shootings stands out for its oddity — we usually see controversy involving a director only when Michael Moore has a new documentary to promote.

headline: China’s Slowdown Raises Questions About Long-Term Growth
text: HONG KONG — The short-term economic signals out of China have not been reassuring.

headline: E.U. Is Split Over How to Prepare for Euro Crises to Come
text: PARIS — During the height of the Greek crisis last summer, five men gathered in a war room at the Finance Ministry in Athens and began poring over the outlines of a surreptitious project. Greece was at a dangerous impasse with its creditors over a bailout, and the group needed to find a way to keep the country functioning if it were to be forced out of the euro.

headline: ‘Amy’ Among Nominees for Documentary Film Awards
text: LOS ANGELES — Music-themed documentaries made their mark as the International Documentary Association announced nominees, and some winners, for its annual documentary awards, to be presented in Los Angeles on Dec. 5.

headline: The Risks and Rewards of Short-Termism
text: The debate has been raging in various forms for the last 30 years — whether corporate short-termism is a problem and, if it is, is it hurting American businesses and the economy? Short-termism is exactly what it sounds like: companies managed for the short term, with decisions driven by the need to meet shareholder expectations about quarterly earnings and stock prices.

headline: Facebook Revenue Surges 41%, as Mobile Advertising and Users Keep Growing
text: It takes money, the adage goes, to make money. And Facebook is spending a lot of dollars to do just that.

headline: Donald Trump to Run His First Campaign Ads … on the Radio
text: Donald J. Trump is buying radio air time in three early states, his campaign manager confirmed, marking the billionaire candidate’s first foray into paid advertising since he began his presidential campaign in June.

headline: Book on Family-Planning Policy Is Banned, Then Promoted, by China
text: In just six years, Fuxian Yi’s book pleading for an end to the “one child” policy went from banned to promoted by the Chinese government.

headline: Short-Term Thinking
text: From Wall Street to Washington and in the towers of academia, people are buzzing about what some say is the pernicious focus in corporate America on short-term profits.

headline: Pictures of the Day: the Philippines and Elsewhere
text: The Philippines and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Ryan McGinley’s “Fall” and “Winter”
text: For his newest photo series, the artist spent time in upstate New York. He shares four photos from the series, as well as the haunts he discovered in the area.

headline: Ryan McGinley’s Upstate New York
text: Since 2004, Ryan McGinley has taken summer road trips across America with a gang of models — excursions that have yielded some of his best-known work. But his next two shows at Team Gallery (running semi-concurrently at both gallery locations in SoHo and Venice, Calif.), reveal a dramatic shift in thematic focus. Whereas McGinley’s road trip series resulted in youthful, sometimes forlorn-feeling images of nude forms set against the backdrop of landscapes that varied according to geographic location, this most recent collection of photographs was shot entirely in upstate New York.

headline: Toxin Taints Crabs and Kills Sea Mammals, Scientists Warn
text: The authorities in California are advising people to avoid consumption of crabs contaminated by a natural toxin that has spread throughout the marine ecosystem off the West Coast, killing sea mammals and poisoning various other species.

headline: A Close-Up of the Sun
text: NASA released a video of the sun created from still images taken by its space-based telescope, the Solar Dynamics Observatory. The labor intensive process takes 10 hours to make one minute of video.

headline: Museum of Natural History Reveals Design for Expansion
text: In designing its $325 million addition on Columbus Avenue, the American Museum of Natural History has opted for an architectural concept that is both cautious and audacious, according to plans approved by its board on Wednesday. The design consumes less coveted park space than expected, while introducing a contemporary aesthetic that evokes Frank Gehry’s museum in Bilbao, Spain, in its undulating exterior and Turkey’s underground city of Cappadocia in its cavelike interior.

headline: ‘One Child’ Culture Is Entrenched in China
text: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: Mysteries Surround Missing Italian Marathoner After He Is Found Safe
text: This much is known: Gianclaudio P. Marengo ran 26.2 miles through the five boroughs in the New York City Marathon on Sunday. How many more miles the Italian runner traveled after finishing the race is still a mystery.

headline: Your Morning Briefing: Russia Crash, Stranded on Bali, China Markets
text: Good morning.

headline: Review: Evgeny Kissin the Curator Illustrates His Breadth
text: Each year Carnegie Hall invites artists to curate concert series through its Perspectives series. Evgeny Kissin is using his to let New Yorkers see double.

headline: Review: Garth Fagan Dance Honors Geoffrey Holder With Festivity, Not Sorrow
text: Garth Fagan knows that mourning doesn’t need to be sorrowful. That attitude guides his latest dance, an ode to the prolific choreographer, performer, painter, director and designer — and Mr. Fagan’s friend — Geoffrey Holder, who died last year.

headline: Nov. 4, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from the Philippines, the West Bank, England and Iraq.

headline: ‘Kwaidan’ and ‘House of Bamboo’: Visions of, and From, the Rising Sun
text: In movie terms, Japan is the land of total mise-en-scène. Western artists from van Gogh to Chris Marker have been fascinated by the “otherness” of Japan’s seemingly aestheticized way of life — taking from and reading into the culture of a nation the French literary philosopher Roland Barthes called “the empire of signs.”

headline: Review: BalletNext, Seeking Abandon in Jazz
text: Live music is more of a luxury than a given in dance, but when Michele Wiles started BalletNext in 2011,  it was part of her mission. At her previous job, as a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, it was a given.

headline: Review: ‘Hagoromo’ Offers More Than Dance at BAM Harvey Theater
text: A central scene of “Hagoromo” occurs in sustained silence, as Jock Soto, playing a fisherman, toys with a mysterious veil that he has found on a remote island. We know — he does not — that this veil is the Hagoromo, a sacred mantle: we have seen an angel dance with it.

headline: Officials on Pakistani Factory Collapse
text: Rescue workers and local government officials were on the scene after a factory undergoing expansion collapsed into rubble Wednesday evening in an industrial park in eastern Pakistan.

headline: Review: American Classical Orchestra, With an Unseasonal ‘Passion’
text: Should it matter if a Bach “Passion” is performed out of season? Handel’s “Messiah,” after all, which was also written for Eastertide, is performed far more often around Christmas.

headline: When Photographs Become Evidence
text: The decision to drop charges against a photographer and indict an arresting officer was based on direct evidence: the photographer’s own photos.

headline: Review: Lionel Loueke’s Sinuous Serenity
text: Lionel Loueke

headline: How Organic Avenue Lost All Its Juice
text: As recently as last month, one could hardly throw a lentil in New York City without hitting an Organic Avenue storefront, with its orange banner, stick-figure logo and promise of better living through $9 cayenne-infused lemonade.

headline: Review: In Carla Morrison’s ‘Amor Supremo,’ Love and the Void
text: Carla Morrison

headline: Review: Chris Janson, With ‘Buy Me a Boat,’ Separates Himself From Bro-Country Genre
text: Chris Janson

headline: In the Cross-Fire: Public Editor’s Notebook
text: I steeled myself before I took the job of public editor for The Times, and I looked on the bright side: This would be the ultimate lesson from the universe in how not to try to please anyone — an occupational hazard for a lot of women, even the most ink stained and battle hardened. What a great growth experience it would be!

headline: Aftermath of Suicide Bombing in Egypt
text: Footage shows the damaged walls of a police club in northern Sinai, Egypt, where at least four police officers were killed.

headline: For a New Comic Role, Carson Elrod Tips His Hat to a Stage-Costume King
text: Gusting into his ground floor studio on Walker Street in TriBeCa, William Ivey Long paused for an instant to point out a suite of artworks by his former friend and neighbor Louise Bourgeois, among them an eerie six-eyed figure traced somewhat tentatively in red over black.

headline: ‘Trumbo’ Recalls the Hunters and the Hunted of Hollywood
text: James Dalton Trumbo, the storied screenwriter of “Spartacus” and “Roman Holiday,” would use many names. Pseudonyms were a necessity for Trumbo (1905-1976), one of the “Hollywood 10” who defied the House Un-American Activities Committee in 1947 during its witch hunt for Communists.

headline: Foo Fighters, Recruited by Viral Video, Play Unplanned Concert in Italy
text: To lure the Foo Fighters to his hometown, Cesena, in northern Italy, Fabio Zaffagnini organized 1,000 musicians to play one of their hit songs, recording a video that was widely shared online in July.

headline: Witness Describes Aftermath of Stabbings
text: A student described security response to the stabbing of five people on the campus of the University of California, Merced.

headline: Groenlandia se desvanece entre ríos helados
text: Groenlandia se está derritiendo. Ahora, un grupo de científicos busca predecir que tan rápido subirán los niveles del mar.

headline: Senate Report Says Pentagon Paid Sports Leagues for Patriotic Events
text: Ceremonial first pitches. Luxury box seats. An athlete’s airport greeting for a returning service member. And at least one appearance by the cheerleaders of the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Expedia to Acquire HomeAway for $3.9 Billion
text: Expedia said it had agreed to acquire HomeAway, adding vacation rentals to its wide swath of online travel booking options.

headline: Review: ‘Killing a King,’ on the Murder That Claimed a Peace Process
text: When contemplating the history of Israel, it is tempting to dream in counterfactuals. It is also an almost certain formula for madness. The idea that Israel generates so many wistful what-ifs is itself a sign of the country’s fraught and fragile existence. No one would mourn what might have been if all of us could agree on what should be.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Recalls 126,000 Vehicles Over Problems With Airbags
text: Mercedes-Benz has joined the ranks of automakers troubled by airbag malfunctions, recalling about 126,000 vehicles in the United States, according to a report from the automaker posted this week on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Russian Plane Crash, Houston, Facebook
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Performa, One Artist Stages a Debate — Among His Own Paintings
text: One of the surprises on the lineup of this year’s Performa biennial, a self-reflexive puppet show by Wyatt Kahn, thrusts the artist — who identifies primarily as a painter rather than a performer — and his studio practice into the performance spotlight. “Her invitation came with carte blanche,” Kahn says, referring to the Performa director and curator RoseLee Goldberg. “So I pitched her a puppet show. I was thrilled when she said yes.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey, Feeling Deeply, at Café Carlyle
text: It was nearly 30 years ago that Paul Simon’s album “Graceland” introduced “The Boy in the Bubble,” a prescient song about our perilous, technologized world of “lasers in the jungle” and “the bomb in the baby carriage” with a fragmented expression of apocalyptic dread that still feels remarkably contemporary. And to hear Jessica Molaskey perform it on Tuesday evening with her husband, John Pizzarelli, on guitar at Café Carlyle was to be brought up short by the song’s telegraphic sense of alarm. Just like that bomb, the images explode in your mind.

headline: Doctor at Sheldon Silver Trial Tells of Elaborate Arrangement, Years in Making
text: In New York’s ornate Capitol building in Albany, a plan two years in the making was taking root. Everyone would benefit: Victims of mesothelioma, a rare but deadly form of cancer caused by exposure to asbestos, would be sent to a reputable law firm; the firm would pick up new clients; and a well-regarded cancer research clinic would receive funds.

headline: ‘Defensive Medicine’ May Lower Malpractice Risks
text: Some doctors practice “defensive medicine,” ordering extra tests and procedures believing this will ward off malpractice suits. A new study suggests that it does.

headline: Putting the Cool in Cool-Weather Style
text: Parkas, boots, sweaters and gloves to help you take the perfect “weekend upstate” selfie.

headline: U.S. Offers Account to Encourage Retirement Saving
text: After an extended test period, the federal government is widely promoting its new savings plan called myRA, which is aimed at people who do not have a retirement plan at work.

headline: Quintessential Britain, Accessories and Other Shopping Events
text: Cheerio! From Thursday to Sunday, 20 British companies will celebrate home on Madison Avenue with quintessentially British in-store programming. At Jimmy Choo, you can sip tea in Wedgwood china while shopping for glamorous footwear like the Dolly 100 silver glitter pump with fox-fur pompoms ($995), while Anya Hindmarch will offer free embossing on bespoke purchases, including keepsake boxes ($510 for a large size). Jimmy Choo is at 716 Madison Avenue; Anya Hindmarch is at 795 Madison Avenue.

headline: Indian Muslim, Accused of Stealing a Cow, Is Beaten to Death by a Hindu Mob
text: NEW DELHI — Amid a politically charged national debate over religious intolerance, a Muslim man was beaten to death on Monday by a mob of Hindus who suspected him of stealing a cow, a revered symbol in the Hindu religion. It was the fourth time in six weeks that Hindus had killed Muslims they suspected of slaughtering, stealing or smuggling cows.

headline: Donald Trump Is Said to Have Reached Out to the Megadonor Sheldon Adelson
text: Donald J. Trump has mockingly accused Sheldon Adelson, a casino developer and one of the biggest Republican megadonors, of wanting a “puppet” to back when it was reported that Mr. Adelson was considering throwing his support to Senator Marco Rubio.

headline: Charles Herbert, Mid-Century Child Star on TV and in Movies, Dies at 66
text: Charles Herbert, who was 4 years old when he was discovered by a Hollywood talent scout on a bus while out shopping with his mother and went on to become a top-earning child actor of the 1950s and ’60s, died on Oct. 31 in Las Vegas. He was 66.

headline: Actors Studio to Stage Play by María Irene Fornés
text: The Actors Studio in New York City will stage a half dozen free performances of “Mud,” a provocative play by the Cuban-born American playwright and director María Irene Fornés that deals with such themes as illiteracy, hunger and poverty, the non-profit organization announced Wednesday.

headline: Buffalo’s Next Top Start-Ups
text: The 43North business idea contest, which recently held its second annual competition, is America’s largest, with $5 million in total prize money.

headline: Buffalo Entices Start-Ups to Relocate With $5 Million Contest
text: BUFFALO — Until two weeks ago, Ace Callwood had never set foot in this chilly, postindustrial city, but he committed, sight unseen, to move his fledgling technology business and its four employees here. The lure that drew him was cash: a guaranteed investment of at least $250,000 and a shot at as much as $1 million.

headline: Bitcoin Basics
text: Bitcoin is both a virtual currency and an online payment system — one that some people believe will transform the global financial system. But the details of this new technology have remained a mystery to most.

headline: Brett Gardner’s Wrist Injury Led to Drop-Off, Coach Says
text: When the Yankees were shut out by the Houston Astros in the American League wild-card game, the crowd at Yankee Stadium saved its most vociferous boos for one of its favorite players, Brett Gardner, the Yankees’ only homegrown starter.

headline: Highway Bill Debate Tests Paul Ryan’s Promise for a More Open House
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Vicky Hartzler, Republican of Missouri, wanted an amendment that would prohibit the use of federal highway money for “landscaping and beautification.”

headline: Iran President Pushes Back Over Anti-U.S. Crackdown
text: TEHRAN — President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Wednesday criticized the recent arrests of journalists and others by the Revolutionary Guard Corps, which has accused detainees of being part of seditious plots hatched by the United States.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Browns (2-6) at Bengals (7-0)
text: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: State Dept. Denies Request for Delay on Pipeline Review
text: The State Department on Wednesday notified TransCanada, the company seeking to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline, that it would not grant a request to suspend its review of the project. “A lot of work has gone into this to date, and the secretary wants that work to continue,” John Kirby, the department spokesman, said, referring to Secretary of State John Kerry. In a letter to Mr. Kerry, TransCanada said a delay would allow time for a review by Nebraska. Environmental groups said the request is a bid to avert President Obama’s expected rejection of the pipeline. TransCanada said on Wednesday that it respected the State Department’s decision and would continue pressing to show that the pipeline is “in the national interest of the United States.”

headline: Bitcoin Surges, Emerging From a Lull in Interest
text: After a long period of quiet, the price of the virtual currency Bitcoin is surging again as signs of interest from China and Wall Street have helped kick off a new speculative frenzy.

headline: Officials Debate Whether ‘Ferguson Effect’ Is Real
text: WASHINGTON — A rift widened Wednesday within the Obama administration over the politically charged question of whether a surge in crime in some cities reflects the reluctance of the police to confront suspicious people because of increased public scrutiny of their behavior.

headline: In Houston, Hate Trumped Fairness
text: Sometime in the near future, a transgender teenager in Texas will attempt suicide — and maybe succeed — because vilifying people for their gender identity remains politically acceptable in America.

headline: Suicide of a Dishonest Officer
text: There is no way to fully process the betrayal by Charles Joseph Gliniewicz, a police lieutenant in Illinois who an investigator said Wednesday had committed a “carefully staged suicide” after years of stealing money from a local youth group that he ran.

headline: Cavaliers, Taking Cue From LeBron James’s Sleeves, Go on Tear to Beat Knicks
text: CLEVELAND — Carmelo Anthony and LeBron James go way back. They knew each other in high school. They entered the N.B.A. together as lottery picks in 2003. They became friends.

headline: Ex-Prosecutor Details Robert Durst Case in New Book, but Some Fear It Could Aid Defense
text: Just when the story of Robert A. Durst, the New York real estate scion who is a suspect in two murders, could not get any stranger, a new book arrives from a former Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine Pirro, describing her quest for justice in his case.

headline: Airbnb and Uber Mobilize Vast User Base to Sway Policy
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last few years, so-called sharing companies like Airbnb and Uber — online platforms that allow strangers to pay one another for a room or a ride — have established footholds in thousands of communities well before local regulators have figured out how to deal with them.

headline: Highlights From the Trial of Sheldon Silver
text: Sheldon Silver, an assemblyman who rose from the Lower East Side of Manhattan to become one of New York State’s most powerful politicians, was found guilty on Monday in a federal corruption trial.

headline: Trump ‘SNL’ Petitions Arrive at 30 Rock
text: Petitions from Latino and immigration groups calling on NBC to drop Donald J. Trump as the “Saturday Night Live” host this week were delivered to its offices.

headline: Donald Trump’s Scheduled Appearance on ‘Saturday Night Live’ Draws Protest
text: Donald J. Trump has appeared unconcerned with the possibility of angering Latinos since declaring during the announcement of his presidential campaign in June that Mexico was sending rapists to the United States.

headline: Memphis Is Powerful. The Problem: Its League Isn’t.
text: Three tigers enter a room before the evening circus. They appear equally fierce. Two are sent to the big tent. The third? His pedigree is called into question, and he is sent off to a sideshow.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis and the 1975 Law Complicating Matters
text: To appreciate why it is proving so hard for Washington to help debt-burdened Puerto Rico, it helps to go back to 1975, the year New York City went broke, and consider the role played in that crisis by a prominent Republican senator from Texas named John Tower.

headline: N.F.L. Says Teams Will Have to Return Improper Military Payments
text: The N.F.L. said that any of its teams found to have been paid by a branch of the military for promotional purposes would have to return the money.

headline: Budget Could Be the Last of the Big Deals for President Obama
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Republicans in Congress are enjoying a rare season of peace and productivity, eschewing debt defaults, government shutdowns and budgetary brinkmanship as they move long-stalled legislation. But for the White House, the suspension of dysfunction has a darker side: the demise of dreams.

headline: Charges for 2 Connecticut Students Said to Have Dressed Like Columbine Killers
text: Two high school students in western Connecticut were arrested on Wednesday after they were said to have worn Halloween costumes that looked like the gunmen responsible for the Columbine mass killings in 1999 and threatened to harm other students, the authorities said.

headline: Divine Being
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When you’re solving a themed crossword, how long would you say it takes you to “guess” or solve the theme before you finish the puzzle? I see many comments from people who claim not to see themes, and it seems to me that these solvers are missing some of the fun of deciphering a crossword puzzle.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 6: ‘A High Hope for a Low Heaven’
text: On Wednesday’s “Empire,” a kidnapping mystery was resolved almost as quickly as it unfurled. Hakeem got snatched by three gang members with matching longhorn back tattoos, but they only held him for an afternoon and asked for a modest $40,000 ransom for his safe return. The ordeal leaves the youngest Lyon shaken, and a smack from the butt of a gun renders him temporarily hearing-impaired and unable to perform. Hakeem’s unearned bravado frequently makes him insufferable, so the vulnerability he radiates throughout the crisis and its aftermath is rewarding, whetever the cost, though he still manages to treat his family poorly throughout.

headline: San Francisco’s First Female Sheriff Plans to Improve Ties in Criminal Justice System
text: SAN FRANCISCO — San Francisco elected its first female sheriff on Tuesday: Vicki Hennessy, a city native who pledged to work with the whole criminal justice system — including the police, the district attorney’s office and federal immigration officials — to build better relationships.

headline: One Is Dead After Plane Crashes Off Queens Coast
text: Search crews found the body of a man amid the debris from a small plane that crashed off the coast of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

headline: Official Cites Past Arrests for Driver in Fatal Brooklyn Bus Crash
text: The bus driver with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who was charged in connection with a crash that killed a 70-year-old woman on Tuesday in Brooklyn had been arrested three times over the last decade, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Brooklyn Man, 35, Is Fatally Shot in His Building’s Hallway
text: A Brooklyn man died on Wednesday after he was shot in the head in the hallway of his apartment building, the police said.

headline: Kentucky’s Next Governor, Matt Bevin, Rode In on Outsider Status
text: LOUISVILLE — Matt Bevin, Kentucky’s new Republican governor-elect, likes to catch his opponents off guard. So on a Friday in September, while driving by the state Democratic Party headquarters — where a sign declared “We Can’t Trust Matt Bevin” — he decided, spur-of-the-moment, to pop in.

headline: Thomas Gilbert Jr. Is Fit for Trial in Wealthy Father’s Death, Psychologist Says
text: Although two court-appointed psychiatrists have found Thomas Gilbert Jr. too mentally ill to be tried on charges he killed his wealthy father, a forensic psychologist hired by the Manhattan district attorney’s office said in court on Wednesday that he had reached a starkly different conclusion.

headline: Elder Bush Says His Son Was Served Badly by Aides
text: WASHINGTON — After years of holding back, former President George Bush has finally broken his public silence about some of the key figures in his son’s administration, issuing scathing critiques of Vice President Dick Cheney and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

headline: M.L.B. Decision on Nationals’ Rights Fees Is Overturned
text: A Major League Baseball committee’s decision to award the Washington Nationals five years of annual rights fees from the Mid-Atlantic Sports Network, which would have peaked at about $66 million in 2016, was thrown out Wednesday by a New York State Supreme Court judge.

headline: CUNY Faculty Members Arrested After Staging Protest
text: Several dozen City University of New York faculty members were arrested on Wednesday when they blocked the entrance to the Midtown Manhattan building housing the administration’s offices as part of a demand for salary increases.

headline: Death Among Middle-Aged Whites
text: Two Princeton economists startled other Americans — and themselves — when they uncovered a trend that had escaped the medical and scientific world: Between 1999 and 2013, white middle-aged men and women in the United States, especially those with only a high school education, began dying at a sharply increased rate, largely a result of problems with legal and illegal drugs, alcohol-related liver disease and suicide. The health and financial implications are disturbing for the country, and for what the two economists called a “lost generation.”

headline: Democrats Undermine Efforts to Protect Retirement Savers
text: Forty-seven House Democrats are threatening to derail the  Obama administration’s effort  to protect Americans from retirement advisers who put their own interest in earning commissions above their clients’ need for expert advice.

headline: Why America Invented Ahmad Chalabi
text: WITH his death, the Iraqi politician Ahmad Chalabi is once again in the news. Detractors rage about his supply of fabricated intelligence on Iraqi weapons of mass destruction that supposedly tricked Washington into war. Supporters claim he was a heroic dissident who was never given the chance to transform his troubled country into paradise.

headline: What We Owe the MythBusters
text: WHEN the reality TV show “MythBusters” debuted on the Discovery Channel in 2003, its producers weren’t on a mission to transform science and education in America. They just wanted to entertain. In each episode, the hosts would try to debunk or confirm a few classic urban legends. Could a penny dropped off the Empire State Building really kill a person? Could eating a poppy-seed bagel actually make you test positive for heroin? The producers cast two San Francisco-based special-effects artists, Jamie Hyneman and Adam Savage, as hosts. The show was a surprise hit — pulling in as many as 20 million viewers a season — and it helped changed our culture.

headline: Drugs, Greed and a Dead Boy
text: Andrew Francesco was a rambunctious, athletic and joyful child, but also a handful. When he was 5 years old, a psychiatrist prescribed Ritalin. As he grew older, he disrupted classes and was given a growing number of potent antipsychotic and other medications.

headline: What My Mother Wanted Us to Pack
text: After our mother died last year at age 91, my four sisters and I gathered to clear out her apartment. We didn’t imagine the work would be onerous, since our mother — a modest, orderly person determined never to be a burden to her kids — had consciously downsized over the years as she and my father moved from their suburban home to a three-bedroom condo and then to a small apartment in a “senior residence.”

text: Before the Whitney Museum of American Art moved to its new location in Lower Manhattan, it hosted a discussion about what it means for a museum to be a safe and welcoming space.

text: WASHINGTON — President Obama vowed a year ago to give Central American children fleeing violence a new, legal way into the United States by allowing them to apply for refugee status while in their own countries instead of accepting help from smugglers or resorting to a dangerous trek across Mexico.

headline: Alabama Is Rolling in Cash, With Tide Lifting All Boats
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Bill Battle is near the 30-yard line with his fellow alumni, gripping hands and flashing a lighthouse smile, reassuring one and all that all is right in the University of Alabama athletics department, which he runs. Near the edge of the field, Molly Brautigan and fellow sorority sisters laugh and plot their postgame festivities.

headline: Should Prostitution Be Legal?
text: This summer Amnesty International passed a resolution supporting the decriminalization of sex work. The organization decided that decriminalization is the best way to defend sex workers’ human rights and lessen the risk of abuse they face. But will making prostitution legal only increase the demand for sex workers, without actually protecting them from the violent abuse and exploitation that is common in the industry?

headline: Before, During and After: Strategies From Our News Q’s Feature for Reading Nonfiction
text: Every weekday on this blog we take an important or interesting news or feature story from the week and turn it into what we call News Q’s — a quick series of questions and activities designed to help students both understand the story and connect it to their own lives.

headline: New York Today: Spring Eternal
text: Updated 11:13 a.m.

headline: How to Help
text: Every day in 2014, an average of 42,500 people left their homes looking for protection and safety elsewhere, and the number of refugees in the world has quadrupled in the past five years, to close to 60 million. More than 50 percent of those refugees are children, the highest figure for child refugees in more than a decade. Chuol, Hana and Oleg — the children featured in the New York Times Magazine article “The Displaced” — are three young refugees who were forced to leave everything behind because of violence, conflict and persecution.

headline: The Displaced: Oleg
text: Oleg Teryokhin was living with his mother and father in Nikishino, a rural village of fewer than 1,000 coal miners, farmers and their families in eastern Ukraine, when fighting broke out in April 2014. Hastily formed separatist militias, goaded and armed by Moscow, rose up in a rebellion against a new, pro-Western government in Kiev. In the first months of the conflict, the fighting was far from Nikishino, and Oleg, then 10, spent the early summer tearing about the village on his bicycle, zipping past its old brick cottages and apricot orchards. Then, in July, scorched scraps of clothing and bits of paper with foreign writing blew through the village — debris from the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the passenger jet that was shot down, killing hundreds of people whose bodies lay in fields just south of the village. When Oleg carried some of these items home, his mother, Galina, was horrified that the conflict had come so close.

headline: The Displaced: Chuol
text: Chuol was only 5 in 2011, the year South Sudan, after decades of war, became the world’s newest nation. He was living with his parents, grandparents and other relatives in a village near the city of Leer, not yet old enough to understand the hope and joy sweeping through the small East African country.

headline: The Displaced: Introduction
text: I have two photos on my desk. The first shows a child, a girl of about 10. She is standing behind an enormous pile of her family’s belongings, which have been tightly packed for a long journey. Her face is blank with uncertainty, but she strikes a bossy pose — one hand on her hip, the other planted firmly against the bundles. Her companions are an older woman, probably her mother, and a little boy — her younger brother? Both look directly at the photographer, Henri Cartier-Bresson, who took this picture in Dessau, as scores of Germans displaced during World War II began returning home. It is 1945. Where has this girl been, and what has she seen?

headline: The Displaced: Hana
text: At 4:45 in the morning on a Saturday in early August, stars were still bright in the sky above a refugee settlement in rural Lebanon where Hana Abdullah, a 12-year-old girl from Syria, now lives. The morning call to prayer floated down a dusty road and wound its way around the mostly silent tents. At 5 o’clock, Hana was still sleeping on her bamboo mat by the edge of her family’s tent, her arms folded, her hands under her head. Her baby brother and three of her four sisters slept nearby. Many mornings Hana was up at 4 o’clock. She worked in the nearby fields of Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley, picking fruits or vegetables, and everyone started early. But today the truck that would take her there was late. Now came its familiar rumble, next the crunching of gravel: She stirred, her mouth twitched, her eyelids fluttered. Then she was up, vertical in one swift movement, stretching, pulling on a hat from a stash of her belongings. She grabbed lunch — a tomato, and a pita she folded around a potato — and ducked outside to wait on one of the benches in front of her tent.

headline: Virtual Reality: A New Way to Tell Stories
text: One hundred nineteen years ago, the inaugural issue of this magazine published the first photographs ever to appear in The New York Times, beginning on the cover with three small halftone images of the former presidential candidates Stephen Douglas, John Bell and John Breckinridge. Elsewhere in the magazine, readers found images of X-rays, then a nascent technology, showing a hand and a foot. Now, more than 6,000 Sundays later, the magazine is proud to introduce another visual innovation: In conjunction with this week’s cover story on the global refugee crisis, we are unveiling The New York Times’s first contribution to the new field of virtual-­reality journalism.

text: Today, The New York Times takes a step into virtual reality. NYT VR is a mobile app that can be used — along with your headphones and optionally a cardboard viewing device — to simulate richly immersive scenes from across the globe.
