headline: Chris Christie Seeks to Capitalize on a Widely Shared Personal Moment
text: When The Huffington Post put up a Facebook video on Friday of Gov. Chris Christie speaking about his mother’s addiction to cigarettes and his friend’s death from addiction, it wasn’t with the expectancy that it would become one of the most watched videos on its Facebook account. Mr. Christie, of New Jersey, has been talking about drug overhaul since 2010, and he frequently touches on the subject on the campaign trail, as have other candidates, like Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: New Barclays C.E.O. James Staley Buys $10 Million of Bank’s Shares
text: LONDON — James E. Staley, the incoming chief executive of Barclays, has bought shares in the British bank valued at about 6.5 million pounds, or about $10 million, the lender said on Thursday.

headline: Reaching for Vigor, Jeb Bush Slips In Some Gentle Profanity
text: Eager to demonstrate urgency and vigor in his campaign, Jeb Bush seems to be testing a new tool: gentle profanity.

headline: Review: In ‘Spectre,’ Daniel Craig Is Back as James Bond, No Surprise
text: Does it mean something that James Bond drinks a dirty martini in “Spectre,” the latest in the seemingly unkillable franchise? It’s too soon to know, though true Bondologists will be parsing this new drink’s significance shortly. As more of an amateur in all-things Bond, I had hoped a dirty bomb would go boom or that the actress Léa Seydoux would do something unspeakable to Daniel Craig, given that the pre-credit sequence features female nudes writhing alongside an octopus with busy arms. Part of the bankable pleasure of the series, after all, is that every so often, among the usual guns and girls, the unexpected happens — a bikini stops the film, a villain revs it up, Bond surprises.

headline: An Arts Explosion Takes Shanghai
text: In Shanghai, the historic Bund grabs much of the spotlight — the stretch of former banks and trading houses along the Huangpu River, built a century ago in a kaleidoscope of architectural styles, is a monument to the grandeur of another era. It can also be downright suffocating on weekends, with tourists jostling for selfie positions.

headline: Equality, Then What? New Plays Explore Modern Gay Life
text: In 2011, when the New York State Legislature announced the passage of a marriage equality bill, Mark Gerrard and his partner, Tom Broecker, raced to celebrate outside the Stonewall Inn. In the middle of the laughter and the merriment and the dancing, Mr. Gerrard recalled a moment of uncertainty. “So now we’re supposed to get married?” he thought. “Now we’re supposed to want to get married?”

headline: From Army of One to Band of Tweeters
text: IT was the end of a long combat patrol near a district called Adhamiyah, in northwest Baghdad, in the fall of 2008. It started like most daily missions but ended with a hidden enemy throwing a grenade at a vehicle convoy, missing it but hitting a young Iraqi child instead. As the company commander, I met the soldiers at the site and after a few hours followed them back to our base. I left the men, went to stow my equipment and brief other officers.

headline: ISIS Claims It Struck Police in Bangladesh

headline: A Post-Peronist President at Last?
text: BUENOS AIRES — The last time Argentina was scheduled to hold a presidential runoff election was 12 years ago. That occasion was very unusual in that the winning candidate, intimidated by the thin margin of his victory, decided to quit the field. Rather than risk losing in the second round of voting, he chose to step down, leaving the presidency to the candidate who had been the runner-up in the first round.

headline: Twenty Designers on the Art That Inspires Them

For a new sale on the site Paddle8, 20 American designers — including Michael Kors, Thom Browne, Francisco Costa and Diane von Furstenberg — have each picked one piece of art that has influenced their work; the proceeds of the sale will go to benefit the CFDA and its programs. (The Alice + Olivia designer Stacey Bendet Eisner has even donated a Francesco Clemente painting.) Click through the slide show here to see the work that inspires each designer — and why.

The V, found on Cadillac, is the last of them alphabetically but possibly Speed Racer’s first consonant of choice. Seriously. The ATS-V sedan and coupe, built to take on C63, M3 and M4, is the real deal for taming tarmac. If only Cadillac had street cred.

headline: 1915: Spurious Night Clubs to Close
text: LONDON — The doom of the many spurious night clubs, which have become very numerous in London and other English cities, is now practically sealed. These clubs have been the cause of a succession of scandals, and Lord Curzon, moving the second reading of the Night Clubs Bill in the House of Lords yesterday, said that officers have, in some instances, been drugged and afterwards blackmailed in these resorts. ‘‘The Night Clubs Bill,’’ he said, ‘‘is designed to put an end to a great scandal — namely, the rapid and unarrested growth of what are commonly called night clubs, which are really haunts of temptation and dens of iniquity.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 6, 1915

headline: Edie Campbell on the Influence of Seoul
text: In between modeling during New York and London fashion weeks this September, I took a 48-hour break to fly to Seoul. My younger sister, Olympia, and I went for the opening party of a new store my mum, the British architect Sophie Hicks, had designed and built for the Stockholm-based fashion brand Acne Studios. Initially, it seemed a strange fit: a small piece of Scandinavia in South Korea.

headline: Decoding Keith Haring’s Early Works
text: The art dealer and curator Jeffrey Deitch is most fascinated by both bookends of an artist’s career — not just the late works, which are typically profound and full of reflection, but the first compositions, too. “In the early periods, you get the exuberance, the promise,” he explains. “Sometimes you don’t get the refinement, yet you feel this sincerity.”

headline: Serena Williams Thwarts Phone Theft, Complete With Highlight Video

headline: Why Your Kids Love Snapchat, and Why You Should Let Them
text: In the picture that sprang to life on my phone, the girl’s hair was an unruly nest. Her eyes were crusty slits as she squinted, unsmiling, at the camera. She was still in bed, blankets askew. It is not a glamorous shot.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 5: We Have Two Selves
text: The Hotel Cortez is pretty sick. There’s the gratuitous depravity, of course, but what I really mean is that a virus is running rampant. The Countess calls it “our precious virus,” a sort of vampirism that, yes, keeps one young and beautiful, but also spreads death and destruction.

headline: Wine Gift Options Abound for Thanksgiving
text: A good Thanksgiving guest has one responsibility and one elective. The responsibility is to carry out with good will whatever tasks, if any, have been assigned. The elective (and let’s face it, good manners would call this a responsibility, too) is to bring a little something for the hosts.

headline: Juror Excused From Sheldon Silver’s Corruption Trial

headline: Boeing to Pay $57 Million to Settle Suit Over Retirement Plan
text: Boeing has agreed to pay $57 million to settle a lawsuit that accused it of charging excessive fees and choosing higher-cost investment offerings for the workers and retirees who participate in its 401(k) retirement plan.

headline: Ben Carson Releases Rap Ad on the Radio
text: A new 60-second radio ad by Ben Carson’s campaign will begin airing Friday in eight markets — including Atlanta, Detroit and Miami. The Carson campaign is putting $150,000 behind the ad, titled “Freedom,” which takes the form of a rap song and is aimed at African-American voters.

headline: House Passes $300 Billion Bill to Improve Roads and Bridges
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a multiyear highway bill that includes more than $300 billion in transportation and infrastructure programs to address the nation’s deteriorating roads and bridges.

headline: Public Theater Adds Transgender-Themed Musical to Season
text: The Public Theater is adding a musical about a transgender group of friends to its winter schedule, and putting out a direct call for transgender actors to audition.

headline: Pilot Was Sole Victim of Plane Crash Off Queens Coast, Authorities Say
text: The cause of a plane crash off the coast of the Rockaway Peninsula this week remained unclear, investigators said on Thursday, even as officials confirmed that only one person was killed.

headline: Team From Uncle Boons to Open Diner in NoLIta
text: Ann Redding and Matt Danzer, the married cooks who have drawn acclaim (and a Michelin star) for their no-holds-barred approach to Thai cuisine at Uncle Boons in NoLIta, are planning to shift away from Asia and toward heartland Americana with a new restaurant in the same neighborhood.

headline: The Magazine Leaps Into Virtual Reality
text: The magazine editor, Jake Silverstein, on a new adventure in storytelling. Susan Lehman is the host.

headline: The Naturally Alchemical Power of Gold Makeup
text: Gold makeup plays a part in some of the most irresistible female archetypes — the sun-kissed blonde bombshell, the ancient queen, the glittering disco diva. Think of Brigitte Bardot and her honey-bronzed skin, Cleopatra and her gold-leaf eyes and gilded-to-the-hilt Studio 54 girls like Veruschka, Jerry Hall and Grace Jones. It’s no surprise that Ian Fleming, a master of male fantasy, dreamed up Auric Goldfinger, a villain who kills his bodacious victim by drenching her skin in gold paint. Watching ‘‘golden girl’’ Shirley Eaton’s metallic naked body glowing on pristine white sheets in the 1964 Bond movie, one feels like dying a golden death might not be such a bad thing.

headline: Where to Go in the East Village of Des Moines
text: A once-desolate downtown edge is redefining the urban heart of Des Moines.

headline: Grandchamps in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn
text: A restaurant wants to evangelize on behalf of Haitian food, but also serve the neighborhood.

headline: Will Airport Security Accept Your Driver’s License?
text: Come 2016, your state driver’s license may not be enough to get you on a commercial flight.

headline: 1935 | A Family Battle for Succession
text: Adolph S. Ochs did many things brilliantly, not least among them reinventing the moribund New York Times, which he purchased in 1896, as the newspaper of record.

headline: ‘You Us We All’ Creates a Baroque Vision of Modern Life
text: Early in the new opera “You Us We All,” two fashionable women of the 17th century, wearing elaborate wigs, gowns and corsets, sing about boredom while twilight gathers over modern-day Los Angeles. “I forgetith how glorious the sunset is at thy infinity pool,” one sings forlornly in pseudo-antique English, sipping a martini, her voice underscored by a Baroque ensemble.

headline: Scientists Study Links Between Climate Change and Extreme Weather
text: Did climate change cause that heat wave? That hurricane? That drought?

headline: Forbes Sues Integrated Whale Media Over Deal
text: A year ago, when Forbes Media agreed to sell a majority stake to a consortium of Asian investors, Steve Forbes, the chairman and editor in chief, said he got nearly everything he wanted out of the deal.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret World Inside You’ Explores the Microbial Human
text: There are trillions of them, crawling on you, and in you. This is the disturbing news that comes early in “The Secret World Inside You,” an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. “Your body is teeming with bacteria, viruses and other microbes,” a small video screen announces. The screen stands near the entrance, in a cosmic sea of tiny suspended lights, as sonorous space music pours forth in a sonic ooze.

headline: For Taylor Swift and Drake, Friends Serve the Brand
text: This year, Taylor Swift took her blockbuster album “1989” on tour, and as much as it was a celebration of her blossoming into a full-fledged, gleaming pop idol, it also served as a treatise on the virtues — and perks — of friendship.

headline: Watches that Take the Plunge
text: New sporty timepieces are elegant enough to handle any expedition.

headline: For a Single Mother, an Alternate Reality
text: The sentimentalist in me has always appreciated the idea of an alternate reality. Like the mythical farm where parents claim to send the family dog after it meets a tragic fate, the alternate reality is a place where not-so-happy endings get a second chance.

headline: For Brides in the Military, Free Gowns
text: Last-minute deployments, financial constraints and injuries suffered on duty can make it difficult for military couples to marry, much less organize and enjoy their weddings.

headline: Grandchamps Welcomes You to Haiti, via Bedford-Stuyvesant
text: In a photograph on the wall of Grandchamps, a Haitian restaurant near the eastern edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, a woman in a sundress and long earrings carries a plate of seemingly just-gathered string beans. The image is bucolic and sternly glamorous at once, a reminder to the chef, Shawn Brockman (who happens to be the woman’s son-in-law) that she has trusted him with her recipes and he had better watch what he’s doing.

headline: Chelsea Boots for Fall
text: Five Chelsea boots for your fall wardrobe.

headline: The Sleeker Side of Diving Watches
text: These watches are elegant enough to handle any expedition.

headline: Barnes Foundation Names New Chief Curator
text: The Barnes Foundation — which is still feeling out its new identity in downtown Philadelphia after relocating in 2012 from its original home in the suburb of Merion, Pa. — announced Thursday that it had chosen Sylvie Patry, a longtime curator at the Musée D’Orsay in Paris, to be its new chief curator and deputy director for collections and exhibitions.

headline: David Vitter Is Dealt Setback in Louisiana Governor’s Race
text: Senator David Vitter has had a rougher road to the Louisiana governor’s office than he or most anyone expected, and on Thursday it got a little bit rougher. Lt. Gov. Jay Dardenne, one of Mr. Vitter’s Republican rivals in the primary, endorsed the Democrat in the runoff election, State Representative John Bel Edwards.

headline: Voice for the Voiceless
text: As chairwoman of the New York City Commission on Human Rights, Carmelyn P. Malalis helps the city’s most vulnerable citizens find justice.

headline: Miranda Lambert, Carrie Underwood and Justin Timberlake at the C.M.A. Awards
text: Guests arrived dressed in their red-carpet finest (and sometimes sparkliest) for the Country Music Association’s annual awards ceremony.

headline: Carmelyn P. Malalis: Leading Through Praise, Not Fear
text: This interview with Carmelyn P. Malalis, chairwoman and commissioner of the New York City Commission on Human Rights, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Shooting in Queens Leaves 2 Teenage Friends Dead
text: They were two young men close in age, growing up next door to each other on a quiet street in Queens lined with narrow, two-story houses. That is how Peyton Manwaring and Marcus Mendez became friends.

headline: Greeks Move to Meet Bailout Demands, but May Need to Do More
text: ATHENS — Greek lawmakers late on Thursday approved some of the economic changes that international creditors have demanded in order to unlock the first loan installment from the country’s bailout program. But the legislation pointedly lacks some of the main measures demanded by lenders.

headline: Review: Aziz Ansari, in ‘Master of None,’ Negotiates Technology and Social Mores
text: In the best episode of Netflix’s “Master of None” — I think, it’s hard to pick just one — Dev (Aziz Ansari) wants tacos, but doesn’t know where to go. So he whips out his laptop and smartphone, consults Google, Eater and Yelp, finds lists and reviews, dozens of them, New York City’s trendiest tortillas, dissected and annotated by social media. Finally he settles on a food truck said to have the most delicious tacos in the city.

headline: Two Former Traders Found Guilty in Libor Manipulation Case
text: A jury in Manhattan on Thursday found two former London traders guilty in the first convictions in the United States stemming from the global investigation into the rigging of an interest rate benchmark known as Libor.

headline: Grimes Takes Over the Guggenheim
text: ASAP Rocky, Lake Bell, Raf Simons and Mark Ronson were among the celebrants at the Guggenheim International Gala pre-party.

headline: Donald Trump Sent Sheldon Adelson a Glossy Booklet of Photos
text: During the hot months of summer, when Donald J. Trump was suddenly on top of the polls as the candidate who shunned fat cats and would finance his own campaign, the real estate developer sent a personalized memento to the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson.

headline: Mars’ Atmosphere Stripped by Solar Winds, NASA Says
text: The air on Mars — what there is of it — is leaking away, about half a pound a second sputtering into space, scientists announced on Thursday.

headline: 36 Hours in Bogotá, Colombia
text: Colombia’s newly resurgent capital boasts beautiful colonial buildings, chef-driven restaurants and cool new cafes and galleries.

headline: Matt Harvey Wins N.L. Comeback Player Award; Alex Rodriguez Denied in A.L.
text: A New York baseball star whose off-the-field activities are fodder for the city’s gossip pages was chosen Thursday as a comeback player of the year.

headline: Claims for Cryotherapy Treatment Get New Scrutiny After a Death
text: DENVER — You step into an upright cylindrical capsule, padded on the inside and open on top. The floor grinds upward, and your head pops out. There’s a whoosh. And suddenly you are encased in gas, below the neck, in a tank that is minus 300 degrees Fahrenheit — colder than the coldest naturally occurring temperature recorded on Earth.

headline: The Mad Scientists of Levi’s
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If you are here to see the man in charge of Levi’s Eureka Innovation Lab, a test kitchen of denim in a former mill 10 minutes from the company’s Embarcadero-area headquarters here, look for what appears to be a blue manicure.

headline: Denim Is Dead. Long Live Denim.
text: Like other great American innovations, bluejeans emerged from a mélange of worldwide influences.

headline: Made in Japan, Coveted in the U.S.
text: “Average consumers, outside of the metropolitan areas, they’re not into this,” said Gordon Heffner, an owner of Blue in Green, a small shop in SoHo.

headline: Me and My Jeans Jacket
text: The summer I turned 16, my best buddy hitchhiked cross-country to drop acid and live in a tepee, and I made up my mind that I had gotten all I was ever likely to get out of high school and followed him. This was deep in hippie antiquity.

headline: An American Fashion Story
text: Modern takes on denim.

headline: Sizing Up Baseball’s Class of Free Agents
text: In August and September, as Yoenis Cespedes went on an offensive tear that helped carry the Mets to the postseason, the dollar figures bandied about for what he might earn as a free agent became comical. A Cuban-born outfielder who made his major league debut in 2012, Cespedes has been around long enough for most of the baseball world to be plenty familiar with him, but he was suddenly on his way to 35 home runs and a contract worth the gross domestic product of a midsize country.

headline: Donald Trump Is Boring
text: If you’ve been following Donald Trump’s presidential campaign over the past few months, you already know what’s in his book.

headline: Germany 101: Refugees Get Guidebook to Their New Home
text: BERLIN — How to get along in Germany: Follow its laws, including showing respect for all religions, especially in the case of Jews, to whom the country has a historical obligation. Don’t be late. Do shake hands. And learn a few basic phrases, from “Cheers” to “I don’t eat pork.”

headline: No, Hot Dogs Do Not Contain Human Meat
text: The eye-catching headlines on the new findings started coming in waves. “Report: Human DNA Found in Hot Dogs” said USA Today, in a typical example.

headline: Doctors Without Borders Says Clues Point to ‘Illegal’ U.S. Strike on Afghan Hospital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Doctors Without Borders hospital was among the most brightly lit buildings in Kunduz on the night a circling American gunship destroyed it.

headline: Poll Finds Global Consensus on a Need to Tackle Climate Change
text: As world leaders prepare to gather in Paris next month to address global warming, their populations generally agree on the need to curb greenhouse gas emissions, but the countries that emit the most carbon dioxide per person are also the ones least worried about climate change, according to a poll released Thursday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Exxon Mobil Investigated for Possible Climate Change Lies by New York Attorney General
text: The New York attorney general has begun an investigation of Exxon Mobil to determine whether the company lied to the public about the risks of climate change or to investors about how such risks might hurt the oil business.

headline: Market Report: Sweater Vests
text: In playful patterns and schoolboy silhouettes, this season’s styles riff on the classic knit.

headline: Taking a Break, John Kasich Practices His Golf Swing
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio had a few minutes Thursday between the end of his remarks to the Portsmith Rotary Club at the country club here and when his lunch arrived. So, taking advantage of a gorgeous fall day, he walked to the driving range and took four swings. He was quite pleased with his shots, exclaiming to his staff after every swing how true he had hit the ball.

headline: Dewey Jury’s Deadlock Exposes a System’s Flaws
text: When the founding fathers enshrined a right to an impartial trial by jury in the Sixth Amendment, it’s hard to imagine they were anticipating the jury in the Dewey & LeBoeuf criminal case.

headline: Not Your Grandpa’s Sweater Vests
text: In playful patterns and schoolboy silhouettes, this season’s styles riff on the classic knit.

headline: Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin to Unite at Sadler’s Wells
text: LONDON — Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin, two of ballet’s biggest stars, will perform together in a program of new work by Russell Maliphant, Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui and Arthur Pita at Sadler’s Wells next year. The theater announced the new partnership at a news conference on Thursday, along with details of its spring-summer 2016 lineup, which includes a program of all-female choreography for English National Ballet; a new piece by Javier de Frutos for the BalletBoyz; a work for dancers and horses by Bartabas; a new piece by Crystal Pite, and a “multi-installation” event by the lighting designers Lucy Carter and Michael Hulls and the composer Nitin Sawhney.

headline: Human Cost Rises as Old Bridges, Dams and Roads Go Unrepaired
text: WASHINGTON — A routine trip to run errands almost cost Katherine Dean her life. In February, just as Ms. Dean, of suburban Maryland, drove underneath a bridge on the Capital Beltway, a large chunk of concrete fell from the structure, crushing the hood of her car and smashing the windshield.

headline: The George Bushes: A Father’s Critique of His Son’s Advisers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Death Toll in Pakistan Factory Collapse Rises to 20
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — Rescue workers on Thursday intensified their search for survivors in the collapse of a factory near Lahore the day before after pulling out 108 survivors over two days, Pakistani officials said.

headline: U.S. to Share Criminal Records With Native American Police
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department moved Thursday to fix what it described as “an information gap” that has allowed offenders living on Native American reservations to buy guns illegally and for years has blocked tribal police from access to important criminal records.

headline: Pandora and Sony/ATV in Deal on Songwriter Payments
text: Pandora Media and the publisher Sony/ATV have often been bitter opponents in the music industry’s streaming wars. But on Thursday they announced a direct licensing deal that gives both sides benefits while the music world braces for possible changes in government regulation of songwriting rights.

headline: Where to Find the Best Jeans in New York
text: In recent years, among the truly committed, truly discerning jeans shopper, a beau ideal has taken hold: raw selvage denim in styles that evoke the rugged workpants of yesteryear. Think Marlon Brando in “The Wild One” (or his jeans, anyway).

headline: Ride-Sharing Apps Bring Back Car-Pooling
text: JACK DeMANCHE’S commute to work was like many in the Boston area — long. But that was before Mr. DeManche, a digital strategist for an advertising agency, began sharing a ride with other commuters with the service Bridj.

headline: Ayumi Tanaka’s “Wish You Were Here”
text: The artist’s dreamlike photo collages are based on memories of her childhood in a small Japanese village.

headline: Goldman Sachs Rolls Out New Policies to Retain Junior Bankers
text: In an effort to appease young investment bankers over the last few years, Goldman Sachs increased their salaries and gave them Saturdays off.

headline: N.F.L. Week 9 Previews and Picks
text: Here’s a look at the best games of N.F.L. Week 9, and who we think will win them.

headline: Dreamlike Photo Collages, Created From Memory
text: Encountering the photographer Ayumi Tanaka’s series “Wish You Were Here” feels like stepping into her subconscious: Though the images and themes might not be yours, the feelings they evoke are familiar. Tanaka constructs three-dimensional dioramas, composed of overlapping multiple layers of photo collages, assembled and photographed to illustrate the “landscapes of my memory,” as she puts it: images that might serve as jumping-off points for all sorts of fairy-tales. The artist constructs her collages with family photos taken when she was growing up in a small village in the mountains of Japan; more recent personal snapshots; self-portraits; and pictures of everyday objects taken from the Internet that become symbols evocative of her childhood memories. The artist herself takes on a poetic tone when discussing her work. “At times in my day-to-day life, I find myself stumbling over reminders of days gone by. Partly formed memories rise up from a forgotten abyss within, surrounding me like a powerful fragrance and rocking my emotions to the core,” she says. “In these moments, I am seized with the desire to gather and collect, to retrieve what has been lost and weave it into something whole.”

headline: Former Goldman Employee Pleads Guilty in Leak Case
text: Highlighting the hazards of Wall Street’s revolving door with regulatory agencies, a former employee of Goldman Sachs pleaded guilty on Thursday for obtaining documents leaked to him by a former colleague at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: ‘Why Would I Join a Party That Doesn’t Really Like Me?’: Readers on Asian-Americans and the Republican Party
text: Many Asian-American readers said the Republican Party’s rhetoric on immigration, education and poverty were top reasons they largely support Democrats for public office, in response to a column by Thomas Edsall.

headline: Scientists Engineer a Plant to Reject Its Own Pollen
text: Field poppies do not self-pollinate, a strategy that helps keep the species’ gene pool diverse. Now, researchers at the University of Birmingham in England have successfully transferred two genes from a poppy plant to a self-fertilizing plant called thale cress. The genetically modified thale cress rejects its own pollen and that of close relatives, the researchers report in the journal Science. The experiment may help researchers breed plants that are stronger than their parents and provide better yields.

headline: Why Barclays May Want to Mull a Move to the U.S.
text: HSBC has caused a scene by suggesting it might move its headquarters from London. But it is rival Barclays that really ought to consider a domicile switch.

headline: Ex-Player’s Suit Challenges N.C.A.A.’s Transfer Rules
text: A former college football player has filed suit against the N.C.A.A., charging that the association’s transfer rules and limits on scholarships violate United States antitrust laws. The lawsuit, filed in a federal court in Indianapolis on Thursday on behalf of the former Weber State cornerback Devin Pugh, seeks to allow players to transfer freely between colleges and to abolish the cap on football scholarships — currently 85.

headline: Four New Ways to Make Fancy Drinks at Home
text: Paris's Experimental Cocktail Club shares tips and recipes from its new book.

headline: 1940: Roosevelt Wins Third Term
text: President Franklin D. Roosevelt won re-election yesterday to become the first President ever honored by a third term in the 151 years since the first inauguration of George Washington. The President and his running mate, Henry A. Wallace, rolled up an overwhelming margin in the electoral college over their Republican opponents, Wendell L. Willkie and Charles L. McNary. However, this plurality fell short of the one that President Roosevelt and John N. Garner attained in the 1936 landslide. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 6, 1940

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Marvel’s Iceman Cometh Out
text: “If I knew then, what I know now” is a familiar, wistful refrain. What would we tell our younger selves if we could? In “Uncanny X-Men” No. 600, which was published Wednesday by Marvel Entertainment, readers get to see the mutant hero Iceman have a conversation with his past self thanks to time travel (because, you know, comics). But it is the younger Iceman that forces the older to acknowledge a truth: He, Bobby Drake, is gay.

headline: Nov. 5, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, Serbia, Myanmar and the West Bank.

headline: Doctor in Sheldon Silver’s Corruption Trial Denies Improper Relationship
text: The bonds of friendship between Dr. Robert N. Taub and Sheldon Silver were evident, from small favors — Mr. Silver once gave Dr. Taub handmade matzo, and helped the doctor’s son find a job — to larger ones.

headline: Bilingual Etiquette for In-Laws
text: Our son lives across the country from us. We visit twice a year. My daughter-in-law, who was raised abroad but speaks perfect English, wants my granddaughter, 4, to be bilingual. She has only spoken to her in her native language from the day she was born. This doesn’t change when we visit. We sit clueless for long stretches while they talk. The same thing happens to my son, who barely speaks their language. We don’t object to our granddaughter learning another language, but we don’t want to feel so left out. Do you agree that this behavior is totally rude?

headline: Sotheby’s Day Auction of Taubman Collection at $42.7 Million
text: Daytime auctions don’t usually make big news. But at Sotheby’s Taubman Modern and Contemporary Art sale on Thursday afternoon, the results, which totaled $42.7 million with fees, left the auction house feeling encouraged enough to announce that it was on track to cover the $500 million it had guaranteed in selling the collection of its former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman. With 123 scheduled lots, the estimate for the sale was $30.2 million to $43.4 million.

headline: A Very Mod Ballet at the Guggenheim Gala
text: What do the painter Alberto Burri and the author Jacqueline Susann have in common? At first glance, not much. But leave it to the Guggenheim to mash up the incongruous for the sake of art — or in this case, for the Guggenheim International Gala, which for the last three years has been lent some extra oomph by Dior. Currently, the Guggenheim’s main floorspace is devoted to a retrospective of work by Burri, the Italian iconoclast whose postwar rejection of pictorial tradition influenced Arte Povera and Neo-Dada. The entertainment at tonight’s gala will come via Tom Gold, the former New York City Ballet principal now leading his own company, who has unearthed “November Steps,” an overlooked ballet by Burri’s wife Minsa Craig. “To me, it looked like Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham en pointe in Andy Warhol’s factory,” Gold says. “Or ‘Valley of the Dolls!’”

headline: Review: ‘Sam Phillips: The Man Who Invented Rock ’n’ Roll,’ by Peter Guralnick
text: Sam Phillips, the founder of Sun Records in Memphis, is frequently remembered for a single sound bite: “If I could find a white man who had the Negro sound and the Negro feel, I could make a billion dollars!” He seems cynical at best, racist at worst.

headline: Flannel Escapes Its Grunge Past
text: Men’s wear designers have gone back to the flannel shirt, but not in a way that evokes Seattle in the ’90s.

headline: Living With Cancer: The Lure of Alternative Remedies
text: When I get tired of being told to juice carrots, I remember that the essayist Anatole Broyard took tap-dancing lessons as he underwent treatment for prostate cancer. Sick people need all sorts of strategies, alongside medical ones, to deal with disease.

headline: Your Morning Briefing: Taiwan-China Meeting, Trans-Pacific Partnership
text: Good morning.

headline: ‘Four Marilyns’ Is Back on the Auction Block
text: Those perusing catalogs for the coming art auctions may have done a double take when viewing Christie’s cover for its postwar and contemporary art sale on Tuesday, featuring Warhol’s 1962 acrylic and silk-screen “Four Marilyns.”

headline: A Vote in Houston Leaves the N.F.L. in a Bind
text: In this age of always-on media attention, there are few more effective ways to silence most professional athletes than to ask a pointed political question. Schooled to carefully manage their public personas, many players will studiously sidestep anything with a whiff of controversy.

headline: Review: In ‘The Seedbed,’ an Uneasy Marital Truce Frays Over Dinner
text: A biblical proverb glimmers behind a meaningful title in “The Seedbed,” a new psychological drama now having its world premiere at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

headline: Review: ‘Miss You Already,’ on Female Friends and Crying
text: As Jess (Drew Barrymore) is going into labor, she flashes back through her long friendship with Milly (Toni Collette), who should be with her but isn’t. “Miss You Already” will eventually account for Milly’s absence, and in the course of doing so it will illuminate the intimate, difficult bond between the two women, who met as 10-year-old schoolgirls and have been nearly inseparable ever since.

headline: With ESPN Gains, Disney Profit Rose 12 Percent in Fiscal Year
text: Wither ESPN? Not this time.

headline: Ben Carson Appeals to Black Voters, but His Campaign Doesn’t, Yet
text: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark. — Sam Hawkins Jr. said he came to a rally here last week for the Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson because he finds Mr. Carson’s social conservatism appealing, relishes his newness to politics and believes that President Obama “sold out for the vote” in supporting same-sex marriage.

headline: Review: BalletCollective Plays With Wildfire
text: BalletCollective’s program “Invisible Divide” leaves a number of burning images in the mind, chiefly ones that revealingly illustrate modern masculinity. Thanks to the choreographer Troy Schumacher, the three male dancers — Harrison Coll (who has moments worthy of James Dean), David Prottas and Taylor Stanley — register with powerful individuality. The way they do so in the contexts both of women and of one another is arresting, fresh, exploratory.

headline: Don McCullin at War
text: The legendary photographer counsels those seeking conflict: look close to home at the social wars being waged every day.

headline: An H.C. Westermann Retrospective Melds Humor and Provocation
text: “Homage to American Art (Dedicated to Elie Nadelman)” is one of 38 sculptures in “See America First,” a terrific exhibition of works by the great American visionary H. C. Westermann (1922–1981) at Venus (formerly Venus Over Manhattan). From a wooden hook attached to a post anchored to a neatly dovetailed wooden pedestal hangs an object with the handle and shaft of a shovel but, instead of a conventional blade, a wooden sphere the size of a bowling ball. It’s hard to imagine what sort of useful work could be done with this curious tool, made in 1966.

headline: Jared Bark’s Black-and-White Photo Booth Creations
text: From 1969 to 1976, the artist Jared Bark all but exhausted the aesthetic possibilities of the common photo booth.

headline: In Rachel Rossin’s ‘Lossy,’ the Virtual Reality of Living in a Painting
text: The artist’s show at Zieher Smith & Horton harnesses a Rift headset and her near abstract paintings.

headline: PaJaMa, Whose Photographs Breathed Eroticism
text: This exhibition explores the work of this stylish collaborative, who made the most of anything at hand in the 1930s and ’40s.

headline: Jasper Cropsey Paintings on Display at His Hudson Valley Home
text: Paintings by the Hudson River School artist Jasper Cropsey reside in the White House, the National Gallery of Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and museums at Yale and Princeton, but the best place to commune with Cropsey’s glorious 19th-century landscapes is in an oasis in Hastings-on-Hudson.

headline: Lively Debate and Discussion at Festival Albertine
text: These days, a good chat about current events or an earful of cultural commentary is readily available on podcasts and online. But Twitter messages and Facebook posts often fail to satisfy the Miser’s thirst to join the conversation.

headline: Furniture Designers With Fates Tied to the Nazis
text: The Lampedo gallery in Lower Manhattan has assembled 30 pieces of playful furniture with some unsettling back stories for the exhibition “Berlin Deko — German Furniture 1910-1930.” The items in this show, on view through Nov. 21, have been arranged to create a kind of off-kilter living room, with jagged black shards painted and mounted on the walls, floors and ceiling.

headline: The Lindberghs, From Triumph to Tragedy, an Exhibition at Morven
text: As soon as Charles Lindbergh completed his trans-Atlantic flight on May 21, 1927, souvenir hunters started tearing apart his plane and trailing after him. Manufacturers put his image on lingerie, crayon boxes, calendars, cigar wrappers, pocket mirrors, board games, tapestries and bookends.

headline: Rock, Pop & Cabaret Listings for Nov. 6-12
text: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Adam Rapoport, Bon Appétit’s Editor, on 5 Favorite Things
text: Adam Rapoport, editor in chief of Bon Appétit, is more likely to be found in designer sneakers than kitchen clogs. Even so, he promises he makes a mean stuffing (“I literally use Jimmy Dean sausage,” he said. “It’s my mom’s classic and very right-down-the-middle American.” ) and perfect mashed potatoes, which he’ll serve on Thanksgiving. But first, he dishes up five of his favorite things.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: How to Style, and Care For, Indoor Plants
text: Damien and Jacqueline Harrison, of the landscape design firm Harrison Green, share their tips for maintaining greenery when outdoor gardens aren’t an option.

headline: At the Armoury, Classics Are Always In Style
text: For nearly two years, Jake Grantham, the manager of the Armoury, an elegant clothing shop in TriBeCa, has been introducing, or reintroducing, classical tailoring to a range of men looking for something that is at once new and old.

headline: James Corden on His Latest Modeling Gig
text: Seven months after strutting the runway for Burberry during its Los Angeles fashion show, and five months after hosting the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards in New York, James Corden, the host of the “The Late Late Show,” is once again having a fashion moment: starring alongside Elton John and Naomi Campbell in the new Burberry holiday campaign directed by Christopher Bailey, the chief executive and chief creative officer of the brand. How did a portly British comedian become the latest “it” boy of the style set? In a phone call from Los Angeles, he talked through the story.

headline: A Take on Seurat, Unseen Since the ’70s
text: “Years ago,” says Roberta Cerini Baj, the widow of the Italian neo-avant garde artist Enrico Baj, “I remember that my daughter, Marianna, told Enrico, ‘When you see paintings in the house, you treat them like friends. When you see them outside of it, in an exhibition, they look totally different.’ And usually, this is true” — though not in the case of Luxembourg & Dayan’s current gathering of her husband’s pieces. The intimate gallery, which is wallpapered and homey, is filled with 50 works by the late artist. Among them is “The Double Grande Jatte,” her husband’s homage to and spin on Georges Seurat’s exercise in pointillism, “A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte.” Its inclusion represents a reunion for Roberta, who last saw “The Double Grande Jatte” when it was on display at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, in 1971. “I found it so fresh here,” she remarks. “When he was making it, we were in an apartment in Milan and there was a door between the living room and the studio,” and the 20-foot-long mural ran parallel to the door jambs. “It was in front of us all of the time and at the end, Enrico said, ‘I understand now why Seurat died so young, from getting bored of making all of those points.’” A quip, sure, but fitting for someone consumed by the need for change.

headline: Cats, Monsters and Detonations at the Park Avenue Armory’s Print Fair
text: The International Fine Art Print Dealers Association Print Fair offers prints from a range of eras and of production techniques. Here are highlights.

headline: Letters: ‘Doomed to Succeed’
text: To the Editor:

headline: R.H. Quaytman’s Variations on Klee’s Angel
text: Two years ago, the New York artist R. H. Quaytman was invited to do a show at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art. She traveled to Israel to research themes for a new body of work, and found one in a piece of 20th-century Modernist art: Paul Klee’s 1920 monoprint “Angelus Novus,” a jewel in the collection of the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for Nov. 6-12
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘A Wonderful Life’ an Adaptation of a Frank Capra Film
text: “A Wonderful Life” has wonderful leading performances, and they alone are a reason to consider visiting the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam to see this musical stage adaptation.

headline: Review: For New York Philharmonic, an All-Mozart Program
text: “Perfection, revelation, incarnation, grace, redemption.” Those are just some of the qualities that two centuries of thinkers have associated with Mozart, writes the musicologist Scott Burnham in his book “Mozart’s Grace.”

headline: ‘Soldier, Spectre, Shaman,’ an Alternate History at MoMA
text: In 1936, the first director of the Museum of Modern Art mapped out the art of his time in a famous chart, the first taste of the museum’s persistent narrative of Modernism. The doctrine goes something like this: Western art of the early 20th century develops in a single direction, toward abstraction. Artists working toward that goal were the true radicals. Those who held onto representation were aesthetic conservatives (whatever their actual politics).Conveniently enough, the artists who broke most definitively with figuration, and who made abstract painting and sculpture into the One True Art, were living in New York — the city that, in the words of the art historian Serge Guilbaut, “stole the idea of Modern art” from Paris after World War II.

headline: Review: ‘The Peanuts Movie’ Curses the Red Baron in 3 Dimensions
text: “The Peanuts Movie” may be simultaneously the most charming and the most daring experiment in human genetics ever conducted. At issue is whether the character summaries and back stories of fictional pop-culture figures can be passed from one generation to the next solely through DNA.

headline: Review: In ‘Opus,’ the Troupe Circa Melds With the Debussy String Quartet
text: The grimly somber slow movement of Shostakovich’s String Quartet No. 8 might seem an unlikely musical backdrop for a troupe of acrobats. But the 14 members of the Australian ensemble Circa who performed “Opus” on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are more like acrobatic dancers. Or dancing acrobats. Either way, they are amazing.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 6-12
text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Egypt, James Bond, NASA
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Carlo Crivelli, an Overlooked Renaissance Master, in Boston
text: BOSTON — If your admiration for Italian Renaissance painting is more culturally received than deeply felt, “Ornament and Illusion: Carlo Crivelli of Venice” at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum is the show to see. It is the first exhibition in an American museum devoted to Crivelli, a great but neglected Early Renaissance master, and his fabulously fraught panel paintings, with their charged emotional moods, exquisitely detailed and richly appointed settings, gleaming trompe l’oeil jewels and tracts of gold gilt. There are only 26 paintings here, but they form a thrilling, seductive and edifying experience.

headline: Review: Orquesta Buena Vista Social Club Bids Adiós, With Notes of Loss
text: Last year, Orquesta Buena Vista Social Club began one long, final spin around the globe, under the banner of its official “Adiós Tour.” The operative word there is “adiós,” and it carries more than the usual implications of a band bidding its audience farewell. A feeling of departure weighed heavily, often dispiritingly, on the ensemble’s sold-out concert on Wednesday, its second of two nights at the Beacon Theater, and its last scheduled stop in the continental United States.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 6-12
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Oscar Munoz, United’s Chief, to Return in First Quarter
text: United Airlines said on Thursday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, would return sometime in the first quarter after suffering a heart attack last month.

headline: Review: In ‘Fight or Flight,’ Whine, Women and Songwriter
text: Mathieu Amalric can loll on the floor — shirt unbuttoned, feet bare, face stubbly, cigarette smoldering away — and not appear ridiculous. This is a particular gift of the French, and Mr. Amalric, a film actor making his American stage debut with “Fight or Flight (Le Moral des Ménages),” presented by French Institute Alliance Française, has it all wrapped up in a pleasantly scruffy package.

headline: As Refugees Flee, Thousands of Children Have No Country to Call Their Own
text: UNITED NATIONS — Two years old, Yazan al-Najjar is a boy without a country.

headline: Boy, 9, Was Pawn in Gang War, Chicago Police Say
text: A 9-year-old boy who was shot to death in a Chicago alley, in one of the most notorious crimes in the city’s recent history, was the target of the shooting, not a bystander who became an accidental victim, officials said Thursday.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 6-12
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Sand Dollars,’ Unrequited Love in the Dominican Republic
text: A coldhearted prude might be tempted to describe “Sand Dollars,” an empathetic portrait of the relationship between Anne (Geraldine Chaplin), a forlorn older woman of means, and Noelí (Yanet Mojica), a lithe 20-year-old beauty in the Dominican Republic, as a condemnation of sexual tourism. But Ms. Chaplin, in one of her most touching screen performances, imbues Anne with a world-weary melancholy that makes your heart sink. She is in love, despite her better judgment. And her paramour loves her back — a little.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 6-12
text: What if a blue jay could also be a D.J.?

headline: F.D.A. Approves Genvoya, a New One-Pill Treatment for H.I.V.
text: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new one-pill H.I.V. treatment on Thursday with a new, apparently safer form of tenofovir, a powerful H.I.V. inhibitor. The new pill, called Genvoya, from Gilead Sciences , joins several other one-pill treatments, including Atripla, Complera, Triumeq and Stribild. It contains the same four drugs as Stribild, but with the tenofovir disoproxil fumarate replaced by tenofovir alafenamide. The new form of the inhibitor, Gilead said, enters cells where H.I.V. replicates more efficiently, resulting in 91 percent less tenofovir in the bloodstream. That should make the pill less likely to cause kidney damage or loss of bone density, which have become major problems among people with H.I.V. who survive into old age.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 6-12
text: Information on events for possible inclusion in Spare Times should be sent to weekend@nytimes.com by Friday at 5 p.m. for publication that week. Longer versions of Around Town and For Children listings are in a searchable guide at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘Theeb,’ a Bedouin Boy’s Brutal Coming-of-Age
text: If you were a preadolescent boy stranded in the desert with a sinister grown-up stranger on whom you depended for your survival, what would you do? That question, posed in the spellbinding Jordanian adventure film “Theeb,” drives a story set in the farthest reaches of the Ottoman Empire in 1916. The man, who is seriously wounded, and the boy play cat and mouse as they help each other stay alive in a do-or-die struggle.

headline: Review: Bryan Cranston in ‘Trumbo,’ as a Screenwriter in a Hollywood Under Siege
text: In “Trumbo,” an ill-conceived take on one of the most famous targets of the Hollywood blacklist, the writer Dalton Trumbo clenches a cigarette holder that juts in the air like a sword. Given that he’s played by Bryan Cranston (“Breaking Bad”), you have hopes that Trumbo will soon be making like Errol Flynn and dashing and slashing through the movie, giving it verve, excitement. The real Trumbo (1905-1976) was a pistol. A baker-intellectual turned industry insider, he was funny, barbed and wildly prolific, with screen credits that range from “Kitty Foyle” to “Spartacus.” He was also a Communist, which for many made him a traitor, the Devil, no more than a terrorist.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Brooklyn’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Brooklyn.”

headline: Exxon Mobil and the G.O.P.: Fossil Fools
text: Well before one hottest-year-ever was followed by yet another record-breaker, before Arctic ice vanished in real time and Pope Francis made a plea to save our troubled home, the world’s largest private oil company discovered that its chief product could cause global havoc.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Spotlight’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Spotlight.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Spectre’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Spectre.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | Nov. 6, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Spectre,” “Spotlight” and “Brooklyn.”

headline: Chris Christie and Mike Huckabee, in Blow to Their Campaigns, Are Cut From Main Debate Stage
text: When the Republican presidential hopefuls take the stage in Milwaukee on Tuesday night for their fourth debate, familiar faces will be missing from the prime-time lineup — Mike Huckabee and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Review: In ‘The Hallow,’ Evil Lurks in the Irish Woods
text: The title of “The Hallow” refers not to a place, but to the vicious supernatural beings who inhabit a lush Irish forest. Into this initially peaceful paradise come Adam and Claire (Joseph Mawle and Bojana Novakovic) and their new baby, following the money offered to Adam, a tree expert, by a logging company wishing to survey its latest acquisition.

headline: Congress Split on Tapping Fed or Banks to Fund Roads
text: WASHINGTON — The banking industry scored a surprise victory on Thursday when the House voted to pay for part of a new highway bill by draining a rainy-day fund at the Federal Reserve rather than cutting federal payments to some of the nation’s largest banks.

headline: Art and Real Estate Collide at Events in the Bronx and at the Brooklyn Museum
text: A major museum is scheduled to host a real estate conference addressing questions like “Where is the bleeding edge of neighborhood transformation?” and “What opportunities for value-add exist in the seemingly picked-over areas?”

headline: Review: ‘The House That Jack Built,’ a Gritty, Busy Tale of the City
text: Poor Jack (E. J. Bonilla) — so many things on his plate. His drug-dealing business at the corner bodega, which enabled him to buy the building where his family lives, is threatened by rival dealers; the marriage of his brother (Leo Minaya) is in trouble; he wants his sister (Rosal Colón), a lesbian, to stop seeing her girlfriend (and hopes to “cure” her by having a buddy sleep with her); his pregnant girlfriend (Melissa Fumero) won’t stop asking about marriage; and his alcoholic father (John Herrera) keeps bickering with his mother (Saundra Santiago). But we know that Jack is decent, because he beats up a drug addict pimping out his own daughter.

headline: Union for Reform Judaism Adopts Transgender Rights Policy
text: The largest Jewish group in North America adopted a broad transgender rights policy on Thursday, not only stating its own commitment to equality, but also urging synagogues and other Jewish groups to be advocates for transgender rights and to take steps like training their staffs on accommodating transgender people.

headline: Howard Green, Who Found a Way to Grow Skin and Saved Lives, Dies at 90
text: On July 1, 1983, two young brothers and a friend were exploring a derelict house in their Casper, Wyo., neighborhood when they stumbled on several seductive cans of paint in a cupboard. Mischievously, they splashed the paint on the walls and, inevitably, on themselves.

headline: Review: ‘In the Basement,’ What Lies Beneath in Austria
text: Ulrich Seidl’s raw portrayals of ordinary people have been criticized as unflattering and wallowing in abjection. But occasionally, as in his newest, “In the Basement,” the director can make you wonder whether the problem doesn’t lie with his films but with everyone else’s. This often hilarious movie descends into the unseen spaces of Austrian homes — literally and figuratively — and creates a stage for their residents’ fantasies of sex, violence and power.

headline: The Push for Legal Marijuana Spreads
text: Support for making marijuana legal is increasing around the world, and that is a good thing. Earlier this week, the Mexican Supreme Court opened the door to legalizing the drug by giving four plaintiffs the right to grow cannabis for personal use.

headline: Review: In ‘Lost in the Sun,’ a Motherless Teenager Teams Up With a Petty Crook
text: Remove the charm and the Depression-era aura from “Paper Moon” and you have “Lost in the Sun,” a road movie that goes nowhere particularly interesting.

headline: Michael Keaton Discusses ‘Spotlight’
text: The actor Michael Keaton discusses playing the Boston Globe journalist Walter "Robby" Robinson in “Spotlight.”

headline: Melissa Mathison, the Screenwriter Behind a Classic, ‘E.T.,’ Dies at 65
text: Melissa Mathison, who wrote the screenplay for “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,” the science-fiction fable that became one of Hollywood’s signature depictions of the anxieties and longings of childhood and cemented the reputation of Steven Spielberg as a leading director of artful, popular movies, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 65.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Brooklyn Charter School of Failing to Provide Special Education Services
text: Special education students at a Brooklyn charter school did not get mandated services and were punished for behavior that arose from their disabilities, according to a lawsuit filed in federal court on Thursday.

headline: ‘Graphic Appeal’ Explores Image Transfers at Heckscher Museum of Art
text: Some are serene landscapes. Others are vibrant abstracts. A few, like a whimsical depiction of flying slices of pizza, are mischievous illustrations. The works in “Graphic Appeal: Modern Prints From the Collection” at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington cover a range of subjects and styles, but they have one thing in common: They were made by transferring an image from one medium to another, usually from a block, a plate or a screen to a sheet of paper.

headline: Former Manhattan Prosecutor Avoids Jail in Assault on Woman in Bar
text: A former prosecutor in the Manhattan district attorney’s office who was found guilty of assaulting a woman at a bar avoided jail when a judge ordered him on Thursday to perform 10 days of community service and to complete counseling for alcohol abuse.

headline: News Corp., Time Inc. and Tribune All Report Flat or Falling Quarterly Revenue
text: When News Corporation, Time Inc. and Tribune Publishing were spun out of their respective corporate parents in recent years, it was said to be as much for the sake of the media companies themselves as for the bottom lines of the more lucrative businesses they left behind.

headline: Connecticut School Seeks to Expel 2 Accused of Wearing Columbine Costumes
text: LITCHFIELD, Conn. — Questions about when a menacing costume verges on a criminal threat swirled around this rural town after two high school sophomores were arrested and accused this week of dressing as the Columbine killers for Halloween and threatening to hurt other students.

headline: Spain’s News Media Are Squeezed by Government and Debt
text: MADRID — Newspapers almost everywhere have struggled to adjust to digital technology and declining advertising revenues.

headline: Restaurant Review: Mokomiya, a Ramen Shop in White Plains
text: At Mokomiya, staff members call out in unison when you walk through the door: “Irasshaimase” (“Welcome,” in Japanese). Japanese-language newspapers sit in a pile at the entrance; Japanese is spoken at many of the tables.

headline: In Rio, Pacification Without Peace
text: In Complexo do Alemão, one of Rio de Janeiro’s largest favelas, surging violence has claimed the lives of children and police officers, calling into question the government’s police pacification strategy.

headline: ‘Bond, James Bond,’ Through the Years
text: There have been bumps in the road — moguls on the slopes — but yes, the Bond franchise has lived on, lucratively and babe-lusciously, for more than a half-century. Here’s what critics of The New York Times had to say about the films starring 007 No. 1, Sean Connery. Bosley Crowther picked up the pen for the first five.

headline: Legislators Could Upend Finance Laws in Wisconsin
text: CHICAGO — For months, it was the biggest political story in Wisconsin: a secret criminal investigation into whether Gov. Scott Walker’s campaign in a 2012 recall election had illegally coordinated fund-raising and spending with several conservative groups. But in July, the state’s conservative-leaning Supreme Court ordered the investigation ended, ruling that state campaign finance law included unconstitutionally vague language.

headline: Witness in Sheldon Silver Trial Reveals Greed Masquerading as Altruism
text: “Not that I am aware of,” said Victor Franco, a legislative budget director, unhappily summoned as a witness in the federal corruption trial of Sheldon Silver, the former speaker of the New York State Assembly.

headline: Authorities Assess Toll of Burst Dam in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A dam from an open-pit mining complex burst on Thursday in southeastern Brazil, flooding a nearby community and enveloping homes and cars in sludge. Rescue teams descending from helicopters scoured the site for survivors.

headline: Macquarie Sets Up Brazil Infrastructure Fund
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, has raised over 600 million reais, or $159 million, from Brazilian investors and is nearing a first close for its debut Brazil infrastructure fund, according to a person briefed on the bank’s plans.

headline: A Cell Therapy Untested in Humans Saves a Baby With Cancer
text: A baby girl who was close to dying from cancer has been rescued by a cell therapy envisioned as a “one size fits all” treatment that had never been tested in people, doctors reported on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘The Nightingale,’ the Beauties of Rural China
text: The virtues of understatement and restraint are vividly apparent in Philippe Muyl’s “The Nightingale,” a gentle tale that could easily lapse into mawkish sentiment but largely steers clear of doing so.

headline: Nationals Keep Making Errors but Stumble Into a Winner in Dusty Baker
text: WASHINGTON — With great fanfare and no small amount of trepidation, the Washington Nationals, a laughingstock for the last few days, finally introduced a new manager on Thursday: the affable Dusty Baker.

headline: George Barris, California King of Customized Cars, Dies at 89
text: George Barris, one of the pioneer car customizers immortalized in Tom Wolfe’s essay “The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby” and the designer of the Batmobile, the Munster Koach and other specialty cars for television and film, died on Thursday at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 89.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Genvoya, One-Pill Treatment for H.I.V.
text: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new one-pill H.I.V. treatment on Thursday with a new, apparently safer form of tenofovir, a powerful H.I.V. inhibitor. The pill, called Genvoya, from Gilead Sciences, joins other one-pill treatments like Atripla, Complera, Triumeq and Stribild. The new form of the inhibitor, Gilead said, more efficiently enters cells where H.I.V. replicates, resulting in 91 percent less tenofovir in the bloodstream. That should make the pill less likely to cause kidney damage or loss of bone density, which have become major problems among people with H.I.V. who survive into old age.

headline: Restaurant Review: Abril Cocina in Maplewood
text: Rancho La Puerta, a spa nestled in a valley near Mount Kuchumaa in Mexico, just south of the border, seems like paradise for many Americans. It does to me as well, mostly because of the meals it serves. The handmade tortillas, fresh-roasted corn, sauces and salsas are the kind of light, rarefied Mexican fusion food that is scarce in the New York area.

headline: Chief Executive of United Will Return Early Next Year
text: United Airlines said on Thursday that its president and chief executive, Oscar Munoz, would return in the first quarter after suffering a heart attack last month. Four days after Mr. Munoz was hospitalized, United named its general counsel, Brett J. Hart, as acting chief. At the time, United provided no information about when Mr. Munoz might return. Mr. Munoz was appointed in September after United dismissed its previous chief, Jeff Smisek, during a corruption investigation into the airline’s trading favors with the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Festive Eggplant Rolls
text: If you’re looking to wow your crowd this Thanksgiving, consider these festive eggplant rolls. Courtesy of reader Christine Vartanian Datian of Las Vegas, these decadent rolls of Japanese eggplant strips, ricotta and walnuts are colorful and tasty, with an added crunch.

headline: Why Health Care Start-Ups Like Theranos Need Investing Expertise
text: The Silicon Valley start-ups that often grab headlines are typically in the Internet and consumer technology world. But there’s another part of start-up land that is also highly active: health-related technology, which includes biotech, health care services and medical devices.

headline: A Centennial Celebration for Brooklyn’s Only Saint
text: Brooklyn has just one saint, and his name is Raphael Hawaweeny.

headline: Review: ‘Of Men and War’ Chronicles the Trauma of Combat Veterans
text: “Of Men and War” opens with a quotation from Erich Maria Remarque’s 1929 novel, “All Quiet on the Western Front,” but there’s no quiet to be had for any of its damaged subjects. Filmed almost entirely inside the Pathway Home in California, a residential therapy center for veterans, this devastatingly raw documentary shows that for some the fighting may stop, but the suffering continues.

headline: Restaurant Review: Bin 300 World Bistro Serves Italian Fare in Wolcott
text: In the dark, earthen tones of its ocher walls and faux-brick paneling, Bin 300 World Bistro in Wolcott exudes something of the ambience of Amsterdam’s famous brown cafes. That is no easy feat, as structurally the space for the restaurant, which opened in 2007, still bears traces of its earlier inhabitant, an A & W Drive-In.

headline: Review: In ‘Palio,’ Sights and Sounds of This Sienese Horse Race
text: Chariots don’t careen around the Colosseum anymore, but the Italian city of Siena still holds a competition from the Middle Ages that evokes a gladiatorial spirit. The Palio, a horse race first recorded in 1238, is a Tuscan feast of civic pride, medieval pageantry and Machiavellian strategies.

headline: First President George Bush Swings at Son’s Aides, Rattling Clan
text: WASHINGTON — Former President George Bush’s unusually sharp indictment of his son’s presidential advisers touched off a round of recriminations on Thursday that exposed rifts within America’s leading political dynasty and complicated its efforts to recapture the White House.

headline: Using Only Local Talent, Athletic Bilbao Goes a Long Way
text: BILBAO, Spain — The buzzword at the best soccer clubs in Europe these days is global, as in global brand or global footprint or global reach. Bayern Munich wants to be known in Asia and Australia. Barcelona wants to be known in the Middle East. Everyone wants to be known in Africa and the United States.

headline: Time Inc.’s Record of the 20th Century, in Thousands of Boxes, Is Moving
text: America’s attic is moving uptown.

headline: A Peek Inside the Boxes
text: Time Inc. has donated its company archive to the New-York Historical Society. Among the 7,500 linear feet of files are these intriguing objects.

headline: Canada: Interim Chief for Conservatives
text: Following its election defeat last month and the resignation of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, the caucus of the Conservative Party of Canada elected Rona Ambrose, 46, of Alberta, as its interim leader on Thursday. Ms. Ambrose, who was first elected to Parliament in 2004, has been the minister of eight departments, including the department responsible for environmental matters. She is widely seen as less partisan than many of her Conservative colleagues. Under the party rules, Ms. Ambrose will not be able to run in the coming party race to select a permanent replacement for Mr. Harper. But as leader of the opposition, she will get a pay raise as well as an official residence. Mr. Harper will continue to represent his Calgary, Alberta, constituency as a member of Parliament.

headline: Review: ‘Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addict,’ Portrait of an Heiress With a Cause
text: “Peggy Guggenheim: Art Addict,” Lisa Immordino Vreeland’s sleek, entertaining portrait of the collector and gallerist who assembled one of the great troves of Modern art, cannot be accused of hagiography. From curators to historians to biographers, art world denizens describe Guggenheim’s flaws and failings: She had no formal training; she used art to promote herself; she was a narcissist. And that’s just in the first five minutes.

headline: Battling Depression, and Getting a Clearer View of His Future
text: It was shortly after he found his brother’s body inside the small apartment they shared in New Rochelle, N.Y., that depression, so severe it had already made him give up on school and his job, made William Medonis want to give up on his own life.

headline: Review: ‘Sembène!,’ a Documentary About the Senegalese Auteur
text: The film focuses on the life and legacy of the director Ousmane Sembène, who showed a fearlessness in a country with no cinematic tradition.

headline: Review: ‘On Your Feet!’ Rides the Rhythm of the Estefans
text: The recipe may be familiar, but the flavor is fresh in “On Your Feet!,” the half-formulaic, half-original and undeniably crowd-pleasing musical about the lives of Emilio and Gloria Estefan that opened on Thursday at the Marquis Theater.

headline: Something to Stand On
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s Friday, and I’M UP FOR WHATEVER, how about you?

headline: New York Fed Chief Calls for Improved Wall Street Culture
text: A prominent Wall Street regulator on Thursday continued to press senior bankers to clean up the culture of their firms so that they can avoid the sort of recent scandals that have undermined the reputations of big banks.

headline: Inmates Slash Rikers Guard Several Times
text: A correction officer was held down and slashed several times in an attack by several inmates at the Rikers Island jail complex on Thursday, officials said.

headline: Review: ‘What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy’
text: “Imagine what it must be like to grow up as the child of a mass murderer.”

headline: Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, Poland’s Last Communist Prime Minister, Dies at 90
text: Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, who helped crush the Solidarity movement in Poland in 1981 and eight years later presided briefly over the country’s transition to democracy as its last Communist prime minister, died on Thursday in Warsaw. He was 90.

headline: Robert P. DeVecchi, Who Led International Rescue Committee, Dies at 85
text: Robert P. DeVecchi, who helped resettle dispossessed people around the world as director, president and, ultimately, chief executive of the International Rescue Committee, died on Oct. 26 at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 85.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | collaborate
text: collaborate • \kə-ˈla-bə-ˌrat\ • verb

headline: Toyota Invests $1 Billion in Artificial Intelligence in U.S.
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Silicon Valley is diving into artificial intelligence technology, with start-ups sprouting up and Google and Facebook pouring vast sums into projects that would teach machines how to learn and make decisions. Now Toyota wants a piece of the action.

headline: New York’s Week in Pictures: Nov. 6
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: A Fast Lane for Pedestrians? A City Dweller’s Dream
text: A popular British retailer said it would designate a strip of sidewalk in front of its Liverpool store specifically for fast walkers, that uniquely urban breed of pedestrians who silently fume over the ambling gaits of those in front of them.

headline: What to Watch on Friday
text: At last, Friday has arrived! Viewers with limited steam can veg out to knife-wielding munchkins on “MasterChef Junior” or to a contender for the year’s best comedy. Brain cells still intact? Rachel Maddow interviews Democratic candidates; the nation’s 41st president gives up some secrets; and Quentin Tarantino explains his comment about the police.

headline: Austerity’s Grim Legacy
text: When economic crisis struck in 2008, policy makers by and large did the right thing. The Federal Reserve and other central banks realized that supporting the financial system took priority over conventional notions of monetary prudence. The Obama administration and its counterparts realized that in a slumping economy budget deficits were helpful, not harmful. And the money-printing and borrowing worked: A repeat of the Great Depression, which seemed all too possible at the time, was avoided.

headline: In Iran, a Deal and Then a Crackdown
text: The anti-American backlash in Iran since the nuclear deal was signed has gotten so bad that one Iranian-American businessman in Tehran now likens it to a witch hunt. As alarming as that is, the crackdown will probably get worse.

headline: In the Dry West, Waiting for Congress
text: Klamath Falls, Ore. — DROUGHT in the West is an ugly thing. Rivers trickle away to nothing, fires rage, crops fail, ranchers go broke, tribal people watch fish die. As Westerners fight over the little water left, tempers crack, lawsuits fly and bitterness coats whole communities like fine dust.

headline: Great News! We’re Not Doomed to Soaring Health Care Costs

headline: Back to the Future, Please, Candidates
text: To run for president this year, it’s not enough to be a neurosurgeon, a senator or a former secretary of state. One must be a neurosurgeon who chased his mother with a hammer as a child; a senator whose father was beaten toothless in prison and fled Cuba with $100 sewn into his underwear; or a former secretary of state whose mother went without food as a first grader.

headline: When Neighbors Tangle Online
text: Complaining about the co-op or condominium board is practically a blood sport in New York, an unfortunate side effect of living under the rule of elected volunteers. Usually, disputes go no further than a heated exchange at the annual meeting. Much like a family feud, the dirty laundry is rarely aired in public. But thanks to the Internet, that is changing.

headline: Driving Alaska’s Dalton Highway
text: On the Dalton Highway, most conversations concern the Dalton Highway. Though there aren’t many people on the road, they inevitably talk about the road. My first conversation, during a three-day drive along the isolated freeway in Alaska, was with a man named Steven Duffy who was working as a waiter at the Yukon River Camp, a lonesome rest stop marooned among the spruce trees four hours north of Fairbanks.

headline: Review: Finding Beauty in a Wrenching ‘Lulu’ at the Met
text: The South African artist William Kentridge is now two for two at the Metropolitan Opera. In 2010, in a momentous company debut, he directed a dazzling, frenetic production of Shostakovich’s wildly satirical opera “The Nose,” based on a Gogol short story. The staging, which involved inventive projections and animated drawings by Mr. Kentridge, was not just the talk of the opera world. It made the Met the center of the New York contemporary art scene for the duration of the run.

headline: The 10.25.15 Issue
text: RE: ANNA STUBBLEFIELD

headline: Sex, Death and Mushrooms
text: The forest air is sweet and winy with decay. It’s raining hard. I wipe drops of cold water from the tip of my nose, open an umbrella and ready myself for a walk with my old friend Nick, emeritus professor of the history of science and amateur mycologist. For the last 15 years I’ve accompanied him on autumn mushroom hunts; today we’re visiting Thetford Forest, in Suffolk. Both of us carry trugs, traditional English wooden baskets of willow and sweet chestnut, to hold what we will find. Perhaps tiny fungi with hairlike stalks, or lumpy shelves on the trunks of rotting trees, or pale masses like discarded round pillows, or splayed red starfish arms emerging from the ground.

headline: A Long Engagement
text: I first learned of my would-be betrothal to a man named Stephen in 1993, when I was 21. My parents had just returned to the States from a trip to the territory of my mother’s people, the Karen; their home is the country I will always call Burma, though it had been renamed Myanmar by its military-backed government. A 29-year-old soldier engaged in resistance against the junta, this Karen man was also a self-taught programmer and engineer — and he appeared to have dazzled my parents. ‘‘I promised you in marriage to him,’’ my mother informed me, only half in jest.

headline: How to Make a Time Capsule
text: ‘‘Be anti-tech when it comes to what you put inside,’’ says William E. Jarvis, a founder of the International Time Capsule Society. You don’t want your message to the future formatted irretrievably on an obsolete technology like a floppy disk. Include stable items that will not damage everything else by corroding (electronics), exploding (beer bottles) or decomposing (flora and fauna). Put in objects that show evidence of human touch. ‘‘Suppose you wanted to include a book of erotica,’’ Jarvis says. ‘‘Make it a used one, so that the person who finds it can tell which pages have been thumbed more.’’

headline: ‘My Life’
text: The subtlest changes in syntax can work in a poem to evoke a feeling of strangeness. Here, the inversion in the first line places the emphasis not on the sentence’s noun, the “I,” but on the comparison to the biblical story. And the alliteration and cadences of the lines evoke the actual feeling of tumbling — “How heel over head was I hurled down.” That inversion of heel and head enlivens a common phrase, making the poem an experience in language.

headline: Gary Danielson of CBS on L.S.U.-Alabama and Going Pro Early
text: When Gary Danielson joined CBS and began covering Southeastern Conference football in 2006, SEC teams had won four national championships in the previous 20 years. But it’s self-selecting. The people who come tend to be interested in art. It can bring out some quirkiness.”
