headline: The Crispr Quandary
text: One day in March 2011, Emmanuelle Charpentier, a geneticist who was studying flesh-eating bacteria, approached Jennifer Doudna, an award-winning scientist, at a microbiology conference in Puerto Rico. Charpentier, a more junior researcher, hoped to persuade Doudna, the head of a formidably large lab at the University of California, Berkeley, to collaborate. While walking the cobblestone streets of Old San Juan, the two women fell to talking. Charpentier had recently grown interested in a particular gene, known as Crispr, that seemed to help flesh-eating bacteria fight off invasive viruses. By understanding that gene, as well as the protein that enabled it, called Cas9, Charpentier hoped to find a way to cure patients infected with the bacteria by stripping it of its protective immune system.

headline: World Anti-Doping Agency Report on Russian Doping Program
text: The report described a pervasive doping culture among Russia’s sports programs and implicated athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors and various Russian institutions.

headline: 1965: Pacifist Sets Fire to Himself
text: NEW YORK — A young student who once tried to become a Trappist monk set himself on fire in front of the United Nations here today [Nov. 9] screaming that he was against all wars. Police said Roger Laporte, 22, identified as a student and part-time volunteer for the Catholic Worker Movement, a pacifist organization, was in critical condition in Bellevue Hospital with burns over his entire body. Last rites were administered after Mr. Laporte expressed repentance over his violation of the Roman Catholic Church’s strict religious credo against suicide. It was the second incident of its kind in a week. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 10, 1965

headline: In Ancient Times, Salamanders Bared Their Fangs
text: Researchers have discovered amphibian fossils in northeastern Brazil that date back 278 million years, to the time of the supercontinent Pangaea. Until now, little was known about animal life in the southern tropical regions of the continent.

headline: Unesco Rejects Kosovo Membership in a Victory for Serbia
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — Unesco, the United Nations’ cultural agency, narrowly denied Kosovo membership on Monday, handing a sizable political victory to Serbia, which had fought a fierce battle against the bid for months.

headline: The True Heart of French Seaside Chic
text: Let the partiers keep the Riviera. Just a few hundred miles to the west sits the alluring little island of Île de Ré, and its unspoiled pastures and vineyards.

headline: A.D.H.D. Rates Rise Around Globe, but Sympathy Often Lags
text: Last year, Sinan Sonmezler of Istanbul refused to keep going to school. His eighth-grade classmates called him “weird” and “stupid,” and his teachers rebuked him for his tendency to stare out the window during class. The school director told his parents he was “lazy.”

headline: Lapsing Faculties
text: This week’s puzzle is an original suggested by Marc Roth, a math teacher at the Woodside Learning Center and presenter at Math Circles in the San Francisco Bay Area. Let’s try —

headline: Locking in Votes and Doling Out ‘Dogs’: How Roberts Assigns Opinions
text: WASHINGTON — When the chief justice is in the majority, he gets to decide who will write the Supreme Court’s opinion. This is, Justice Felix Frankfurter once wrote, “perhaps the most delicate judgment demanded of the chief justice.”

headline: Animals Rely on Hair to Keep Clean, Study Finds
text: The honeybee and the squirrel have the same number of hairs: about three million. A moth has 10 billion hairs, while the human head has only 100,000.

headline: Gansevoort Street, With Up-and-Down History, Could Grow Taller Again
text: Despite what you might have heard, the cobblestones of the meatpacking district still run red. But now it is with flecks of beef tartare and hibiscus cocktails, the crimson soles of Louboutins and what looks like a blob of plasma but is actually red paint from one of the half-dozen artists’ stalls that followed the Whitney Museum downtown.

headline: The Gold Bug Bites Texas Politicians
text: Fantasies of secession danced like tumbleweed when Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas signed an odd new law in June authorizing the state to be the first in the nation to create its own gold bullion depository. The goal, Mr. Abbott’s office announced, is to “repatriate $1 billion in gold bullion from the Federal Reserve in New York.” That’s repatriate, as in moving 6,643 gold bars from one country to another.

headline: When to Ignore a Promise to ‘Never Put Me in a Home’
text: Our new patient, 88 years old, had been demented for years. She was admitted to the hospital with a deep, malodorous and infected pressure sore stretching from the top of her right shoulder down to the middle of her spine.

headline: Human Trafficking at Sea: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Sometimes even open secrets are worth exploring. During the year I spent reporting on lawlessness at sea, many sources mentioned so-called manning agencies that trick seafarers into working on the world’s ships, especially fishing vessels.

headline: American Prisoner in Yemen Said to Face Death Sentence
text: CAIRO — Lawyers for an American held prisoner in Yemen’s capital said that their client could be sentenced to death on murder charges at his next hearing scheduled for Wednesday, despite the difficulty of conducting a trial during Yemen’s civil war.

headline: With a Mobile Website Like an App, Flipkart Takes a Swipe at Apple
text: India’s e-commerce start-up Flipkart has worked with Google to make a new mobile website that could eliminate the need for apps, in a move that takes a swipe at Apple’s grip on the mobile experience.

headline: Weyerhaeuser’s Big Acquisition Looks Good on Paper
text: Weyerhaeuser’s new $23 billion woodland monster looks good on paper. Weyerhaeuser, the forestry giant, is paying a 14 percent premium for a $7 billion rival, Plum Creek Timber. That’s modest but fair, given the expected cost savings and a planned $2.5 billion stock buyback for both sets of shareholders.

headline: One Paris Boutique Takes Inspiration From the Catskills
text: For several years, Sarah Andelman, the founder and creative director of the cult Paris boutique Colette, has been a regular visitor to the Catskills, where she and her family have owned a house for the past decade. In 2011, she got married in Woodstock, and she now spends many of her holidays and summers in the region. “I think I feel a little guilty spending so much time upstate,” she recently told T in an email from the house, where she and her family had come from Paris to celebrate Halloween.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Police Officer Who Shot Man in Car Chase
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled for a police officer who shot and killed a fleeing suspect from a highway overpass. The court’s decision was unsigned and issued without full briefing and oral argument, an indication that the majority found the case to be easy.

headline: Fecal Transplants Made (Somewhat) More Palatable
text: Two years ago, Catherine Duff, then 57, tearfully described eight debilitating bouts of antibiotic-resistant Clostridium difficile infection to a government panel in Washington. She grew better, she said, only after treating the gastrointestinal infection at home with her husband’s feces, a blender and an enema bag.

headline: As Golf Returns to the Olympics, a Brazilian Golfer Hopes to Return to Rio, Too
text: Candy Hannemann had been sidelined from the L.P.G.A. Tour for several years because of wrist operations when she learned that golf would return to the 2016 Olympic Games.

headline: Obama and Netanyahu Seek to Move Past Rift Over Iran Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel sought on Monday to move beyond their bitter rupture over the Iran nuclear deal, turning the page on a season of poisonous relations during a White House meeting that focused on collaboration over acrimony.

headline: Review: In ‘tiger tiger,’ a Quest for Answers in a Mauling
text: Jessica Almasy’s “tiger tiger (on the nature of violence)” at Dixon Place burns loudly and hotly, though not especially brightly. Based glancingly on a Christmas Day mauling at the San Francisco Zoo in 2007 that left a teenager dead, at first it seems to be about the need to assign meaning to catastrophe. Then it doesn’t seem to be about much of anything at all.

headline: Trial of Vincent Asaro Highlights Loss of Mafia’s Code of Silence
text: After he had helped pull off one of the biggest cash robberies in American history — the Lufthansa heist of 1978 — and stashed millions of dollars, along with burlap sacks of gold chains, crates of watches, and diamonds and emeralds, in his cousin’s basement, Vincent Asaro thought first about the code: Protect the family.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C. Hires Patrick Vieira as Coach
text: New York City F.C. named the French World Cup winner Patrick Vieira as its coach Monday, plucking him from a developmental role with its parent club, Manchester City, to try to improve on a disappointing first season in Major League Soccer.

headline: Campbell Rethinks Its Soup Recipe as Consumer Tastes Change
text: CAMDEN, N.J. — Food companies tinker with the signature products in their portfolios at their own risk — and few products are as classic as Campbell’s chicken noodle soup.

headline: Placing a Cap on Americans’ Consumption of Added Sugar
text: Health experts have been nudging Americans to kick the sugar habit for years, and now it’s official: The Food and Drug Administration is recommending a daily cap on sugar for the first time.

headline: Can a Trip Ever Be ‘Authentic’?
text: In a globalized age — when a McAloo Tikki is just as Indian as the Taj Mahal — has the very word lost its meaning?

headline: VW Looks at Cost Cuts and Offers Money to Diesel Car Owners
text: Volkswagen said on Monday that it would begin talks with worker representatives about how to cut costs, in the latest sign that the company’s crisis over cheating on emissions tests is taking a heavy toll.

headline: Ben Carson Moves Into a Tie With Donald Trump in South Carolina Poll
text: Ben Carson’s surge in the polls has made its way to South Carolina, where a new poll from Monmouth University shows him deadlocked with Donald J. Trump as the leading Republican presidential candidate in the state.

headline: University of Missouri President Resigns
text: Timothy M. Wolfe announced on Monday his resignation as the president of the University of Missouri, after months of student and faculty protests over racial tensions.

headline: 3 Things to Know About the Sprint Blood Pressure Trial
text: New data from a major study called Sprint, released Monday, has shaken some of the basic assumptions about the treatment of high blood pressure. The trial found that lowering systolic blood pressure from currently recommended levels of 140 to 150 to below 120 could prevent heart attacks and strokes and potentially save many lives.

headline: New Treatment Slows an Epidemic of Sleeping Sickness
text: Cases of human sleeping sickness have fallen greatly in parts of rural Uganda where cattle were given an experimental dual treatment that killed both the parasites that cause the disease and the flies that carry them, researchers in Scotland said Monday.

headline: Kath Mainland Stepping Down as Head of Edinburgh Fringe
text: With her short hair, multiple ear piercings and penchant for wearing a leather jacket, Kath Mainland gives off an aura of hipness that has long seemed appropriate for her role in helping to oversee the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the enormous arts festival that pops up annually in the Scottish capital and includes a lot of scrappy productions. But after seven years as chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society, the organizational force behind the event, Ms. Mainland is leaving. Beginning in February she will take over as executive director of the Melbourne Festival.

headline: Data on Benefits of Lower Blood Pressure Brings Clarity for Doctors and Patients
text: When the federal government announced in September that it had abruptly halted a large blood pressure study because its results were so compelling, doctors were left in frustrating limbo.

headline: Truth and Lies: The Orwellian World of Politics

headline: Killer Whales to Take Final Bows at SeaWorld San Diego
text: SeaWorld said on Monday that it planned to phase out next year its San Diego killer whale performance, a central point for criticism of how its animals are treated.

headline: Astronauts Needed: NASA Wants to Make Mars Your Corner Office
text: Many childhood dreams come to nothing, but here is a chance to make one come true: For the first time in four years, NASA is looking for more astronauts.

headline: Obama Starts Personal Facebook Page
text: The leader of the free world now has a personal Facebook page, and more than 45,000 people clicked “like” on it in the first hour it was live on Monday.

headline: Catalan Legislators Raise Stakes in Push for Secession From Spain
text: BARCELONA — Catalan separatist lawmakers intensified their standoff with Spain’s central government in Madrid on Monday, approving a resolution that lays out a path for the region to “disconnect” from the rest of Spain by creating its own institutions, including a separate Catalan tax agency and social security system.

headline: Cuban Peers Dispute Ted Cruz’s Father’s Story of Fighting for Castro
text: MATANZAS, Cuba — Since he was a boy, Senator Ted Cruz has said, all he wanted to do was “fight for liberty” — a yearning that he says was first kindled when he heard his father’s tales of fighting as a rebel leader in Cuba in the 1950s, throwing firebombs, running guns and surviving torture.

headline: Wood You Can Wear
text: Hand-carved jewelry — with gold, diamonds and gemstones — makes a statement while maintaining a natural delicacy.

headline: Afghan Fighters Loyal to ISIS Beheaded 7 Hostages, Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan militants claiming loyalty to the Islamic State were found to have beheaded seven ethnic Hazara civilians who had been abducted in the southern Afghan province of Zabul, officials said on Monday, as infighting among Taliban splinter factions intensified.

headline: Delayed Opening for Mamet’s ‘China Doll’
text: The producers of “China Doll,” a new play written by David Mamet and starring Al Pacino, said on Monday that the play requires more work than they had expected and so they are delaying the official opening by two weeks.

headline: Judge Deals a Blow to N.S.A. Data Collection Program
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday partly blocked the National Security Agency’s program that systematically collects Americans’ domestic phone records in bulk just weeks before the agency was scheduled to shut it down and replace it. The judge said the program was most likely unconstitutional.

headline: Starbucks’s Red Holiday Cups Inspire Outcry Online
text: For some reason, Starbucks keeps trying to coax its customers to share a bit more over their coffee cups.

headline: Target Keeps Thanksgiving Opening at 6 p.m. on the Holiday

headline: Chris Stapleton Rides C.M.A.’s to a Big Week on the Album Chart

headline: Canadian Pacific Said to Weigh Deal for Norfolk Southern
text: If at first Canadian Pacific could not succeed in buying a fellow railroad operator, it looks prepared to try again with another target.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Stuffing Muffins
text: Stuffing is a traditional Thanksgiving accompaniment to the turkey, but turning stuffing into muffins helps it hold its own on the holiday table — with or without the bird.

headline: Review: Donny Deutsch’s ‘Donny!,’ a Crass, Infuriating Talk Show Host
text: Don’t watch “Donny!” because it might make you laugh. Then you’ll hate yourself for liking a sitcom that stars an advertising executive, and a moderately annoying one at that.

headline: Bond Giant Pimco Calls Gross’s Lawsuit ‘Legally Groundless’
text: Pimco, the bond investment giant, responded on Monday to a $200 million lawsuit filed by its former star portfolio manager, William H. Gross, by asking that his claim be dismissed as “legally groundless.”

headline: Russian Artist Sets Security Service’s Door on Fire
text: MOSCOW — The artist’s brush was a cigarette lighter, his paint a can of gasoline and the canvas, as it has always been for Pyotr Pavlensky, a symbol of the Russian state.

headline: 1890: The Electric Chair, ‘Far Worse Than Hanging’
text: It was supposed to be a humane alternative to the noose. On March 22, 1890, The Times reported on a New York Court of Appeals ruling that a new invention, the electric chair, did not constitute cruel punishment. It would be used to execute a convicted wife killer, William Kemmler.

headline: Ackman Defends Fund’s Valeant Losses and Digs at ‘Snide Comments’
text: The billionaire investor William A. Ackman, whose firm is among the worst-performing hedge funds this year, used an investor conference call on Monday to take a swipe at the media and those on Wall Street who he said relished “betting against” him.

headline: Artificial Patients, Real Learning
text: BOSTON — The patient’s blood pressure had reportedly crashed in the ambulance; a gunshot wound had damaged the heart. In the operating room, a medical resident, Dr. Dan Hashimoto, slid a knife into the patient’s chest and sliced horizontally, from the sternum across the torso.

headline: Hollywood in the Operating Room
text: Surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital have four minutes to save this gunshot wound victim. So how do residents learn such a risky procedure? With a little help from Hollywood.

headline: Deal Talks Start Early, but Mets’ Sandy Alderson Will Miss Meetings

headline: With a Presidential Boost, ‘Hamilton’ Tops Broadway Box Office

text: After the resignation of President Timothy M. Wolfe, students and faculty agreed that a new approach is needed to combat the rising number of racist incidents at the University of Missouri.

headline: Review: In ‘Hotels of North America,’ Rick Moody Examines the Middle-Aged Male in Free Fall
text: One drawback of American journalism is that newspapers and magazines don’t have hotel critics. Into this cultural void steps Reginald Edward Morse, the hero of Rick Moody’s new novel, “Hotels of North America.”

text: Myanmar and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Prosecution Witness in Lufthansa Trial Is Scrutinized in Closing Arguments
text: It was not so much Vincent Asaro but his cousin Gaspare Valenti, the key prosecution witness against him, who was under scrutiny as closing arguments in Mr. Asaro’s trial on racketeering charges concluded on Monday.

headline: Breakthrough Prize Looks to Stars to Shine on Science
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Movie stars. Red carpet. Awards.

text: Photos from Myanmar, Brazil, the United States and Germany.

headline: Facts & Figures: Where People Worry About Climate Change
text: Americans are less likely than people in Latin America and Sub-Saharan Africa to believe climate change is a very serious problem, according to a recent Pew report. Forty-five percent of people in the United States see climate change as very serious, compared with 86 percent in Brazil and 79 percent in Burkina Faso.

headline: A Vagabond Teahouse Pours Camaraderie, One Free Cup at a Time
text: Giuseppe Spadafora opened a side door of his white Ford bus, spread a light blue carpet on a sidewalk near McCarren Park in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and placed a small wooden sandwich board next to it reading “Free Tea.”

headline: Chloë Sevigny’s Wild Gucci Dress
text: The Star: Chloë Sevigny

headline: Review: In ‘Ballet (New York),’ Nondancers Try Their Jetés
text: Commissioned by Performa 15 and choreographed by Jérôme Bel, the show was cast with 13 New Yorkers of various ages and backgrounds.

headline: Donald Trump’s Not-So-Fond Farewell on ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: Donald Trump’s appearance on “Saturday Night Live” last weekend was memorable for a few things, none having much to do with his comedic skills.

headline: Review: ‘Dead and Breathing,’ About the Right to Die
text: Carolyn Whitlock, the long-ailing woman at the center of Chisa Hutchinson’s play “Dead and Breathing,” at the National Black Theater, has wealth in abundance. What’s lacking is the ease she expects it to bring her.

headline: Egypt Extends Detention of a Journalist, Hossam Bahgat
text: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Egyptian military prosecutors on Monday extended the detention of Hossam Bahgat, an investigative journalist and the founder of Egypt’s leading human rights organization, in a sign that the government is moving to bring him to trial on charges of publishing false news harmful to national security.

headline: Verbatim: Would Jeb Bush Kill Baby Hitler? ‘Hell Yeah.’
text: — Jeb Bush, in an interview with The Huffington Post, on whether he would kill a baby Hitler if he could go back in time. The question was inspired by a New York Times Magazine survey.

headline: ISIS Ally in Egypt Emerges as Key Suspect in Russian Jet Crash
text: CAIRO — Within months of the military takeover here two years ago, a little-known group calling itself Ansar Beit al-Maqdis managed to penetrate rings of checkpoints and heavy security to carry out a string of startling attacks, assassinating a senior police official at his home near here and blowing up a security headquarters here and in Mansoura, Egypt.

headline: Hannah Rothschild Adds Novelist to Her Résumé
text: LONDON — There wasn’t a minion in sight at the Rothschild offices here, and Hannah Rothschild — author, filmmaker, chairwoman of the National Gallery — was looking dubiously at the coffee-making apparatus on a table in a small boardroom. “I think this machine works,” she said.

headline: Lindsey Graham to Make His Voice Heard During Debate, on Social Media
text: With poll numbers that barely register, Senator Lindsey Graham will not be participating in either of Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debates, leaving the stages without the witty wisecracks that have become one of his claims to fame.

headline: An Artful Homage to Roller Disco
text: When Hauser & Wirth moved into its Dieter Roth-designed West 18th Street space two years ago, the gallery inherited an unexpected treasure trove: hundreds of roller skates left over from the former tenant, the famous Roxy roller disco. With the opening of Mark Bradford’s new exhibition, “Be Strong Boquan,” this past weekend, the history of the building comes back to life. Immediately upon entering the show, visitors encounter “Deimos,” a video installation depicting dozens of the little orange wheels from the Roxy’s skates, spinning from one end of the frame to the other. T premieres the video exclusively here (in the gallery, it’s displayed across three screens on one very long wall).

headline: Hillary Clinton on Familiar Ground in Registering for the New Hampshire Primary
text: CONCORD, N.H. — For the fourth time in her career — as a political spouse and as a presidential candidate — Hillary Rodham Clinton made her way into the crowded and crusty office of New Hampshire’s secretary of state as the Clinton surname was placed on the ballot for the state’s primary, the first in the nation.

headline: Gov. Christie Doesn’t Want Your Vote
text: New Jersey’s voter-turnout rate is among the lowest in the country. During the 2014 midterm elections, 30.4 percent of the state’s eligible voters went to the polls. Last week, only 21 percent of voters came out — the worst showing for a general election in state history.

headline: A New L.A. Wellness Destination Deals in Affordable Luxury
text: In a city where ayahuasca ceremonies and crystal healings are as openly discussed as traffic and the weather, healing and wellness in Los Angeles can feel velvet rope-exclusive. Not everyone can afford to go six days off-the-grid or devote an entire weekend to juicing — and even those who do have the time and the means may find themselves at the very bottom of of a Kabbalistic intuitive counselor’s waitlist.

headline: Martin O’Malley Receives Support From Obama’s Finance Circle
text: Five people who served on President Obama’s national finance committee during his first presidential campaign are circulating a letter seeking to rally support for Martin O’Malley, the former governor of Maryland who has been struggling to gain traction in the Democratic presidential race.

headline: Mike Bartlett Turns to Shakespeare to Voice His ‘King Charles III’
text: How do you write a play about the British royal family without making its members seem risible, banal or irrelevant? Except for Queen Elizabeth, who orbits in her own special universe, today’s royals often appear to be trapped in a dreary reality show whose ostensible dramas (Who did Kate wear? What did Charles say?) are anything but dramatic.

headline: Laminate Maker Ark Is Accused of Selling Tainted Flooring
text: As Lumber Liquidators continues to struggle after a safety crisis over its Chinese-made laminate flooring, a much smaller flooring company has been drawn into the spotlight.

headline: Students Celebrate University of Missouri President’s Resignation
text: Students and faculty members at the University of Missouri in Columbia erupted in cheers at word of Timothy M. Wolfe’s resignation as president of the university system on Monday.

headline: The Stonehenge Landscape
text: To many visitors, Stonehenge is not much more than some big stones and not as impressive as they imagined. But the story is not just Stonehenge.

headline: Stonehenge Begins to Yield Its Secrets
text: AMESBURY, England — About 6,300 years ago, a tree here toppled over.

headline: Panel: What Today’s News Tells Us About the 2016 Election
text: We are a year out from the 2016 United States presidential vote, but it is clear that election madness is already in full swing. With such a long lead time, it’s hard to tell: Who will be in? Who will be out? And above all, which of the current political stories matter for next year’s election — and which don’t?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: In ‘Mediterranea,’ Two Migrants Speak for Many
text: LONDON — As Europe faces its largest migrant crisis since World War II — more than 780,000 people from the Middle East and Africa have arrived this year, according to the United Nations’ refugee agency — it can be easy to forget that there is a story behind each decision to attempt the difficult journey.

headline: A Teenage Son’s Kind Acts, Revealed as He Is Laid to Rest
text: They knew that their son, Miles Kirkland Thomas, had used his time and talents to be supportive to others. They knew he made the varsity football team as a freshman. He volunteered with an organization called Health for Youths at a local police precinct house. He always saw the good in people.

headline: A Design Gallery That Wants a Strong Reaction
text: There are tough acts to follow — and then there’s Takashimaya, the Japanese department store that reigned over Fifth Avenue until it closed in 2010. The store itself hasn’t returned, but its instantly recognizable postmodern building has undergone a face-lift at the hands of David Chipperfield and even found a new tenant grand enough to fill its duplex penthouse: Carpenters Workshop Gallery, opening tomorrow.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: University of Missouri, Myanmar, Doping
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Digital Dig Unpacks Atlanta Dive Bar Rich in History
text: ATLANTA — The artist and documentary filmmaker Ruth Dusseault calls the stuff that has found its way onto the walls of Manuel’s Tavern, a beloved Eisenhower-era dive bar here, an “organic archive” and a “60-year installation piece.”

headline: Goodbyes to the Lord of the Dance and Mademoiselle Non
text: Michael Flatley and Sylvie Guillem begin their farewell appearances in New York this week.

headline: U.S. Soccer, Resolving Lawsuit, Will Limit Headers for Youth Players
text: The United States Soccer Federation unveiled a series of safety initiatives Monday aimed at addressing head injuries in the sport, including a policy that sets strict limits on youth players heading the ball. The new guidelines, which resolve a proposed class-action lawsuit filed against U.S. Soccer and others last year, will prohibit players age 10 and younger from heading the ball and will reduce headers in practice for those from age 11 to 13.

headline: Skelos Case Hearing Offers Hint of Possible Defense Strategy
text: When the corruption trial of State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son Adam begins next week, there will probably be snippets of salacious talk from both men, on a father’s influence and on undermining the governor in budget negotiations.

headline: Scuffle Between Nevada Casino Company and Union Pulls In Deutsche Bank
text: The long-running fight between culinary workers and a casino owner in Las Vegas is about to go another round. And the workers are hoping the regulatory troubles faced by a German bank might give them the advantage they have been looking for.

headline: Panel to Examine Tolls for New Tappan Zee Bridge
text: The New York State Thruway Authority announced on Monday that a new task force would examine whether to raise tolls for the crossing that is being built to replace the Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: With $170.4 Million Sale at Auction, Modigliani Work Joins Rarefied Nine-Figure Club
text: In an overheated art market where anything seems possible, a painting of an outstretched nude woman by the early-20th-century artist Amedeo Modigliani sold on Monday night for $170.4 million with fees to Liu Yiqian, a former taxi driver turned billionaire art collector, in a packed sales room at Christie’s. It was the second-highest price paid for an artwork at auction.

headline: Hoping for His Backing, Jeb Bush Meets With a Cautious Scott Walker
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — Leaving an event here with Gov. Scott Walker, Jeb Bush said he would be happy to land Mr. Walker’s endorsement in the 2016 presidential race.

headline: College Athletes’ Potential Realized in Missouri Resignations
text: Well, that was fast.

headline: Bill Cosby Faces New Suit for Saying Accuser Lied
text: A New Hampshire woman who accused Bill Cosby last year of drugging and sexually assaulting her in 1965 has sued the entertainer, contending that he wrongly branded her a liar after she came forward.

headline: Shift to Lower-Carbon Energy Is Too Slow, I.E.A. Report Warns
text: LONDON — Even as the world shifts toward lower-carbon forms of energy, the changes are happening too slowly to keep global temperatures from rising to dangerous levels in the coming decades, an international research group warns in a report released on Tuesday.

headline: Egypt’s Brazen Crackdown on Critics
text: Update: Hossam Bahgat was released Tuesday. It is not clear whether he still faces charges.

headline: U.A.W.’s Tentative Deal With Ford Tops Other Automaker Contracts
text: DETROIT — Local leaders of the United Automobile Workers on Monday endorsed a proposed new labor agreement with Ford Motor Company that is slightly richer than contracts agreed to by union workers at General Motors and Fiat Chrysler.

headline: NATO War Games Unwittingly Put Soviets and U.S. on ‘Hair Trigger’ in ’83, Analysis Suggests
text: In December 1988, Jörg Winger was a West German Army radio operator eavesdropping on Soviet military channels when he overheard a startling message: The Russians wished him Merry Christmas by name.

headline: Pimco Suit Sheds Light on Murky Investor Fees
text: With the trading desks of investment banks cut to the bone, the ability to pin a fat fee on a fast-growing pile of assets has become the holy grail for financial firms.

headline: Invitation List Looms as Test for Syria Talks
text: When world powers gather in Vienna this weekend to discuss a possible postwar political deal for Syria, one of the main points of contention will be to determine whom to include among opposition groups in future negotiations — and the West may back groups that are less than “moderate,” Britain’s top diplomat said on Monday.

headline: Manhattan Man Charged in Wife’s Killing Is Barred From Talking to Anyone but Lawyer
text: A judge denied bail on Monday to a Manhattan man accused of strangling his estranged wife six years ago and covering up the crime, then took the unusual step of barring the defendant from speaking to anyone except his lawyer — a move intended to prevent him from sending messages to witnesses.

headline: A Rebuke to India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi
text: During a national election in India last year, Narendra Modi promised “development for all.” As prime minister, he has yet to deliver big economic improvements, but in the meantime, members of his government and political party have shredded his promise of inclusion by inflaming sectarian tensions. Now, voters in the country’s third most populous state have sent Mr. Modi a message: Put an end to the hatemongering.

headline: Brookie Maxwell, an Artist and Curator, Dies at 59
text: Brookie Maxwell, a painter, sculptor and curator who immersed herself in social causes and viewed art as a spiritual haven for homeless children, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Appeals Court Deals Blow to Obama’s Immigration Plans
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court said Monday that President Obama could not move forward with his plans to overhaul immigration rules by providing up to five million people with work permits and protection from deportation.

headline: Bill Ackman’s Enigmatic Approach to Valeant Pharmaceuticals
text: William A. Ackman, the activist investor, has described his billion-dollar bet and continuing crusade against the nutritional supplements company Herbalife as a “moral obligation.” In at least one presentation, he nearly cried onstage and said that if his Herbalife trade was successful, he would give the profits to charity because he would consider them “blood money.”

headline: Jeb Bush Allies Threaten Wave of Harsh Attacks on Marco Rubio, an Ex-Mentee
text: The cash-rich group aiding Jeb Bush’s White House run has filmed a provocative video casting his rival Marco Rubio as ultimately unelectable because of his hard-line stand against abortion.

headline: Letter from Capitol Hill: Allow Government Officials to Read Full Torture Report
text: The executive summary of the report on C.I.A. torture was publicly released in December 2014, but the complete 6,700-page report was confined to executive branch safes. Senators Dianne Feinstein and Patrick J. Leahy wrote this letter imploring the heads of the Justice Department and the F.B.I. to allow more government officials to read the report.

headline: Classified Report on the C.I.A.’s Secret Prisons Is Caught in Limbo
text: WASHINGTON — A Senate security officer stepped out of the December chill last year and delivered envelopes marked “Top Secret” to the Pentagon, the C.I.A., the State Department and the Justice Department. Inside each packet was a disc containing a 6,700-page classified report on the C.I.A.’s secret prison program and a letter from Senator Dianne Feinstein, urging officials to read the report to ensure that the lessons were not lost to time.

headline: Years Later, Bittersweet Victory for Alysia Montaño
text: Alysia Montaño, an American 800-meter runner, woke up early in Valencia, Calif. Knowing the World Anti-Doping Agency was releasing the findings of its extraordinary inquiry into doping and corruption in Russian track and field, she devoured the details of the report in bed as soon as she awoke.

headline: Don Gregory, Theater Producer of Solo Shows, Dies at 80
text: Don Gregory, a theater producer who specialized in star vehicles, including one-actor shows for Henry Fonda, Julie Harris and James Earl Jones on Broadway, died on Thursday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Albert Woodfox, Angola Inmate, Can Be Tried 3rd Time, Court Rules
text: A federal appeals court ruled on Monday that Louisiana could keep an inmate locked up for the 1972 murder of a prison guard and said prosecutors may try him a third time for the killing.

headline: Preparing for Jets, Bills’ Rex Ryan Finds Way to Needle Them
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — Maybe it was sleep deprivation. Maybe it was the excitement surrounding his return to the New York metropolitan region to face his former team for the first time. But Buffalo Bills Coach Rex Ryan, normally a champion talker, uttered a few uncharacteristic linguistic lapses and malapropisms on Monday.

headline: Wojciech Fangor, Painter Who Emerged From Postwar Poland, Dies at 92
text: Wojciech Fangor, one of the most distinctive painters to emerge from postwar Poland, died on Oct. 25 in Warsaw. He was 92.

headline: Russia: Official Says Delayed Deal to Sell Iran Missiles Remains in Force
text: Russia’s most senior arms executive said Monday that a contract to supply Iran with powerful S-300 air defense missiles was now active. But with no delivery date or any other details, the announcement seemed aimed more at warding off an Iranian lawsuit than a major step toward delivery of the weapon system. Sergei V. Chemezov, Russia’s chief arms trade executive, made the announcement at an air show in Dubai, Russian news agencies reported. “The contract to deliver the S-300 was not only signed by both sides, but has already come into force,” Mr. Chemezov was quoted as saying by the RIA Novosti news agency. The initial contract to deliver the weapons was signed in 2007, before the current international arms embargo against Iran was established. But the deal was canceled in 2010 by Dmitri A. Medvedev, then Russia’s president, under pressure from the United States and Israel. In response, Iran filed a lawsuit claiming breach of contract that could cost Moscow as much as five times the $800 million value of the original deal. President Vladimir V. Putin reversed Mr. Medvedev’s decision in April, as a nuclear deal between Iran and the world powers began to appear likely. But the system still has not been delivered. The hitch, military experts say, is that Russia wants to keep the unfulfilled contract as a bargaining chip in its relations with the West, perhaps with an eye to ending economic sanctions imposed over its actions in Ukraine.

headline: Lamar Alexander Seeks Path to Change in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Nothing touches off a political war in the Senate like proposals to tinker with the arcane rules that govern the often creaky chamber. Talk of eliminating the filibuster is called the nuclear option for a reason.

headline: ‘I Need Some Muscle’: Missouri Activists Block Journalists
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — A video that showed University of Missouri protesters restricting a student photographer’s access to a public area of campus on Monday has ignited discussions about press freedom.

headline: Review: In ‘Lost Girls,’ Derailed Blue-Collar Lives, With Zingers
text: So you’re driving along through what you think is a drearily familiar landscape, when suddenly there’s a bend in the road. All at once, in a single click of perception, everything looks slightly but revealingly different, and not just where you are now, but also where you’ve been. The view in the rearview mirror has changed.

headline: Review: ‘Dada Woof Papa Hot,’ About Gay Men and Parenthood
text: Spare a teardrop or two for the troubled gay fathers in “Dada Woof Papa Hot,” a slick, mostly enjoyable new play by Peter Parnell that opened on Monday at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

headline: Keeping Everything in Balance
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The last time we saw Will Treece, he was making his New York Times crossword debut, overzealously correcting the sensational spelling of various creatively spelled musical groups. Today, he’s back with a relatively easy theme about name doppelgängers.

headline: Sheldon Silver’s Grants Suppressed in Budget Reports, Official Testifies in Corruption Trial
text: Until Sheldon Silver’s arrest and subsequent resignation as speaker of the New York Assembly, he was considered one of the state’s most powerful politicians, controlling how billions of dollars of state funds were doled out.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Likely to Have Thumb Surgery After Game
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Ryan Fitzpatrick has a torn ligament in his left thumb that only surgery can repair. That surgery, he hinted strongly, is likely to occur Friday so that he can maximize recovery time before the Jets’ next game.

headline: Are You Smarter Than a Billionaire?
text: Art auctions can be unpredictable. See how you match up in this interactive quiz.

headline: Retrial in ’90 Killing of Tourist on a New York Subway Platform Is Delayed
text: The Manhattan district attorney has decided to appeal a judge’s decision to grant a new trial to a Queens man convicted of taking part in the 1990 killing of a tourist on a New York subway platform, a crime that for many residents marked a low point in an era of fear and disorder.

headline: Off the Field, Charting the X’s and O’s of a Protest Movement
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Jonathan Butler’s hunger strike to protest what he viewed as systemic racism at the University of Missouri, where he is a graduate student, was raised to the level of national news Saturday night, when black Missouri football players went on strike pending the removal of the university system president, Tim Wolfe. On Sunday, the rest of the Tigers squad joined in, and their coach backed them.

headline: Coalition of Start-Ups and Labor Call for Rethinking of Worker Policies
text: A major threat that has loomed over so-called on-demand companies is the potential of new labor definitions that would force the companies to treat contract workers like traditional employees.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 2, Episode 5: The Butcher of Luverne
text: Children make mistakes. And as they get older, they still make mistakes — maybe not as many, but bigger and more dangerous ones. They rebel. They test their boundaries. They slip around (or smash through) the guardrails their parents have set up for their protection. For Charlie and Simone Gerhardt, the children of criminals, growing up comes with a deep moral confusion and a nefarious sense of duty. Will they be ready to run the family business? (Is that something they even want?) And what sort of twisted values are their elders instilling in them to prepare them for it?

headline: ‘Blindspot’ Season 1, Episode 8: Hot-Button Issues
text: Characters on NBC’s “Blindspot” often remark on how prescient the tattoo artist or artists who inked up Jane were. “How did he/she/they know we would be in this specific place at this exact time and find this obscure clue?” Another sort of prescience took over Monday night’s episode: The tattoos are also freakishly good at steering the plot toward hot-button real-life issues.

headline: Pepsi Is Departing Citi Field, Leaving Behind a Bare Porch
text: Thanks to their surprising success in 2015, the Mets should see a healthy bump in ticket sales over the winter and more companies lining up to sign sponsorship deals with the club, which made it to the World Series after six consecutive losing seasons.

headline: Hank Penza, Owner of Mars Bar in the East Village, Dies at 82
text: Hank Penza, who owned and presided over Mars Bar, a gritty, storied dive bar in the East Village and one of the neighborhood’s last holdouts in the face of gentrification, died on Oct. 29 in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Use of Long-Acting Birth Control Methods Surges Among U.S. Women
text: WASHINGTON — The share of American women on birth control who use long-acting reversible methods like intrauterine devices and implants has nearly doubled in recent years, the federal government reported Tuesday.

headline: Man Is Killed as Car Jumps Curb in Brooklyn
text: A man was fatally injured on Monday when a car jumped a curb, flipped over and struck him on a Brooklyn sidewalk, the police and fire officials said.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: A cup of joe or a glass of blaufränkisch? The choice is yours, thirsty viewers, as two competitions — one for baristas, the other for sommeliers — showcase the commitment and quirks of those who aspire to become masters of their domains. Or sit back with your beverage of choice while John Stamos and Dave Coulier evoke their “Full House” days on “Grandfathered,” and Ric Burns pays tribute to disabled veterans throughout American history.

headline: Astellas Pharma to Acquire Ocata Therapeutics
text: Ocata Therapeutics, a sometimes controversial pioneer in developing human embryonic stem cells, will be acquired by Astellas Pharma for about $379 million, the companies announced on Monday night.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Tim Wolfe’s resignation was a necessary step toward healing and reconciliation on the University of Missouri campus.”

headline: Seeking Changes From E.U., David Cameron Outlines Conditions for Britain to Stay
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday formally laid out Britain’s conditions for remaining in the European Union, seeking changes in his country’s relationship with Brussels that he is betting are substantial enough to win over a majority of British voters but modest enough for the rest of Europe to swallow.

headline: Rival Bid for Asciano, an Australian Port and Railroad Company
text: SYDNEY, Australia — A group of infrastructure investors and operators has emerged as a rival suitor for Asciano, the Australian port and railroad company.

headline: ‘White-Haired Girl,’ Opera Created Under Mao, Returns to Stage
text: Mao Zedong was said to have been moved to tears when he watched an early performance of “The White-Haired Girl,” an opera created to meet his call for rousing revolutionary art. And under President Xi Jinping, a revival is on the road, reinvented once more to appeal to a Communist Party leader’s stringently ideological tastes.

headline: Schools Can’t Stop Kids From Sexting. More Technology Can.
text: “YOUTH is subjected by our civilization to aggressive sex stimuli and suggestiveness oozing from every pore.” So declared the education professor Clark Hetherington in 1914, condemning the proliferation of racy movies and tell-all magazines. Lest adolescents succumb to the “indulgence” on display, he wrote, schools needed to teach “self-control” and “higher standards.”

headline: Robin Williams’s Gift
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rand Paul’s Lost Moment
text: Senator Rand Paul doesn’t like country music.

headline: The Things They Carry
text: Kennedy Odede is one of the most joy-filled people I’ve met.

headline: The Risks of Assisting Evolution
Your Kids Will Live Longer Than You Thought
text: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, life expectancy at birth in the United States was 78.8 years in 2013 — 76.4 years for men, 81.2 years for women. But I have good news. Those statistics don’t mean what you probably think they mean.

headline: Can Companies Be Trusted?
text: Volkswagen's vast cheating on emissions tests has been called proof that stronger regulation is needed.

headline: Smart African Politics: Candidates Debating Under a Tree
text: Political debates are good even when they’re bad. Even when candidates are cringe-worthy, they’re cringe-worthy in public view. And voters learn about all the candidates, not just new ones. In the United States, for example, Hillary Clinton has been center stage in political life for 24 years. Donald Trump is the very definition of “overexposed.” Still, the debates tell us new things about them — their positions, temperament, grace under pressure (or lack thereof), charisma and political skill.

headline: Defeating My Anxiety
text: When the stock market crashed in 2008, my wife and I were 70. And we saw half of our retirement funds disappear. Before the crash, we felt secure in the belief that we had enough money to last as long as we lived; after the crash, we feared that we would not, and I worried about it a great deal. I had a hard time going to sleep and an even harder time going back to sleep after getting up to go to the bathroom in the middle of the night. I came to hate going into that bathroom because I knew my demons resided there and would invade my consciousness immediately.

headline: Australia Uses Tear Gas in Riots at Christmas Island Detention Center
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian authorities on Tuesday used tear gas and force to quell rioting at a detention center on Christmas Island that began after an Iranian refugee being held there died over the weekend.

headline: Dutch Government Aims to Raise $4.6 Billion in ABN Amro I.P.O.
text: LONDON — The government of the Netherlands said on Tuesday that it expected to raise 4.3 billion euros, or about $4.6 billion, through the sale of shares of the state-owned lender ABN Amro in an initial public offering this month.

headline: News Q’s | Web Poets’ Society: New Breed Succeeds in Taking Verse Viral

headline: Amazon’s Streaming Music Aims for More Casual Listeners

headline: Should Voting Be Mandatory?
text: A healthy representative democracy depends on citizens exercising their right to vote. Yet here in the United States, usually 40 percent of eligible voters don’t vote during presidential elections, and typically 60 percent don’t vote in congressional midterm elections.

headline: Racial Tension and Protests on Campuses Across the Country
text: Instances of racism and bigotry have ignited protests at colleges across the United States, and social media has amplified students’ messages far beyond campus. Here are some examples.

headline: Criticism and Litigation Over Renewal Clause in Rent-Freeze Program for Older New Yorkers
text: As New York City officials encourage older tenants to take advantage of an underused program that freezes their rents, they have also been cutting off participants who fail to renew on time, advocates say.

headline: Afghans Arriving in Germany Find the Welcome Is Wearing Thin
text: BERLIN — A growing sense that Afghanistan is slipping into greater chaos and will not stabilize anytime soon is driving rising numbers of Afghans to flee for Europe, hopeful that they will enjoy the same welcome given to Syrians and Iraqis seeking safety from war and terror.

headline: What to Look For in Republican Debate
text: Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee will bring the eight leading contenders together at a time when two are confronting questions about their pasts, one faces mounting doubts about his seriousness, and another who began the race as a favorite is under intense pressure to show he can be as forceful as he was cracked up to be. Yet their ability to address those problems could actually depend on whether Fox Business Network, the host of the debate, fails to deliver on its promises for a policy-driven evening focused on sober economic issues.

headline: The Killer App: Storytelling
text: Brian Storm was raised in the Detroit area and attended the College of the Ozarks on a baseball scholarship. While obtaining a graduate degree at the University of Missouri’s School of Journalism in 1993, he discovered computers and began making interactive CD-ROM disks. He started a company, MediaStorm, but put it on hold while working for MSNBC and Corbis over the next decade.He relaunched MediaStorm in 2005 as a film-production company and interactive design studio, which this month celebrates its 10th anniversary. He spoke with James Estrin about the future of photography and multimedia. Their conversation has been edited.

headline: ‘Nabokov in America,’ by Robert Roper
text: Who would have thought there’d be more to say about Vladimir Nabokov? This most scholarly and mandarin of writers, an incontestable master of his craft, has been parsed and chronicled to death — the subject of Brian Boyd’s two-­volume biography as well as Stacy Schiff’s portrait of a marriage (“Véra: Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov”), not to mention thousands of critical studies. So my first thought when I set eyes on Robert Roper’s “Nabokov in America: On the Road to ‘Lolita’ ” was, “Is this book necessary?”

headline: In ‘Letters to Véra,’ Vladimir Nabokov Writes to His Wife
text: My sun, my soul, my song, my bird, my sweetheart, my pink sky, my sunny rainbow, my little music, my inexpressible delight, my softness, my tenderness, my lightness, my dear life, my dear eyes. . . . These endearments and salutations (backed up by a crowded menagerie of surrogates: Goosikins, Poochums, Tigercubkin, Puppykin) suggest a sky-filling ­adoration and, more than that, a helpless dependency. As early as Vladimir Nabokov’s second letter to Véra Slonim, after a couple of months of chaste acquaintanceship, he lays it all before her: “I cannot write a word without hearing how you will pronounce it — and can’t recall a single trifle I’ve lived through without regret — so sharp! — that we haven’t lived through it together. . . . You came into my life . . . as one comes to a kingdom where all the rivers have been waiting for your reflection, all the roads, for your steps.”

headline: Ask Well: The Health Benefits of Meditation
text: Question:
