text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: New York Today: Book Drop
text: Updated 9:39 a.m.

headline: Conference Seeks to Prompt Candidates to Discuss Education
text: Gov. Terry E. Branstad, Republican of Iowa, and Gov. Jack Markell, Democrat of Delaware, will bring a bipartisan focus to education on Tuesday in the hopes of urging the presidential candidates to focus more closely on developing strong teachers nationally.

headline: Morning Agenda: Ackman Defiant Over Valeant
text: ACKMAN DEFIANT OVER VALEANT | William A. Ackman took a swipe at the news media and the people on Wall Street who relished betting against him in an investor conference call yesterday,

headline: John McCain Consults Earlier Legislation in Bid for a Pentagon Overhaul
text: When he was handed the chairman’s gavel of the Senate Armed Services Committee this year, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said changes to the way the Pentagon spent its money and to its overall structure would be his top priorities.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Release Plan to Address Veterans Affairs Scandal
text: WINDHAM, N.H. — On Monday, just after she officially registered as a Democratic candidate in New Hampshire, Hillary Rodham Clinton declared, “This election is about our veterans.”

headline: Donald Trump Sees a Bump in Attention After ‘S.N.L.’ Appearance
text: Few candidates for president have been as deft at garnering free media attention as Donald J. Trump. His appearance on “Saturday Night Live” is the latest example.

headline: Seeing Voting Rights Under Siege, Philip Glass Rewrites an Opera
text: WASHINGTON — Each new chapter of American history has a way of casting what came before it in a different light. So when the composer Philip Glass and the playwright Christopher Hampton decided to revive “Appomattox,” the opera about the Civil War that they wrote a decade ago, they found that the changing civil rights landscape cried out for a rewrite.

headline: In Ireland, Milk Chocolate Reigns
text: Everyone we met in Ireland told us that our trip last year couldn’t have been better timed. We were there in early summer. The countryside was at its ripest green, the characteristic clouds and rain were nowhere to be seen, and the crowds of summer tourists hadn’t yet arrived. But never mind the weather and the sights. We were there for the chocolate. Well, actually, I was there for the milk chocolate. My husband, Mahir, who proclaims his allegiance to dark, was my grumbling recruit.

headline: The Cult of the ‘Amateur’
text: Late in October, the retired brain surgeon Ben Carson took the stage at a Christian college in Colorado and pitched himself as president. ‘‘I love it when people come up to me and they say: ‘B-b-b-b-but-but you’ve never been elected to any public office! You can’t possibly know how to do anything!’ Well, let me tell you something. The ark was built by amateurs. The Titanic was built by professionals.’’ Carson touched his fingertips together and smiled softly to himself. The crowd went nuts. Outside, one Carson supporter pinpointed the surgeon’s appeal: ‘‘People are sick of politicians.’’

headline: You, Only Better
text: Dave Asprey does not like infomercials. He didn’t want our conversation to feel like one, he said, raising both hands in a gesture of innocence, like a magician showing there was nothing up his sleeve. But once he planted the suggestion, it wouldn’t go away. There was the register of his voice, oscillating between breathy and enthusiastic, and the complete absence of qualifiers to soften his bold claims. And then there were the wares clustered on the table in front of him. He had laid out cups of his signature product, Bulletproof Coffee, which is made with grass-fed butter and Brain Octane, a trademarked oil extracted from coconuts. Next to the cups lay Bulletproof-branded protein bars in chocolate and vanilla. ‘‘I am not plugging my stuff,’’ he said with a semi-embarrassed laugh. ‘‘I’m just talking about how things work.’’

headline: A Visit to the Strange, Secretive World of David Bowie’s ‘Lazarus’
text: On a recent weekday morning, the Belgian director Ivo van Hove sat at a corner table in the bar of the Standard Hotel. A bound script of “Lazarus,” his latest stage project, nestled on the table beside his Americano.

headline: Economists, Biologists and Skrillex on How to Predict the Future
text: Lots of people pretend they’ve got tomorrow figured out: tech gurus, politicians, C.E.O.s and (yes) journalists. But if we’re honest with ourselves, the view ahead of us has never been murkier. That’s because the problems that most haunt our world today — climate change and pollution, inequality and war — are problems for which technology, long our spur to envisioning better futures, looks more like a cause than a solution. Our future is hard to imagine because we have trouble imagining how we can possibly act to improve it.

headline: Poll Watch: Overseas Elections Offer Warnings for U.S. Pollsters
text: Pre-election polls in numerous countries this year have widely missed their marks, often by underestimating support for candidates on the ideological fringes. The polling failures in countries like Britain, Poland and Israel point to technical issues that could well foreshadow polling problems in the United States, many analysts believe.

headline: Chinese Taxi Driver Turned Billionaire Bought Modigliani Painting
text: BEIJING — Liu Yiqian, a former taxi driver turned billionaire art collector, confirmed on Tuesday that he was the buyer of the painting of a nude woman by Amedeo Modigliani that sold for  $170.4 million at Christie’s New York on Monday night.

headline: Hossam Bahgat, Journalist and Advocate, Is Released by Egypt’s Military
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian military on Tuesday released the journalist Hossam Bahgat, hours before planned demonstrations in Cairo, London and other cities to call for his freedom.

headline: Atulya Pandey’s H-1B Visa Is Denied
text: The Department of Homeland Security denies a temporary worker visa.

headline: How the H-1B Visa System Can Hurt American Workers
text: Congress set up the H-1B visa program to help American companies hire foreigners with specialized skills. But in recent years, many H-1B visas have gone to temporary immigrants who lacked special skills and displaced American workers from jobs.

headline: How Outsourcing Companies Are Gaming the Visa System
text: How 20 companies took more than a third of the H-1B visas available in 2014.

headline: Large Companies Game H-1B Visa Program, Costing the U.S. Jobs
text: Théo Négri, a young software engineer from France, had come up with so many novel ideas at his job at an Internet start-up in San Francisco that the American entrepreneur who hired him wanted to keep him on.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 3-9, 2015
text: Have you been following the news?

headline: Even as House Speaker, Paul Ryan Sleeps in His Office
text: WASHINGTON — The speaker has no house.

headline: Do We Romanticize Writers Who Die Young?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Dana Stevens and Benjamin Moser discuss how we view authors who die before their time.

headline: What Mass Incarceration Looks Like for Juveniles
text: After two decades of researching mass incarceration — and advocating for its demise — I decided in 2005 to take more direct action and accepted a job running corrections departments, first in Washington, D.C., then in New York City. It was a rude awakening.

headline: Subject, Meet Verb
text: Singular subject, singular verb; plural subject, plural verb. What could be simpler? And yet …

headline: Emma Roberts Shares Her Beauty Routine
text: Emma Roberts, 24, plays the lead character Chanel Oberlin, a terrifying sorority co-president who lords over her minions (the Chanels) on the hit fall show “Scream Queens.” In real life, Ms. Roberts, who was born in the Hudson Valley but grew up in the Hollywood Hills, is quite a bit more approachable and a beauty product junkie to boot. Here, the actress and Aerie model shares her beauty favorites.

headline: Football Inequality, and a Patriots-Panthers Super Bowl?
text: Midway through the N.F.L. season is often the juncture at which sportstalk obsesses about parity driving every team toward .500. Instead, in this midway point there are three 8-0 teams and 16 losing clubs. No one’s ever satisfied — there are complaints of not enough parity.

headline: Let Go of Irrational Fears
text: When we talk about the chances of something bad happening, people tend to fall into three general groups.

headline: Where Humans and Computers Agree in College Football
text: Cover your ears, Bowl Championship Series haters. Many computer rankings, which rely on statistics and algorithms to rate teams, tracked closely with how the committee’s 12 flesh-and-blood experts ended up listing the teams in the season’s first College Football Playoff ranking last Tuesday night.

headline: Allen Toussaint, New Orleans R&B Mainstay, Dies at 77
text: Allen Toussaint, the versatile producer, songwriter, pianist and singer who was a fixture of New Orleans R&B, died after appearing in concert in Madrid on Monday night. He was 77.

headline: Ex-British Soldier, 66, Is Arrested in Bloody Sunday Massacre
text: LONDON — The police in Northern Ireland arrested a 66-year-old man on Tuesday in connection with Bloody Sunday, the infamous massacre of unarmed civilian marchers by British soldiers in Londonderry on Jan. 30, 1972. It was the first time anyone has been arrested in the massacre, for which the British government formally apologized in 2010.

headline: China’s Crackdown on Financial Markets Gets Top-Level Support
text: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping of China called for more measures to protect stock market investors after meeting with financial regulators, the state news media said on Tuesday, signaling top-level support for a national campaign to crack down on market manipulation and to increase transparency.

headline: Everywhere a Bodhisattva
text: Dear Diary:

headline: TAG Heuer, Intel and Google Raise the Stakes in Smartwatches
text: It wasn’t quite the frenzy of the Balmain x H&M event last week, but by noon on Monday, there were lines outside the TAG Heuer store on Fifth Avenue stretching at least partway down the block, as watch aficionados awaited their first glance at what has been thought of as the first real luxury competitor to the Apple Watch: the TAG Heuer Connected, a Swiss-engineered smartwatch with an Intel chip and a Google platform.

headline: 1915: Japan Crowns Emperor
text: With all the strangely picturesque ceremony customary to the occasion, the coronation of Emperor Yoshihito of Japan took place yesterday at Kyoto, the Holy City. Strictly speaking, by reason of the fact that in Japan the sovereign has no crown nor does he receive any anointment, the ceremony was not so much that of a coronation as of the consecration of the new Emperor by a solemn ritual homage paid by him to his ancestors. The festivities in connection with the celebration of the Emperor’s accession to the throne last a month and began on Saturday with the departure from Tokyo of the sovereign and his suite for Kyoto, where on Sunday he deposited in the sacred pavilion called the Shunko-Den the sword, mirror and jewels bequeathed by the first Emperor of the Meiji dynasty. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 11, 1915

headline: Ben Carson Fans in Iowa Stand by Their Man and Against the News Media
text: DES MOINES — As he faces a swirl of questions about whether elements of his compelling biography are true, Ben Carson is finding stubborn allies: his many fans in Iowa, who are shrugging off accusations that he made things up, calling them reflective of news media bias.

headline: American Ambassador Builds Diplomatic Bridges With British Teenagers
text: LONDON — Matthew Barzun, the American ambassador to the Court of St. James’s, stood before a buzzing, boisterous audience of several hundred teenagers in a poor borough on the southern edge of greater London and asked them what frustrated or concerned them the most about the United States.

headline: Daily Report: The Match and Square Road Shows
text: Let the road shows begin.

headline: Man, 90, Dies in Queens Apartment Fire
text: A 90-year-old man died on Tuesday after he was found unconscious by emergency workers responding to a fire in his apartment in Queens, the authorities said.

headline: Helmut Schmidt, Assertive West German Chancellor, Dies at 96
text: Helmut Schmidt, the former West German chancellor who marshaled personal dynamism, managerial brilliance and often acid-tongued impatience to push his country into an assertive international role as the Cold War dragged on into the 1970s, died on Tuesday at his home in Hamburg. He was 96.

headline: Court Rules Against French Comedian Dieudonné in Free-Speech Case
text: LONDON — In 2008, the French comedian Dieudonné M’bala M’bala finished a performance in Paris by inviting a Holocaust denier onstage to receive a prize from an actor dressed in striped pajamas resembling a concentration camp uniform, with a yellow star bearing the word “Jew.”

headline: Facebook to Appeal a Belgian Court’s Ruling on Data Privacy
text: Facebook intends to appeal a privacy ruling in Belgium that forces the social media giant to stop collecting digital information about people who are not its users.

headline: Vito J. Lopez, Ex-New York Assemblyman Tainted by Scandal, Dies at 74
text: Vito J. Lopez, a former community organizer and New York assemblyman who parlayed a small antipoverty center in Brooklyn into a political machine that made him a power broker in New York City and Albany until he was brought down by a sexual harassment scandal, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Now for the Positive: Jay Cutler Becomes Bears’ Top Passer
text: When you think about Jay Cutler, you might think about ... well, what do you think about?

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 5: Who Will She Choose?
text: “Jane the Virgin” has done a superb job navigating the love triangle, a common television plot device that is often done poorly, as when series allow it to overtake the main narrative or spend too long building multiple “will-they/won’t they-“ scenarios. Yet “Jane the Virgin” has deftly managed its triangle in a way that remains engaging and new, and doesn’t make viewers sick of the love between either Jane and Michael or Jane and Rafael.

headline: 1940: Italians Flee in Greece
text: ATHENS — The Italian lines in the Epirus sector have broken and the Fascist troops are in full retreat there, at the extreme left, or southern, end of the Greek front, according to the latest reports reaching here tonight [Nov. 10]. The Italians are retreating in disorder and are abandoning quantities of war material, it was stated in the reports. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 11, 1940

headline: Why Tuberculosis Is Back
text: WASHINGTON — New data from the World Health Organization shows that we have allowed a preventable, curable disease to become the world’s biggest communicable killer. The millenniums-old lung disease tuberculosis now outranks even H.I.V./AIDS in the number of lives it claims. The fact is that we’ve been very successful at curing people of TB since the 1950s — so why is this illness still such a scourge?

headline: The Designer Who Doesn’t Want You to Sit Down
text: The Spanish industrial designer Patricia Urquiola tackles the ultimate frontier of bad design: the American office.

headline: Miami City Ballet Returns for Joyce Season
text: Miami City Ballet will give a season in New York for the first time since 2009. Alessandra Ferri and Herman Cornejo team up for a program of contemporary ballet pieces with the pianist Bruce Levingston. These are some of the highlights of the Joyce Theater’s offerings for its spring and summer season, announced on Tuesday, which also includes the tap ensemble Dorrance Dance, the Stephen Petronio Company, Pennsylvania Ballet and a Cuba Festival.

headline: Escaping Reality With Brazil’s Globo TV
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Last year, The Economist published an article about TV Globo, Brazil’s largest broadcast network. It reported that “91 million people, just under half the population, tune in to it each day: The sort of audience that, in the United States, is to be had only once a year, and only for the one network that has won the rights that year to broadcast American football’s Super Bowl championship game.”

headline: Cuffing Season Is Here: Till Spring Do Us Part
text: Camille Sanches, a Columbia University sophomore, was eating lunch with friends when another girl stopped by with some news: A guy had asked her out on a date.

headline: A Bleak Future in Eastern Ukraine’s Frozen Zone
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — The 28-year-old accountant with a bob of chestnut hair would dash from work to meet her wide circle of friends at bars, restaurants and dinner parties. “It’s not how you spend your time, but who you spend it with,” Irina Filatova, the accountant, said of her humming social life.

headline: Opening Eyes
text: On my 2015 win-a-trip journey with Nicholas Kristof through India and Nepal, I spent most of the time reporting on issues related to extreme poverty, malnutrition and human rights abuses. As I wrote these columns, I battled feelings of futility and hopelessness. I was determined to change hearts and minds through human-centered stories, but I was afraid that the scale of the problems I was witnessing would engulf any efforts made to combat them.

headline: Scott Campbell Wants to Tattoo You
text: As the best man at Justin Theroux and Jennifer Aniston’s wedding; the husband of the actress and filmmaker Lake Bell; and the tattoo artist who has inked the likes of Sting, Marc Jacobs, Robert Downey Jr. and Courtney Love, the New York tattoo artist turned fine artist Scott Campbell has enjoyed a degree of media attention not usually afforded the anonymous skin-scribblers of the East Village.

headline: A Pre-emptive Strike From Marco Rubio, Using Jeb Bush’s Words
text: Senator Marco Rubio is ready for an onslaught of attacks from Jeb Bush, and ahead of Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate he offered a preview of the comeback that he may use should Mr. Bush go on the offensive.

headline: Prosecutors Allege Persistent Heating Oil Fraud in New York City
text: In a city of glittering office towers and computerized transactions, of records kept in the cloud and fuels that send less soot into the sky, the authorities say old-fashioned corruption of the most brazen kind still poisons the heating oil industry.

headline: Tasting and Testing a Genetically Modified, Non-Browning Apple
text: Innovations in biotech crops aren’t known for getting children excited, but there is a new fruit trait on its way to the market that families may appreciate and children may actually notice. It’s a genetically modified apple that doesn’t turn brown when it is bruised or sliced. My children and I had a chance to try some last week. We beat them up and put them through a battery of tests to see how child-friendly and tasty they really are — a snack and a science lesson in one.

headline: Obama to Appeal Immigration Ruling to Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will ask the Supreme Court to clear the way for his far-reaching overhaul of the nation’s immigration system, administration lawyers said Tuesday, setting up a battle in the nation’s highest court over whether nearly five million undocumented immigrants can legally live and work in the United States.

headline: A History of Racism at the University of Missouri
text: Timothy Wolfe’s resignation on Monday from the presidency of the University of Missouri system will not resolve the racial tensions that forced him from office. His tone-deaf style certainly inflamed the problem at the flagship campus in Columbia. But racist acts and utterances aimed at black students and black faculty have been an issue there for many years.

headline: Hindu Nationalist Killed in Clashes at Indian Celebration of Muslim Ruler
text: NEW DELHI — Tension between Hindus and Muslims flared anew in India on Tuesday when a Hindu nationalist in the southern state of Karnataka died from injuries he suffered while protesting a celebration honoring an 18th-century Muslim ruler.

headline: New York Regulator Seeks Proposals to Improve Cybersecurity
text: New York’s financial industry regulator is seeking suggestions from other regulators on proposed regulations to shore up digital security defenses in the industry.

headline: Obama Turns to Diplomacy and Military in Syria, and Is Met With Doubts
text: WASHINGTON — For the first time in the four-year Syrian civil war, President Obama is beginning to execute a combined diplomatic and military approach to force President Bashar al-Assad to leave office and end the carnage.

headline: Raymond Kelly, Former New York Police Commissioner, Joins K2
text: Since leaving his role as the longest-serving commissioner of the New York Police Department two years ago, Raymond W. Kelly has hardly retired.

headline: Modern Vessels With an Ancient Feel
text: The stoneware vessels crafted by the Los Angeles-based ceramist Eric Roinestad evoke the persevering elegance of water jugs pulled from the volcanic soil of Pompeii. Yet while the objects nod to the past, with their whitewashed bisque palette and smooth matte surfaces, they are clearly of their time. After giving these substantial pieces, which range between 14 and 20 inches tall, a flat wash, Roinestad fires them and then sands them to let some of the clay show through the glaze, giving the vases the feel of having been hauled, gently, from the ashes of time.

headline: Myanmar Military Still Big Power Despite Opposition Victory
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Amid the mold-covered facades of downtown Yangon are police stations, a five-story building housing the Special Branch state security agency and government offices where citizens are required to register out-of-town houseguests.

headline: Volkswagen Hires Expert in Self-Driving Cars From Apple
text: Volkswagen has hired an expert in self-driving car technology from Apple, sending a signal that it will continue to invest in leading-edge technologies despite the financial burden created by its emissions cheating crisis.

headline: Beware the Beer Belly
text: A beer belly is a dangerous thing.

headline: Arrest of Jose Reyes May Test Baseball’s New Domestic Violence Policy
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Colorado Rockies shortstop Jose Reyes, who was arrested in Hawaii recently on charges of assaulting his wife, may become the first player to face discipline under Major League Baseball’s new domestic violence policy.

headline: Jams
text: Jonathan Waxman reboots the restaurant that helped bring nouvelle California cuisine to New York.

headline: Jams Gets a Reboot in Midtown
text: By the early 1980s, New Yorkers knew that something major was happening in the kitchens of California. They had heard about the revolution, but most of them hadn’t tasted it until Jonathan Waxman opened Jams in 1984. Here was a report from the West Coast front lines brought by a chef fresh from Michael’s in Santa Monica and, before that, Chez Panisse in Berkeley.

headline: New Tour Reveals Vietnam’s Many Sides
text: A new tour to Vietnam from Adventure Life combines cultural and outdoor activities in urban and rural settings. Highlights of the 12-day trip include trekking through remote Hmong villages, exploring Hanoi and spending two nights on a junk cruising around the towering limestone islands in Ha Long Bay, above. On the way back to Hanoi from Ha Long, travelers will visit the porcelain ceramics factory at Bat Trang and take a rickshaw ride along the bank of the Perfume River to the Hue Imperial City. On some days, guests will be able to choose among cycling, rock climbing or a trek to the massive Son Doong Cave in Phong Nha-Ke Bang National Park, open to the public only since 2013.

headline: Tale of Gowanus Canal’s Three-Eyed Fish May Be Too Good to Be True
text: A lot of strange things lurk in the murky, tainted depths of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. But a three-eyed catfish is very unlikely to be one of them.

headline: A ‘Star Wars’ Fan Dies After Getting His Last Wish
text: After learning that he was losing his two-year battle with cancer, Daniel Fleetwood, a longtime “Star Wars” fan, had one last wish: to see an early version of the newest film.

headline: In the South of France, a Sophisticated Ease
text: Exaggerated tailoring and classic stripes take new shape by the sea.

headline: Justice Department Opposes United-Delta Swap for Newark Landing Slots
text: The Justice Department said on Tuesday that it would seek to block United Airlines from further expanding its hold at Newark Liberty International Airport because the carrier already has a near monopoly there.

headline: Readers Respond: Kicked Off a Plane
text: Last week, several airplane passengers in Los Angeles who had boarded their Spirit Airlines flight to Dallas got kicked off the plane after an exchange over a seat that had been double-booked. (The passengers say the decision was racially motivated; the carrier says it’s looking into the matter.)

headline: Atmospheric Greenhouse Gas Levels Hit Record, Report Says
text: Global concentrations of carbon dioxide in Earth’s atmosphere surpassed 400 parts per million for a monthly average this past spring, breaching a symbolic barrier set by climate scientists and policy makers, according to a report released Monday.

headline: Prosecutors Announce More Charges in Hacking of JPMorgan Chase
text: Billing it as the largest hacking case ever uncovered, federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Tuesday described a global, multiyear scheme to steal information on 100 million customers of a dozen companies in the United States and use the data to advance stock manipulation activities, illicit online gambling and fraud.

headline: In Russia, Doping Accusations Are Taken in Stride
text: MOSCOW — The sweeping accusations that a Kremlin-backed program facilitated doping by elite Russian track-and-field athletes in the Olympics and other top sports events earned a collective shrug Tuesday from the Russian public and even, to some extent, from the officials who oversaw the debacle.

headline: Neel Kashkari, Ex-Treasury Official, Named Minneapolis Fed President
text: WASHINGTON — Neel T. Kashkari, who oversaw the government’s bailout of the banking industry as a Treasury official in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations, was named the next president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis on Tuesday.

headline: Fashion by the Sea
text: Exaggerated tailoring and classic stripes inspire a more sophisticated ease.

headline: Valeant Chief Says Issues Stem From Fast Growth
text: J. Michael Pearson, the embattled chief executive of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, sought on Tuesday to reassure investors that the once highflying company still had a solid future despite a steep fall in its stock price and growing questions about its business model and debt levels.

headline: Aziz Ansari on Acting, Race and Hollywood
text: Fisher Stevens was cooking dinner when I got him on the phone. I had wanted to talk to him for years because, as I recount in my new Netflix series, “Master of None,” this actor played a strange role in my relationship to television and film.

headline: Cuomo to Raise Minimum Wage to $15 for All New York State Employees
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday that he would unilaterally establish a $15 minimum wage for all state workers, making New York the first state to set such a high wage for its public employees.

headline: How to Watch the G.O.P. Debate
text: Republican presidential candidates will get another opportunity to share their views on the economy on Tuesday night in Milwaukee, when Fox Business Network and The Wall Street Journal host the party’s fourth debate this cycle.

headline: Deployment Solace From an Earlier Generation of Military Spouses
text: When my husband, a Navy helicopter pilot, deployed a little over a month ago, I drove our two children home in relative silence, wondering how we would handle the better part of the next year. I found my answer — my solace — in an unlikely place: love letters that aren’t mine.

headline: Meatballs and Instruction Manuals: Indiana Braces for Ikea.
text: Lingonberries, Swedish meatballs and the frustrations of furniture assembly manuals are coming to central Indiana: Ikea, the Swedish home furnishings retailer, announced plans on Tuesday to open a new store outside Indianapolis.

headline: Einat Admony’s New Restaurant Set to Open
text: Combina The chef Einat Admony’s latest restaurant, a wide room with an open kitchen and bar and an expanse of windows, will feature her trademark Israeli-Middle Eastern fare, but often with a bright Spanish inflection. The haloumi (cheese) comes dressed with chimichurri; a burger is made with merguez, the North African sausage; fried eggplant comes on a tostada; and there are salt cod doughnuts. “Not fritters, real doughnuts,” Ms. Admony said. The drinks list includes sherries, ciders, vermouths and homemade limoncello made with Moroccan-style preserved lemons. Joining her as chef in this venture is Molly Breidenthal. Lacking basement storage, the owners installed shelving all around to hold ingredients. (Opens Saturday): 330 West Broadway (Grand Street), 212-226-1248.

headline: University of Missouri Professor Who Confronted Photographer Quits Journalism Post
text: After a University of Missouri professor was seen on video calling for “some muscle” to remove a journalist from a public demonstration, the professor cut her ties to the university’s journalism school on Tuesday as protest organizers — and the professor herself — joined college officials in stating that journalists had a right to be present.

headline: Liberty Global and Discovery Communications Take Stakes in Lions Gate
text: John C. Malone, the media and telecommunications billionaire, has never been one to shy away from making deals. And in a year when he helped orchestrate one of the biggest cable transactions in recent years, he has struck another play.

headline: Senate Passes Military Bill That Bans Transfers of Guantánamo Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday approved an annual military policy bill, and the White House spokesman said President Obama would sign it despite provisions that will make it extremely difficult for him to fulfill his promise of closing the terrorist detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Reese Witherspoon, Caitlyn Jenner and Others Honored by Glamour

headline: Portugal’s Government Ousted in Challenge to Austerity
text: An alliance of left-wing Portuguese lawmakers on Tuesday brought down the government of Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho, turning the country’s politics on its head just weeks after inconclusive elections and offering up a strong new challenge to the austerity policies that have divided Europe.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner, Reese Witherspoon and Others Honor Women With Glamour
text: At the Glamour Women of the Year awards on Monday night, the dresses were designer and the heels hard to walk in, but the speeches were fiery and progressive.

headline: Helmut Schmidt, West Germany’s Assertive and Popular Chancellor
text: Mr. Schmidt, elected in 1974, pushed his country into a forceful international role during the waning Cold War years. He died Tuesday at 96.

headline: Have You Encountered Racial Conflict on Campus?
text: New York Times journalists would like to hear about readers’ experiences with racial conflict on college campuses.

headline: Why People Actually Like the Denver Airport
text: Airports are an inevitable part of the lives of most travelers. But few would say that they have a passion for them. Kim Day, the chief executive of Denver International Airport, is an exception. In a previous life, Ms. Day, 61, was an architect, and she says that shaped her career running airports. “I see the world, and airports, differently than most people,” she told the audience at the Skift Global Forum, a travel conference held last month in Brooklyn. “I can’t walk into a space without critiquing it and wanting to rearrange the furniture. And I plan every vacation around buildings and spaces around the world that I want to see.”

headline: Caution Needed on Push Into Repo Lending
text: Regional lenders like Wells Fargo, Nordea and the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group have been bulking up in repo, a form of short-term collateralized lending that principally helps nonbank financial groups fund themselves and their clients. It’s not a wholly positive trend.

headline: Montreal to Dump Raw Sewage as It Makes Repairs
text: OTTAWA — The mayor of Montreal, Denis Coderre, said Tuesday that the city would begin dumping about 2.1 billion gallons of raw sewage into the St. Lawrence River early Wednesday morning.

headline: Romania’s President Picks Dacian Ciolos as New Prime Minister
text: BUCHAREST, Romania — Romania’s president on Tuesday nominated an expert on agriculture to replace Prime Minister Victor Ponta, who was ousted last week after major demonstrations by protesters angered by graft and lethargy in the government.

headline: No Charges Against Rio Police in Fatal Shooting of 10-Year-Old Boy
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Just seven months ago, this city was stunned by images of the lifeless body of Eduardo de Jesus, a 10-year-old boy fatally shot by a police officer on the doorstep of his home. The authorities promised justice to Eduardo’s parents. Protests flared in Complexo do Alemão, the maze of cinder block homes where Eduardo lived.

headline: No Rio, Pacificação Sem Paz
text: No Alemão, uma das maiores favelas do Rio, a vaga de violência custa a vida de crianças e policiais, colocando em causa a estratégia das Unidades de Polícia Pacificadora.

The film, about the travels of a girl and a friendly beast, is expected to cost about $50 million, and will feature Jake Gyllenhaal, Tilda Swinton, Bill Nighy and others.

headline: 2 Accused of Being Russian Soldiers Appear in Court in Ukraine

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended on Wednesday
text: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: From Hotel to Hospital: The Perils of Reporting in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The last time I worried about being the victim of a poison gas attack was in Baghdad, back when we still believed in the WMD fairy tale. The last place I ever expected a poison gas attack was in a five-star hotel here in Pakistan’s capital.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Case for Tyson Foods Class-Action Lawsuit

headline: Rehabilitating a Prison

headline: Survey Finds Corporations Looking to Reduce Outside Legal Spending
text: Close to half the corporate law departments that responded to a recent survey plan to cut spending on outside legal work, according to Altman-Weil, a legal consulting firm that surveyed 258 corporate law departments. Instead, corporate counsel offices plan to parcel out more work among their own employees and to contract lawyers.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Group Abandons Plans for Inequality Forum in Iowa
text: The liberal advocacy group founded by Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York has abandoned its plans to hold a forum in Iowa focused on income inequality, bringing an abrupt and anticlimactic end to his initial efforts at shaping the economic debate in the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: New York’s Funniest Stand-Up Finalists Gear Up for a Serious Smackdown
text: It’s a maxim that stand-up comedy, like many artistic pursuits, is a marathon, not a sprint: There aren’t many lightning victories, just one long slog. But after taking part in the New York’s Funniest Stand-Up semifinals last month, Randy Syphax seemed to think that the competition gave comics an incentive to pick up the pace. “Nights like this definitely feel like someone shot a gun,” he said.

headline: Review: How to Pet a Dog and Other Gnawing Issues in ‘Going Deep With David Rees’
text: “Don’t overthink it” is usually pretty good advice; the list of things that can be made worse or less enjoyable by too much analysis is endless. But “Going Deep With David Rees” turns overthinking into an art form.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Festive Vegan Torte

headline: Russian Airplane Crash Shakes Egypt’s Tourism
text: The Oct. 31 downing of the Russian airliner Metrojet over the Sinai Peninsula of Egypt, which killed all 224 passengers and crew aboard, represents the latest blow to Egyptian tourism, which has been reeling since the 2011 Egyptian uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Hillary Clinton Pledges to Make Better Treatment of Veterans a Priority
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday called the Department of Veterans Affairs an “archaic system” that was “built for the past, not the future,” as she unveiled a multipronged set of proposals to expand care and medical services to the country’s 21.8 million veterans.

headline: Review: Flora Crockett, a Forgotten Abstract Painter
text: The paintings of the American abstractionist Flora Crockett have not been exhibited in New York since a group show at the Overseas Press Club of America in 1965. That was the year she turned 73 and began her most productive period as a painter.

headline: On ‘Mr. Misunderstood,’ Eric Church Pays Homage to His Influences
text: Eric Church is the sort of singer who sings earnestly about other singers, whose songs posit music as a magical sun shower to bathe in blissfully. In his songs, music is fuel for love, for anguish and, naturally, for other music.

headline: A Beloved L.A. Surf Hangout Gets a Second Act
text: When the Rose Café — a longtime artist hangout in Venice Beach — closed its doors earlier this year, many of its fans feared a big change was underway. But for its next incarnation, open now, the new owner Bill Chait wanted to honor the space’s history and reflect the neighborhood’s culture. So he called on Jeffrey Deitch, the New York-based art dealer and curator who just a few years earlier had served as the director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles. “We talked to Ed Ruscha, and Ed Moses, and reached out at some point to John Baldessari, and ended up talking to Craig,” Chait says, referring to the artist Craig Stecyk, who decorated the new space. “Craig knew a lot of these artists and obviously had been very involved in the Venice surf and skateboard scene, and so I think what he’s doing was very sort of trying to enhance the history of the Rose.”

headline: Oy or Yo? Sculpture With Something to Say Lands at Brooklyn Bridge
text: The rude interjection is a staple of New York life. Now, the landscape of the city will itself heckle residents and tourists, with a brash new sculpture in Brooklyn Bridge Park that yells “YO” if you are looking at it from Manhattan or “OY” if you are gazing out from Brooklyn.

headline: A Conversation With Martin Cohen
text: Mr. Cohen, 66, is the executive chairman and a founder of Cohen & Steers, a publicly traded investment company known for its real estate investment trust, or REIT, mutual funds. The company, which Mr. Cohen started in New York in 1986 with Robert Steers, was among the first to specialize in listed real estate. It manages around $50 billion in assets, which now also include infrastructure, natural resource and commodity equities.

headline: Designing Arthur Miller: Simple Gestures, Big Ideas
text: A compelling silhouette appears on the cover of a new digital edition of the playwright Arthur Miller’s “Playing for Time,” about a women’s orchestra in Auschwitz. It takes a second to notice the swastika at the base.

headline: Nevada: Lack of Oxygen Is Cited in Death in Cryotherapy Tank
text: The woman who died at a cryotherapy center in Henderson while giving herself a cold-air treatment died from lack of oxygen, the Clark County coroner’s office said Tuesday. The woman, Chelsea Ake-Salvacion, 24, was an employee at Rejuvenice, which allowed customers to spend up to three minutes encased in capsules cooled to minus 240 degrees. She was found dead in one of the chambers on Oct. 20, prompting questions about safety in the growing industry. The coroner’s office said nitrogen used to cool the chamber had displaced the oxygen Ms. Ake-Salvacion needed to breathe, and ruled her death an accident.

text: Rain tapped lightly on the windows of Dora and Motel Shkolnick’s one-bedroom apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Inside, Mr. Shkolnick, 96, and Mrs. Shkolnick, 91, sat at a dining room table and shared warm pastries she had baked.

headline: Thanksgiving for All
text: There is no more inclusive holiday on the American calendar than Thanksgiving — and perhaps no more ambitious for the home cook. From turkey to the trimmings, Sam Sifton, Melissa Clark, Julia Moskin, Eric Asimov and the editors of The New York Times Food department tell you everything you need to know to plan the menu, prepare the food and serve it all with style and grace.

headline: In Republican Debate, Candidates Battle Sharply on Immigration
text: MILWAUKEE — After weeks of personal sniping, the Republican presidential candidates clashed sharply over immigration and other policies in their debate here on Tuesday, with Gov. headline: Canada: Montreal to Dump Sewage Into River During Repair Work
text: The mayor of Montreal, Denis Coderre, said Tuesday that the city would begin dumping about 2.1 billion gallons of raw sewage into the St. Lawrence River early Wednesday. The diversion, which may continue for up to seven days, will allow workers to repair and alter a major collector sewer. “If we could have avoided this choice, we would have done it,” Mr. Coderre told reporters. After initially approving the city’s plan, the former Conservative federal government banned the city from diverting the sewage in the midst of the recent election campaign. The Conservatives were routed by the Liberal Party last month. The new Liberal government said Monday that the diversion could go ahead, provided that the city addressed concerns raised by a panel of scientists. That review found that while dumping the sewage was not ideal, it was preferable to the potential consequences of a sewer failure.

headline: A Criminal Record and a Fair Shot at a Job
text: Nineteen states and 100 cities and counties forbid public agencies — and in some cases, private businesses — to ask job applicants about criminal convictions until later in the application process, when they have had a fair chance to prove their qualifications. Last week, President Obama added the weight of the federal government to this movement when he ordered federal agencies to stop asking most people about convictions at the outset.

headline: The Misuse of Interpol’s Database
text: Fugitive alerts issued by Interpol, the international law enforcement clearinghouse, can make it hard for fugitives to slip across borders. But the group’s “red notice” database, which can be reviewed by authorities across the world to identify people facing prosecution, is frequently used by authoritarian governments to control and persecute dissidents, human rights activists and journalists.

headline: Voters, You Can Have Everything!
text: I confess, as much as I am troubled by Donald Trump’s anti-immigrant, anti-free-trade tirades, I do find The Donald’s campaign strategy truly interesting. He’s not, as people say, an “anti-politician.” He’s actually caricaturing politicians. And like any great caricaturist, Trump identifies his subject’s most salient features and then exaggerates them.

headline: How Much Do Black Lives Matter to the Presidential Campaign?
text: The onslaught of confrontations between blacks and the police, as well as intense coverage on TV and online of college campus protests and of the Black Lives Matter movement, have decisively affected the Democratic Party’s position on a core issue: the use of force to maintain public order.

headline: Hope and a Laptop for College
text: Someday, Jada Williams hopes to become a veterinarian. “I’ve always loved animals,” she said. “They always seem to make me happy.” But the path toward attaining that goal has not been an easy one.

headline: Obama Should Let Fossil Fuels Lie
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S rejection of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline last week had the ring of a great victory for the environment. But even as he declared the United States a “global leader” in the transition to cleaner energy, he revealed a challenge that neither he nor his administration has confronted: “If we’re going to prevent large parts of this earth from becoming not only inhospitable but uninhabitable in our lifetimes,” the president said, “we’re going to have to keep some fossil fuels in the ground, rather than burn them and release more dangerous pollution into the sky.”

headline: Should Drug Addicts Be Forced Into Treatment?
text: Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker wants to give hospitals the power to commit substance abusers. Is this the right approach?

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Completes Agreement for SABMiller
text: LONDON — Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Wednesday that it had completed an agreement to acquire its closest rival, SABMiller, for nearly $106 billion, creating what it said would be the first “truly global brewer.”

headline: Lessons in End-of-Life Care From the V.A.
text: The voice on the phone was that of an older man. He sounded cultured, well educated, and thoughtful. Also very angry.

headline: Who Won the Republican Debate? It’s Hard to Say
text: There was no runaway winner of the fourth Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night, according to commentators, journalists and pundits who watched. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas drew some scolding for an “oops” moment when he failed to name five agencies he wanted to eliminate, and Donald J. Trump may be remembered for shushing Carly Fiorina. But unlike after earlier debates this cycle, no consensus emerged about the outcome.

headline: Tullett Prebon Agrees to Buy ICAP’s Global Brokering Business
text: LONDON — The British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire the global brokering business of its British counterpart ICAP in an all-stock deal.

headline: Saving Richard Haas’s SoHo Mural, Chipped Away by Time and Vandals
text: The artistic equivalent of demolition by neglect is playing out in SoHo, an area of Lower Manhattan that was once synonymous with the arts.

headline: When the Famous Dressed Themselves
text: Imagine a time before the red carpet.

headline: Groupies, From Sex Symbols to Style Icons
text: Cultural photographers try to capture images others miss. But even when they do, some people don’t see what is really there.

headline: What Do We Owe Our Veterans?
text: “Thank you for your service.” It’s a common expression of gratitude that our country offers veterans. But is a quick “thank you” all we owe returning soldiers? In a society with an professional military, where fewer families have a connection to service, is there a growing disconnect between those who serve in the military and everyone else?

headline: Gordon Parks’s Harlem Argument
text: Fresh from assignments at Vogue and Glamour in 1948, Gordon Parks appeared one morning at Life’s New York headquarters, determined to show his portfolio to Wilson Hicks, the magazine’s esteemed picture editor. Mr. Hicks was initially reluctant, but he warmed to Mr. Parks’s work and the story he pitched about the gang warfare then plaguing Harlem.

headline: Singles Day in China Draws New Suitors: Foreign Sellers
text: HONG KONG — Over the last year, A2, an Australian milk company, made an unexpected discovery: A sharp increase in domestic sales came from Chinese bulk buyers, not local mothers.

headline: David Mitchell’s ‘Slade House’
text: At one point in this novel a character is led through an “aperture” into a magical, intradimensional garden. Her host is planning to dine on her soul, after using a kind of science-fiction thingy to reach in through her nostrils and pluck it out. To do this, the host must first get her victim to eat or drink something containing banjax, a substance that makes the soul easier to harvest. When she refuses to eat a wild strawberry, the would-be victim gives the following explanation: “In all the tales, the myths, the rule is, if you eat or drink anything — pomegranate seeds, faerie wine, whatever — the place has a hold on you. . . . When I’m in doubt — as I am now — I ask myself, ‘What would Carl Jung do?’ — and act accordingly.”

headline: Hotel and Resort News: Winter in New York; Holiday Packages
text: AFFORDABLE NEW YORK? THINK WINTER

headline: Apps to Improve Your Swing, Lift or Stride
text: My husband and my iPhone did not agree about my running form. My husband, eyeing me critically as I ran back and forth in our backyard while he filmed me, told me that I needed to keep my head up and stop flailing my arms like Jerry Lewis in “The Nutty Professor.”

headline: China Corruption Fight Extends to Top Officials in Beijing and Shanghai
text: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping’s sweeping crackdown on corruption has claimed senior officials in China’s two largest cities, the latest indication that Mr. Xi’s effort to consolidate power and sideline political enemies shows no signs of abating.

headline: Cybersecurity Looms as Obstacle for Nominee to Lead the Office of Personnel Management
text: Nominating someone to lead the Office of Personnel Management — the federal government’s version of the human resources department — does not typically result in a high-profile showdown. But it might be a different matter with the White House’s announcement on Tuesday that President Obama wants Beth Cobert, currently the acting director, to officially assume the top job.

headline: New York Today: Honoring Veterans
text: Updated 9:47 a.m.

headline: Glut of Coal-Fired Plants Casts Doubts on China’s Energy Priorities
text: DONGXIANPO, China — Just outside the southwest border of Beijing, a new coal-fired power and heating plant is rising in Dongxianpo, a rural town in Hebei Province. Cement mixers roll onto the site. Cranes tower above a landscape of metal girders.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Morning Agenda: Anheuser-Busch InBev Finalizes SABMiller Deal
text: ANHEUSER-BUSCH INBEV FINALIZES SABMILLER DEAL  | Anheuser-Busch InBev said it had finalized an agreement to buy its closest rival, SABMiller, for about $105 billion, Chad Bray reports in DealBook.

headline: E.U. Move to Label Israeli Settlement Goods Strains Ties
text: JERUSALEM — In a stinging rebuke to Israel, the European Union insisted on Wednesday that some goods produced on land seized in the 1967 war must be labeled “made in settlements,” a mandate that added to Israel’s deep unease over a growing international boycott.

headline: Should I Tell My Friend’s Husband That She’s Having an Affair?
text: I am a man (if it matters) and friends with a married woman, ‘‘Jane,’’ and her husband, ‘‘Peter.’’ The friendship is more with Jane than with Peter. Jane and I have known each other for years and work in the same profession, and I knew her before she married Peter, and I am closer to Jane. But Peter has become a friend since the marriage. Peter and I share some typically ‘‘male’’ interests and occasionally ‘‘bro bond.’’ Jane and I are quirky ‘‘intellectuals.’’

headline: The Dream Life of Driverless Cars
text: On a brisk afternoon in October, an oddly-­equipped Honda CR-V inched through London traffic. At the wheel was Matthew Shaw, a 32-year-old architectural designer; with him was a fellow designer, William Trossell, 30, and a small team of laser-­scanner operators. All were skilled in their technical fields, but their goal was art. What they hoped to scan was not just the shape of the city streets but the inner life of the autonomous cars that may soon come to dominate them.

headline: John Hodgman on What Makes a Creepy Christmas Card
text: Matt writes: My wife wants to include a photo with our Christmas card. We do not have children, and two adults sending out a photo of themselves seems creepy and vain. My wife says that we see the people on our card list less often than we would like, and they look forward to the photo.

headline: The Taste of Serendipity
text: ‘‘Genius,’’ E.B. White wrote, ‘‘is more often found in a cracked pot than in a whole one.’’ Judging by how many of my possessions are chipped, broken, worn, bowed and burned, it’s apparent I’ve invested in his odds. It’s not a popular attitude — certainly not in cookbooks, where kitchens often seem embodiments of sunny, enameled perfection — but I hold to it. I was particularly glad recently to open the cookbook ‘‘This Is Camino,’’ by Russell Moore and Allison Hopelain, the owners of the Oakland restaurant Camino, and find in its pages a catechism for my crackpot ways.

headline: Perfect and Unrehearsed
text: ‘‘I couldn’t believe such a thing could be caught with the camera. I said, ‘Damn it,’ took my camera and went out into the street.’’ This was Henri Cartier-Bresson’s dazzled and vexed reaction to Martin Munkacsi’s photograph of boys running into the surf in Liberia. He saw it in 1932: the dark, sinuous bodies of three African boys — their rhyming legs at the place where sea meets land; their interweaving arms dialed to varying heights; their interlocking limbs creating abstract shapes; and the grace note, on the left side, of a single silhouetted arm. This image, Cartier-Bresson said, inspired his own approach, showing him that ‘‘photography could reach eternity through the moment.’’

headline: On the Road? You Can Still Eat Like It’s Thanksgiving
text: As more travelers are on the go during Thanksgiving, many global destinations are offering traditional dinners blended with regional fare.

headline: Detroit Symphony Tackles an Adventurous Premiere
text: DETROIT — The composer Tod Machover sat on the floor in a circle of third graders one recent morning at the brightly colored, mural-filled Detroit Achievement Academy. He spoke with them about their city and asked for their help with his new piece, “Symphony in D,” which the Detroit Symphony Orchestra will play for the first time on Friday, Nov. 20.

headline: Communist Party Warns Secret Dalai Lama Followers in Its Ranks
text: BEIJING — The Chinese Communist Party in central Tibet is aiming to peer into the hearts of its members to hunt down secret worshipers of the Dalai Lama or people who secretly hold religious beliefs.

headline: Supply, Demand, and Neel Kashkari
text: So, if the Minneapolis Fed felt the need to maintain conservation of NK, they could have chosen to replace Narayana Kocherlakota with a New Keynesian. Instead, they chose Neel Kashkari. Brad DeLong isn’t happy, and this Twitter exchange suggests that he has good reason to worry.

headline: In ‘The Bedford Stop,’ Reality in Williamsburg Is the Perfect Parody
text: The young stars of an online reality show about life in Williamsburg are finding out what happens when viewers on the Internet stop being polite and start writing blog posts.

headline: Slovenia Builds Border Fence to Stem Flow of Migrants
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia — Slovenia began erecting a razor-wire fence at its border with Croatia on Wednesday to stem the inflow of migrants, as winter closes in and countries to the north tighten their own border controls.

headline: Drone Racing Dreams
text: Drone racing is a fast-growing extreme sport in which pilots compete head-to-head with small flying drones while wearing first-person-view goggles.

headline: A Day at the Drone Races
text: Images from the California Cup in Pomona, Calif., an event in the emerging sport of drone racing.

headline: What Victoria’s Secret Has to Teach Us About Fashion
text: When you tell someone — a friend, colleague, a fellow parent waiting at the school gate — that you are going to the Victoria’s Secret show to look at the clothes, you are liable to get pretty much the same response: “Clothes?”

headline: Classical Music This Week: Modern Baroque, ‘Workers Union’ and Rachmaninoff
text: Good morning, classical listeners!

headline: Boys Do Cry
text: In 1972, the former N.F.L. star Rosey Grier sang “It’s All Right to Cry” on the “Free to Be . . . You and Me” album, inviting a generation of boys to let their softer feelings show. It seemed like a watershed moment. The Vietnam War was nearing its end, and the grown-ups were emotionally exhausted. Finally, little boys would be freed from the tyranny of the tough-guy stereotype! But that hasn’t exactly happened. Perhaps even more now than in the 1970s, an ever-growing pantheon of superheroes and ninjas and other tough-guy fantasy figures surrounds American boyhood. These imaginary figures show vulnerability only in tiny doses, and preferably while they’re encased in protective, muscle-hugging spandex.

headline: Psychiatry’s Mind-Brain Problem
text: Recently, a psychiatric study on first episodes of psychosis made front-page news. People seemed quite surprised by the finding: that treatment programs that emphasized low doses of psychotropic drugs, along with individual psychotherapy, family education and a focus on social adaptation, resulted in decreased symptoms and increased wellness.

headline: Meet the Mystery Dancer Who Performed With Sia on ‘S.N.L.’
text: Who was that lithe, bewigged doppelgänger dancing next to Sia on “Saturday Night Live” this past weekend? In “Alive,” she was a karate-kicking warrior; in “Bird Set Free,” she escaped from a sheath of fabric, writhing on the floor and rising to discover her dancing voice. She wasn’t, as Rolling Stone described, a “young martial artist,” but the Butoh-trained Japanese dancer Mina Nishimura, an important presence on New York’s downtown dance scene who is still in shock about the experience of performing on television. She sees herself, she said, as a “quirky starfish, which draws attention from only a few certain people.”

headline: Briton, 74, Jailed for Having Alcohol in Saudi Arabia, Returns Home
text: LONDON — A 74-year-old British grandfather who spent more than a year in a Saudi jail for possessing homemade wine has returned home, the British foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, said on Wednesday.

headline: Gentlemen, Start Your Drones
text: LOS ANGELES — On a cool October night, after the stores in a shopping mall had closed, six young drone racers gathered in a subterranean parking garage to hone their aviation skills. Using remote-control joysticks, they navigated small X-shaped drones around pylons and beneath shopping carts, each vying for the lead.

headline: Indonesia Won’t Slide Back Into Military Rule, Security Minister Says
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia will not allow the country’s armed forces to make a political comeback and undermine civilian rule, the country’s security minister said on Wednesday, amid growing fears that Indonesia’s nascent democracy was backsliding toward its authoritarian past.

headline: Ramen Noodles With a Hell’s Angel
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Protest in Kabul for More Security After Seven Hostages Are Beheaded
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Through a persistent rain in the Afghan capital on Wednesday, thousands of protesters carried the coffins of seven beheaded Hazara hostages to the presidential palace, demanding greater security and an end to a wave of targeted violence.

headline: Europe Banks on Incentives and Persuasion to Keep Migrants Home
text: Along the Sahara trail that tens of thousands of Africans take each year to reach the shores of Italy, Europe is paying for a pit stop, of sorts — one that it hopes will give these young people on the move a reason to go back home.

headline: Why Did the ‘Twitter Revolutions’ Fail?
text: Sofia, Bulgaria — SHORTLY after Louis Napoleon’s 1851 coup in Paris, five of the greatest political minds in Europe hustled to their writing desks to capture the meaning of the events.

headline: J.C. Penney Settles Shoppers’ Suit Over False Advertising
text: The J.C. Penney Company announced on Wednesday a settlement to a class-action lawsuit that had accused the retailer of marking up prices on apparel and accessories before putting them on sale to deceive shoppers into thinking they were getting heavy discounts.

text: On a recent warm evening, the cobbled lanes around Strada Lipscani in the historical heart of Bucharest were bustling as young Romanians and tourists filled the many bars and restaurants in this once-dilapidated part of the city.

text: LONDON — Dometic Group, a Swedish maker of appliances for boats and recreational vehicles, said it could be valued at as much as 15 billion Swedish kronor, or about $1.7 billion, in an initial public offering this month.

text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

text: Here are the dishes that Dale Talde says you can’t miss in Chicago, with some commentary from the chef himself. Read more on Talde and his favorite Chicago restaurants.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Seattle’s Gum Wall
text: After accumulating for 20 years in a deeply encrusted display, about 2,200 pounds of gum is being removed from the gum wall near Pike Place Market in Seattle.

headline: Saying Goodbye a Little Longer as Seattle Scrapes Off Its Gum Wall
text: SEATTLE — William Ward sells a lot of gum. He works at a newspaper stand just around the corner from a bizarre attraction called the gum wall near Pike Place Market just off the waterfront here, and people show up unprepared. He also sells a lot of hand sanitizer.

headline: Even Famous Female Economists Get No Respect
text: Men’s voices tend to dominate economic debate, although perhaps this is shaped by how we talk about the contributions of female economists. This is easiest to see in how we discuss the work of economist power couples.

headline: Share Your Story
text: We invite you to share your experiences ​confronting issues of race in your life.

headline: ‘A Conversation With Police on Race’
text: Over the past year or so, our nation has been embroiled in a difficult conversation about our history of police brutality and racial profiling. Stories of young black men shot by officers, and footage of police behavior before many of those deaths, have raised hard questions about institutional racism and misconduct within our police force. They have sparked protests, investigations and policy changes.

headline: A City Choking on Cars Hopes Commuters Will Return to Two Wheels
text: BEIJING — In the early morning haze, Sun Jian pedaled his bicycle along a bustling ring road in Beijing, dodging buses and cars as he weaved his way through multiple lines of traffic.

headline: Drinking In the Beauty of Picasso’s Sculptures at MoMA
text: At the moment, Lynda Zycherman, the Museum of Modern Art’s sculpture conservator, is in her element. She’s supervising what might be called the care and feeding of the 120 objects in the Modern’s extraordinary “Picasso Sculpture,” an array that traces the artist’s breathtaking inventiveness in bronze, wood, clay, plaster, sheet metal and stones through six decades.

headline: Both Parties Have Equal Chance to Win White House
text: It’s a mismatch — and an even match.

text: With mountain and sea views from its back deck, the home is on the market for $1.291 million.
