text: A COTSWOLD COTTAGE-STYLE HOME IN VICTORIA, BRITISH COLUMBIA

headline: App Smart | Apple TV Apps
text: New devices for the televisionlike Apple TV can now run apps, including shopping apps like Gilt and games like Asphalt 8.

headline: Video Feature: Playing to the Strengths of the New Apple TV
text: The new Apple TV has been out for only about two weeks, but there are already hundreds of apps available for downloading to the set-top box. The apps have the potential to make your television truly “smart,” so it’s time to experiment with the best gaming, shopping, video and utility apps and see how they transform the set in your living room.

headline: Airbnb Pledges to Work With Cities and Pay ‘Fair Share’ of Taxes
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A week ago, Airbnb  fired off a warning shot to cities that it would fight back if municipal officials proposed rules that might curtail its home-sharing service.

headline: A Software Firm That Wines and Dines the Restaurant Industry
text: Celebrity chefs and other food maestros who oversee four- and five-star restaurants are a discerning and confident lot who typically don’t like anyone outside interfering with — let alone offering advice on — how they buy ingredients for their menus.

headline: A Typical American Life, a Very American Death
text: Last month, after working a long shift at the hospital, I walked to a restaurant in my neighborhood to have dinner with a male friend. The weather was unseasonably warm, so we ate outside. As we sat talking, our conversation was interrupted by something that sounded like a car backfiring. We paused, made a joke about the crowd at the nearby grocery store, and continued our meal. On my walk home, I didn’t notice the flashing lights at the end of my street.

headline: 1940: Czechs and Poles Drop Feuds
text: LONDON — Laying the groundwork for a possible new order in central Europe, the Polish government and the provisional government of Czecho-Slovakia buried their past quarrels and jointly declared today [Nov. 11] their intention at the end of the war to enter into a closer economic and political association. The two governments-in-exile expressed the hope that they would be joined by other countries in the same part of Europe, and that free people throughout the world would help their cause by combating the German menace to the full extent of their power. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 12, 1940

headline: Ranking George Washington, the General
text: The 1918 truce that halted fighting in World War I went into effect at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month. Today, that is commemorated in the U.S. as Veterans Day.

headline: They’re With the Band
text: A book by the photographer Baron Wolman shows the playful energy and style of the classic groupies of the late 1960s.

headline: Ex-Allies of Christie Didn’t Receive Evidence in Lane Closings Case, Lawyers Say
text: Lawyers for two former allies of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey have complained to a federal court that prosecutors and the governor’s lawyers had not provided emails and other documents related to the scheme to snarl traffic at the entrance to the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.

headline: Rankings Indicate Big 12 Could Miss College Football Playoff Again
text: With the release of the season’s second college football playoff rankings, the pecking order at the top continues to clarify. If No. 1 Clemson wins the Atlantic Coast Conference, No. 2 Alabama the Southeastern Conference and No. 3 Ohio State the Big Ten, and if No. 4 Notre Dame wins the rest of its independent schedule, they are likely to be the four teams in the playoff.

headline: ‘Incident at Vichy,’ a Revival of Arthur Miller’s Harrowing Wartime Drama
text: Guilt is as inescapable as oxygen in the works of Arthur Miller, whose centennial is being celebrated this season with a formidable assortment of revivals, including Broadway productions of “A View From the Bridge” and “The Crucible.” But seldom did he dissect the nature of moral responsibility as rigorously as he did is in his lesser-known “Incident at Vichy” (1964), which opens Sunday, Nov. 15, in a Signature Theater production. Set in France during World War II, the play centers on a group of male detainees, most of them Jewish, who have been rounded up by German and French officers for interrogation. As the men try to figure out why they have been brought together, their conversation widens to embrace the most fundamental questions of identity, both ethnic and ethical. Michael Wilson (“The Orphans’ Home Cycle”) directs a cast that includes Richard Thomas and Jonathan Hadary. (Through Dec. 13, Pershing Square Signature Center, Manhattan; 212-244-7529, signaturetheater.org.)

headline: Macy’s Lowers Its Guidance on Sales Slump
text: A slump in tourist spending and warmer weather hit Macy’s business in the third quarter, driving sales lower and prompting the department store chain to lower its guidance for the year.

headline: Jean Butler Brings Her Irish Dance to St. Mark’s Church
text: This tale of two Irish dance stars began with a six-minute performance at the Eurovision Song Contest in Dublin in 1994. They were the central couple backed up by a rousing ensemble: Jean Butler, a poised redhead, and Michael Flatley, a flamboyant blond in a shiny teal blouse who would later become the self-proclaimed Lord of the Dance. Together, they created and starred in “Riverdance,” the international megahit spawned by that TV appearance.

headline: At University of Missouri, Black Students See a Campus Riven by Race
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — At first, Briana Gray just chalked up the comments and questions from her new roommate at the University of Missouri to innocent ignorance: How do you style your hair? What do you put in it?

headline: A Philharmonic Menu of Young Composers
text: American composers 40 and under are the focus of the New York Philharmonic’s latest Contact! new-music concert, on Monday, Nov. 16. The first Contact! to be hosted at the recently opened performance space National Sawdust, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the event features chamber works by Kate Soper, Adam Schoenberg, Nathan Heidelberger and Caroline Mallonée. Mario Davidovsky, born in Argentina but a resident of the United States for the past half-century, represents an older generation with his sextet “Flashbacks.” (7:30 p.m., 80 North Sixth Street, 646-779-8455, nationalsawdust.org.)

headline: ‘The Art of More,’ on Crackle, Reveals the Ugly Side of Pretty Things
text: Sex, blood, dirty money. “Smuggled, stolen and forged art is a $10 billion business,” intones a voice more Bensonhurst than Beekman Place. “The big collectors are more than willing to look the other way.” That’s where Graham Connor (Christian Cooke) — a former soldier in Iraq turned antiquities thief who has maneuvered his way into a top Manhattan auction house — comes in. “I get them to look my way,” he says in “The Art of More,” a new series streaming Thursday, Nov. 19, on Crackle.

headline: In ‘Fat City,’ Boxing Has a Starring Role
text: Another “Rocky” movie, this one called “Creed,” is just days away from release, but before the manipulative hero-making of that franchise, there was John Huston’s “Fat City,” a whole different kind of boxing movie. A new restoration of it begins a one-week run on Friday, Nov. 20, at Film Forum, and Leonard Gardner, who wrote both the screenplay and the novel it was based on, is scheduled to be on hand at the opening night showing at 7 to introduce this 1972 movie. The film was an early showcase for Stacy Keach and Jeff Bridges, Mr. Bridges playing a young boxer just starting out, Mr. Keach a somewhat older one who tries a comeback. In his review in The New York Times, Vincent Canby had high praise for the acting and for the script, “full of the kind of dialogue that movies usually can’t afford, that defines time, place, mood and character while seemingly going nowhere.” (At 209 West Houston Street, South Village; 212-727-8110, filmforum.org.)

headline: Living In Easton, Conn.
text: Easton is home to at least 20 farms of varying sizes, from part-time specialty operations to large-scale agritourism attractions.

headline: Easton, Conn.: Embracing a Farming Culture
text: Patti and Allan Popp didn’t move to the rural town of Easton, Conn., to take up farming. They were simply searching for more privacy than they had at their previous home in Stratford. Ms. Popp happened to fall in love with a 1740 house in foreclosure along one of Easton’s main routes, Sport Hill Road.

headline: Coltrane’s ‘A Love Supreme,’ Rereleased and Celebrated at Lincoln Center
text: The saxophonist John Coltrane released his most revered album, “A Love Supreme,” on the Impulse! label in 1965, and from the start it was understood as something special: a four-part suite that drew Coltrane’s magnificent quartet into deep, devotional focus. The album has been reissued in a deluxe edition before, but a boxed set due out on Friday, Nov. 20, “A Love Supreme: The Complete Masters,” offers the deepest dive yet, with alternate takes, studio chatter, photo reproductions and a new essay by Ashley Kahn, who once wrote a book on the subject.

headline: Coney Island Culture, at the Brooklyn Museum
text: It is a microcosm of American popular culture in all its ersatz glory, the anti-Disneyland, a realm of tawdry spectacle and mindless distraction catering to the basic instincts of hoi polloi. It is, of course, Coney Island, whose history and culture are chronicled in “Coney Island: Visions of an American Dreamland, 1861-2008,” opening Friday, Nov. 20, at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Le1f Speaks Out, Like His Fearless Models, on ‘Riot Boi’
text: On his first full-length album, “Riot Boi,” the New York rapper Le1f is playful, painfully clever, aloof, outraged and deadly serious, often in the span of a few lines. “Rats and roaches running all over the hood in the daytime,” he begins on Track 1, “but I still don’t see none of that in their raps, their rhymes or their headlines.” Topical issues covered across the 12 songs include homophobia, misogyny, transgender rights and Black Lives Matter. “You just wanna ignore it all, don’t you?” Le1f scoffs. “Basic.”

headline: Empathy Card Contest: And the Winner Is . . .
text: Last week, we introduced Well readers to Emily McDowell, a writer and graphic artist, and her line of empathy cards, a series of greeting cards that helps provide support during times of serious illness and loss.

headline: Is Fat Stigma Making Us Miserable?
text: Being overweight doesn’t necessarily make a person distraught, researchers are learning. Rather, it’s the teasing, judgment and unsolicited advice directed at overweight people that can cause the greatest psychological harm.

headline: Facebook’s Notify App Funnels Custom Updates Onto Phone Screens
text: In this age of data overload, information providers and social networks are competing to provide just the highlights that you want, when you want them. News outlets send alerts with breaking news and editors’ picks of top stories. Twitter curates top tweets, organized by subject, into collections it calls Moments. Weather apps warn you of rain minutes before the droplets arrive.

headline: There’s ‘Kung Fu,’ and, in ‘Into the Badlands,’ There’s Hong Kong Kung Fu
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF. — In AMC’s new martial arts series, “Into the Badlands,” Daniel Wu plays Sunny, a motorcycle-riding, katana-wielding assassin whose loyalty to his flinty-eyed master is matched only by his prodigious kill count (400 and climbing).

headline: Lauren Pritchard on Her Musical Childhood and Her New Show, ‘Songbird’
text: One grandfather played ukulele at family gatherings while she was growing up in Jackson, Tenn., and the other was a Hank Williams fan, so perhaps it’s unsurprising that Lauren Pritchard was evolving as a singer-songwriter before she was 10.

headline: Podcast: Beware Fine Print
text: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery share insight into their report on arbitration and the way it circumvents justice for millions of Americans.

headline: A Lesson in Journalism at the University of Missouri
text: To the Editor:

headline: 1965: Rhodesia Claims Independence
text: SALISBURY — Rhodesia today [Nov. 11] declared its independence in the most momentous defiance of Britain since America threw off colonial rule nearly 200 years ago. The white-ruled colony in the heart of Africa immediately found itself outlawed in a largely hostile world. Britain imposed economic sanctions and called for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to recruit world-wide support. In Pretoria, South African Premier Dr. Hendrik Verwoerd declared that his country would continue normal relations with Rhodesia, thus becoming the first government to recognize the ‘‘rebel’’ nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 12, 1965

headline: Great Midweek Recipes
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. Beginning today, that email will also appear on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Another Setback for Immigration Action
text: President Obama’s effort to overhaul the immigration system through executive action has lost in court again. On Monday a federal appeals-court panel, in a 2-1 vote, blocked the administration from moving forward with programs to shield up to 5 million people from deportation.

headline: Review: In ‘The Bachelors,’ Three Men Are Mired in Frat-Boy Misogyny
text: It’s Friday night on fraternity row in the unnamed college town of Caroline V. McGraw’s “The Bachelors.” But by the end of this unlikely comedy, presented by Lesser America and Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, no one feels much like a party.

headline: Cruz vs. Rubio: The Overture
text: The most interesting story out of last night’s Republican debate is probably the one written up by McKay Coppins here: In several different moments we watched a preview of the way that Ted Cruz intends to go after Marco Rubio if and when the field begins to winnow and the two of them rise toward the top. Coppins cites a couple of Cruz lines on immigration and sugar subsidies that were clearly implied digs at Rubio; I would add Cruz’s stress on how his own tax and spending plan adds up (it doesn’t, really, but compared to Rubio’s it does) and his attempt to position himself in between Rubio and Paul when the two clashed on foreign policy. Add them all together and you have a clear blueprint for an anti-Rubio offensive: Attack sharply on immigration, find his Floridian weakness on corporate welfare, claim the mantle of fiscal hawkishness at home and cast Rubio as a little too Wilsonian abroad.

headline: New Marco Rubio Backer Bankrolls Ad and Writes It, Too
text: Senator Marco Rubio’s newest financial backer not only bankrolls his own super PAC, but also writes its TV ads.

headline: Unicredit of Italy to Cut 18,200 Jobs as Part of Overhaul
text: LONDON — UniCredit, Italy’s largest bank by assets, said on Wednesday that it would eliminate up to 18,200 jobs and accelerate its cost-cutting over the next three years as part of a revamping of its operations that it hopes will help it avoid the need for a capital increase.

headline: Weighing Benefits of Windows 10 Upgrade
text: Q. Should I update to Windows 10 now that I’ve gotten used to Windows 8.1? How big a change is it?

headline: What It Takes to Save a Mockingjay
text: LONDON — The pressure is on. The endgame is near. There will be blood, brutality, death and scary lizard mutants smashing through a sewer. The final film installment of Suzanne Collins’s best-selling trilogy, “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2,” will reach American screens on Friday, Nov. 20, and millions of fans worldwide will scrutinize the movie for its fidelity to the books; the portrayal (by Jennifer Lawrence) of its intrepid, taciturn heroine Katniss Everdeen; and its evocation of the civil war that rends Panem, the totalitarian state built from the ashes of North America at some unspecified time in the future.

headline: 10 Years With Times Video
text: Erik Olsen, senior video journalist, talks about a decade of filmmaking with The Times.

headline: Stephen Colbert to Follow 2016 Super Bowl
text: CBS is handing the coveted post-Super Bowl programming block to its newest late-night host, Stephen Colbert.

headline: Bottles Upon Bottles of Wine at Heights Chateau
text: The wine shop on a stretch between Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill is an oenophile’s apothecary.

headline: At Heights Chateau, a Welcoming Home for Wine Lovers
text: On a recent brisk Saturday afternoon, at the point where the tail of Atlantic Avenue dips toward New York Harbor, wine and spirits buyers ducked into Heights Chateau to assemble their weekend libations. Behind an antique-looking facade, the store is an oenophile’s apothecary.

headline: At Paradise Cove, Where Less is More
text: America’s most glamorous trailer park, Paradise Cove in Malibu, has million-dollar views, hip residents and a location on one of the world’s most iconic beaches.

headline: Justin Bieber Announces 58-Date ‘Purpose’ Tour
text: Justin Bieber’s all-grown-up album, “Purpose,” comes out on Friday, and all the final pieces are falling into place for his meticulously crafted, apology-filled comeback. After a steady stream of convincing singles, including “Where Are Ü Now,” made with Diplo and Skrillex, and “What Do You Mean?”, Mr. Bieber’s first No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100, he has announced a 58-date North American tour for 2016, promoted by AEG Live.

headline: America’s Most Glamorous Trailer Park
text: In 1979, David Carter, then a 30-year-old surfer, decided to move from Maui, where he’d spent a few years chasing waves and making surfboards, to Southern California. He and his wife were in search of that real estate oxymoron: an affordable place close to the ocean where they could raise their two sons. On the advice of friends, they went to visit a curious little subdivision called Paradise Cove, a private waterfront community of 265 trailers in Malibu.

headline: Steelers’ Antonio Brown Has Been Only as Good as His Quarterback
text: N.F.L. wide receivers are some of the most athletic people on the planet. Speed, leaping ability and the ability to change directions quickly are hallmarks of the position.

headline: Silicon Valley Tries to Alter Your Perception of Cannabis
text: One morning in September, I logged on to the website of HelloMD, a medical start-up that promises to connect patients with doctors instantly over the Internet. I filled out my personal details, explained my ailment — I often get heartburn — and entered in my credit card number to cover the $50 consultation fee.

headline: Podcast: Beware the Fine Print
text: Arbitration clauses. They sound innocuous enough. But, in a three part-series about clauses buried in tens of millions of contracts, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery (along with another reporter, Robert Gebeloff) reported on the way these clauses have deprived Americans of one of their most fundamental constitutional rights: their day in court.

headline: Daily Report: Breezes Could Become Headwinds in Silicon Valley
text: For months now, the scorching tech industry has shown signs of feeling a slight breeze. As early as September, for example, Nicole Perlroth reported that some security start-ups, used to easily raising new money, were being asked something almost novel: Where are the profits?

headline: Bridget Anne Kelly Court Filings
text: Lawyers for Bridget Anne Kelly filed discovery motions.

headline: Bill Baroni Court Filings
text: Lawyers for Bill Baroni filed motions seeking evidence and a change of venue.

headline: The Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show
text: Top models, such as Gigi Hadid and Kendall Jenner, donned feathers and jewels on the runway at the Victoria’s Secret fashion show.

headline: Borrowing From Solar and Chip Tech to Make Diamonds Faster and Cheaper
text: Just a decade ago, Silicon Valley had high hopes of becoming a vibrant manufacturing center by making solar panels. But price competition from abroad, particularly from China, quickly dashed those dreams.

headline: In the Studio With Marques’Almeida
text: T visits Portuguese design duo Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida at work in Hackney, London.

headline: Review: Michael Flatley’s New Show Has Unicorns, Rainbows and Some Footwork, Too
text: The main reason to see Michael Flatley’s “Lord of the Dance: Dangerous Games,” which opened on Tuesday at the Lyric Theater, is to watch Michael Flatley dancing. It’s your last chance. This Irish-American step-dancing star, now 57, has announced that he will retire from performing at the end of this eight-week run. The trouble is, to see Michael Flatley dancing, you have sit through a Michael Flatley show.

headline: A Debate With Bernanke Over the Fed’s Easy Money Policies
text: By the end of our recent conversation, Ben S. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, and I had a gentleman’s bet. I believe the easy money policies he pushed for and put in place while serving as Fed chairman starting in 2008 (and that remain in place under his successor, Janet L. Yellen) will lead inevitably to a near-term financial crisis; he thinks that idea is beyond ridiculous.

headline: Inside the Denim-Filled Studio of Marques’Almeida
text: Since winning the LVMH prize, Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida have focused their energy on growing their brand. T visits them at work in Hackney, London.

headline: 7 on Business Trip Among Dead in Akron Plane Crash
text: A Florida company confirmed Wednesday that seven of its employees were on a private jet that crashed into an apartment building in Akron, Ohio, on Tuesday, bringing the death toll to nine.

headline: To Win a Free I.V.F. Cycle, Contestants Share Losses, Grief and Hope. Is it Worth It?
text: “Please,” the woman says, staring directly into the camera at the end of a video that lays bare her infertility, her attempts, her losses, her hopes, her dreams, her fears. “Vote for me.”

headline: Confrontation Brews as Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Vie for Conservative Vote
text: After a Republican presidential debate in which sober policy discussions edged out the loud personality clashes that have dominated so far, the campaign’s focus narrowed on Wednesday into a battle for the party’s most conservative voters.

headline: Saks Fifth Avenue
text: The landmark store opened in 1924.

headline: Shelley Poem, 200 Years Later, Returns to Oxford
text: LONDON — A poem written by Percy Bysshe Shelley during his first year as an Oxford student has been acquired by the Bodleian Libraries there and placed on public display.

headline: With Los Angeles in Play, Cities and Teams Update N.F.L. on Plans
text: The N.F.L. season is just past the halfway mark, but team owners are already preparing for the biggest decision of the new year: whether to allow one or two teams to move to Los Angeles in 2016.

headline: Michael Leonard, Whose Songs From Failed Musicals Endured, Dies at 84
text: Michael Leonard, a composer and arranger whose songs, especially from the 1965 musical “The Yearling,” lived on as standards for singers like Barbra Streisand and Nancy Wilson, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Republican Debate Draws 13 Million Viewers as Ratings Slip
text: More than 13 million people tuned in to Fox Business Network to watch the fourth Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night in Milwaukee, according to Nielsen ratings data provided on Wednesday by the business news network.

headline: Waiting for the Republican Shakeout
text: Watching Tuesday’s Republican presidential debate, with the eight prime-time contenders talking over and past one another, the question arises: Should the party show a few of these candidates the door?

headline: Goose Barnacle Caters to Its Brooklyn Neighbors
text: The other afternoon, a sharp-looking guy opened the door of Goose Barnacle and asked for help. The old-style door — the heavy wooden kind where one side bolts into the ceiling and floor — was only half open, and therefore not wide enough for what he was pushing, which was a stroller.

headline: Why Has Trust in the News Media Declined?
text: Why do so many people say they distrust journalists, and what does that mean?

headline: Buffalo Bills at New York Jets: Who Has the Edge?
text: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: On the Road in Syria, Struggle All Around
text: RMEILAN, Syria — After boiling crude oil from the ground near here all day in a metal tank to refine it into diesel, Ali Mohammed braved the fumes to bang the tank’s drain open with a shovel. He stepped back as the dregs oozed into the dirt and burst into flames.

headline: Shia LaBeouf Offers View of Himself Viewing His Movies
text: Shia LaBeouf, an actor whose erratic behavior often veers into the realm of bizarre performance art, has invited us all to watch him watch his movies — all 29 of them, in reverse chronological order.

headline: Amundi Raises $1.6 Billion in I.P.O. in Paris
text: LONDON — Amundi, one of the largest asset managers in Europe, said on Wednesday that it had raised 1.5 billion euros, or about $1.6 billion, in its initial public offering of stock in Paris.

headline: South Africa Court Sentences 8 Ex-Policemen in Immigrant’s Murder
text: LONDON — A South African judge on Wednesday sentenced eight former police officers to prison for the murder of a taxi driver from Mozambique who was handcuffed to the back of a police van, dragged about a third of a mile and then placed in a police holding cell, where he was beaten.

headline: Philosophers (and Welders) React to Marco Rubio’s Debate Comments
text: Philosophers say the discipline prepares them for a range of useful career choices, while welders say their skill is always in demand and touches most parts of the economy.

headline: Effort to Revive City Opera Includes a ‘Tosca’ Staging
text: If the death of New York City Opera was tragic, attempts to revive it have sometimes entered the farcical territory of opera buffa: a bidding contest for its name that yielded no sale, a legal battle and a skirmish over a bequest from a patron who died just as the company did.

headline: A Landscape of Blooms, in Dorset
text: Charlie McCormick takes a modern approach to a traditional English country garden.

headline: Egyptian President Makes First Visit to Sharm El Sheikh Since Russian Crash
text: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The Egyptian president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, made an unannounced, and somewhat belated, visit to this seaside town on Wednesday, saying he was here to “reassure people” after a Russian plane that took off from the local airport broke apart in midair over the Sinai Peninsula late last month.

headline: An English Garden for All Seasons
text: In Dorset, Charlie McCormick has created an embroidered tapestry of blooms that lasts well into fall.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Deal for SABMiller Pays Off for Molson
text: Molson Coors Brewing is getting a tasty chaser from its rivals’ mega-deal.

headline: Donald Trump’s ‘Deportation Force’
text: Some of Donald Trump’s rivals mocked him at the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night for saying he could deport 11 million unauthorized immigrants.

headline: European and African Leaders Near Deal on Returning Migrants
text: VALLETTA, Malta — The European Union was closing in on a deal Wednesday to return more migrants to Africa, but there was skepticism that the plan would meet the goal of reducing the numbers of refugees arriving in Germany, Scandinavia and other destinations.

headline: Promised Bipartisanship, Obama Adviser Found Disappointment
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama first won the White House, he recruited Ray LaHood, a Republican congressman, to join his cabinet. The appointment, Mr. Obama said, “reflects that bipartisan spirit” that would distinguish his presidency.

headline: Israelis Condemn E.U. Labeling Move
text: Officials from Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization disagreed on whether the European Union should label goods from Israeli settlements, and a factory manager spoke out against the move.

headline: Expansion of T-Mobile Data Plans Comes With Higher Prices
text: The phone carrier T-Mobile USA made lots of noise this week about allowing many subscribers to stream content from some video services over their cellular connections without burning through their data allotments — so much noise that it was easy to overlook that T-Mobile also raised prices on many of its data plans.

headline: Donald Trump Insists That Wages Are ‘Too High’
text: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday morning repeated a statement he made the night before in the Republican presidential debate: that wages are “too high” in the United States, an argument he made to explain his opposition to raising the minimum wage.

headline: VW’s Emissions-Test Trickery May Not Be Illegal in Europe
text: LONDON — Four years ago, European auto regulators identified and debated a loophole in their pollution testing rules that could render vehicle emissions tests ineffectual, but it was ultimately left in place, internal documents show.

headline: In Iowa, Jeb Bush Tries to Capitalize on Latest Debate Performance
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa — It wasn’t quite a victory lap. Call it more of a coffee klatch lap.

headline: Elizabeth, N.J., Explosion Kills One and Injures 15
text: A man in his 20s was killed and 15 people were injured in an explosion at a two-story duplex in Elizabeth, N.J., on Wednesday morning, city officials said. Investigators believe it was related to gas.

headline: The Flat Tax Goes Mainstream
text: Remember when the flat tax was a fringe idea? Competitors and others derided it when Steve Forbes made it the center of his 1996 presidential campaign. Though Mr. Forbes won the Arizona and Delaware primaries, he did poorly in Iowa and New Hampshire and dropped out of the race in March of that year. He did even worse in 2000, finishing third in the Delaware primary and ending his campaign soon after.

headline: Cuomo Signs 2 Bills to Speed Up Medical Marijuana Distribution
text: ALBANY — In a surprising move, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed two bills on Wednesday to establish an “emergency medical marijuana” program for qualified patients, two months before the planned debut of a statewide program providing for the medical use of the drug.

headline: Review: ‘W/ Bob & David’ Resumes a ‘Mr. Show’ Vibe
text: The great television resurrection machine has been busy lately. Fox is bringing back “The X-Files” next year. Showtime is reviving “Twin Peaks.” Netflix brought back “Arrested Development,” is making a sequel to the family comedy “Full House” and is reportedly planning the return of “Gilmore Girls.” Death, for a TV show, is an increasingly temporary state, as long as enough mourners are lighting the candles.

headline: The Modern Princess, On and Off the Runway
text: Inspired by young girls’ fantasies (and a hint of irony), designers have begun to think pink.

headline: Review: ‘Aquaria,’ a Dark Debut Album by Boots
text: “Aquaria”

headline: When a Child’s Project Shows a Parental Hand at Work
text: When my younger son, Finn, was in third grade, his class staged a wax museum as the culmination of a biography project. Each student researched a historical figure they admired, prepared a monologue about that person’s life and historical significance, and on the day of the wax museum presentation, dressed up like their chosen hero. As no academic project is complete without the requisite trifold poster, each student also had to create an illustrated, informative display.

headline: El País Columnist Says Dismissal Tied to His Criticism of Media Independence
text: MADRID — A veteran journalist said on Wednesday that El País, Spain’s leading newspaper, had ended his column after he questioned editorial independence in Spain in an article in The New York Times about the growing financial and government pressures on the Spanish news media that also discussed recent newsroom tensions at El País and other publications.

headline: To Reach the Truly Rich, Television Ads Won’t Do
text: Private jets. Grand estates. Fast cars. High fashion.

headline: Investing in Racehorses, Despite the Long Odds
text: One morning this past summer, Ahmed Zayat was in a stall at Del Mar racetrack in California alongside the 2015 Triple Crown winner American Pharoah.

headline: Stronger Dollar Emboldens More Americans to Seek European Dream Home
text: BARCELONA — With the exchange rate against the euro persistently not in his favor and his retirement still 20 years away, Dr. Kenneth Bermudez had decided to delay his dream of owning a villa in Tuscany, Italy.

headline: ‘Supersavers’ Focus on the Goal
text: During the 2007-8 financial crisis, Chris Reining said, he panicked. His state of anxiety wasn’t brought on by the collapse of the United States stock market or the global economic crisis that followed. It was prompted by his office mates in Madison, Wis.

headline: Making an Adviser Relationship Work
text: In spring 2001, after losing about $75,000 in the dot-com crash, Jerrie Champlin and her husband, Robert Baranowski, decided it was time for professional help.

headline: For Investors, ‘Portfolio Insurance’ Against Market Declines
text: Whenever the stock market shows a bad hand, as it did in the third quarter, nearly all stock investors hope they have something akin to an ace in the hole.

headline: Plan Your Digital Legacy, and Update Often
text: Andrew Magliochetti, 38, always feared dying without an estate plan. In his 20s, he prepared a will. But after consulting with his money manager, Mr. Magliochetti took an even more unusual step: He listed his digital assets, which include digitized family movies and social media accounts, as well as some assets that are more esoteric, like digital currencies and domain names.

headline: India’s Rising Tides and Temperatures
text: Ghoramara and its sister islands in the Bay of Bengal are vanishing, their shoreline borders shifting, shrinking and sinking with rising temperatures and tides.

headline: Giving Up the Affluent Suburbs for City Living
text: Pete Fader often looks eagerly out the window of his office in West Philadelphia, where he is a marketing professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, at the rising One Riverside, a 22-story luxury condominium building across the Schuylkill.

headline: Estate Planning for the Never-Married
text: When Adam Cooperman opened a technology consulting firm in New York City eight years ago at age 33, he also prepared a will and other legal and medical documents. “If I have all these professional matters, I should probably have my personal affairs in order, as well,” he explained.

headline: Stormy Markets Today May Offer Steady Growth Tomorrow
text: There are times when a cautious investor can take risks that a rough-and-ready speculator cannot.

headline: Irrational Game Aims to Steer Consumers Toward Rational Choices
text: In his 2008 best-selling book, “Predictably Irrational,” Dan Ariely, a Duke University professor of psychology and behavioral economics, proposed the idea of a “self-control credit card.”

headline: The Metal Chair, Elevated
text: Two major design fairs are on the horizon: the Salon Art + Design in New York this week and Design Miami at the beginning of December. But before they open, a trio of New York shows are making a case for investing in industrial metal furniture this fall. At Friedman Benda, Paul Cocksedge debuted a room of furniture cast entirely of metal. The London-based designer achieved seamless joints using an experimental sealing technique that uses freezing in place of welding. A haven for self-reflection, Cocksedge’s circular tables and mirrored bookshelves possess unexpected warmth — perhaps it’s the touch of brass?

headline: Jeb Bush Says He’s ‘a Better Bet’ (Than Marco Rubio) to Beat Hillary Clinton
text: ATLANTIC, Iowa — Though Jeb Bush stood alongside Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Tuesday night at the Republican debate, he largely steered clear of his former-mentee-turned-political-rival.

headline: An Old Chinatown Lounge Gets a New Life
text: Looking to wade through the squalor of an after-hours party but lack the endurance for all-nighters? That’s the subtext of Tropical, a gucky 14-year-old lounge that has surged in popularity since new owners took over recently.

headline: Republican Debate on Fox Business Draws 13.5 Million
text: Fox Business Network has long stood in the shadow of its much larger and louder sibling, Fox News Channel, and its outsize personalities like Bill O’Reilly. And in the financial world, the network consistently trails its competitor CNBC in television ratings.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear Mr. You,’ Mary-Louise Parker Writes to Men, With Lust and Rue
text: Mary-Louise Parker, the luminous, bright-eyed actress, makes her literary debut with the equivalent of a one-woman show. Even though “Dear Mr. You” is nominally about men, there’s no question about who has the starring role. This book is enchantingly arranged as a set of letters to men who have mattered to Ms. Parker, many of them alive only in her memory or imagination. But the narrator has endless ways of upstaging them, and why not? They exist in “Dear Mr. You” only to define who Mary-Louise Parker is and how she got that way.

headline: Take Two: George Saunders and Carly Rae Jepsen
text: George Saunders and Carly Rae Jepsen go ballistic while considering a levitating light and the most expensive socks ever made.

headline: Velvet Suits Are a Holiday Alternative to Sparkly Dresses
text: Plus: Fort Gansevoort, a space for artisans, also serves barbecue; Live the Process and Moon Juice team up on workout wear and Annie Costello Brown offers dangly cutout earrings.

headline: Ruth Bell’s Breakout Fashion Season
text: Ms. Bell was one of the star models from the spring 2016 shows.

headline: First Draft Focus: In Memory of the Fallen
text: President Obama participated in a wreath-laying ceremony Wednesday in honor of Veterans Day at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Tarantino’s ‘The Hateful Eight’ Resurrects Nearly Obsolete Technology
text: LOS ANGELES — When Quentin Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight” is released in a special roadshow version (with overture, intermission and additional footage) on Dec. 25, it will represent a feat worthy of the heist in the director’s “Jackie Brown.”

headline: Model Ruth Bell’s Star-Is-Born Tale Comes With a Set of Clippers
text: Ruth Bell, 19, of Deal, England, wears her hair clipped close to her skull and bleached the color of creamed butter. Seen from behind, it gives her the aspect of a baby chick; from the front, coupled with her soft seaside accent, of a holdover from the Victorian era, a fever patient bravely accepting her cropping cure.

headline: Serbia to Give $5.4 Million to Bosnian Town, Site of 1995 Massacre
text: LONDON — Serbia’s prime minister said Wednesday that his country was donating about $5.4 million to foster economic development in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica, where about 8,000 Muslim men and boys were massacred by Bosnian Serb forces in 1995.

headline: Yankees Acquire Twins’ Aaron Hicks in Quest for Younger Lineup
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — When the Yankees were in Minnesota in late July, Twins center fielder Aaron Hicks ranged far into the spacious gaps to run down deep drives by Jacoby Ellsbury and Brian McCann. The next night, he belted a long home run off C. C. Sabathia in the first inning.

headline: At Doc NYC, Women’s (Film) Work
text: Thom Powers, the artistic director of Doc NYC, the largest festival of documentary films in the country, said he didn’t realize what he had done until after this year’s lineup of 104 features was released. Someone else had to point out to him that his opening night, closing night and centerpiece selections were all directed or co-directed by women.

headline: IAC/InterActiveCorp Offers to Buy Angie’s List
text: The Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp offered on Wednesday to buy Angie’s List, the repository of online reviews for home repairs and other services, for about $512 million, taking its offer public after being rebuffed.

headline: Review: ‘Book of Hanging Gardens,’ Sung by Christian Gerhaher
text: Schoenberg’s “The Book of Hanging Gardens” is an atonal song cycle based on poems by Stefan George that obsessively dissect a love affair in 15 feverish, labile verses. The German baritone Christian Gerhaher, who gave a vulnerable and intense performance of the work in the Park Avenue Armory’s Board of Officers Room on Tuesday, has said that the cycle is “like Christmas, 15 times over.” In a book of conversations published in Germany earlier this year, Mr. Gerhaher notes how Schoenberg creates an entirely new set of colors for every emotional nuance, likening each stanza to a gift to the listener.

headline: Review: On ‘Free TC,’ Ty Dolla Sign Delivers Off-the-Cuff R&B
text: “Free TC”

headline: Review: ‘Aria,’ by Sullivan Fortner, Full of Assurance
text: “Aria”

headline: Glenn O’Brien Reinvents Himself (Yet Again)
text: It wasn’t supposed to end this way. Glenn O’Brien, GQ magazine’s Style Guy columnist, bolted in a huff in May after 16 years.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Madam Phung’s Last Journey’ Follows a Gender-Bending Troupe
text: The subject of “Madam Phung’s Last Journey” describes herself and the carnival family in orbit around her as neither male nor female but half and half — citizens who have no place within the strictures of Vietnam’s official society and few opportunities for legitimate employment.

headline: Mexico’s Governing Party Vows to Stop Using Neuromarketing to Study Voters
text: MEXICO CITY — The leader of Mexico’s governing party has said it will stop hiring neuroscience consultants to register voters’ brain waves and read their facial expressions, responding to a political outcry over its use of the tools of neuromarketing to shape its campaign and governing messages.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa, the West Bank and Elsewhere
text: The West Bank and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 11, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from the West Bank, South Africa, Syria and the United States.

headline: Review: ‘Rock in the Red Zone’ Goes Beyond Music in a War-Torn Israeli Town
text: Long before the director inserts scenes from her own wedding video into “Rock in the Red Zone,” it’s apparent that she’s grown quite close to her subject. A lack of critical distance isn’t always fatal to a documentary. But here, that segment is just one more piece in an often scattershot project.

headline: The G.O.P. Tax Debate: Low or Lower; Flat or Flatter?
text: At Tuesday’s Republican debate, candidates discussed two main questions about taxes: Should they be lower than they are now, or should they be way lower? And should there be fewer tax rates, or just one single rate for everyone, rich and poor?

headline: Young Caribbean Team Braces for Daunting Task in World Cup Qualifier
text: If Jurgen Klinsmann, the German coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, thinks he is at his lowest ebb, Cornelius Huggins can offer him a startling reality check.

headline: Nephews of Venezuela’s First Lady Face Drug Charges
text: Two nephews of the wife of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela were arrested this week in Haiti and flown to the United States where they will face drug trafficking charges, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

headline: More Young Women Waiting to Leave Home
text: The share of young women living at home with their parents or other relatives has reached its highest level since the statistics were first gathered, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data.

headline: Review: Chamber Music Society, Bilingual in ‘Channel Crossing’
text: “Channel Crossing,” the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center called its program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, and the society’s artistic directors, David Finckel and Wu Han, supplied information about the English Channel in an introductory note. At its narrowest, the channel is some 20 miles wide, they wrote; for the hardiest, it’s a seven-hour swim.

headline: 106 Indictments Handed Down in Waco Twin Peaks Biker Shootout
text: AUSTIN — A biker shootout in Waco, Tex., that left nine people dead and nearly 20 wounded in May has resulted in 106 felony indictments, and Central Texas prosecutors say more indictments are likely in the protracted investigation.

headline: Mizzou, Yale and Free Speech
text: On university campuses across the country, from Mizzou to Yale, we have two noble forces colliding with explosive force.

headline: A Flurry of Holiday Pop-Up Stores and Other Shopping Events
text: On Thursday, the Dannijo designers Danielle and Jodie Snyder will open a holiday pop-up they’re calling “Conversation Pieces” near their showroom. There you’ll find jewelry designs like an oxidized silver-plate bib necklace with Swarovski crystals ($520) along with lingerie by Morgan Lane and vintage clothing from A Current Affair. At 68 Gansevoort Street.

headline: Bob Dole Endorses Jeb Bush, and Knocks Ted Cruz
text: Former Senator Bob Dole of Kansas endorsed Jeb Bush for president on Wednesday, saying he believed that the former Florida governor was the best qualified candidate — and also making clear that he still held a grudge against Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: T-Mobile Video Plan Could Test F.C.C.’s New Net Neutrality Rules
text: A new plan from T-Mobile USA to allow unlimited streaming of some video services may become the first test of the federal government’s rules to prevent favoritism on the Internet.

headline: Republican Voters Slowly Begin to Rally Around Candidates
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa — At a Marco Rubio rally the day after the Republicans’ fourth debate, Scott Bell pressed through a crowd to deliver a direct message to the Florida senator. “I’m all in,” he told Mr. Rubio.

headline: Review: The Violinist Leila Josefowicz at Carnegie Hall
text: From child prodigy to go-to star for major commissions, the reinvention of the violinist Leila Josefowicz, just 38, is complete. Glance at her menu for the season and see a feast of new music: a garnish of Sibelius topping the meat of concertos by Thomas Adès, John Adams, Oliver Knussen and Sean Shepherd.

headline: Review: Kyle Abraham, Sleekly Protesting Racial Injustice
text: Race and music are potent tools for Kyle Abraham, a Pittsburgh-born choreographer and dancer who grew up enmeshed in hip-hop culture. In his newest work, “Absent Matter,” Mr. Abraham takes inspiration from jazz and hip-hop to focus on racial injustice. It’s a timely — and, for a dance, a huge — subject. Yet despite his status as a 2013 MacArthur Fellow, Mr. Abraham is not fully formed enough as a choreographer to tackle it.

headline: Friends or Friendly? Sheldon Silver’s Trial Focuses on Ties to Doctor
text: Their relationship seemed to pass the tests of friendship. Sheldon Silver and Dr. Robert N. Taub had mutual friends; their families had met, and even stayed at the same hotel during Passover celebrations.

headline: ‘No Easy Answers’ in Murder Charge Against 8-Year-Old
text: ATLANTA — With its unadorned language and matter-of-fact tone, the announcement on Tuesday by the authorities in Birmingham, Ala., at first read like nearly any other law enforcement statement about a homicide investigation.

headline: Home Health Aide Becomes a Guardian and, He Hopes, a Father
text: As Marco Muñoz speaks, recalling the past few years of his life, Jose Hernandez slips one of his shoes onto Mr. Muñoz’s hand. It is an odd yet effective gesture that signals to Mr. Muñoz that Jose wants to go for a walk.

headline: Apple Plans Peer-to-Peer Payment Service
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is working on a person-to-person payments service that may give iPhone owners another reason to use their Apple Wallets.

headline: Racial Discrimination Protests Ignite at Colleges Across the U.S.
text: The passion that ousted the heads of the University of Missouri after protests over racial discrimination on campus is spreading to other colleges across the country, turning traditional fall semesters into a period of intense focus on racial misunderstanding and whether activism stifles free speech.

headline: FanDuel and DraftKings Prepare for Court Fight in New York
text: The two largest daily fantasy sports operators acknowledged Wednesday that New York State was vital to the future of their businesses and said they would pursue all legal options to remain in operation there despite a demand by the state attorney general that they stop allowing residents to play because their games constituted illegal gambling under state law.

headline: André Glucksmann, French Philosopher Who Renounced Marxism, Dies at 78
text: André Glucksmann, one of the most prominent of the French “New Philosophers,” a group of former radicals who broke with Marxism in the 1970s and became an intellectual counterweight to France’s political left, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 78.

headline: Review: Andrea Burns at Feinstein’s/54 Below
text: Andrea Burns, who plays Gloria Estefan’s mother in the musical “On Your Feet!,” knows who she is: a Latina fish out of water who grew up in Miami, obsessed with Broadway. Ebullient and playful, Ms. Burns, 44, brought a breath of tropical air to Feinstein’s/54 Below on Monday evening. She compared her parents’ 46-year relationship to a union between Jerry Seinfeld and Sofia Vergara. The person onstage had a little of both. “I happen to be part Jewish,” she added. “I have the guilt.”

headline: Betsy Drake, 92, Actress Who Starred With (and Wed) Cary Grant, Dies
text: Betsy Drake, a film actress who starred alongside Cary Grant after bumping into him on the Queen Mary, eloping with him and remaining married to him longer than any of his other wives, died on Oct. 27 at her home in London. She was 92.

headline: G.O.P. Fight Now a Battle Over What Defines a Conservative
text: MILWAUKEE — For months, the Republican presidential race has been animated by the party’s inchoate anger about the state of the country and an equally undefined hope that a candidate would emerge who could usher in an era of civic renewal. But the debate here and its aftermath marked an abrupt transition from vague promises about making America “great again,” in Donald J. Trump’s phrase, to a new season of the campaign shaped more by the glaring policy fissures that are dividing Republicans over what exactly to do about the nation’s problems.

headline: Corporation to Oversee New Hudson Rail Tunnel, With U.S. and Amtrak Financing Half
text: Federal and state officials announced an agreement on Wednesday to create a corporation within the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to oversee long-awaited plans to build a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River.

headline: Israeli Opposition Leader Withholds Judgment on Netanyahu’s U.S. Visit
text: Isaac Herzog, head of the political opposition in Israel, reserved judgment on Wednesday about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s visit this week to Washington, saying the outcome was unclear despite what appeared to be an improved atmosphere created by the trip.

headline: Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn Pledges Loyalty to Queen, if Not to Tradition
text: LONDON — A lifelong republican and veteran leftist, Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, caused consternation among traditionalists in September when he failed to sing the national anthem, “God Save the Queen,” at a ceremony to commemorate World War II.

headline: Veteran Italian Diplomat at U.N. to Get Top Refugee Post
text: UNITED NATIONS — A veteran United Nations official who earned his diplomatic credibility in the Israeli-Palestinian crisis will take over the United Nations refugee agency amid the world’s worst migrant crisis in decades.

headline: Shock and Few Leads After Murder of Lois Colley, Society Matriarch
text: NORTH SALEM, N.Y. — This pastoral playground in the northeast corner of Westchester County, laced with horse paddocks and stone walls, has long been a draw for the wealthy and well-connected. Among those who call it home are David Letterman, the composer Alan Menken and the financier Steven Rattner. Michael R. Bloomberg, who has many homes, also owns an estate here.

headline: Facing Rex Ryan’s Bills, Foundation of Jets’ Defense Is Sagging
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Once, there was a house.

headline: A Bit of Housekeeping Removes a Confederate Flag in a U.S. Capitol Building
text: WASHINGTON — The guardians of the United States Capitol, with the serendipitous convenience of a modest renovation underway in the Rayburn House Office Building, have quietly removed the Mississippi state flag with its Confederate battle insignia from a well-traveled hallway.

headline: Joe’s Crab Shack to Test No-Tipping Policy
text: Following in the footsteps of the Danny Meyer restaurant group, Joe’s Crab Shack, a Houston-based chain with more than 130 locations nationwide, announced on Wednesday that it would test a no-tipping system in one of the largest trials yet of the policy.

headline: Giants’ Pass Rush Has High Hopes for Matchup With Tom Brady
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Cullen Jenkins is a 12-year N.F.L. veteran, an anchor on the Giants’ defensive line, and lavish praise for opposing quarterbacks does not often pass through his teeth four days before a big game.

headline: Greensboro Puts Focus on Reducing Racial Bias
text: The police chief in Greensboro, N.C., has ordered his officers to stop pulling over motorists for minor infractions involving vehicle flaws like broken taillights, an action he called a first step toward eliminating “alarming” racial disparities in traffic stops.

headline: Jacqueline Berrien, Head of E.E.O.C., Is Dead at 53
text: Jacqueline Berrien, a civil rights lawyer who was President Obama’s chairwoman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, died on Monday in Baltimore. She was 53.

headline: Scott Gomez Brings His Playoff Experience to the Blues
text: Scott Gomez was the first St. Louis Blues player to step on the ice at Madison Square Garden for practice Wednesday.

headline: Carol Doda, Pioneer of Topless Entertainment, Dies at 78
text: Carol Doda, who was widely credited with triggering a nationwide topless revolution as a 26-year-old go-go dancer in 1964, died on Monday in San Francisco. She was 78.

headline: Richard Horowitz, Timpanist and Craftsman of Conductors’ Batons, Dies at 91
text: In a Queens boiler room, armed with little more than a champagne cork and a length of wood, Richard Horowitz helped bring to life some of the foremost symphonic music in the world.

headline: Review: ‘Shear Madness,’ Where Getting a Haircut Is Murder
text: Only $30 for a woman’s haircut at a Manhattan salon? That’s what they charge at Shear Madness, a wacky little shop that’s just opened on West 50th Street, though it looks as if it had been there forever. The walls are baby blue, the floor is linoleum, and isn’t that a ficus tree in the corner, over near the exposed brick?

headline: M.L.B. Considers Adjusting Rules on Slides and Replays
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Whether the slide that wiped out Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada’s season will be outlawed when he returns next season remains uncertain.

headline: Review: ‘Henry IV,’ Donmar Warehouse’s All-Female Version
text: Leave it to an army of sharp-witted women to point out just how much Shakespeare’s “Henry IV” plays are — how shall we put this? — manhood-measuring contests. As embodied by a rousing all-female cast in this seriously entertaining Donmar Warehouse production, which opened on Wednesday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, Shakespeare’s soldiers, nobles and carousers seem to be forever engaged in vociferous argument as to who has the bigger ….

headline: Why Germans Loved Helmut Schmidt
text: Hamburg, Germany — HELMUT SCHMIDT, the former German chancellor and renowned postwar statesman who died Tuesday at 96, would have hated to read the adulatory obituaries that have poured forth over the last 24 hours. Henry A. Kissinger, one of his closest friends, once said he hoped Mr. Schmidt would survive him, because “a world without him would be very empty.”

headline: Repeat Train Thief Steals Bus at Port Authority, Police Say
text: Darius McCollum, known for his obsession with buses and trains and his proclivity for taking them for joy rides, has been no stranger to law enforcement in New York City.

headline: Researchers Say There May Be Undiscovered Tomb at Great Pyramid of Giza
text: Researchers in Egypt using advanced scanning techniques to study the Pyramids said this week that they had detected “thermal anomalies” within the Great Pyramid of Giza that could indicate the presence of an undiscovered tomb.

headline: Northern Ireland: Ex-Soldier Is Released on Bail in Bloody Sunday Investigation
text: A former British soldier who was arrested Tuesday in connection with the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre of unarmed civilians in Londonderry has been released on bail, the Police Service of Northern Ireland announced Wednesday. The former soldier, 66, has not been charged. A 2010 inquiry found that the British government was responsible for the massacre, and it prompted the police to open a criminal investigation. This was the first arrest in the case.

headline: Knicks Are Finally Healthy, Besides Heartbreak at Buzzer
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Nine games into his N.B.A. career, with four double-doubles to his credit and greats like Magic Johnson already hinting at future greatness to come, the 7-foot wonder Kristaps Porzingis is the subject of good-natured ribbing by his Knicks teammates.

headline: Senate Approves Research Into Combat Effects on Mental Health
text: Research into veterans’ suicide received a lift on Tuesday with Senate passage of a measure requiring an independent research program on the effects of combat service on suicide rates and other mental health issues among troops and veterans. A report by The New York Times in September found that monitoring of suicide was not coordinated between the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense, and many veterans fell through the cracks because the effect of combat exposure was poorly tracked.   After more than decade of war, neither department has the data to show whether troops exposed to combat have a higher risk of suicide, and how that risk changes over time. Because of this, veterans say suicide prevention programs do not fit their needs. “We simply don’t know enough about the effects of combat on mental health issues among service members and veterans both during and after service,” said the amendment’s sponsor, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado. The measure passed as part of the Military Construction and Veterans Affairs and Related Agencies Appropriations Act for fiscal year 2016.

headline: In India, Many Voters May See Corruption as the Lesser Evil
text: NEW DELHI — What do Indians despise more: communal conflict or corruption?

headline: Kurds, Backed by U.S. Air Power, Try to Regain Sinjar From ISIS
text: MOUNT SINJAR, Iraq — Kurdish forces aided by thousands of lightly armed Yazidi fighters began a long-awaited offensive early Thursday to reclaim Mount Sinjar and an accompanying town from the Islamic State, which seized the northern Iraqi territory last year and murdered, raped and enslaved thousands of Yazidis.

headline: Hawaii Confronts Dengue Outbreak as 33 Are Infected
text: Health officials in Hawaii have confirmed at least 33 cases of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne tropical illness not usually found there, and warned that the entire Big Island is at risk for its spread.

headline: Why Cutting a Crucial ISIS Route May Not Stop Flow of Fighters and Supplies
text: The ease of creating roads through the desert could limit the effectiveness of the offensive to cut off a key ISIS supply route.

headline: Obesity Rises Despite All Efforts to Fight It, U.S. Health Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — Despite years of efforts to reduce obesity in America, including a major push by Michelle Obama, federal health officials reported Thursday that the share of Americans who were obese had not declined in recent years, and had edged up slightly.

headline: The Stealth Attack on Abortion Access
text: A YEAR ago, a mother and self-described “God-fearing woman” called me after she had an abortion. She said that earlier, when she found herself unexpectedly pregnant, she drove straight to what she thought was a comprehensive health care provider near her home in Columbus, Ohio. When she asked about abortion, the staff told her she shouldn’t murder her child. Ohio requires an ultrasound before an abortion, so the woman listened to the staff’s condemnations, taking them to heart, crying. She told me later, “I didn’t know where else to go.”

headline: Death Penalty and the Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wow, More Terrifying Than Trump
text: Perhaps you didn’t watch the Republican presidential debate this week. That in no way excuses you from having an opinion about it. It’s the last one until December, and all you’ll have to work with if you want political conversation at Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Who Is Entitled to Be Heard?
text: SOME of the most potent threats to free speech these days come not from our government or corporations, but from our citizenry. Pitched battles being waged at Yale and the University of Missouri pit speech versus speech in a contest of who and what is entitled to be heard. These are only the latest examples: In recent years speakers have been disinvited, campus events disrupted and activists threatened for speaking their minds.

headline: Judicial Energy and the Supreme Court
text: Terry Eastland, a Reagan-era conservative activist who now edits The Weekly Standard, wrote a book back in 1992 that he called “Energy in the Executive: The Case for the Strong Presidency.” He took to task both President Ronald Reagan, for whom he had worked in the Justice Department, and the first President Bush for having failed to use all possible levers of presidential power to advance the conservative agenda.

headline: An Antidote to Cynicism in Canada
text: It has become common to bemoan the sorry state of politics, what with all the big money, dirty tricks, image molding, partisan gridlock and general cynicism. Yet voters seem never to cease longing for a leader who can restore pride to high office and rekindle the national spirit.

headline: The Trouble With Fantasy Sports Gambling
text: The millions who play and lose on daily fantasy sports websites are engaged in gambling, plain and simple. Now, state and federal officials are finally starting to clamp down on this fast-growing online business.

headline: Men Do More at Home, but Not as Much as They Think
text: Men today are much more committed to equality at home, sharing dinner-cooking and diaper-changing duties, than in previous generations. But even in families in which both parents work outside the home, the division of labor at home remains unequal.

text: You have not truly heard the trauma that a lifetime in the spotlight can cause until you hear Justin Bieber sing, “What about the children?/Look at all the children we can change.”

headline: Leaked Emirati Emails Could Threaten Peace Talks in Libya
text: CAIRO — The United Arab Emirates was shipping weapons to favored belligerents in Libya over the summer in violation of an international arms embargo while simultaneously offering a highly paid job to the United Nations diplomat drafting a peace accord there, leaked Emirati emails show.

headline: David Vitter’s Race for Governor Could Bring the Senate Together

headline: Malcolm Turnbull of Australia and Joko Widodo of Indonesia Seek to Mend Ties
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The new Australian prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, made a half-day visit to Indonesia on Thursday to hold talks with President Joko Widodo, a meeting intended to help mend diplomatic relations that plummeted this year over issues including human smuggling, refugee boats and the executions of Australian drug offenders.

headline: Kurds Retake Strategic Highway in Iraq’s North From ISIS
text: MOUNT SINJAR, Iraq — Sweeping down in hodgepodge convoys of trucks and buses, Kurdish forces and Yazidi fighters opened their offensive against Islamic State militants in northern Iraq on Thursday with a burst of initial success: The forces cut off the main highway the jihadists used as a supply line, and they moved in to begin fighting for the town of Sinjar.

headline: On Minimum Wage, Ben Carson Is No Longer an Outsider Among Republicans
text: Among the many issues dividing the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates, few are as clear-cut as the minimum wage. While the Democrats support raising it, the Republican field has been overwhelmingly opposed, citing concerns about possible job losses.

headline: Scottish Nurse Pauline Cafferkey Recovers From Ebola for 2nd Time
text: LONDON — A Scottish nurse who became critically ill last month — 10 months after recovering from Ebola — has again recovered.

headline: Shares of French Asset Manager Amundi Rise in Debut After I.P.O.
text: LONDON — Shares of Amundi, one of the largest asset managers in Europe, rose by about 4 percent in their debut on the Euronext stock exchange in Paris on Thursday after its initial public offering.

headline: Greek Strike Shows Conflict Within Government Over Austerity
text: ATHENS — Hundreds of thousands of Greeks walked off their jobs on Thursday to protest austerity economics as officials of the leftist-led government wrangled with the country’s international creditors over the terms of Greece’s third bailout. At least one Athens protest turned violent.

headline: David Brat Thinks Congress Is Plenty Smart
text: What kind of speaker of the House do you think Paul Ryan will be? I’m looking forward to working hand in hand with him to solve the biggest issues that our country faces.

headline: Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Maintaining Lead Over Bernie Sanders
text: Despite a month of sharpened attacks, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has failed to significantly dent Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lead in the Democratic presidential race, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey released on Thursday.

headline: Retracing a Mother’s Path of Escape Along a Wintry Merrimack
text: A thick curtain of snow fell over the Merrimack River, obscuring the far bank. While my friend Chris Pierce and I searched for a place to launch our canoe, the flurries drifted away. Paddling carefully on the swollen expanse of the Merrimack, we passed a small island fringed with ice, and thus entered a forgotten chapter in American history.

headline: Choose Your Own Adventure: A Conversation With Jennifer Egan and George Saunders
text: Jennifer Egan: I want to start by talking about how we define writing about the future. Some things that I think of as futuristic, when I’ve looked at them again for this conversation, I’m not sure they really are. So I guess my question would be: What leads you into territory that feels futuristic? How do you end up there? And what makes it the future?

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The ‘Death in … ’ Books
text: This summer, two female bears, each with a set of twin cubs, took up residence along a tree-lined trail in Denver. Hikers in the park had proved themselves prone to snapping selfies with bears, sometimes by creeping within 10 feet of them, so in response, the city pre-emptively shut down the trail. This story circulated online as evidence of human stupidity’s direct correlation with modern technol­ogy’s advancement, but I thought that was unfair. People have been making mistakes in nature for a long, long time.

headline: Review: In Angelina Jolie Pitt’s ‘By the Sea,’ an Unhappy Ménage and Tear-Streaked Mascara
text: Meta with a vengeance, “By the Sea” stars Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt as itinerant married artists who are suffering, beautifully, through a rough patch. Any resemblance to real life is strictly coincidental and completely intentional. At first luxurious blush it’s a jet-setting marital melodrama, one of those he-said, she-said (and wept) encounter sessions decked with designer shades, to-die-for digs and millionaire tears. More interestingly, the movie, which Ms. Jolie Pitt wrote and directed, is a knowing or at least a ticklishly amusing demonstration of celebrity and its relay of gazes from one of the most looked-at women in the world. Take, watch, she seems to say, this is my body.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Made Rare Visit to Tibet, China Says

headline: Rights Lawyers in China Routinely Face Abuse, Report Says
text: BEIJING — Legal activists and those suspected of crimes in China are routinely abused and mistreated at the hands of law enforcement officials, a report released on Thursday by Amnesty International found, despite recent efforts by the government to crack down on inhumane judicial practices.

headline: 1915: Winston Churchill Resigns
text: LONDON — Mr. Winston Churchill, the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, who was First Lord of the Admiralty until the formation of the Coalition Ministry, has resigned office and will rejoin his regiment in France. Mr. Churchill, in tendering his resignation, said that his chief reason for resigning was that Mr. Asquith, who had promised six weeks ago to make him a member of the new War Council, had not seen his way to do so. Mr. Churchill, therefore, declined to remain any longer in well-paid inactivity. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 13, 1915

headline: A Mother’s Hoarding, a Daughter’s Art
text: When a bicycle accident left her mother with severe brain damage, Stephanie Calvert began to reexamine what had been a difficult relationship. Her mother had been a hoarder — when the family moved to an isolated schoolhouse in Thatcher, Colo., she filled it with clothes, papers and other objects. Ms. Calvert was deeply embarrassed by her mother’s habit — she became depressed and “wanted to leave as soon as I could and move far away.”

headline: Coordinated European Raids Target Ring Supporting Terrorist Groups
text: ROME — The authorities arrested 15 people in four European countries on Thursday, breaking up what officials called a terrorist network that sought to overthrow the Kurdish government in northern Iraq and to recruit militants to fight in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Adele Cries to Her Music, Too
text: LONDON — “I’m not going to cry,” Adele said. She was practicing with her band at Music Bank rehearsal studios, an unglamorous warehouse space in South London, and had just finished “When We Were Young,” one of the torchiest ballads on her new album, “25.” It’s a song about running into an old flame that confesses, “I still care” and then, tentatively, asks, “Do you still care?”

headline: Deutsche Bank Names Management Team for New Investment Division
text: LONDON — Deutsche Bank on Thursday named the management team for its new corporate and investment banking division. The move is part of an overhaul by John Cryan, the bank’s new co-chief executive, to simplify the structure of the lender and improve its returns.

headline: In Run-Up to Olympics, Rio’s Property Market Already Looks Hung Over
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Home buyers in Rio de Janeiro used to get into intense bidding wars as they tried to secure even a modest apartment in one of the city’s exclusive beachfront districts. Not anymore.

headline: Daily Report: Imagining the Road Ahead
text: If predictions about the future are true, many of us will soon be riding around in self-driving cars. But a crucial part of making that prediction a reality is making sure that the car can see — or sense — the world around it.

headline: 1965: Russians Send Probe to Venus
text: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union took another stab at inter-planetary space exploration today [Nov. 12] — a field in which it has been unsuccessful for four years — with the launching of what is called the ‘‘Venus-2’’ spaceship to the earth’s cloud- covered ‘‘sister planet.’’ The 2,123-pound craft got off to a good start on its three- and-a-half-month flight to Venus, and then Tass, the government news agency, announced that it had been launched. Venus-1 was launched on Feb. 12, 1961, but its radios went dead about two weeks later. After that first failure, Soviet space engineers failed on at least four more occasions, according to American sources, to send rockets toward Venus. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 13, 1965

headline: In Victoria, British Columbia, Where to Go on Trounce Alley
text: Trounce Alley, a tiny Euro-chic pedestrian passage connecting two busy downtown thoroughfares, has emerged as a diverse micro hub.

headline: How #BlackOnCampus Convened a Twitter Debate on Race
text: The uproar that began over on-campus race relations at the University of Missouri and quickly spread to other campuses has found a new home on social media.

headline: Review: Stacy Schiff’s ‘The Witches,’ a Reign of Terror in 17th-Century Salem
text: The feverish Salem witch hunts of 1692 have become a metaphor not just for anti-Communist mania in the 1950s but for the larger strain of what the historian Richard Hofstadter has described as “the paranoid style in American politics,” and for all manner of conspiratorial hate-and-fear mongering, inquisitional madness and communal hysteria.

headline: The Danger of Knowing ‘Just Enough’ Spanish
text: I speak just enough Spanish to be dangerous.

headline: How a Company Can Be Both Downgraded and Upgraded
text: The ratings agency Fitch downgraded the Chesapeake Energy Corporation’s issuer default rating last week to BB- from BB. At the same time, Fitch upgraded the rating on the company’s bank loan to BB+ from BB.

headline: With Aung San Suu Kyi’s Rise, China and Myanmar Face New Relationship
text: BEIJING — Even though China has long supported the generals who have wielded most of the power in Myanmar, the government in Beijing prepared this year for the possible election victory of the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, by inviting her to the capital to meet with President Xi Jinping.

headline: Pistons’ Andre Drummond Hits the Boards and Makes a Huge Leap
text: Andre Drummond pulled down 17 rebounds on Wednesday night, the eighth-highest total by any N.B.A. player this season. Yet his rebounding average for the year dropped.

headline: Why Jeffrey Lacker Is Worried About Inflation
text: Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, was the only member of the Fed’s policy-making committee who voted to raise interest rates in September, and again in October. Mr. Lacker has long expressed skepticism about the benefits of the Fed’s stimulus campaign, and he has been concerned that inflation will begin to rise more quickly as the economy gains strength.

headline: In Obama Era, G.O.P. Bolsters Grip in the States
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Young, telegenic and news media savvy, State Auditor Adam Edelen looked like a shoo-in for re-election when Democrats gathered in a horse barn here for a buffet dinner late last month. Most figured he would go on to challenge Senator Rand Paul, whose Republican presidential bid is faltering even as he seeks re-election.

headline: Bright Lights, Strange Shapes and Talk of U.F.O.’s
text: When strange things appear in the sky, many people can’t help but turn their thoughts to extraterrestrials. But there’s usually a more down-to-earth explanation.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 6: Impersonation of Love
text: What does it mean to fall in love in the world of “American Horror Story”? When the body count is this high, is there any room for such sentiment?

headline: How Period Trackers Have Changed Girl Culture
text: My 18-year-old daughter knows exactly when it will be that time of the month. Since June, she’s been plugging the dates of her menstrual cycle into a popular period tracking app called Clue, and has it programmed to send her an alert every month, two days before her next period is due.

headline: Palestinian Dies as Undercover Israelis Raid a Hospital
text: JERUSALEM — About two dozen men wearing bulky jackets, woolen caps, hoodies and checkered kaffiyehs barged into a hospital in the West Bank city of Hebron before dawn on Thursday, pushing what appeared to be a very pregnant woman in a wheelchair.

headline: Cola, a New Start-up, Introduces Ways to Do More in Text Messages
text: For better or worse, text messaging is the app people spend more time using than any other on their smartphones. A new start-up, Cola, believes it can make it a bit better.

headline: Bringing iPhone-style Medical Research to the Android World
text: Since Apple introduced its ResearchKit software in March, scientists at leading medical schools across the country have written apps to study asthma, Parkinson’s disease, autism, epilepsy, melanoma, breast cancer and other ailments. Medical experts are hopeful that using smartphones to gather health data from millions of people, with their consent, can open a window to new insights into diseases, treatments and lifestyle effects.

headline: When Headlines Play Down Dads, All Parents Lose
text: Female readers, did you gravitate toward certain articles about a recent Pew Report (Raising Kids and Running a Household: How Working Parents Share the Load)? Maybe you clicked on a headline like Equal division of labor at home for working parents? Not exactly (CNN), or “Who does more at home when both parents work? Depends on which one you ask” (Pew Fact Tank), or lingered knowingly over the paragraphs in the many articles that described how mothers do more: more to manage children’s schedules and activities, more chores, more coping with sick days. Much of the reporting included a wry poke at the “fun” statistic: More fathers than mothers say they share equally in the work.

headline: The House of Lords: The Constitutional Dinosaur Britain Can’t Kill
text: LONDON — Imagine President Obama introducing a controversial welfare proposal that quickly became the contentious subject of many columns and talk shows — but was approved, nonetheless, by Congress.

headline: Review: ‘The 33’ Recalls a Chilean Mine Disaster and the Men Who Endured It
text: The ordeal of the 33 Chilean miners trapped deep inside the earth after the collapse of a mine shaft in August 2010 was both an intensely local story and a global phenomenon. As family members waited in a makeshift camp near the mine’s opening, viewers across the world followed the progress of the rescue efforts thanks to round-the-clock news media attention. We breathed sighs of relief and wept tears of joy when the men finally emerged, after more than two months in subterranean heat and darkness. And then, as is our habit, we moved on.

headline: With a Hush, an American Lexus Plant Goes to Work

headline: Russia Says Leak of Secret Nuclear Weapon Design Was an Accident

headline: Transgender, and Facing Prison or Deportation
