headline: Rollie Massimino’s Latest Act: A Smaller Stage, but Just as Frenetic
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Recovering from a collapsed lung, under treatment for small recurrences of the cancer that was surgically removed four years ago, and on medication, Rollie Massimino was under strict doctor’s orders to take it easy for 48 hours and especially to avoid driving his car.

headline: Grief in Paris
text: At least 129 people were killed and dozens more were wounded in coordinated attacks.

headline: France Strikes ISIS Targets in Syria in Retaliation for Attacks
text: PARIS — France bombed the Syrian city of Raqqa on Sunday night, its most aggressive strike against the Islamic State group it blames for killing 129 people in a string of terrorist attacks across Paris only two days before.

headline: 1965: Anti-Red Law in U.S. Is Voided
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court today [Nov. 15] unanimously ruled that Communist party members do not have to register with the government because they might incriminate themselves. The high tribunal declared a requirement that Communist party members register under the 1950 Subversive Activities Control Law, sometimes referred to as the McCarran Act, violates the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.

headline: Paris Attacks: What We Know and Don’t Know
text: French warplanes struck Islamic State militants in Syria, two days after Islamic State terrorists killed at least 129 people in Paris. The airstrikes appeared to be focused on Raqqa, the self-proclaimed capital of the Islamic State.

headline: Pope Condemns 'Barbarity' of Paris Attacks
text: Pope Francis expressed condolences to all the citizens of France and said that using the name of God to justify violence and hatred was "blasphemy."

headline: Beirut, Also the Site of Deadly Attacks, Feels Forgotten
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ali Awad, 14, was chopping vegetables when the first bomb struck. Adel Tormous, who would die tackling the second bomber, was sitting at a nearby coffee stand. Khodr Alaa Deen, a registered nurse, was on his way to work his night shift at the teaching hospital of the American University at Beirut, in Lebanon.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker on Life With and Without Men
text: The other day in the Brooklyn Heights duplex Mary-Louise Parker shares with her two children and Mrs. Roosevelt, a cocker spaniel in a red diaper, the actress was stroking one of the oyster shells she keeps in a bowl in her living room.

headline: A Street-Level Search for Women to Put on a Manhattan Pedestal
text: Joan of Arc’s armor glistened in the noonday sun as she walked slowly through the lunchtime crowds rushing past the Flatiron Building in Manhattan recently. Every now and then, she paused and scanned the sidewalk, slightly tilting her head back as she announced her mission.

headline: Invoking Nazis, Marco Rubio Hits Hillary Clinton for Not Saying U.S. Is at War With ‘Radical Islam’
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, arguing that the United States is “at war with radical Islam,” sharply criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton for declining to characterize the perpetrators of the Paris attacks in that way, invoking Nazi Germany to make his point.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Honors Paris
text: “Saturday Night Live” skipped its usual cold open on Saturday, instead delivering a message of support to Paris after Friday’s attacks.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. Let’s put aside Thanksgiving planning for a moment. It’s not just the horrible news out of France. You thought about Thanksgiving yesterday, and will think about it tomorrow, and next weekend will be filled with preparations large and small. For this day, at least, we’re going to concentrate on the short term: dinners for the week ahead.

headline: Efforts to Rein In Arbitration Come Under Well-Financed Attack
text: A television ad during the Republican presidential debate last Tuesday depicted pale bureaucrats rubber-stamping the word “DENIED” on the files of frustrated Americans, beneath a red banner of Senator Elizabeth Warren evoking a Communist apparatchik.

headline: Muslims in Paris Condemn Attacks
text: Muslims in the French capital condemned the terrorists that attacked their city, saying they tarnished Islam.

headline: Fear and Friends
text: The news from Paris was horrifying, and deserved a break in the usual round of commentary, but surely nobody who has been paying attention was completely shocked. We know that there are jihadists out there, and even the best efforts at prevention will fail sometimes. We’ll have to see how this fairly elaborate plot went undetected, but really nothing about the story so far suggests that it should fundamentally change how we see the world.

headline: ‘Love the Coopers’ Beats Expectations, but James Bond and Charlie Brown Win the Box Office
text: The feel-good comedy “Love the Coopers” seemed to arrive just in time for moviegoers weary of word events, while the ripped-from-the-headlines drama “The 33,” about the 2010 Chilean mining tragedy, may have been a little too real.

headline: Unraveling the Connections Among the Paris Attackers
text: As many as six of the assailants in the coordinated Islamic State terrorist assault in Paris were Europeans who had traveled to Syria.

headline: Jeb Bush Says U.S. ‘Should Declare War’ in Fight Against Islamic State
text: Jeb Bush said the United States “should declare war” as it responds to the Paris attacks and the rise of ISIS in general.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Democracy’s First Steps in Myanmar
text: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party, the National League for Democracy, won a solid majority in parliamentary elections.

headline: Irish Repertory Theater Set to Honor Brian Friel
text: The Irish playwright Brian Friel, who died last month at 86, will be honored in a memorial service on Dec. 7, presented by The Irish Repertory Theater at the Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Additionally, Broadway theaters will dim their lights for Mr. Friel on Dec. 8.

headline: Projection Kicks Off Countdown to Black History and Culture Museum Opening
text: By this time next year, a new Smithsonian museum dedicated to telling the history of black Americans will be welcoming visitors on the National Mall.

headline: Man Who Gave Psychics $718,000 ‘Just Got Sucked In’
text: He sat in a Denny’s restaurant, drinking coffee between cigarette breaks after a long and sleepless night, answering question after question.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: If you need an escape from all the news, Anthony Bourdain will take you to a sunny island, and Bob’s Burgers will bring you an early Christmas.

headline: For Once, the Knicks Protect a Fourth-Quarter Lead
text: Frustrated with his limited role on the Knicks, Kevin Seraphin recently went to Coach Derek Fisher’s office and asked what he could do to earn more playing time. It was a long and frank conversation, Seraphin said, and Fisher essentially told him to focus on his defense and rebounding. Fisher also preached patience: Seraphin’s time would come.

headline: Obama and Putin Discuss ISIS and Syria in Informal Conversation
text: ANTALYA, Turkey — President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met face-to-face here on Sunday, broaching once again their longstanding disagreement about how to confront the Islamic State and deal with the civil war in Syria.

headline: Fear Rising Among Refugees in Paris
text: Refugees in central Paris have heightened fears about their security and their future in France following Friday's attacks.

headline: Hillary Clinton Botches Wall Street Questions
text: Hillary Clinton should have seen that Wall Street shot coming. Instead, she compounded the damage.

headline: Review: ‘The Latin Explosion: A New America,’ on HBO, Is a Music Civics Lesson
text: The best moments come early in “The Latin Explosion: A New America,” an hourlong HBO documentary on Monday night. Desi Arnaz dancing with his conga and wailing “Babalú.” Rita Moreno laying down the law in “West Side Story.” A series of early rock ’n’ roll one-hit wonders matched with their real names: Sam the Sham, a.k.a. Domingo Samudio; Question Mark (of Question Mark and the Mysterians), a.k.a. Rudy Martinez; Cannibal (of Cannibal and the Headhunters), a.k.a. Frankie Garcia.

headline: Penguins, Known for Dangerous Attack, Are in Peril Themselves
text: NEWARK — As usual, the crowd at Prudential Center directed an obscene chant at Pittsburgh center Sidney Crosby, the Penguins’ captain. But this time was different: When the jeers began in the middle of the third period on Saturday night, the Penguins were three goals behind.

headline: Paris Attacks Pose Test for U.S. Presidential Candidates
text: WASHINGTON — The tragedy in Paris is roiling American politics, bolstering the Republican right’s anti-immigration demands in the short run and perhaps ultimately enhancing Hillary Rodham Clinton and her credentials as the candidate with experience.

headline: Review: St. Thomas Church Season Honors John Scott
text: When John Scott, the revered organist and choirmaster at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, programmed Mozart’s Requiem to open the church’s concert season on Thursday evening, he could hardly have anticipated that the performance would be dedicated to his memory. But in August, having returned from the first leg of a triumphant European recital tour, Mr. Scott, a vigorous 59, died of a heart attack.

headline: Review: The Mezzo-Soprano Anne Sofie von Otter at the Frick Collection
text: Lovely as it was, it had an air of unreality. To have canceled the concert or significantly altered the program on Friday night — a delicious mix of the sublime and the ridiculous, featuring the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter — would have achieved nothing.

headline: Israeli Forces Arrest Palestinian in Drive-By Shooting in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli authorities announced on Sunday the arrest of a Palestinian man suspected of carrying out a deadly drive-by shooting against Israelis in the West Bank, and said the suspect’s father had informed the military about his son’s involvement in the hope of preventing the demolition of their family home.

headline: Watching Missouri From Afar, and Seeing Lesson for All Black Athletes
text: More than a week after the president and the chancellor of the University of Missouri were forced to resign, the activism of the football players who helped bring about those changes is being celebrated as an example of what can be achieved when athletes lend their celebrity to a cause. What many found extraordinary about the affair is that athletes stepped out of the sports cocoon.

headline: 15 Sudanese Migrants Killed at Egypt-Israel Border, Officials Say
text: CAIRO — At least 15 Sudanese migrants trying to cross from Egypt into Israel were shot and killed at the border early Sunday, possibly by Egyptian police officers, according to security officials and news reports.

headline: More Than 8.5 Million Watched Democratic Debate on CBS
text: More than 8.5 million people watched the second Democratic presidential debate on CBS on Saturday night, according to Nielsen data provided by the network.

headline: Review: ‘Prem Ratan Dhan Payo,’ a Bollywood Tale of a Prince-and-Plebe Double
text: The Bollywood movie “Prem Ratan Dhan Payo” is set in contemporary India, though it’s one of palaces and quaint villages and low-rise cities, with the occasional iPhone and Mercedes thrown in for modernity and luxury branding’s sake.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 16
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘Appomattox’ at the Kennedy Center
text: WASHINGTON — Eight years ago, the composer Philip Glass unveiled a new opera, “Appomattox,” at the San Francisco Opera. Set to a libretto by Christopher Hampton, it centered on the gentlemanly negotiations between Generals Grant and Lee at a rural Virginia home that effectively brought the Civil War to a close in 1865. But the appearance of a chorus of civil rights protesters signaled that the opera’s true subject was race relations in America.

headline: Review: Ry Cooder, Ricky Skaggs and the Whites, a Roots-Music Celebration
text: Ry Cooder began the first encore at Zankel Hall on Saturday night with a shadowy, droning solo on electric bouzouki, in no hurry to settle on a tempo. After a few moments, Ricky Skaggs joined him on mandolin, and their searching interplay coalesced into a slow processional. Only as Mr. Cooder started singing, with a light husk in his baritone, did the shape of a song become clear.

headline: Review: ‘Spectator’ at the Japan Society
text: When a friend heard I was going to a production at the Japan Society, he guessed I would see one of the traditional Japanese genres — Noh, Kabuki, Bunraku — and said at once, “Interesting.” My visit on Friday, however, was for Shuji Onodera’s “Spectator,” which, certainly interesting, was new in Tokyo in 2013.

headline: Paris Attacks Shift Europe’s Migrant Focus to Security
text: WARSAW — With hundreds of thousands of migrants pouring across its borders, and economic and political pressure growing to enact tighter controls, Europe has nevertheless stayed fairly steady in its response to the humanitarian emergency.

headline: Review: In ‘Destiny and Power,’ George H.W. Bush Epitomizes a Vanishing G.O.P.
text: For better or for worse, George Herbert Walker Bush has been enshrined in collective memory as a series of caricatures, all of them evoking ineffectuality. He was the effete Yale man and the blue blood wimp; the awkward statesman who, when called upon to speak, diced the English language into an uneven and mysterious julienne. It didn’t help that his face was generally a fresco of befuddlement. The last thing one would have expected of him was tigerish ambition. Unlike so many politicians who thrust their way into the Oval Office — TheodoreRoosevelt, Lyndon B. Johnson, Bill Clinton — there seemed nothing overtly appetitive about him.

headline: Tic-Tac-Toe Win
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you’re an experienced solver, you will find this debut puzzle by Jim Holland pretty easy. You probably won’t stop writing in entries from the time you start until you write in the last letter.

headline: For Spike Lee, an Honorary Oscar, but Diversity Takes Center Stage
text: LOS ANGELES — “We can talk, you know, yabba, yabba, yabba, but we need to have some serious discussion about diversity, and get some flave up in this!” Spike Lee admonished members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, as he accepted an honorary Oscar at a black-tie banquet in Hollywood on Saturday night.

headline: Beneath New York Public Library, Shelving Its Past for High-Tech Research Stacks
text: As they skate or snack in Bryant Park, visitors might dismiss the stately New York Public Library next door as a dog-eared relic in an age of digital information.

headline: Blacks Are Challenged to Buy From Black-Owned Businesses to Close Gap
text: CHICAGO — Should black people go out of their way to patronize black-owned business?

headline: What Will Come After Paris
text: The terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday, along with twin bombings in Beirut on the day before and the downing of a Russian jetliner over the Sinai Peninsula on Oct. 31, show a new phase in the Islamic State’s war against the West, a readiness to strike far beyond areas it controls in Iraq, Syria, and increasingly, Libya.

headline: Blocks From Charlie Hebdo, Area Known for Bonhomie Is Shaken Again
text: PARIS — The massacre Friday night  by militants wielding assault rifles provoked an eerie and disturbing sense of familiarity for all of France. But that feeling was even more profound for one quickly gentrifying, multicultural neighborhood of Paris known for its “bourgeois bonhomie” — the 11th Arrondissement.

headline: Joel Schumacher, Directing ‘Neighborhood 3,’ Gets an Education
text: On the first preview night for the Flea Theater premiere of “Neighborhood 3: Requisition of Doom,” the set was not quite finished, the music was temporary and the sound designer was not even due to begin work until after the curtain call. “I have no idea what’s going to happen tonight,” said the director, Joel Schumacher, before the show. But he was not sweating it. “I don’t mind anything, except the Republican debates,” he said breezily.

headline: Layoffs Coming at Weinstein Company, Mostly in Film Division
text: LOS ANGELES — The Weinstein Company on Sunday confirmed that it will lay off as many as 50 of its more than 200 employees, mostly in its film division. The layoffs were first reported by Variety. Weinstein has been shifting much of its focus toward television, but continues to work on future films, including “The Six Billion Dollar Man,” planned for 2017, and has high-profile films set for release this year. Those include a pair of likely awards contenders, Todd Haynes’s “Carol” and Quentin Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes a More Defined Stance on ISIS
text: AMES, Iowa – The day after a debate in which Democratic presidential candidates tangled over the causes of Islamic State terrorism but not how to confront it, Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a more forward-looking view of American leadership in response to the threat.

headline: 5 Yemeni Guantánamo Inmates Are Sent to United Arab Emirates
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Defense announced on Sunday that it had transferred five lower-level Yemeni detainees from the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba to the United Arab Emirates. The United States had held each for nearly 14 years as wartime prisoners, and none had been charged with a crime.

headline: Tensions in Iran After Nuclear Deal Grow in Hostility
text: Tensions between the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, and more conservative authorities over the country’s nuclear agreement and its future are turning increasingly bitter, punctuated by public exchanges and growing signs of an anti-American backlash, including arrests.

headline: Mormon Resignations Put Support for Gays Over Fealty to Faith
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Ever since she was an infant being blessed during a church naming ceremony, Lindsay Matson had been on the books of the Mormon Church. As it has done with millions of other members, the church kept note of her spiritual life as she moved from congregation to congregation, took youth leadership posts and married at age 19 in a Mormon temple.

headline: Japan Economy Contracts 0.8%, Returning to Recession
text: TOKYO — The Japanese economy deteriorated more severely than expected in the third quarter, government data released on Monday showed, extending a downturn into a second consecutive three-month period and putting the country in technical recession.

headline: 노스탤지어의 풍경, 뉴욕의 1970년대 말
text: 1970년대 말은 뉴욕 역사상 가장 어둡고 황량하던 시절이었습니다. 그럼에도 왜, 그 시절에 대한 이야기가 끊이지 않는 걸까요?

headline: New York State Workers Laud Higher Minimum Pay
text: Tessa Sheehy works full time as an office assistant for the New York State Department of Labor but lives at home with her mother because she does not earn enough to move out.

headline: How Belgium Became Home to Recent Terror Plots
text: The attacks in Brussels on Tuesday have refocused attention on the Belgian capital as an incubator of radicalism and center for terrorist plots.

headline: Charleston Mayor, Champion for Integration, Prepares to Bow Out
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. sat behind the big desk in his formal and stately City Hall office here, with a photo of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on one wall and a portrait of Gen. Robert E. Lee staring down from another.

headline: Boko Haram Attacks Persist, but Nigerian Officials Say Group Is Losing Ground
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Boko Haram has lost significant ground in northern Nigeria, according to some of the region’s top officials and international security experts, dealing a setback to a group that for years has menaced the nation with murder, abductions and other violence.

headline: First Responders by Accident
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Strip. A Drop. Then a Giants Win Over the Patriots Slips Away.
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the Giants’ locker room minutes after Sunday’s 27-26 loss to the New England Patriots, the players and the coach could not stop replaying all the ways the game could have ended differently.

headline: Inquiry Finds Mounting Proof of Syria Link to Paris Attacks
text: PARIS — On both sides of the Atlantic, the fast-moving investigation into the deadly Paris terrorist attacks steadily accumulated clues on Sunday: a car discovered in the Parisian suburbs with a cache of weapons. Mounting proof of links between the Islamic State in Syria and the attackers. And intense scrutiny on three brothers, living in Belgium, as crucial suspects in the elaborate plot.

headline: Global Soccer Brings Its ‘A’ Game to Brooklyn at BlazerCon
text: “I feel like I just wandered into the soccer-themed bar mitzvah I never had,” said Roger Bennett, one-half of the Men in Blazers duo, seconds after bounding up onto the stage Friday evening to open the festivities at the first BlazerCon, a Comic-Con for soccer nerds.

headline: Retailers’ Earnings, the Star Wars Battlefront Video Game and 2 Technology I.P.O.s
text: Several of the nation’s largest retailers are expected to report earnings this week, and their financial health will be closely watched after dismal numbers from two department store stalwarts — Macy’s and No (Friday)rdstrom — spooked investors last week.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Clippers
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Could Paris Happen Here?
text: Hanover, N.H. — SURVEYING the aftermath of the terror attacks in Paris, most Americans probably feel despair, and a presentiment that it is only a matter of time before something similar happens here. Even as Americans have felt the pain of the French, they have worried, not surprisingly, considering 9/11, about whether their country is next.

headline: At Trial, Prosecutors to Detail Dean Skelos’s Favors for His Son
text: Hydrofracking would seem unlikely fodder for an emotional moment between a father and his son.

headline: For-Profit College System Expected to Pay Millions
text: The nation’s second-largest for-profit college operator, Education Management Corporation, is expected to agree to pay nearly $90 million to settle a case accusing it of compensating employees based on how many students they enrolled, encouraging hyperaggressive boiler room tactics to increase revenue.

headline: Four Teams Will Rise Above the Rest, if Only by Default
text: After a day in which four of the top 10 teams in the College Football Playoff selection committee’s rankings lost, it is fair to ask how anyone can know which teams are good enough to qualify for the Playoff.

headline: Iowa TV Gets Its Close-Up, Enjoying Outsize Influence
text: DES MOINES — The news team at the station KCCI buzzed with nervous anticipation here at Drake University on Saturday night, less than two hours before the start of the Democratic candidates’ debate.

headline: Brands Look Far and Wide for a Niche in Virtual Reality
text: Even in virtual reality, it seems, there will be no escape from advertising.

headline: In Presidential Campaign, It’s Now Terrorism, Not Taxes
text: WASHINGTON — Bernie Sanders dispensed with the threat from the Islamic State in two sentences at the start of the Democratic debate before abruptly pivoting to the dangers of a “rigged economy.” Ben Carson struggled to answer a simple question on Sunday about how he would form a coalition to fight the militant group. And Marco Rubio, after pushing out a new video about the “clash of civilizations,” revamped his plans for an important Monday appearance before a group of executives on the assumption that terrorism, not tax rates, would be their most pressing concern.

headline: Yale College Dean Torn by Racial Protests
text: NEW HAVEN — His cellphone started humming at 11:20 p.m. on Thursday. An urgent voice jolted Jonathan Holloway from his slumber. Students protesting racism on campus were streaming toward the home of the university’s president, the caller said.

headline: Cosmos Win Title in Last Game for Two of Their Stars
text: The Argentine striker Gastón Cellerino scored three goals to lead the Cosmos to a 3-2 victory over the Ottawa Fury in the North American Soccer League championship game on Sunday, stealing the thunder of two more famous teammates but delivering the title they craved in their final competitive game.

headline: Ankle Monitors Weigh on Immigrant Mothers Released From Detention
text: HUNTINGTON, N.Y. — On a recent afternoon, Grace, a 33-year-old mother from El Salvador, sat on a bench inside the train station in this Long Island town, crossed her ankle over her knee, carefully rolled up the cuff of her flared jeans and pointed to the black plastic fist-size object strapped to her ankle. A tiny green light flashed, indicating that the device was charged.

headline: ‘The Leftovers’ Season 2, Episode 7: Crossing Over
text: Kevin Garvey is not dead. Virgil probably isn’t either, not permanently.

headline: Review: In ‘Misery,’ With Bruce Willis and Laurie Metcalf, the Ghost of Productions Past
text: Though it is based on one of Stephen King’s most terrifying novels, the stage version of “Misery” will not, I promise, leave you cold with terror. The production that opened on Sunday night at the Broadhurst Theater, which stars a vacant Bruce Willis (in his Broadway debut) and a hardworking Laurie Metcalf, sustains a steady, drowsy room temperature throughout.

headline: Review: ‘Incident at Vichy,’ an Arthur Miller Tale Set in World War II
text: “We don’t want to alarm people,” says a police captain to a colleague near the beginning of “Incident at Vichy,” Arthur Miller’s 1964 drama about the rounding up of Jews in France under German occupation. The remark resounds with irony, since most of the men surrounding them, who have been pulled off the streets, supposedly so their identity papers can be verified but in fact so they can be revealed as Jews and sent to concentration camps, are practically vibrating with anxiety and subterranean fear.

headline: The Best of Week 10 in the N.F.L.
text: Redskins quarterback Kirk Cousins took advantage of a matchup against the Saints’ struggling defense, throwing a career-high four touchdown passes — each one longer than any he had completed all season — as Washington routed New Orleans. Cousins was 20 for 25 passing for 324 yards, with no interceptions and a perfect passer rating of 158.3. His scoring throws came on passes of 78 yards, to running back Matt Jones; 16 and 8 yards, to tight end Jordan Reed; and 11 yards, to receiver Jamison Crowder. Cousins did not have a scoring toss of more than 7 yards this season.

headline: Ted Cruz and the Anti-Gay Pastor

To be clear, he added that the time for eliminating America’s gay population was “not yet” at hand. We must wait for the nation to embrace the one true religion, he suggested, and gay people must be allowed to repent and convert.

headline: Race, College and Safe Space
text: Before there were the Paris terror attacks that changed everything and the second Democratic presidential debate that changed nothing, much of America had been transfixed by the scene playing out on college campuses across the country: black students and their allies demanding an insulation from racial hostility, full inclusion and administrative responsiveness.

headline: Fearing Fear Itself
text: Like millions of people, I’ve been obsessively following the news from Paris, putting aside other things to focus on the horror. It’s the natural human reaction. But let’s be clear: it’s also the reaction the terrorists want. And that’s something not everyone seems to understand.

headline: Questions for President Obama’s Nominee to lead the F.D.A.
text: President Obama’s nominee to lead the Food and Drug Administration has a long history of close ties to industries the agency regulates. At Dr. Robert Califf’s confirmation hearing on Tuesday, senators will need to ask whether those connections will influence his judgment about the safety or effectiveness of prescription drugs.

headline: Philippines Detaining Homeless Before APEC Summit, Rights Group Says

headline: ‘The Blue Touch Paper: A Memoir,’ by David Hare
text: When David Hare was a child, nothing excited him more than getting lost. From the outset of his adult professional life, however, he knew very well where he was — and how to get from there to where he wanted to be. With his singular combination of talent and tenacity, he always found himself at the center of wherever theatrical daring and excellence were recruited. In 1974, with “Knuckle,” Hare broke through to the West End, among the first of his generation of Oxbridge Young Turks to do so. As a resident dramatist, he ascended the food chain of British theater: from disputatious bouts at the Royal Court to the Nottingham Playhouse during Richard Eyre’s brilliant regime and all the way up to the National Theater, where by 1984 he was an associate director, co-creating the influential Joint Stock Company along the way.

headline: Mindy Kaling’s ‘Why Not Me?’
text: “Why Not Me?” is the title of Mindy Kaling’s breezy new book, arriving on the heels of similar volumes by Tina Fey, Lena Dunham, Sarah Silverman, Amy Poehler and, notably, Kaling herself. Soon, Amy Schumer will tender her offering (which recently sold for a reported $8 million to $10 million, and will doubtless sell like hot cakes, if indeed hot cakes sell in the zillions) to the growing canon of ­memoir-slash-essay collections by women comedians and comedy writers. Clearly, there is something about the combination that’s working.

headline: Les attentats à Paris révèlent les limites de Daesh
text: FLORENCE, Italie — Comme l’a déclaré le Président François Hollande, la France est bien en guerre contre Daesh. La France considère le groupe Islamiste comme son ennemi numéro un. Elle le combat en première ligne avec les Américains au Moyen-Orient, et comme seule nation occidentale dans le Sahel. Elle a engagé dans cette lutte, commencée au Mali en 2013, un pourcentage de son armée bien supérieur à celui des troupes américaines.

headline: Assessing the Fitness of Wearable Tech
text: Like many people who grew up long before personal computers and cellphones became ubiquitous, I’ve never tried a fitness tracker. I already know I walk about five miles a day, in addition to my daily swim. My weight is stable within a range of two pounds. I prefer to remain accountable only to myself, not to a gadget.

headline: Collaborations 3.0: Lee Daniels’s ‘Empire’ and Hood by Air Make a Fashion Statement
text: These days the high fashion designer/fast fashion collaboration has become so ubiquitous (Balmain x H&M, Lilly Pulitzer for Target, the North Face for J. Crew) that it is starting to feel like a calculated formula guaranteed to milk the most from a marketing budget. So it’s nice to see one based on an entirely different premise: fandom.

headline: Jesse Tyler Ferguson Returns to Broadway in ‘Fully Committed’
text: Jesse Tyler Ferguson plays one half of one of television’s most memorable couples on “Modern Family.” But when he returns to Broadway in April, he’ll be all alone. Mr. Ferguson will star in the one-man show “Fully Committed,” a comedy about foodie culture by Becky Mode, starting April 2 at the Lyceum Theater.

headline: Jazzmeia Horn Wins Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition
text: The winner of the 2015 Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition is Jazzmeia Horn. Originally from Dallas, Ms. Horn, 23, is a singer with a smart, steadfast connection to the jazz-vocal tradition, as defined by predecessors like Betty Carter and Sarah Vaughan. Since moving to New York in 2009 to attend the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music, she has been a regular presence on the club scene, often with her band, the Artistry of Jazz Horn.

headline: 1890: Honduras Slays Her Traitors
text: NEW YORK — The Honduras revolution has ended, and General Sanchez and all his principal leaders have been shot. Yesterday morning General Bogran opened fire on the barrack to which the insurgents had retreated. Sanchez and his comrades, knowing that death awaited them, fought desperately; but it was a hopeless struggle from the start. Bogran’s soldiers charged and soon all the rebels remaining alive were prisoners. Without the formality of a court-martial Sanchez and the leading officers were taken to one of the principal squares in the city, blindfolded and stood in line in the presence of hundreds of citizens. The word was given to the firing party, and a crash of musketry rang the death-knell of the revolution. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 17, 1890

headline: It’s Easy to Overestimate Effect of Paris Attacks on 2016 Race
text: Until last week, the threat from terrorism had received little attention from candidates or voters during the 2016 campaign. In one poll, just 3 percent of Americans rated it the most important problem facing the country.

headline: Will Uterine Transplants Make Male Pregnancy Possible?

Is there any reason doctors could not implant a uterus in a man, so that he could become pregnant?”

headline: 1940: King Inspects Coventry’s Ruins

headline: A Savory Alternative to Traditional Stuffing
text: Call this savory mix of wild rice, quinoa, mushrooms and greens a stuffing or a pilaf. It’s not meant to go inside a turkey but it has the definitive herbal flavors I associate with and insist on when I make any kind of stuffing — sage mainly, but also thyme. They are forever stored in my bank of taste memories; I have looked forward to them every Thanksgiving since my first forkful of the packaged stuffing of my youth.

headline: The Challenges for Volkswagen’s Internal Investigation

Step 2 is the key, because the company must then conduct a thorough internal investigation that will deliver the information necessary to assure regulators and prosecutors that the problem has been dealt with and those responsible have been identified.

headline: Taking Stock of the $10 Billion Washington Spent on Colombia’s War
text: The United States has spent more than $10 billion dollars beefing up Colombia’s security forces, supporting development and backing reform of the judicial system in an effort known as Plan Colombia. After playing an instrumental role in giving the Colombian government the upper hand in its decades-long war against the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist guerrilla group, Washington has turned its attention to peacemaking. I talked with Kevin Whitaker, the American ambassador in Bogotá, by email about this evolution and Washington’s decision to sit down with leaders who are under indictment in the United States.

headline: A New Book Looks at the Koch Brothers’ Role in Politics
text: In a 2010 profile of the billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch, the New Yorker writer Jane Mayer described how, from 2005 to 2008, the brothers had vastly outspent ExxonMobil in financing organizations that fight legislation aimed at curbing climate change. Their company, the conglomerate Koch Industries, was also listed as one of the top 10 air polluters in the country, she wrote.

headline: Carnegie Hall Stands Behind Clive Gillinson After Review of Ronald Perelman’s Complaints
text: Carnegie Hall — whose former chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, stepped down last month after clashing with its executive and artistic director, Clive Gillinson — announced on Monday that a legal review that it commissioned had found no evidence to support allegations that Mr. Gillinson had tried to undermine Mr. Perelman’s oversight responsibilities.

headline: Where Ronda Rousey Goes From Here
text: It was Ronda Rousey’s Buster Douglas moment. Those who watched it were stunned. Those who read about it the next morning did a double take. And more than a few people were wondering where it leaves her career.

headline: Defense Rests in Trial of Ex-Coal C.E.O., Calling No Witnesses
text: Lawyers for Donald L. Blankenship, the former coal executive accused of conspiring to violate federal safety standards before 29 people were killed at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia, rested their case on Monday without calling any witnesses.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: Tuesday’s showcase friendly between France and England (3 p.m. Eastern time, Fox Sports 1) has surely morphed into something else by now, part somber memorial service and defiant celebration and group therapy session. The French journalist Philippe Auclair suggested Saturday that English fans join their guests at Wembley in singing the French national anthem, “La Marseillaise,” in solidarity when it is played before kickoff. (England Coach Roy Hodgson has endorsed the idea.) If you want to join in from wherever you are, the lyrics are here. The French probably won’t mind if you fumble a word or two.

headline: Serious Delusions
text: Greg Sargent mocks pundits declaring that the attacks in Paris will finally convince Republican primary voters that they need to get serious, and deflate the Trump/Carson bubble. This time it will really happen!

text: The crush of news from Paris brought an impressive, all-hands response from The Times’s newsrooms in New York and around the world over the weekend. headline: Marriott’s Deal for Starwood Looks Defensive

headline: Donald Trump Repeats Call to Inspect Mosques for Signs of Terrorism
text: Donald J. Trump issued another call for more scrutiny of mosques in the United States as fresh fears of terrorism, spurred by the attacks in Paris, dominated the presidential campaign conversation on Monday.

headline: Taking the (Often Imprecise) Measure of Stress
text: Research has long shown that stress is bad for you, but many people are not even aware when they are feeling stressed.

headline: Early Artworks by Lucian Freud Given to National Portrait Gallery
text: London — A rare collection of 162 childhood drawings; 47 sketchbooks from the 1940s to 2011; and letters and book cover designs by the artist Lucian Freud, who died in 2011, have been given to Britain in lieu of 2.9 million British pounds, or $4.41 million in inheritance tax by the Freud estate.

headline: Paris Attacks Give Rise to Fakes and Misinformation
text: On Friday, as terror attacks unfolded across Paris, rumors were spreading on the Internet even as people remained trapped inside the buildings that were under siege.

headline: AR Capital to Stop Creating Nontraded REITs
text: AR Capital, the real estate investment company built by Nicholas S. Schorsch and William M. Kahane, said Monday that it would stop creating new investment products and close existing ones to new investors to focus on managing the $19 billion it has in current investments.

headline: Cancellation of College Production of ‘Jesus in India’ Over Casting of White Actors Prompts Debate
text: The cancellation of a college production of Lloyd Suh’s play “Jesus in India” over the casting of white actors as Indian characters has prompted a war of words over diversity in theater, with Mr. Suh arguing that the production could send a “dehumanizing” message to minority students and the school countering that the student actors on its rural, predominantly white campus were being “punished for their race.”

headline: Measuring How Financial Advisers Handle Uncertainty
text: Remember how you felt during the financial crisis in 2008? People were scared. Even the professionals were uncertain about what might happen. I know, because I was scared, too.

headline: John Kerry Arrives in Paris to Show ‘Shared Resolve’ After Attacks
text: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Paris on Monday evening, the first senior Obama administration official to visit France since the terrorist attacks on Friday shook the capital and prompted Western nations to re-evaluate their strategy for fighting the Islamic State.

headline: After Paris Attacks, C.I.A. Director Rekindles Debate Over Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — A diabolical range of recent attacks claimed by the Islamic State — a Russian airliner blown up in Egypt, a double suicide bombing in Beirut and Friday’s ghastly assaults on Paris — has rekindled a debate over the proper limits of government surveillance in an age of terrorist mayhem.

headline: In a Tooth, DNA From Some Very Old Cousins, the Denisovans
text: A tooth fossil discovered in a Siberian cave has yielded DNA from a vanished branch of the human tree, mysterious cousins called the Denisovans, scientists said Monday.

headline: Liberty Global to Buy Cable & Wireless for $5.5 Billion
text: Liberty Global, the European cable and wireless operator controlled by John C. Malone, agreed on Monday to buy the British telecommunications company Cable & Wireless Communications for $5.5 billion.

headline: Jawbone in Rock May Clear Up a Mammal Family Mystery
text: With technologies like CT scans and 3-D printing, a team of scientists reported on Monday that it had solved a mystery about the family tree of mammals that started with a single tooth a century and a half ago.

headline: Danny Meyer’s Team Faces a No-Tipping World
text: Thanksgiving came early this year to the Modern. Not the holiday of turkey and cranberry sauce, but the custom of family members lovingly and contentiously coming together to talk (and talk) about the things that unite and divide them.

headline: Europe’s Darkened Future
text: Before we talk about fighting ISIS, let’s talk about the state of Europe. The first time I wrote about the European encounter with Islam in this newspaper was in December of 2009, around the publication of Christopher Caldwell’s “Reflections on the Revolution in Europe,” and the Swiss referendum banning minarets. In that column I wrote critically about the half-thought-out, deliberately un-democratic immigration policies the continent’s leaders had pursued since the 1960s, but I also expressed skepticism about the scenarios of dhimmitude and “Eurabia” floated, long before Michel Houellebecq’s “Submission,” by certain voices on the American and European right. From where I stood, neither demographic projections nor existing patterns of assimilation nor the continent’s ideological currents seemed to support a vision of a Europe where “Shariah has as much clout as liberalism” by, say, 2045. Instead, I argued that the European future would probably be like the present, only more so:

headline: Museum of Modern Art Returns German Artwork to Heirs of Jewish Collector
text: A German Expressionist painting by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner at the Museum of Modern Art will be returned to the heirs of the German art collector Max Fischer, the museum announced Monday.

headline: Homework Help, Pixel by Pixel
text: Parents often worry that technology interferes with a child’s ability to finish homework, but a number of new tech tools are helping students do their homework faster.

headline: Democrats Question Republican-Led Inquiry Into Hillary Clinton’s Aide
text: Members of the Senate Democratic leadership have raised questions about an inquiry led by Senator Charles E. Grassley into Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state, highlighting what one staff member called a “fishy” coincidence: that a former aide to Mr. Grassley now works for the State Department’s inspector general.

headline: Seven Things That Inspire Gaspar Noé
text: The French-Argentine director Gaspar Noé has built his career on the gleeful exploration of the fringes of human experience. Films like “Irreversible,” “Enter the Void” and the newly released “Love” plumb the depths of the uncanny, the impolite, the explicit — with an unflinching eye toward the human capacities for both care and cruelty. They are sometimes hard to watch, and always hard to forget. “Love” is no exception: Noé’s latest film centers on Murphy, an American living in Paris, and his erotically charged relationships; it features many minutes’ worth of unsimulated onscreen sex. (It was also filmed in 3D, and if there’s anything you’re imagining Noé might exploit that technology to depict, you’re probably right.) Here, Noé shares seven of the artworks, films and people who have influenced his work, from Buñuel to Travis Bickle.

headline: That Perfume You Smell Everywhere Is Santal 33
text: Back in 2011, when the fragrance industry saw a rise in celebrity scents and relied on the allure of glossy marketing, the independent perfumery Le Labo proposed an antidote to the obsession with hype: quietly releasing its fifth fragrance in five years — completely unaware of the impact its new unisex perfume would have on a certain set (and generation) of style-conscious women. Like an under-the-radar It bag prized for its unidentifiable features and nondescript branding, Santal 33 quickly became a sort of cult secret, whispered through wafts of sandalwood and cedar, only detected by those in the know.

headline: For French Team, Playing for Country
text: Hugo Lloris, captain of the French national soccer team, spoke about what it would be like to play France’s match with England on Tuesday in London.

headline: Union President, Randi Weingarten, Defends Hillary Clinton on Charter Schools
text: Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, defended Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday over critical remarks she made about charter schools, saying the Democratic presidential candidate had voiced a view many hold about such schools.

headline: An African King in Bolivia
text: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.

headline: Mushroom Essences and More Thanksgiving Helpers
text: It takes but a whiff of two new mushroom elixirs made in the Périgord region of France to understand their vibrant intensity. Added to pan sauces, turkey jus or a toss of sautéed mushrooms and green beans, they would contribute depth of flavor. Morilles (morels), and cèpes (porcini) are the varieties made by macerating fresh mushrooms in alcohol, then distilling the result, which is 36 proof: Mushroom elixirs by Distillerie du Périgord, 6.8 ounces, $21.98 at Zabar’s. $25 at earthy.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: France and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 16, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from France, Belgium, the West Bank and Costa Rica.

headline: Clashes Erupt During Raid in West Bank
text: Israeli troops killed two Palestinians after armed clashes broke out during a raid of the Qalandiya refugee camp in the West Bank.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Twice-Baked Squash
text: Caitlin Galer-Unti, a food writer, thought that baked butternut squash was so nice, she baked it twice.

headline: Chris Stapleton Takes Top Spot on Album Chart Again
text: “Sometimes Cinderella is 37 years old, has a scraggly beard and sounds like a cross between George Jones and Otis Redding.”

headline: Berlin Philharmonic’s Beethoven Marathon at Carnegie Prompts Some Head-Scratching
text: Taking on Beethoven’s nine symphonies in a concentrated marathon of concerts has long seemed almost a requisite undertaking for any conductor of stature — the ultimate public statement of artistic gravitas.

headline: What Travelers Can Expect in Paris
text: France was the top destination for international tourists last year, in no small part because of Paris’s allure. The fatal terrorist attacks in the city on Nov. 13 upended lives and a place that tourists hold dear. Below is information on how hotels and air carriers are accommodating travelers who are affected, when cultural sites are reopening, getting around town and the country and how tourists can do their part to help.

headline: Jets Hope Fitzpatrick’s Thumb Will Be Ready for Sunday
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — After having surgery to repair a torn ligament in his left thumb, Jets quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick will be ready to start at quarterback Sunday in Houston.

headline: For-Profit College Operator EDMC Will Forgive Student Loans
text: The for-profit college operator Education Management Corporation will forgive loans to about 80,000 former students nationwide as part of an agreement with state attorneys general resulting from a multiyear investigation of the company’s aggressive recruitment practices.

headline: Prominent Iranian Cartoonist Reported Arrested in Tehran
text: A prominent press cartoonist in Iran was arrested at work on Monday by security agents who provided no explanation, according to an Iranian news website and rights activists.

headline: Xian Zhang Takes New Jersey Symphony Podium
text: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s next music director will be familiar to some concertgoers in the region: the orchestra announced Monday that the role would be filled by Xian Zhang, a rising Chinese-American star who was an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic for several years before concentrating her recent career in Europe.

headline: ‘School of Rock’ and ‘The Color Purple’ Off to Strong Starts on Broadway
text: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Alice Walker don’t have all that much in common, but Broadway seems to be smiling on both of them this fall.

headline: Scott Campbell’s “Whole Glory”
text: Over four days, the artist gave 23 participants mystery tattoos through a hole in a wall.

headline: Painful Choices for Peyton Manning and the Broncos
text: The Denver Broncos and their quarterback Peyton Manning received another reminder on Sunday that Manning’s illustrious career might be nearing an end.

headline: I Got a Mystery Tattoo From Scott Campbell
text: This past Saturday morning, I got a tattoo from the artist Scott Campbell of Saved Tattoo. Thirty-six hours later, on Sunday night, we met face-to-face for the first time.

headline: Paris in Mourning
text: As France observed a moment of silence on Monday, there were signs of communal grief and heightened security in the capial.

headline: Prison Town in Colorado Doesn’t Want Guantánamo Detainees
text: FLORENCE, Colo. — The Unabomber lives here. So do the men best known as the shoe bomber and the Boston Marathon bomber, as well as a Sept. 11 conspirator and 10,000 other inmates from the infamous to the obscure, sealed behind thick walls and razor-wire fences in the rolling high desert of southern Colorado.

headline: Filings Show Rocky Quarter for Many Hedge Funds
text: Some of the richest investors on Wall Street on Monday gave the world a glimpse of how they make their money. Or, in the case of the last quarter, how many of them lost money for their clients.

headline: Chris Christie, Taking Law-and-Order Stance, Sidesteps Bridge Scandal in ’16 Race
text: Chris Christie’s voice was level, even soft, as he recalled his precise movements on Sept. 11, 2001. Addressing a Republican conference in Florida, he wove a tale that linked his background as a federal prosecutor to a current need for American resolve overseas, and to what he characterized as wavering leadership by a “lawless president.”

headline: Amid Many Emotions, No Choice for France but to Play
text: LONDON — Sitting at a small table in the news conference room at Wembley Stadium on Monday afternoon, Hugo Lloris, the goalkeeper and captain of France’s national soccer team, listened to the question and frowned. Then he hesitated. Then he shrugged. It was clear he wanted to give the right answer, the supportive answer, the answer the French soccer federation would want him to give. But Lloris wanted to be truthful, too.

headline: The Food Police in My Phone
text: It started with a stir fry. I ordered my usual at a nondescript cafe across the street from work: shrimp, tofu, broccoli and snap peas in spicy teriyaki sauce over brown rice.

headline: China Bends Vow on Using Prisoners’ Organs for Transplants
text: BEIJING — When a senior Chinese health official said last year that China would stop using prisoners’ organs for transplants as of Jan. 1, 2015, human rights advocates and medical professionals around the world greeted the announcement with relief.

headline: Governors Against Refugees' Entry
text: Several Republican governors said they opposed letting Syrian refugees enter their states after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday.

headline: ‘Rap Tees’ Catalogs Two Decades of Hip-Hop Merchandising
text: The new photo book “Rap Tees: A Collection of Hip-Hop T-Shirts 1980-1999” by DJ Ross One documents 500 shirts, from hip-hop’s dawn — the first item is a Sugar Hill Gang shirt from 1980, a year after that group released “Rapper’s Delight,” widely considered the first commercial hip-hop single — to its turn-of-the-millennium ubiquity. All the shirts are advertisements, but they go about their job in vastly different ways: Some emphasize logos, others favor slogans or let photos do the talking; a rare few let artists have their way.

headline: The Uncommon Resilience of Parisian Street Life
text: It must be a warm day on the Rue Bichat — a few people have their sleeves rolled up — and the cafes on both sides of the street are open for business, with tables and chairs neatly set up along the sidewalk for customers. Some vendors and deliverymen have left their small carts along the curb. A man, midstride, stares at the camera as he crosses the street, interested in the uncommon event of a photographer setting up his bulky apparatus. A horse-drawn carriage bears a driver and sacks of what appear to be flour or wheat down the Rue Bichat away from its intersection with the Rue Alibert.

headline: Special Section: Wired Well
text: Once personal health technology meant little more than bathroom scales, thermometers and electric toothbrushes. Now, these devices and apps are everywhere: on our wrists, in our phones, the bedroom, the kitchen, even on our children and pets. In this special issue of Science Times, we explore the lives of newly wired consumers and the consequences, good and bad, that arise from our increasing reliance on trackers, monitors, guides and a vast array of other devices to better our health.

headline: Review: Paul Lewis Powers Through a Beethoven Trilogy at White Light Festival
text: The English pianist Paul Lewis was to have more or less anchored the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center this fall, with major appearances early and late. But appendicitis  prevented him from joining the tenor Mark Padmore in three Schubert song cycles last month.

headline: Obama Aims to Shore Up Asian Allies Against Chinese Might
text: ANTALYA, Turkey — President Obama’s arrival in the Philippines on Tuesday morning will kick off five days of presidential diplomacy aimed at bolstering America’s allies in the region against China’s economic and military might.

headline: The Designers Behind Building Block Travel to Taiwan
text: Nancy and Kimberly Wu find inspiration — and eat good food — on their recent trip to the country.

headline: The Designers Behind Building Block Visit Taiwan
text: Since 2011, the designers Kimberly and Nancy Wu have operated Building Block — an L.A.-based design studio that focuses on minimal accessories: handbags, shoes and goods comprised of leather, rubber and wood. Their studio — a whitewashed room (and former feminist art space) in Chinatown — reflects their attitude toward design: simple, clean, not overdone.

headline: More States Are Initiating Programs to Encourage Retirement Savings
text: Nearly 68 million workers do not have access to work-based retirement plans like 401(k)’s for companies and 403(b)’s for nonprofits and government employees. But that is now changing as more states have begun exploring different ways to create savings vehicles for those not covered by existing tax-deferred savings programs.

headline: Pandora Plans to Acquire the Assets of Rdio
text: Since it began 10 years ago, Pandora Media has been focused on one corner of the digital music universe: Internet radio. Now, it is also moving into the world of on-demand music, competing directly with outlets like Spotify and Apple Music.

headline: Review: ‘Sinatra: The Chairman,’ His World, His Way
text: He was America’s greatest vocalist: a consummate artist who redefined the possibilities of popular music, bringing to it an intimacy, an urban swagger and an emotional vulnerability that stamped songs as indelibly his own. A voice — no, the Voice — who could deliver “In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning” and “I’ve Got the World on a String” with equal authority and self-knowledge. A tough guy with Bond-like sophistication and savoir-faire, who sang with uncommon tenderness about loneliness and yearning. A ring-a-ding-ding Vegas showman, rarely without his posse, who could articulate the heartache and existential solitude of the human condition with more conviction than any singer on the planet.

headline: Review: ‘Professor Brenner,’ a 1911 Play About a Generation Gap
text: The New Worlds Theater Project, which presents English adaptations of Yiddish plays, has an intriguing find in “Professor Brenner,” a 1911 work by David Pinski that explores a May-December romance. The production isn’t great, but the historical perspective has some value.

headline: C.I.A. Director Discusses Paris Attacks
text: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, said that the attacks in Paris showed a sophisticated operation and that surveillance internationally had become challenging.

headline: Review: The Formulaic ‘Chicago Med’ Extends an NBC Franchise
text: Most days, Chicago is only the third-largest city in the United States, but beginning this week it may seem as if it’s the dominant one on Tuesdays, as “Chicago Med” joins “Chicago Fire” on NBC’s schedule for that night. If Dick Wolf didn’t have himself a “Chicago” franchise before, he certainly does now; he’s behind those two shows as well as “Chicago P.D.” on Wednesdays.

headline: Review: Jérôme Bel’s ‘Ballet (New York),’ an Exercise in Changing Locations
text: Mr. Bel, the Conceptualist French choreographer, gathers 13 New Yorkers whose training in dance runs from seemingly zero to good enough for New York City Ballet.

headline: Review: Carol Lipnik, a Bewitching Blend of Comedy and Mysticism
text: “Welcome to the séance!” the singer, songwriter and performance artist Carol Lipnik exclaimed to a packed house on Sunday evening at the East Village restaurant and cabaret Pangea.

headline: Review: Yefim Bronfman Plays Prokofiev at Carnegie, Channeling Rage and Grief
text: Before the pianist Yefim Bronfman’s concert on Friday evening at Zankel Hall, Clive Gillinson, executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, requested a moment of silence in honor of the victims of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: Review: David Rabe’s ‘Good for Otto’ Introduces a World of Pain
text: CHICAGO — The sound of an orchestra tuning up signals the start of “Good for Otto,” the new play by David Rabe having its premiere at the small Gift Theater here. It’s a smart touch from the director, Michael Patrick Thornton, for Mr. Rabe’s moving drama does have a symphonic quality, although an apt analogy would be mournful Shostakovich rather than something jubilantly lyrical from, say, Schubert.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Paris, Refugees, Peyton Manning
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: Heidi Latsky Dance and Axis Dance at Skirball Center
text: Anyone walking down LaGuardia Place in Greenwich Village on Sunday night could glimpse Heidi Latsky’s “On Display” through the tall glass doors of the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts. That was just one inclusive dimension of this hourlong movement installation, which was the prelude to an evening shared by Heidi Latsky Dance and Axis Dance Company honoring the 25th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act. Both troupes are made up of dancers with and without disabilities, and reject the notion that disability is a limitation, exploring the potential of many kinds of bodies.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks.

headline: Plan for New Stock Exchange Stirs Furious Debate
text: A proposal to create the first new American stock exchange in five years has set off a fierce debate over how to solve problems created by increasingly complex and high-speed stock markets.

headline: After Paris Attacks, ‘La Marseillaise’ Echoes Around the World in Solidarity
text: It rang out at the Metropolitan Opera, with Plácido Domingo conducting, and before performances by the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and others. Muslim leaders sang it in Paris at the scene of one of Friday’s deadly terror attacks. London’s Wembley Stadium will display its lyrics on large screens to help English-speaking soccer fans muddle through it Tuesday when England plays France.

headline: Amid Tabloid Reports, Charlie Sheen Plans ‘Revealing Personal Announcement’
text: LOS ANGELES — As tabloid reports proliferated on Monday that the troubled television star Charlie Sheen plans to soon reveal his HIV-positive status, one of Hollywood’s top crisis public relations experts confirmed that representatives for Mr. Sheen had in recent months sought his assistance in disclosing the diagnosis.

headline: Paris and Europe’s Anti-Refugee Backlash
text: Berlin — IN Europe, it took the right and the extreme right just hours to turn the terrible events of Paris into political fodder: On Saturday afternoon in France, Laurent Wauquiez, secretary general of the Republicans, the conservative party of former president Nicolas Sarkozy, demanded detention camps for some 4,000 people in France considered potential terrorists by the authorities.

headline: Baltimore Police Assailed for Response After Freddie Gray’s Death
text: BALTIMORE — The first independent review of the Baltimore Police Department’s response to riots in April found “major shortcomings” and said officers were unprepared and untrained for the scale and scope of the unrest.

headline: After Paris Attacks, a Darker Mood Toward Islam Emerges in France
text: PARIS — November is not January. That thought has been filtering through the statements of most French politicians and the news media, and most people seem to understand.

headline: Bronx Program Encourages Fathers to Talk About Sex
text: By the time Victor M. Garcia talked to his father about sex, he himself was already a father of four sons.

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia Questions Logic Behind Gay Rights Protections
text: The Supreme Court’s decisions protecting gay rights were not rooted in the Constitution, and their logic could as easily apply to child molesters, Justice Antonin Scalia told a room filled with first-year law students at Georgetown University on Monday.

headline: Artificial Intelligence Draws New Connections for Personalization
text: An effort to get people better boots may say much about the future of artificial intelligence in the business world.

headline: Minnesota: Federal Inquiry Sought Into Shooting
text: Mayor Betsy Hodges of Minneapolis called Monday for a federal civil rights investigation into an officer-involved shooting early Sunday. The man who was shot, identified by activists as Jamar Clark, who is African-American, remained hospitalized Monday evening. His father, James Hill, said his son was brain-dead. Neighbors quoted in the local news media said Mr. Clark was handcuffed at the time of the shooting, but the authorities said he was not. The Minneapolis police, who have not publicly named Mr. Clark, said the man was a suspect in an assault who disrupted paramedics treating his victim and then fought with officers. The shooting prompted protests. Federal officials did not immediately issue a public response to Ms. Hodges’s request.

headline: U.S.T.A. Responds to Eugenie Bouchard’s Suit Over a Head Injury
text: In response to a lawsuit filed a month ago by Eugenie Bouchard seeking damages for a head injury sustained from a fall during the United States Open, the United States Tennis Association contends that the player did not follow protocol and refused offers of medical attention.

headline: Plan to Close Nuclear Plant in Upstate New York Rattles Its Neighbors
text: SCRIBA, N.Y. — The huge concrete cooling tower standing near the shore of Lake Ontario might give chills to visitors catching a first glimpse of it. But to many residents of this semirural section of Oswego County, the two nuclear power plants in town have been a comforting presence.

headline: Utah Judge Withdraws in Lesbians’ Foster Case
text: DENVER — A judge in Utah who drew national scrutiny for ordering a lesbian couple to give up their infant foster child withdrew from the case on Monday.

headline: Long Island Family Sues Catholic Order and Diocese in Molestation Case
text: In 2009, Augusto Cortez, a Roman Catholic priest, pleaded guilty to forcible touching of a 12-year-old girl in Brooklyn. He was sentenced to six years of probation but was allowed to remain a member of his religious order.

headline: Christopher Kimball, Founder of America’s Test Kitchen, to Leave the Company
text: Christopher Kimball, the face of the public television show “America’s Test Kitchen” and of the magazine Cook’s Illustrated, is leaving the company he helped found after a contract dispute.

headline: The Hidden Costs of Terrorism
text: What is the economic cost of terrorism?

headline: Lobbyist Cites Unease Over Payments to Sheldon Silver
text: The meeting at the State Capitol in Albany took place nearly four years ago, but Richard Runes, a lobbyist who oversees government relations for Glenwood Management, a major real estate developer in New York, recalled his unease at what he had discussed with Sheldon Silver, then the speaker of the Assembly.

headline: Diary of a Food Tracker
text: Research shows that people who keep track of what they eat and weigh on a regular basis are more likely to succeed at losing weight and keeping it off. But as the food diary of Steve Lochner shows, food tracking and weight loss is far from simple.

headline: TIAA-CREF, U.S. Investment Giant, Accused of Land Grabs in Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — As an American investment giant that manages the retirement savings of millions of university administrators, public school teachers and others, TIAA-CREF  prides itself on upholding socially responsible values, even celebrating its role in drafting United Nations principles for buying farmland that promote transparency, environmental sustainability and respect for land rights.

headline: Rookie Honors Follow Playoff Trips for Cubs’ Kris Bryant and Astros’ Carlos Correa
text: The Houston Astros and the Chicago Cubs combined for 197 losses in 2011. No National League teams were worse, and by December of that year, both teams would have new people running their baseball operations. Jeff Luhnow started fresh in Houston, like Theo Epstein in Chicago, both with the necessities for a methodical rebuild: high draft picks and patience.

headline: Martin O’Malley Moving Some Campaign Staff to Iowa
text: Martin O’Malley is shuffling his presidential campaign, sending some staff members from his Baltimore headquarters to Iowa as he tries to climb out of single digits in the polls, a campaign aide said.

headline: Car-Scent Rivals Fight in Trademark Suit
text: In the legal battle of the hanging automotive air fresheners, all that is little are the trees.

headline: Trail’s End Restaurant, Like Much of Montauk, Changes Hands
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — By many measures — mobbed surf lines, outrageous liquor tabs, noise violations, illegal short-term rentals — this was the biggest summer here  since Carl Fisher failed to turn it into Miami Beach North in the 1920s.

headline: G.O.P. Governors Vow to Close Doors to Syrian Refugees
text: Republican fury over illegal immigration and border security took on a new dimension Monday as a growing number of governors, presidential candidates and members of Congress rushed to oppose or even defy President Obama’s plan to resettle 10,000 Syrian refugees.

headline: Encrypted Messaging Apps Face New Scrutiny Over Possible Role in Paris Attacks
text: WASHINGTON — American and French officials say there is still no definitive evidence to back up their presumption that the terrorists who massacred 129 people in Paris used new, difficult-to-crack encryption technologies to organize the plot.

headline: Tree-Shaped Air Freshener Lawsuit
text: Car-Freshner Corporation is suing a competitor that it says used similar packaging, scent names and logos.

headline: A Father’s Love of Sports Inspires a Daughter’s Career
text: Zbigniew Macur, 1933-2015

headline: Before Paris Attack, the Bataclan Had Long History in Music and Politics
text: PARIS — Crowds gathered on Monday to place flowers and candles and pay their respects to the 89 people killed at the Bataclan, as speculation swirled about why the legendary music hall was the target of the most brutal of the terrorist attacks on Friday.

headline: Marco Rubio Criticizes Ted Cruz on Security Issues
text: Marco Rubio of Florida criticized his Senate colleague Ted Cruz of Texas on Monday night, accusing him of being weak on national security as the presidential race takes a sharper focus on how safe Americans are from attack.

headline: Parties Split on Response but United Behind France
text: WASHINGTON — Congress has come a long way from “freedom fries.”

headline: Seizing a Second Chance After a Bout With Cancer
text: In the months after Karen Watson learned she had breast cancer, she tried to shield her three daughters from the daily pain and uncertainty she was living with.

headline: Hey, Mister
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Paula Gamache is back. Are you listening? I said, Paula Gamache is back. And she’s all EARs today, so make sure you leave a comment on her Tuesday puzzle.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 6: Jumping Ahead
text: One of the most interesting elements of “Jane the Virgin” is the pacing. It’s always been pretty quick — after all, it is mimicking the style of a telenovela — but in a way that never confuses viewers or feels rushed. “Chapter Twenty-Eight” uses this rapid-fire approach to its advantage by fast-forwarding through entire months without dropping any important story points. The episode begins the day after the events of last week, immediately reassuring us that baby Mateo is O.K. before jumping into this week’s big plots. Jane is officially starting her life with Michael — and starting graduate school — while getting closer to Rafael, even as the two disagree on finances. Petra has her hands full with Milos’s surprise grenades, Michael is on a strange road trip with Nadine, and Rogelio is trying to figure out what his future will be after his television show ends.

headline: Study Strongly Links Baltimore Mortgage Denials to Race
text: The black population of Baltimore is double that of the white population. Yet in 2013, banks made more than twice as many mortgage loans to whites in the city as they did to blacks.

headline: New York Public Library Acquires Archive of The New York Review of Books
text: The archive of The New York Review of Books has been sold to the New York Public Library, which praised the material in an announcement as providing “unique evidence of intellectual life in the United States in the second half of the 20th century.”

headline: The Paris Attackers: Who Were They?
text: A snapshot of seven men suspected in Friday’s terrorist attacks in Paris, including Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian who is believed to have been the architect of the assaults.

headline: In Suspects’ Brussels Neighborhood, a History of Petty Crimes and Missed Chances
text: BRUSSELS — Just eight days before Ibrahim Abdeslam blew himself up in Paris as part of an elaborate terrorist operation that killed 129 people on Friday, the authorities in the heavily immigrant Brussels district of Molenbeek already had the future terrorist in their sights.

headline: In Mexico, Mennonite Farmers Struggle With Water Shortage
text: Underground reservoirs have been drained by thirsty crops, like corn, that are the mainstay of the Mennonites’ success.

headline: Mennonite Farmers Prepare to Leave Mexico, and Competition for Water
text: RIVA PALACIO, Mexico — On the edge of a high plain fringed by craggy sandstone hills, Johan Friesen’s small farm is a testament to the rural providence of his Mennonite people.

headline: Aaron Shikler, Portrait Artist Known for Images of America’s Elite, Dies at 93
text: Aaron Shikler, an artist whose portraits of America’s economic, political and social elite included a brooding John F. Kennedy, a sorrowful Jacqueline Kennedy and a buoyant Ronald Reagan in jeans and work shirt, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Waiter Killed in Paris Attacks Is Remembered as a Bon Vivant
text: PARIS — A few months ago, when Annabel Mouraud, a waitress, was feeling depressed after losing an uncle to cancer, Guillaume Le Dramp, a fellow waiter, arrived at the restaurant where they worked with a small gift and a wide smile: a children’s book titled “Little Miss Lucky.”

headline: Video of an Arrest in San Francisco Triggers Investigations Into Deputies’ Use of Force
text: LOS ANGELES — The video footage is grainy, but the violence is clearly visible: When sheriff’s deputies catch the suspect fleeing down a San Francisco street, they tackle him, then begin hitting him. First, they use fists, then batons, swinging the clubs down with both hands as the man lies on the ground, moaning.

headline: Where ISIS Claims It Has Struck, and Why
text: The attacks in Paris amounted to the boldest coordinated assault claimed by the Islamic State against a Western country, and showed how the radical militant group has expanded from its beginnings as a Sunni terrorist group in Iraq.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 2, Episode 6: Defending the Common Man
text: The turf war between the Gerhardts and the Kansas City syndicate — incidentally, the Kansas City Syndicate sounds like another prog-rock band — continued to escalate in “Rhinoceros,” an action-packed hour that seems of a piece with last week’s episode, which found the show shifting to backstretch payoff mode. It even begins on the Blumquist’s porch, reversing the angle of last week’s final shot of Luverne policemen coming for Ed.

headline: Donald Trump Questions Whether Syrian Refugees Are a ‘Trojan Horse’
text: Donald J. Trump questioned whether Syrian refugees are part of a “Trojan horse” plot, suggested buying land in Syria to create a “safe space” and said that in 2000 he could “feel” that terrorists were going to strike in the United States, as he rallied a large crowd of supporters in Tennessee on Monday evening.

headline: Paris Attacks Complicate Europe’s Already Strained Border Controls
text: The news that one of the Paris attackers entered Europe with a Syrian passport last month, amid the hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing war and persecution, has alarmed leaders and reinvigorated talk about tightening border controls.

headline: Yankees Hire Bullpen Coach
text: The Yankees hired Mike Harkey as their bullpen coach, completing their coaching staff for next season. Harkey, 49, who served in the same role for the Yankees from 2008 to 2013, was fired as the Arizona Diamondbacks’ pitching coach after the season. He replaces Gary Tuck, whom the Yankees fired last month.

headline: A Survivor’s Story: ‘I’m Coming Home’
text: François Granier, 24, went to the Bataclan concert hall in Paris on Friday night. After gunfire erupted, he grabbed a bloodied drumstick from backstage. “I know it’s pathetic, but this was one of the things that allowed me to try to keep some hope,” he said.

headline: Casper Hopes Its ‘One for All’ Concept Translates to One Pillow
text: Jeff Chapin, the chief product officer at Casper, has 30 prototype pillows strewn around his bedroom. One of them, the end result of a design and testing process that lasted more than a year, is what Casper hopes will be the holy grail of bedding: one pillow, perfect for all sleepers.

headline: Texas: Tornado Rips Through Halliburton Plant
text: A tornado ripped through a Halliburton plant an hour northeast of Amarillo on Monday, causing a chemical leak that emergency crews were working to contain, the authorities said. The Gray County Sheriff’s Office said two deputies who were exposed to the chemical, which was unspecified, refused medical treatment. There were no reports of injuries. Lt. Zach Kidd said no one was inside the building, in Pampa, Tex., when the tornado struck, and several vehicles parked outside were unoccupied. Radioactive material housed at the site was not affected, he said. The tornado was one of four that touched down in the county as a severe weather system moved across the region, according to the sheriff’s office. Two homes and several businesses sustained damage ranging from minor to severe, officials said.

headline: Syria: Iran Reaffirms a Role for Assad
text: An Iranian official said Monday that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria should remain in power and be included in elections as part of any diplomatic negotiation aimed at ending the civil war. The statement, by Hossein Amir Abdollahian, a deputy foreign minister, was not a new position for Iran, Mr. Assad’s regional ally. But it reinforced the deep divide that remains over Mr. Assad’s future in the international talks on Syria, even as pressure has intensified for a solution. Diplomats participating in the talks in Vienna over the weekend represented more than a dozen countries, including the United States, which has said Mr. Assad cannot be part of any final settlement. Mr. Abdollahian was quoted by Iran’s Fars News Agency as saying Iran ensured that a statement issued at the meeting’s conclusion excluded any language that would limit Mr. Assad’s role in a postwar government.

On the other hand, these shows are often careful to avoid tragic subjects where seemingly no comedy can be found.

But those laws, some of which date to the distant past, have been rendered ineffective by debt collectors using new and devious ways to win court judgments that allow them to seize debtors’ paychecks or bank accounts.

headline: How to Help Save the Mentally Ill From Themselves

headline: Inadequate Transportation Bills in Congress

Unfortunately, the legislation will not do nearly enough to improve aging bridges, fix highways or expand the capacity of mass transit and rail systems. Worse, it could make traveling on American roads and railways less safe.

headline: In Bangladesh, a Half-Century of Saving Lives With  Data

When she smiles, she reveals teeth stained brown from betel nut. She has lived all her life in this village in Matlab, a sub-district in central Bangladesh.
