text: Earlier this month, we asked the 22 members of our Student Council to hunt through The New York Times and find pieces on seasonally resonant themes like home, food, family and giving.

headline: Paris Attacks Highlight Jihadists’ Easy Path Between Europe and ISIS Territory
text: LONDON — One of the militants in the Paris attacks traveled to Syria from his hometown in France and back, officials said, even after his passport had been confiscated and he had been placed under judicial oversight. So did another, despite having been arrested eight times in petty crimes and having been listed as a national security risk in France.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names Susie Huang to Lead Mergers in the Americas
text: Morgan Stanley has named Susie Huang head of mergers and acquisitions for the Americas, two weeks after her predecessor announced his plans to leave for Comcast.

headline: Volkswagen Faces Major Spending Cuts and Regulatory Deadlines
text: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen is expected to announce substantial spending cuts on Friday as the carmaker braces for the financial impact of its emissions-cheating crisis — potentially setting up a confrontation with its powerful labor representatives.

headline: Review: New Juilliard Ensemble Embraces Rilke
text: “Why so little Rilke-music?” a critic from The New York Times asked over 20 years ago, noting how many composers have kept a respectful distance from this great poet. Among those who have heeded the challenge of setting his texts is the composer James Primosch, who has turned to Rilke’s religious poetry for a number of songs that elegantly combine personal fervor and worldly sophistication.

headline: Adviser Who Questioned Ben Carson’s Grasp of Mideast Is Consulted for Op-Ed Piece
text: A foreign policy adviser whom Ben Carson publicly distanced himself from after the adviser criticized Mr. Carson’s grasp of the Middle East provided input for an opinion column Mr. Carson published online in The Washington Post on Wednesday about defeating the Islamic State.

headline: Review: A Pierre Boulez Tribute, Eight Months Late
text: This city has not done right lately by Pierre Boulez, who turned 90 in March. The New York Philharmonic — of which he was music director from 1971 to 1977, in a tenure now often criticized as recondite in its programming (untrue) and dire in its ticket sales (ditto) — did nothing to honor the birthday. Nor did our other major cultural institutions.

headline: PHD Terrace Brings ‘Downtown Cool’ to Midtown
text: “Offices, offices, offices,” said Matt Strauss, the managing partner of PHD Terrace in Midtown. “Tourists, tourists, tourists.” He was waving toward the kaleidoscopic lights and humanity glob of nearby Times Square, visible from the two-floor lounge that opened in early October atop the Dream Midtown hotel. “But we’re infusing it with our brand of downtown cool,” he said.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Backing Jeb Bush to Air Ads in Ohio, Home of John Kasich
text: The “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign will start showing television ads next week in Ohio, the home state of Gov. John R. Kasich — a rival candidate who shares a similar political space with Mr. Bush in the Republican primary.

headline: Treasury Plans Additional Rules to Deter Inversions
text: The Treasury Department plans to announce additional proposals this week to deter corporate inversions, a strategy some American companies have used to move their headquarters to lower-tax nations overseas by way of a corporate merger.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: France and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Lea Salonga To Star in ‘Fun Home’ in the Philippines
text: Lea Salonga, the Tony Award-winning actress who is now starring on Broadway in “Allegiance,” will return to her native Philippines next year to star in the first international production of “Fun Home.”

headline: Nov. 18, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from France, Serbia, India and Spain.

headline: At Of Mercer, Making Workwear Less Work
text: Getting dressed for the office is rough. “A girl could croak trying to get it right,” wrote Helen Gurley Brown in her advice bible “Having It All.”

headline: Art Bookstore Printed Matter Has New Home
text: In 2012, Printed Matter, the nonprofit art bookstore started by Sol LeWitt and the art critic Lucy R. Lippard, lost more than 9,000 books and sustained hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Review: Krysten Ritter Is a Gumshoe With Superhero Troubles in ‘Jessica Jones’
text: “Jessica Jones,” the second of Netflix’s original series based on Marvel comic books (after “Daredevil”), is reluctantly superheroic. Created by Melissa Rosenberg, the screenwriter of five “Twilight” movies as well as a writer on TV shows including “Dexter,” and starring the acerbic Krysten Ritter of “Don’t Trust the B____ in Apartment 23,” it’s a clever 21st-century take on film noir, featuring a heroine who hides her superstrength because it’s at the root of her extreme emotional vulnerability and fear. There’s a tricky balancing act going on — crossing a moody detective show with both a comic action thriller and a woman-in-peril psychological drama — but Ms. Rosenberg proves to be mostly up to the task.

headline: Settlement in New York Domestic Violence Case May Set Broader Precedent
text: The New York State attorney general has reached a potentially significant settlement with Bon-Ton Stores, which has more than 200 department stores across the northern part of the country, over a workplace discrimination complaint filed by a victim of domestic violence.

headline: Review: Adele Holds Firm on ‘25,’ Even as Pop Shifts
text: Absence has a way of ossifying an idea and amplifying a legend. Those have been gifts for Adele, who has just returned after a break of almost five years with her third album, “25” (XL/Columbia).

headline: Review: Contact! Presents ‘Young Americans,’ a New York Philharmonic Showcase for Emerging Composers
text: Before introducing his piece “Flashbacks” on Monday evening at National Sawdust, the new performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Mario Davidovsky joked that he didn’t know how he ended up on a lineup of such “talented and handsome” composers.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Paris, Russia, Boko Haram
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Patrick Fallon, Whose Midwest Ad Agency Had National Reach, Dies at 70
text: Patrick R. Fallon, a co-founder of the Minneapolis-based advertising agency that made its name with imaginative campaigns for media companies and luxury carmakers like BMW and Porsche, died on Friday in Robbinsdale, Minn. He was 70.

headline: Maryland College to Remain Closed as Police Search for Student
text: With the police still unable to locate a student who disappeared and may have a gun, the Maryland college he attends said Wednesday that it would remain closed until after the Thanksgiving weekend — two weeks after the search for him began.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Marine Le Pen’s Change in Tone
text: Following the attacks in Paris, a look back at how the National Front party leader's language has evolved over the last five years on issues such as immigration and nationalism.

headline: Cate Blanchett of ‘Carol’ Takes a Bow
text: Cate Blanchett seemed only dimly aware of the cameras registering her arrival Tuesday night at the Museum of Modern Art: She was too deep in conversation with Martin Scorsese, whom she towered above.

headline: A Feminist T-Shirt Resurfaces From the ‘70s
text: In October, Cara Delevingne was photographed in Paris wearing a navy sweatshirt that read “The Future Is Female” in clean white text. The same month, Ms. Delevingne’s girlfriend, the musician Annie Clark (a.k.a. St. Vincent), wore the same shirt, paired with a white Chanel bag, to the Chateau Marmont in Hollywood.

headline: Review: Celebrating Cecil Taylor, a Pianist of Endless Influence
text: “Cecil Taylor: From the Five Spot to the World,” a gala concert at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse on Tuesday night, opened with welcoming remarks wrapped around a disclaimer. “Cecil will not be with us this evening,” Pat Cruz, the executive director of Harlem Stage, announced in a soothing tone, “and we will miss him.”

headline: Half of New Yorkers Say They Are Barely or Not Getting By, Poll Shows
text: Half of New York City residents say they are struggling economically, making ends meet just barely, if at all, and most feel sharp uncertainty about the future of the city’s next generation, a new poll shows.

headline: Punk Portraits of New York
text: William Coupon’s classic style started out in an chaotic place: the Mudd Club. He slowed things down to the pace of formal portraiture, taking the circus out of the tent.

headline: Officer Shoots Man Reaching for Gun After Chase in Brooklyn, Police Say
text: For Kareem Thomas, Wednesday started with an appearance in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, where he is fighting charges of attempted murder in connection with a shooting at a bodega in October 2011. By the evening, the authorities said, Mr. Thomas was in Kings County Hospital Center, a gunshot to his lower back from a police bullet.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/Siena College Poll
text: A survey found 51 percent of New York City residents feel they are either just getting by or finding it difficult to do so, with residents in Brooklyn and the Bronx having the most pronounced sense of economic insecurity.

headline: The Right Tools for Richer Audio
text: Digitizing music has not delivered the sound of CDs and vinyl records. Now that quality can be conjured with the right products.

headline: Turkey’s Role as Migrant Gateway Is Source of New Urgency for E.U.
text: BERLIN — The Turkish border police detained eight Moroccans in Istanbul this week after becoming suspicious that they were Islamic radicals who planned to infiltrate Europe by joining the migrant stream.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow and Valentino Channel Wonder Woman
text: Select looks from the collaboration that will go on sale on Nov. 23.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow Talks About a Surprising Fashion Muse
text: On a recent morning, a soundstage in Long Island City, Queens, was filled with people. The photographer Terry Richardson was running about in one of his trademark flannel shirts. Organic food was being served by the truckload.

headline: New York Store Openings and Other Shopping Events
text: Skip your trip to the dry cleaner this week. On Friday, the Laundress, an eco-friendly detergent line founded by Gwen Whiting and Lindsey Boyd, who met studying fiber science at Cornell and left jobs at Chanel and Ralph Lauren to educate consumers about alternative fabric care, will open a shop in SoHo. The cedar-extract, sulphite-free wool and cashmere shampoo ($19) works wonders in the washing-machine delicate cycle. At 199 Prince Street.

headline: Review: Tyshawn Sorey Goes His Own Way at the Vanguard
text: It’s going to be rare to see the improvising drummer Tyshawn Sorey do anything mechanically or thoughtlessly at the Village Vanguard this week. He’s got hyperprecision technique; he could keep you engaged for a long time with straight swing or regularly accented music, and he’s done that in plenty of groups led by other people, jazz or otherwise.

headline: Marco Rubio Returns Fire on Ted Cruz
text: Two can play at this game, Senator Cruz.

headline: Hurdles for Canadian Pacific-Norfolk Southern Deal
text: Canadian Pacific Railway will probably have to come up with more than $28.4 billion to keep a Norfolk Southern deal on track. The company justifies its unsolicited bid for its American rival by promoting cost savings worth more than $12 billion. But Canadian Pacific shareholders would keep $5 billion of that amount for themselves. Given antitrust risks, the merger price could use stoking.

headline: Results of U.A.W. Vote Show Ford Pact Losing
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union said on Wednesday that a slight majority of workers at Ford Motor Company have so far voted against a proposed new labor agreement.

headline: Attorney General of N.Y. Picks Top Deputies
text: The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has named two top lieutenants who will split oversight of criminal cases and the civil cases brought by the office.

headline: U.S. to Sue Contractor It Says Bilked the Navy
text: After nearly two years of settlement talks broke down, the Justice Department announced Wednesday that it was moving forward with a civil fraud lawsuit against one of the ship-supply contractors said to have overcharged the Navy by tens of millions of dollars.

headline: For Its I.P.O., Square Scales Back Valuation by $3 Billion
text: The long-running gold rush into hot technology start-ups showed signs of faltering on Wednesday, as a much-anticipated market debut had to scale back its ambitions.

headline: Pleased With Progress, Jets General Manager Says There Is Still Work to Do
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — General Manager Mike Maccagnan praised his coach, extolled his starting quarterback, complimented his backup quarterback, hailed the Jets’ depth and lauded their progress. His responses at his midseason news conference Wednesday, in other words, were predictable for a first-year general manager presiding over a team that is — at 5-4 and on the periphery of the A.F.C. wild-card chase — an improvement by any measure over last season’s fiasco.

headline: Fantasy Sports Inquiry Puts Spotlight on a Success for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo has long been a top online destination for sports fans, and this year, it made two big bets to expand that audience: its multimillion-dollar deal to webcast a National Football League game and its July entrance into the world of daily fantasy sports contests.

headline: Jake Arrieta and Dallas Keuchel, Newly Anointed Aces, Win Cy Young Awards
text: Jake Arrieta and Dallas Keuchel reported to spring training in February with a combined career record of 55-59 and zero appearances on Cy Young Award ballots. By the end of the season they were certified aces, lifting their teams to the division series with shutout pitching in the wild-card games.

headline: Robert F. Dall, Mastermind of Mortgage-Backed Bonds, Dies at 81
text: Robert F. Dall, an investment banker and a pioneer of the mortgage bond market on Wall Street, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: China Insists to U.N. That It’s Combating Torture
text: GENEVA — Senior Chinese officials dismissed allegations of the widespread use of torture, responding Wednesday to questions from a United Nations panel by affirming their commitment to eliminating the practice — though with a dearth of details.

headline: Pfizer and Allergan Said to Be Near Merger for Up to $150 Billion
text: Pfizer is nearing a deal to buy Allergan, a rival drug maker that has its headquarters in Ireland, for as much as $150 billion, potentially helping the company move its corporate citizenship abroad and reduce its tax bill, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: De Blasio, Drawing New Battle Line, Takes Aim at Christie on Refugees
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio is already battling one governor. Now he is taking on another.

headline: Malloy Welcomes a Syrian Family to Connecticut as Christie Shuns Refugees
text: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut on Wednesday personally welcomed a refugee family from Syria who had been diverted from Indianapolis to New Haven.

headline: F.B.I. Director Repeats Call That Ability to Read Encrypted Messages Is Crucial
text: The F.B.I. director and the Manhattan district attorney on Wednesday sought to reopen the argument that law enforcement and intelligence officials need to have access to encrypted information on smartphones with court approval.

headline: Refugees From War Aren’t the Enemy
text: The House is expected to vote Thursday on H.R. 4038, the American Security Against Foreign Enemies (SAFE) Act of 2015, which Republican sponsors say “would put in place the most robust national-security vetting process in history” for refugees, one that would “do everything possible to prevent terrorists from reaching our shores.”

headline: Republicans Push to Halt Syrian Refugee Program
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans increased pressure on the White House on Wednesday to halt a program for Syrian refugees, setting up a confrontation with President Obama over the issue as they head into a battle over spending next month.

headline: Senators Revive Financing Tactic From ’70s for Carbon Emissions
text: For years, power companies, manufacturers and entrepreneurs have tried to make capturing and storing carbon emissions from industrial operations like burning coal into a business, to little avail.

headline: Upset Over a Fracking Ban
text: In a phone conversation secretly recorded by the F.B.I., Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son, Adam, discuss Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s support for a fracking ban.

headline: Review: Complexions Contemporary Ballet Performs to Bach and Metallica
text: Complexions Contemporary Ballet, a company formed in 1994 by Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, has done what, for many midsize companies, remains impossible: It has lasted. But for a troupe named in honor of the multicultural makeup of its dancers, it remains distressingly bland. Where diversity also matters — in its choreography — is where this company falls short. No matter the mood or music, a sequence often repeats in Mr. Rhoden’s pieces: After a running start, a dancer slides onto the stage, strikes an assertive pose and then — as if trapped inside a force field — shifts position by flicking a hip or tossing off a pirouette before retreating to the wings.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis, Wanting More, Gives the Knicks Hope
text: Long before it took Kristaps Porzingis all of 12 regular-season games to become a sensation with the Knicks, he plied his trade for Baloncesto Sevilla of Spain’s ACB League. As Sevilla’s general manager, José Luis Galilea became uniquely familiar with Porzingis, and he could sense the player’s bright future.

headline: What Presidential Candidates Have Said About the Black Lives Matter Movement
text: What some of the presidential candidates have said about the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: One Slogan, Many Methods: Black Lives Matter Enters Politics
text: When the Democratic National Committee recently rejected adding a presidential debate focusing exclusively on issues affecting black people, it got divergent responses from two groups widely associated with the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline: De Blasio Unveils Plan to Create 15,000 Units of Housing
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking to bolster his administration’s efforts on homelessness, unveiled a plan on Wednesday to create 15,000 units of housing aimed at veterans, victims of domestic violence, people with mental illness and others with complex needs that go beyond the economics of paying for a place to live in New York.

headline: With Eviction Looming, an Injured Worker Accelerates His Job Search
text: For the 18 months he was homeless, Andre Gomes spent nights sleeping on No. 6 subway trains. He felt safer on the trains than he did in a shelter, where people had threatened his life and knocked out his bottom teeth.

headline: Jury Hears Where Sheldon Silver’s Money Went as U.S. Rests Case
text: With State Assemblyman Sheldon Silver accused of taking in nearly $4 million in illicit fees through various quid pro quo schemes, a question has arisen: Where did the money go?

headline: Search Engine Feature
text: “To sleep, perchance to Dream; aye, there’s the RUB …” — Hamlet, Act III, Scene 1

headline: Review: In ‘Steve,’ Contemplating Middle Age and Monogamy
text: Hello, not-so-young lovers, wherever you are. Do you know what Rodgers and Hammerstein show I’m (sort of) quoting there? Even if you don’t (it’s “The King and I”), you’re likely to have a swell time at “Steve,” a surprisingly serious comedy by Mark Gerrard in which no event is so grave or so trivial that it cannot be annotated with a musical comedy reference.

headline: Ad Supporting John Kasich Derides Rivals’ Experience
text: An independent group backing Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio accuses Ben Carson and Donald J. Trump of being unprepared for the presidency in a new TV ad, linking the political outsiders to President Obama in requiring “on-the-job training.’’

headline: Reviews Reveal Divisions Within the Clinton Health Initiative, Starting at the Top
text: Inside the sprawling philanthropy founded by former President Bill Clinton, its health initiative, run by a longtime friend and policy adviser to the Clintons, holds a vaunted place, with the largest budget of any program in the foundation and a distinguished record of fighting diseases like AIDS and tuberculosis in underdeveloped countries.

headline: Jonah Lomu, 40, Dies; Rugby Superstar Melded Power and Speed
text: Jonah Lomu, whose size, strength and speed made him one of rugby’s most fearsome wings, a record-setting, nearly unstoppable scorer for the All Blacks, New Zealand’s national team, died late Tuesday or early Wednesday at his home in Auckland, New Zealand. He was 40.

headline: California Judge Orders Frozen Embryos Destroyed
text: In the first decision in California to address a dispute over the fate of frozen embryos after a couple’s divorce, a state judge in San Francisco on Wednesday ordered the destruction of five embryos after a man challenged his ex-wife’s right to use them.

headline: Stephen Birmingham, Chronicler of the Rich and Other Elites, Dies at 86
text: Stephen Birmingham, the prolific novelist, purveyor of popular sociology and raconteur of the rich and famous in best-selling books like “ ‘Our Crowd’: The Great Jewish Families of New York” and “The Right People: A Portrait of the American Social Establishment,” died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Nasal Spray to Combat Opioid Overdose
text: A nasal spray designed to reverse opioid overdoses won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, expanding the options for treating drug overdoses without medical training. Until now, all versions of the overdose reversal drug naloxone were injectable. The spray, called Narcan, will make it easier for ordinary people to treat someone who has taken too much oxycodone, morphine or heroin. Adapt Pharma Inc., the company that makes it, said it would offer the spray at a discount to emergency workers, firefighters and the police.

headline: Syria: Truce Near Damascus Is Planned
text: Syrian antigovernment activists said Wednesday that government forces and insurgent factions in the Damascus suburbs planned to announce a Russian-brokered deal for a 15-day cease-fire that could begin as soon as Thursday. United Nations officials and international negotiators are trying to hammer out a countrywide cease-fire as world leaders gather in Vienna in an effort to renew peace talks, and it was unclear whether the Russian-brokered effort was separate and parallel, or a step toward reaching a more comprehensive agreement. The Russian involvement was seen as a sign that it now had the upper hand — more so than Iran, President Bashar al-Assad’s closest ally. The truce would cover the East Ghouta suburbs that have been cut off from Damascus by the fighting. The truce would open checkpoints into East Ghouta, allowing humanitarian aid to get in and civilians to leave, according to several antigovernment activists reached in the area.

headline: Group Led by Turing Chief Acquires Majority of Biotech Firm
text: Martin Shkreli, the brash pharmaceutical executive whose abrupt fiftyfold increase in the price of an old infectious disease drug sparked an uproar, has acquired a majority of the shares of a publicly traded biotechnology company that was about to go out of business.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates Wins National Book Award
text: Ta-Nehisi Coates won the National Book Award for nonfiction Wednesday night for “Between the World and Me,” a visceral, blunt exploration of his experience of being a black man in America, which was published this summer in the middle of a national dialogue about race relations and inequality.

headline: Taking Power
text: Adam Skelos calls to congratulate his father for ousting Senator Jeffrey Klein from his position as co-leader of the Senate.

headline: Tapes Played at Skelos Corruption Trial Portray Strategy Used Against Democrats
text: Jurors at the federal corruption trial of the former State Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, and his son listened on Wednesday to a series of riveting, raw and sometimes bizarre wiretapped conversations. Prosecutors played them as part of an effort to show what was going on behind the scenes as the senator voted on legislation and took other actions that the government has said would benefit his son, a situation most of his fellow legislators were not aware of.

headline: Three Conference Finalists Are Fighting to Return to Last Season’s Level
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The tone of Brian Boyle’s voice had the urgency that N.H.L. players usually save for spring. Emotional and physical reservoirs are only so deep, and the draining quest for a Stanley Cup can grind on for nine months.

headline: Princeton Students Hold Sit-In on Racial Injustice
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Amid racial tension on campuses across the country, Princeton University announced on Wednesday that it would change the title of those who oversee its residential colleges to “head” from “master.”

headline: An Improbable Survival
text: Sébastien rescued a woman hanging from the window of the Bataclan concert hall in Paris. Then he survived a two-hour hostage standoff.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | feral
text: feral • \ˈfir-əl, ˈfer-; ˈfe-rəl\ • adjective

headline: Arena Security Reviewed After Paris Terror Attacks
text: PARIS — In Trinidad, armed police officers in riot gear were called in to secure a soccer match. In Japan, officers positioned on rooftops monitored a marathon. And in Spain, a “very intense security apparatus” is planned for Saturday’s Real Madrid-Barcelona soccer showdown, including a three-layer perimeter around the famed Santiago Bernabéu Stadium and a doubling of the already increased number of security personnel who will, among other things, inspect fans’ sandwiches.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: The holiday starts early, and a mite strange, with a lip sync battle and a series about art smuggling. And it’s the last chance in 2015 for a Shonda Rhimes night.

headline: Corrections: November 19, 2015
text: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I say it firmly: France will remain the country of liberty, of movements, of culture. An active, valiant, dynamic country.”

headline: Israeli Officer Sentenced to Community Service in Beating of Palestinian-American
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli border police officer who was filmed beating a Palestinian-American teenager on the edges of a riot in East Jerusalem in July 2014 has been sentenced to 45 days of community service and a suspended prison term of four months, Israeli officials said.

headline: Stung by Edict on Gays, Mormons Leave Church
text: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints did not seem eager to draw attention to its recently updated guidance on gay marriage. In a memo shared confidentially, the church instructed leaders that Mormons in same-sex relationships were to be treated as “apostates.” Children being raised by two moms or two dads, the edict held, should be banished from the church until they become adults and can renounce their parent’s union.

headline: Chris Christie’s Bridge Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sleazy Business as Usual in Albany
text: The separate federal trials this month of the former Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and Dean Skelos, former leader of the State Senate, are about the same thing: public corruption at the highest levels of New York State government. Both men were bounced from their leadership jobs and both now confront multiple charges of kickbacks, bribery and extortion, all carefully hidden in secret documents and phone calls.

headline: A Holiday Treat From Congress
text: In honor of the coming vacation travel season, the Senate is working on a bill that would loosen the requirement that pilots take medical examinations.

headline: Europe’s Welcome Sign to Terrorists
text: EUROPE’S open-border arrangement, which enables travel through 26 countries without passport checks or border controls, is effectively an international passport-free zone for terrorists to execute attacks on the Continent and make their escape.

headline: Homeless Schoolchildren
text: To the Editor:

headline: Grappling With ISIS and the Refugees
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Should Presidential Candidates Drop Out?
text: Bobby Jindal, the governor of Louisiana, decided it was time to stop his presidential run this week. Unable to find any traction in the crowded Republican field, he said Tuesday night, “I’ve come to the realization this is not my time.”

headline: They Are Us
text: Desperate refugees flee persecution and war, but American politicians — worried about security risks — refuse to accept them.

headline: Protect Doctor-Patient Confidentiality
text: WHEN should a doctor betray a patient’s confidence? This week the Supreme Court of the State of Washington heard arguments on this question in a case that has profound implications for the doctor-patient relationship.

headline: The G.O.P. Establishment Has a Big New Hampshire Problem
text: The last two Republican presidential primary contests have followed the same script: A conservative candidate wins in Iowa, a relative moderate wins in New Hampshire, and the latter — with broader appeal and all of the establishment’s resources — outlasts the former in a protracted fight for the nomination.

headline: After Paris Attacks, a Slow Reawakening for City’s Cultural Offerings
text: PARIS — On Wednesday morning, May Zhang, a tourist from Shanghai, was outside the Louvre using a selfie stick to snap photographs with a friend. The courtyard is normally packed with tourists, but they had it mostly to themselves — and to the dozen or more heavily armed police officers pacing in the background.

headline: News Q’s | Raw Talent and College Sports Mix at Culinary Institute of America
text: Before Reading ‘Raw Talent and College Sports Mix at Culinary Institute of America’:

headline: What Are Your Thanksgiving Traditions?
text: You might know the Thanksgiving story — of the Pilgrims feasting alongside Native Americans in 1621 after a bountiful corn harvest. But do you know where your own family’s traditions come from, whether you eat turkey, snicker salad or sopapilla cheesecake?

headline: A Foothold on the Lower East Side
text: After graduating from Syracuse University in 2013, Sarah Sterns landed a job in Norwalk, Conn. She rented a studio in a modest brick building in nearby Stamford for a little more than $1,000 a month.

headline: The Doomsday Scam
text: The hunt for the ultimate weapon began in January 2014, when Abu Omar, a smuggler who fills shopping lists for the Islamic State, met a jihadist commander in Tal Abyad, a Syrian town near the Turkish border. The Islamic State had raised its black flag over Tal Abyad several days before, and the commander, a former cigarette vendor known as Timsah, Arabic for ‘‘crocodile,’’ was the area’s new security chief. The Crocodile had an order to place, which he said he had received from his bosses in Mosul, a city in northwestern Iraq that the Islamic State would later overrun.

headline: A Virtual Reality Revolution, Coming to a Headset Near You
text: Virtual reality — once the stuff of science fiction — is still in its infancy. But there’s already a gold rush around the technology, which plunges viewers into a simulated 3-D environment and lets them explore their surroundings as if they were really there.

headline: Offline, D.I.Y. Weddings Aren’t So Picture Perfect
text: For those couples who like to exhibit their inner Michelangelo or Martha Stewart, weddings have become festivals of do-it-yourself creativity. But in the days leading up to the event, a couple’s desire for those artisanal touches can come at a cost in lost hours and increased anxiety.

headline: U.S. Investigators Struggle to Track Homegrown ISIS Suspects
text: WASHINGTON — At least three dozen people in the United States suspected of ties to the Islamic State were under heavy electronic or physical surveillance even before the Paris attacks, senior American officials say. But unlike the attackers in France, the officials say, the majority of those under investigation here never traveled to Syria to fight alongside the Islamic State or receive training from it.

headline: Punk Portraits of New York
text: William Coupon photographed Ronald Reagan and he photographed Lydia Lunch, both in the same way: against a backdrop of hand-painted Belgian linen, side-lit by a single fixture. For three and a half decades, he has varied little from this method, whether working in the Oval Office or the tribal regions of the Amazon rain forest. “It’s the classic medium shot, chiaroscuro light,” Mr. Coupon, 62, said the other day, describing his method and mission. “I knew if I focused on other subcultures I could hit on a range of people. I thought, I want to photograph everyone in the world.”

headline: A Quarterback’s New Role
text: Clint Trickett, a former West Virginia quarterback who was forced to retire because of a number of concussions, is the quarterbacks coach of a top junior college team in Mississippi.

headline: Concussions Ended His Football Dreams. Now, at 24, He Helps Others Achieve Theirs.
text: SCOOBA, Miss. — For months, reporters have called Clint Trickett wanting to talk about football and, more specifically, about football safety. Some called soon after he announced his retirement as a player last December, when he revealed that he had sustained five concussions in 14 months in the previous two seasons as West Virginia’s starting quarterback — the last one a year ago Friday. Others have called more recently, prompted by the coming release of the film “Concussion,” in which Will Smith plays the doctor who helped identify a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head trauma.

headline: Paris Attacks Suspect Killed in Shootout Had Plotted Terror for 11 Months
text: VERVIERS, Belgium — Black smudges and faded traces of gunfire on a red brick rowhouse here in eastern Belgium mark the death foretold of Abdelhamid Abaaoud. It is the spot where, 11 months before the announcement on Thursday that he had been killed outside Paris, he began plotting an elaborate campaign of terror across Europe.

headline: Hillary Clinton Presents Her Plan to Battle ISIS

Debs on Thursday afternoon as he delivers the most important speech of his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination: an attempt to demystify Democratic Socialism, his long-held political philosophy, and tie it to his vision of America.

headline: An Unlikely Tourist Attraction in Poland: Storks
text: About a half-mile from the Russian border, hidden in the rolling hills of northernmost Poland, is the tiny village of Zywkowo, population 25 humans and 43 pairs of nesting white storks. It is one of the country’s largest stork breeding colonies — their massive, tousled nests dot chimneys, rooftops and specially made platforms. They are wedged into tree branches and balanced above electrical wires.

headline: Review: ‘The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2,’ Katniss’s Final Battle
text: There’s no risk that Katniss Everdeen, the warrior who has led the charge against oppression in “The Hunger Games” movies, can ever return to her current incarnation. Even if she and her world are rebooted back into franchise existence by a ravenous studio, her moment was now. Katniss, as played by Jennifer Lawrence over three years and four blockbusters, has evolved from a backwoods scrapper in the first movie into a battle-scarred champion and an exemplar of female power on screen and off — and the battles she’s fought have extended far beyond the fictional nation of Panem.

headline: Running Away With the Circus
text: Just for the sake of argument, consider the Ringling Brothers Circus of the year 1890, roughly 17 years before it became the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. That year, you could see Anzo, the Human Serpent, slither on the ground. You could see the La Role brothers, Chris and Harry, the two ‘‘Flying Men of the Air,’’ and the wondrous Nellie on her airborne trapeze. You could see Edward Billings, the King of the High Stilts, as he confounded audience members with his height and balance, and watch the ‘‘educated’’ horses ridden two at a time by one man. You could see Barretta, the Boneless Wonder, whom, years before, a young Winston Churchill had begged in vain to see. (According to Boris Johnson’s biography, ‘‘The Churchill Factor,’’ his parents decided the sight would be ‘‘too demoralizing and revolting’’ for a child.)

Add polyamory, a vampire romance, and an unfortunate tango number, and you’ve got “Flickers.”

headline: 1940: Samaria Docks After a Scare
text: The Cunard White Star liner Samaria, her gray hull and super-structure melting into the gray sea, was two days out of Liverpool, without escort, on Nov. 10 when the rhythmic sound of plane motors far off brought her passengers racing to their lifeboat stations, their lifebelts adjusted, eyes fixated on the approaching specks. The next day the passengers learned from the ship’s officers that German bombers had attacked another ship, twenty minutes’ flying time from the Samaria, and had been driven off. The other ship was not identified. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 20, 1940

headline: Philippine Officials Suspect Severed Head Belongs to Kidnap Victim
text: MANILA — Philippine military officials have not yet confirmed the identity of a man whose severed head was left in a bag in front of a police station this week, but they continue to suspect that it was from a kidnapped Malaysian man who was said to have been beheaded by militants.

headline: Golden State Warriors Close In on Longest Perfect Start

headline: Michael Gross, Who Designed the ‘Ghostbusters’ Logo, Dies at 70

So far in its sophomore season, nimble corporate defection has been the primary course by which Cookie, Hakeem and Lucious have made their harried grabs for Lyon supremacy. As if an ode to vintage season one “Empire,” this week saw the family scramble situate itself squarely in the arena that started it all: the music.

headline: 1965: An Independent British Guiana
text: LONDON — The British government announced today [Nov. 19] that British Guiana will become independent on May 26 and will be known as Guyana. Colonial Secretary Anthony Greenwood said that Guyana will ask for Commonwealth membership. The new country, in South America, will remain a monarchy with a governor-general appointed by Queen Elizabeth. Mr. Greenwood said Britain would be very happy to consult other Commonwealth members on admitting Guyana to membership and would be willing to sponsor Guyana’s membership at the United Nations. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 20, 1965

headline: Review: ‘Carol’ Explores the Sweet Science of Magnetism
text: Mutual attraction may be central to our notion of love, but it is a curiously rare occurrence in art, which tends to split desire into subject and object. Poetry traces a vector from lover to beloved. (“Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?”) In painting and sculpture, the eye of the beholder lingers on the face and body of the beheld. Students of film are schooled in the erotic power of the gaze, and readers of romance fiction know the seductions of the first-person narrative and the free indirect style, which concentrate lust and longing within a single consciousness. (“Reader, I married him.”)

headline: Thanksgiving Guest List Woes
text: My brother and his wife are divorcing. My sister-in-law usually holds Thanksgiving, but this year I am, due to their circumstances. My brother said he will “give up” the holiday and we should invite his wife and children. (He is seeing another woman and probably wants to spend the day with her. Meanwhile, my sister-in-law has been texting me about his infidelity. Too weird!) I like my sister-in-law, but she’s not family. But if I don’t invite her, we won’t see the kids. I told my brother they should all come, but he was noncommittal. Ideas?

headline: Baryshnikov to Perform at His Arts Center for First Time Since 2010

He will perform in the United States premiere of “Brodsky/Baryshnikov,” a previously announced work that is part of the center’s spring season, which was announced on Thursday.

headline: Self-Portraits of a Naked Adventurer
text: The photographer Ruben Brulat was traveling alone through Iceland in 2009 when, in the midst of setting up his camp, he was arrested by the beauty of a rock perched on the mountainside, almost ready to fall from among the clouds seemingly wrapped around its peak. Setting up his camera on a timer, Brulat followed his senses and captured himself lying naked in the primal elements. It was a transformative moment, and it started him on his projects “Primates,” “Paths” and now, seen here for the first time, “Commencements.”

headline: Tie Domi Moves From Penalty Box to Arena Suite, Watching His Son’s Blossoming Career

headline: When Medicine Reverses Itself
text: The boy in the emergency room sat, swinging his legs. He smiled as I examined him, despite having a fever and a throb in his ear. Crouching at his side, I could see through the otoscope an angry drum, bulging and red — mystery solved.

headline: Readers, and Starwood, React to Starwood Customer Agitation
text: After my article ran about Marriott International’s acquisition of Starwood Hotels and Resorts, and how upset it has made some frequent Starwood customers, Starwood sent a message to a frequent customer, Charley Cullen Walters: “We still care.”

headline: Economic Fallout of Paris Attacks Hits Hotels Hard
text: PARIS — The first wave of canceled reservations struck Le Bristol with crushing force after last weekend’s terrorist attacks, across town from the five-star hotel and its elite Right Bank neighborhood. headline: Restaurant Review: The Seductive Spices and Aromas of India at Indigo
text: Someday, the culinary trickle-down will bring to the hinterlands the same creativity of Indian cuisine in the metropolis, exemplified in such boundary-blurring concoctions as duck confit samosas or crab cakes wrapped in tamarind-glazed papadums. But for now, we still have chicken tikka masala, lamb saag and the other traditional favorites. And with these dishes, you will do superbly at Indigo Indian Bistro in Manchester.

headline: A New Threat to Your Retirement
text: In April, the Labor Department proposed an important rule designed to protect Americans’ retirement savings by requiring advisers to act in their clients’ best interests — and not their own. As things stand now, brokers, insurance agents and other salespeople — who often call themselves “consultants” or “advisers” — are allowed to steer clients into high-priced products and strategies when comparable and cheaper ones are available.

headline: An Artist Takes on the Marketing Machine
text: When she began the work for her new show, the artist Aurel Schmidt focused on capitalism — and, particularly, how objects are marketed to the masses. “I am interested in the strange, mutant, man-made objects we buy, we touch, we orbit our identities around,” she tells T in an email. “How they are presented to us, the way they are sold, the images of the objects online — flat and bright — or in stores, pretending to be things they are not.”

headline: Venice Beach’s Influx of Trendy Outsiders
text: Just under a mile from Venice Beach and its winding boardwalk, the once-destitute stretch of Abbot Kinney Boulevard has emerged as a buzzy destination with indie shops, luxe fashion boutiques and eateries. Since Gjelina opened there in 2008, its artisanal pizzas have helped draw in a steady crowd of locals, low-key hipsters, fashionable bohos and intrigued out-of-towners. Just this year, the restaurant released a cookbook and introduced Gjusta, an equally popular bakery, deli, smokehouse, coffee and juice bar next door. (Over the summer, the “Top Chef” alum Nyesha Arrington began serving lamb-belly won tons and wakame-cured hamachi out of the new rustic-chic dining room at Leona, on a nearby street. And not far away, and a month later, the charming restaurant-retail storefront Dudley Market opened its doors, selling utilitarian handmade goods, from minimalist ceramics to artistic cutting boards, alongside gourmet pantry offerings.)
