headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s homes include a seven-bedroom in Pelham Manor, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Bridgeport, Conn.

headline: Going Soft on White-Collar Crime
text: Jennifer Taub is a professor at Vermont Law School. Her financial crisis book “Other People’s Houses” was published in 2014 by Yale University Press.

headline: Jiehae Park’s ‘Peerless’ to World Premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater
text: If there were standardized tests for emerging playwrights, it’s a good bet that Jiehae Park would ace them. Her darkly comic play “Peerless,” which relocates elements of “Macbeth” to an American high school in the Midwest during college admissions season, opens on Nov. 27 at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven. This major, highly esteemed credit now joins a long list of brand-name honors, grants and play-development workshops on her sterling résumé.

headline: Manhattan Dentist Is Arrested on Drug and Pornography Charges
text: John Wolf, a dentist in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, is well known in the neighborhood — not only for his popular, light-filled offices, but also for his AIDS activism. He studied the disease in dentistry school, according to his Google profile, and as a practicing dentist in the 1980s he brought, and won, a prominent lawsuit against a landlord who did not want him to treat patients with AIDS.

headline: Fidelity Joins Growing Field of Automated Financial Advice
text: Fidelity Investments is flirting with the investment robots.

headline: 5 Tips for Potential Corporate Whistle-Blowers
text: Jordan Thomas is chairman of the whistle-blower representation practice at Labaton Sucharow and was a former assistant director in the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Paris: One Week Later
text: Life in Paris is slowly returning to normal, but people are still recovering from the terrorist attacks of Nov. 13. Here, four Parisians discuss the attacks and what has followed.

headline: Escape Rooms Bring New Attractions to New Jersey
text: Eric Rama and Teresa Pulcrano were strangers when they walked into Exit Strategy in Montclair recently. An hour later, when they emerged, Mr. Rama was praising Ms. Pulcrano’s sports trivia knowledge.

headline: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Terrorist Attack in Mali
text: Gunmen seized a hotel in Bamako, the capital of Mali, on Friday, taking about 100 people hostage and killing more than two dozen. The attack is the latest eruption of violence in Mali, a former French colony in West Africa that has been racked by an Islamist insurgency for the past three years.

headline: How Nicole A. Taylor, Cookbook Author, Spends Her Sundays
text: In college, a friend of Nicole A. Taylor’s called her “the black Betty Crocker,” which is not a bad catchphrase to recall when you’re promoting a new cookbook during the holidays. A Georgia native, she is the author of “The Up South Cookbook: Chasing Dixie in a Brooklyn Kitchen” and the host of the podcast “Hot Grease,” in which she tells stories related to Southern food. Ms. Taylor, 37, who said Southern cooking didn’t become part of her career until she moved to New York City in 2008, lives with her husband, Adrian Franks, 39, an artist and a user-experience design director at IBM, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

headline: For Woman Dead in French Police Raid, Unlikely Path to Terror
text: LONDON — When about 100 heavily armed police officers and soldiers took position shortly after 4 a.m. Wednesday outside the building in the Paris suburb of St.-Denis where the presumed ringleader of the Paris attacks was holed up, a young woman appeared in a window.

headline: Iowa Coach Kirk Ferentz Guides Undefeated Hawkeyes to Unfamiliar Heights
text: IOWA CITY — In the early 1970s, amid the Iowa football team’s 19-year streak without a winning season, the former University of Iowa president Willard Boyd arrived early to a Big Ten meeting and made small talk with his friend Novice Fawcett, the president of Ohio State.

headline: A Tender, Intimate Video by Dash Snow
text: The exhibition “Dash Snow: Freeze Means Run,” on view now at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., was conceived as a labor of love. The career-spanning retrospective was organized in part by three of the late artist’s best friends: Dan Colen, Hanna Liden and Nate Lowman. Their mission to honor the memory of their comrade and (sometimes literal) partner in crime is evident throughout the show, which comprises many of the artist’s best known and most controversial works — including the front pages of newspapers he infamously decorated with his own bodily fluid — but which is more striking in its inclusion of more personal work from Snow. Among the more than 100 previously unexhibited Polaroids on display are many that depict Snow and his friends drinking and drugging, or in lithe, louche repose — windows on a moment in time that seems, in retrospect, inevitably brief.

headline: Thanksgiving Leftovers Go Beyond the Turkey Sandwich
text: Some cooks prefer the Thanksgiving meal proper, with its generous platters and long, festive table. Others are impatient for the after-party, the prospect of raiding the fridge at midnight, or the anticipated snack the next day, when the bounty is neatly packed away.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 1: The Worst in People
text: While immediately engaging, “A.K.A. Ladies Night,” the first episode of “Jessica Jones,” sometimes leans too hard on its title character’s alienated, hyper-cynical worldview. The pilot’s pseudo-hard-boiled (read: moodily under-lit) style and intricate narrative, with multiple overlapping subplots integrating by episode’s end, is mostly an effective continuation of the Hell’s Kitchen-focused, adult-oriented brand of drama that Marvel Comics and Netflix first tried with “Daredevil” earlier this year.

headline: An Eerie New Sound Installation, Made From Broken Instruments
text: When visitors enter the Duveen galleries in London’s Tate Britain this weekend, they’ll be greeted by the sound of bugles that once played at the battle of Waterloo and the Charge of the Light Brigade. The breathy, rasping tones — which are broadcast from 14 large, horn-shaped speakers — are part of “War Damaged Musical Instruments,” a new work by the sound artist Susan Philipsz.

headline: Bobbing and Weaving With New York’s Bravest
text: Susan Merlucci Reno coaches the Fire Department’s boxing team ahead of its annual bout with Police Department fighters at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Draining ISIS' Coffers
text: Can ISIS be undermined financially as it is being attacked militarily?

headline: Poll Watch: Democrats, Even Clinton Supporters, Warm to Socialism
text: Senator Bernie Sanders’s speech on Thursday explaining his democratic socialist ideology carried little risk among supporters and other Democrats: A solid majority of them have a positive impression of socialism, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll released this month.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 11: Rankings and Matchup Analysis
text: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 11 games and Monday’s matchup between the New England Patriots and the Buffalo Bills. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 11 player rankings.

headline: More Trump and Carson on Syrian Refugees
text: While the G.O.P. hopeful Ben Carson walked back his “rabid dog” statement about Syrian refugees, Donald J. Trump said it is easier for Syrian Muslims to get into the United States than Christians.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: David Hare’s Memoir
text: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

headline: Donald Trump Steps Back From Calling for Muslim Registry
text: Donald J. Trump drew back Friday from calling for a national database to keep track of Muslims in America, saying that the suggestion had come from a reporter.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and in Manhattan’s Kips Bay and Upper West Side neighborhoods.

headline: Lighting a Fire Under New York’s Bravest Boxing Squad
text: New York City firefighters are known for rushing to emergencies, but getting to boxing practice, at least according to Susan Merlucci Reno, is another story.

headline: Experience the Vigils in Paris in Virtual Reality With NYT VR
text: Our newest virtual reality film looks at Paris in the aftermath of the Nov. 13 terror attacks. Use the free NYT VR mobile app, with your headphones and optional cardboard viewing device, to experience it.

headline: For Transgender Rights Opponents, Houston Wasn’t Enough
text: The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance would’ve granted those who visit, live or work in Houston protection from “discrimination based on sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity or pregnancy.”

headline: A West Village Penthouse for $25.49 Million
text: The latest in a flurry of sales at the Greenwich Lane, an almost blocklong condominium complex on the site of the former St. Vincent’s Hospital campus in the West Village, was filed with the city this past week — a spacious duplex penthouse with a private rooftop terrace that sold for $25,489,849.99 and was the most expensive closed sale, according to public records.

headline: British Police Apologize for Undercover Officers’ Intimate Tactics
text: LONDON — They lived together, traveled abroad on vacation and, for five years, behaved like any other couple. Then one day the man, who called himself Mark Cassidy, disappeared, leading his bewildered ex-partner to eventually discover that she had been living with a married police spy.

headline: In Los Angeles, Jewelry Mingles With Midcentury Design
text: It took some convincing to get Tommy Perse, the owner of the L.A. boutique Maxfield, to agree to the jewelry installation “Nomad 1957.” But Lisa Eisner is nothing if not persuasive. A longtime patron of the Los Angeles fashion institution, Eisner, a jewelry designer (and sometime artist, stylist, photographer and publisher), began selling pieces at Maxfield earlier this year. Three months ago, the store approached her to do an out-of-the-box installation with her pieces. Eisner’s first instinct was to ask about Structure Nomade — a large, prefab space designed by the French architect Jean Prouvé in 1957 that sits just outside Maxfield’s entrance, which had never been used for anything.

headline: Funeral in Pakistan for Militants Killed in U.S. Strikes Draws Hundreds
text: LOWER DIR, Pakistan — A mass funeral on Friday for as many as 20 local militants said to have been killed by American airstrikes in neighboring Afghanistan drew hundreds of mourners in the northwestern Pakistani district of Lower Dir, according to local residents and participants.

headline: The Divergent Styles of Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson
text: The artists Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson had a lot in common besides their first names. Both were painters, both worked in the East End of Long Island starting in the late 1950s, both lived at the same address for a time and both died recently at age 90, within five weeks of each other.

headline: Who Turned My Blue State Red?
text: IT is one of the central political puzzles of our time: Parts of the country that depend on the safety-net programs supported by Democrats are increasingly voting for Republicans who favor shredding that net.

headline: Why It Takes Two Years for Syrian Refugees to Enter the U.S.
text: Syrians must pass through many steps of security clearances before being admitted to the United States.

headline: Miguel Cotto Nears Retirement Fighting Canelo Alvarez, and the W.B.C.
text: LAS VEGAS — Miguel Cotto sat expressionless on the dais, arms crossed, as he listened to Oscar De La Hoya speak at a prefight news conference on Wednesday.

headline: Deforestation May Threaten Majority of Amazon Tree Species, Study Finds
text: Deforestation threatens more than half of all tree species in the Amazon, a new study suggests.

headline: Yahoo Restricts Ad-Blocking Software for Some Email Users
text: Millions of people swear by the ad blocker, software that lets you browse the web free of online advertising. The companies who want you to see the ads are starting to push back.

headline: Review: Anthony de Mare Introduces the Last of His Sondheim Project
text: It’s all in the details. That could almost be a motto for Stephen Sondheim, who works so hard to get the details right in his songs.

headline: Review: ‘Saints & Strangers,’ a Thanksgiving Story Told in a Native Tongue
text: In “Saints & Strangers,” National Geographic’s compelling two-part film about the Mayflower settlers and the first Thanksgiving, the cast members playing American Indians speak their lines in an almost extinct language called Western Abenaki. It’s a bold choice, both because of the challenge for the cast and because it means much of the film is subtitled. But it’s strikingly appropriate, since in this story, the language barrier is everything.

headline: Review: Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba Brings Precision to a Fusion
text: Hamstrings can’t be the only strained body parts for a member of Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba. They must also need to ice their jaws. These dancers smile so hard that after the third or fourth number, your own mouth may start to ache in solidarity.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Campaign rallies, speeches on political philosophy and threats to national security, and South Carolina barbecue in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Caring for Premature Babies, With a Little Help From Beyoncé
text: Jane Chen founded Embrace to build better and cheaper incubators for babies around the world.

headline: New Rentals Steps From St. John the Divine
text: Although luxury apartment towers and revered religious buildings might seem like awkward neighbors, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights will soon welcome the second residential development to its 11.3-acre campus.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Roanoke Mayor Apologizes for Japanese Internment Remarks
text: The longtime mayor of Roanoke, Va., who faced criticism this week for citing Japanese internment camps in his defense of limiting Syrian refugee assistance, apologized on Friday.

headline: Michael Skolnik Taps His Social Network to Fight for Civil Rights
text: In mid-September, in the enduring boil of the national debate over race and the police, President Obama appeared one afternoon in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building to host a screening of a new documentary from Vice magazine on the criminal-justice system. It was one of those carefully organized Washington affairs: There were speeches, panel talks and a curated guest list that included Senator Cory A. Booker of New Jersey, the hip-hop artist Ludacris, the actor Tim Robbins, the Rev. Al Sharpton, an activist from Ferguson, Mo., some former prison inmates and Shane Smith, the chief executive of Vice.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Daisy Prince on Her Greenwich Village Apartment
text: When Daisy Prince and her husband, Hugh Chisholm, returned to New York in 2009 after eight years in London, they moved to Greenwich Village, where she had wanted to live since she was a college student in the 1990s. “I attended Barnard, and you spend most of your time trying to go downtown to a club or hear music,” she said. “And then when we moved downtown, I was like, wait a minute, I missed the memo — when did everyone move to Brooklyn?”

headline: What I Love | Daisy Prince
text: Daisy Prince, the editor of Avenue magazine, which just published its 40th anniversary issue, lives in Greenwich Village with her family.

headline: Hillary Clinton Proposes Middle-Class Tax Cut Tied to Health Care
text: MEMPHIS — Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday proposed a tax credit for families and individuals who face excessive and unexpected health care costs, the first part of multipronged approach to giving middle-class Americans tax relief that she will unveil in the coming days, according to her campaign.

headline: Why ‘Cool’ Is Still Cool
text: THE word “cool” has been cool for a long time. Originally associated with temperature, by the 16th century the term had evolved to describe not just the atmosphere, but also an internal state of calm, almost icy composure. And by the late 1800s it began to signify style and hipness and some of the other meanings with which it is associated today. Now cool is used as a synonym for almost anything good. Music can be cool and restaurants can be cool. Every so often even a minivan seems cool.

headline: Review: Julia Murney in Honesty Mode at Feinstein’s/54 Below
text: Julia Murney doesn’t mince words. The high point of her untitled opening-night show at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Thursday was a sing-along rendition of Sara Bareilles’s “Sweet as Whole.” It was prefaced by an anecdote about a man urinating in a New York subway station, Ms. Murney’s disgust and another observer’s mean-spirited reaction.

headline: My Life as a Muslim in the West’s ‘Gray Zone’
text: Some months ago, I gave a reading from my most recent novel in Scottsdale, Ariz. During the discussion that followed, a woman asked me to talk about my upbringing in Morocco. It’s natural for readers to be curious about a writer they’ve come to hear, I told myself. I continued to tell myself this even after the conversation drifted to Islam, and then to ISIS. Eventually, another woman raised her hand and said that the only Muslims she saw when she turned on the television were extremists. “Why aren’t we hearing more from people like you?” she asked me.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow Cover The Rolling Stones
text: Sometimes you get what you need.

headline: States Urged to Review Health Insurer Mergers
text: Consumer advocates and antitrust experts are urging state regulators to closely examine the proposed mergers of major health insurance companies, saying they threaten to leave consumers with fewer choices and higher prices.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Nov. 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, Mali, Israel and India.

headline: Review: ‘More Up a Tree,’ Performance Art Through the Looking Glass
text: Ten minutes before the start of “More Up a Tree,” if you had walked into the Fishman Space, the black-box theater within BAM Fisher, you would have first seen the performers themselves, the dancer Claudia de Serpa Soares and the drummer Jim White, both in the middle of a wood-framed glass enclosure in the center of the room. You had nothing else to look at — except the other members of the audience, free to walk around the enclosure before and during the performance.

headline: Americans View Paris Attacks With Empathy, Fear and Resolve
text: DENVER — It made parents worry for their children studying abroad. It sent a shiver of fear into plans for vacations to France. Cafes and nightclubs in Miami and Los Angeles felt newly vulnerable, not so different from the bloody scenes unfolding on people’s phones and televisions. For Americans accustomed to tuning out foreign conflicts, it brought the world crashing in.

headline: Fox Drops Ratings for Live Viewership
text: Fox became the first broadcast network to declare that it no longer would acknowledge or release ratings for its shows that measure only live or same-day viewing, calling the figures irrelevant as viewers increasingly stream shows or watch on DVRs or on demand.

headline: Greek New Testament Papyrus Is Discovered on eBay
text: Last January, Geoffrey Smith, a scholar of early Christianity at the University of Texas, noticed something startling: an eBay listing for an ancient Greek papyrus fragment of the Gospel of John — with an opening bid of only $99.

headline: What Was That Above Ohio?
text: People in Ohio, Kentucky and Indiana reported a fireball in the sky on Thursday night. A security camera in Cincinnati captured footage of the reason: a meteor.

headline: Syrian Refugees Biking to Safety
text: Syrian refugees seeking safe haven in Europe have taken to the Arctic Circle, where they cycle the final stretch across the border from Russia into Norway.

headline: Review: Resurrecting a Pair of Rachmaninoff Flops
text: The New York Philharmonic played two famous failures on Thursday: the pieces that brought Rachmaninoff perhaps the most excoriation when they were new.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Mali, Adele, Donald Trump
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bill Cunningham | City Blues
text: A surprise: blue among the autumnal foliage. It was all over the city, from Storefront Academy’s 1890s rowhouse porches in Harlem to, for the first time, morning glories that cascaded over the Fifth Avenue fence of the 1914 Frick home that now houses Henry Clay Frick’s art collection. Some wearers added burgundy hats to their outfits that were the shade of some of the closed morning glories in the evening.

headline: A Dutch ISIS Fighter Takes Questions on Tumblr
text: Usually, by the time the public learns the names and biographies of Islamic State militants, or radicals from other groups who attack civilians, they are already dead, and so unable to speak for themselves, except occasionally in the ritualized form of martyrdom videos or manifestoes posted online.

headline: For Gregg Turkington’s Character, There’s No Success Like Failure
text: In the film “Entertainment,” Gregg Turkington plays a comedian grinding through a surreally low-level gig circuit and beginning to suffer delusions and near-catatonia.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Celebrities Will Evade Fans and Photographers at Los Angeles Airport Lounge
text: LOS ANGELES — Kanye West has had words (and more) with photographers chasing him at Los Angeles International Airport; a friend of the actor Jared Leto tangled with one in August, and the list goes on and on.

headline: An Ancient Stream Under a Manhattan Building Leads to a Dispute
text: With New York City’s overheated real estate market showing no signs of cooling, disputes over developments tend to sprout like weeds. Many feel familiar: A project is too big or too unsightly and will blight a neighborhood or force out people of modest means or end the long run of a beloved mom-and-pop shop.

headline: Bipartisan Bill Would Protect Service Members’ Right to Avoid Arbitration
text: Two senators have introduced a bill aimed at preserving the rights of military service members to go to court.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates: ‘I Don’t Want to Be Anybody’s Expert’
text: As he accepted the National Book Award for nonfiction for “Between the World and Me” on Wednesday, Ta-Nehisi Coates took a moment to marvel that he had written the book at all.

headline: Russian Newspaper’s Scoop? Based on Fake Letters, U.S. Says
text: MOSCOW — When reporters at Russia’s government-leaning newspaper Izvestia found an archive of letters, supposedly written by State Department employees to a prominent Russian gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex activist, they thought they had stumbled upon an extraordinary trove.

headline: Adam Johnson, Inspired by Holograms, Humor and Escape
text: When Adam Johnson’s short-story collection “Fortune Smiles” won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night, Mr. Johnson joined an elite group of literary greats who have won that honor and the Pulitzer Prize in quick succession, a club that includes Philip Roth, Wallace Stegner, Saul Bellow and Eudora Welty.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Plans 2-Month Paternity Leave From Facebook
text: Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, said he planned to take two months of paternity leave after his daughter is born this year, amid a debate about work-life balance at technology companies.

headline: With Permanent Squad, New York Police Step Up Fight on Terrorism
text: In January, several days after heavily armed terrorists attacked Charlie Hebdo, a satirical newspaper in Paris, top officials with the New York Police Department held a drill to test the city’s response to such an attack and found they had a problem.

headline: Mexico’s Participation in ’16 Olympics Imperiled by Intramural Dispute
text: MEXICO CITY — A dispute between Mexico’s government and the nation’s sports federations over how public money is spent and how athletes will be selected for the 2016 Olympics could result in Mexico’s being barred from participating as a team at the Games.

headline: U.N. Security Council Approves Resolution Urging Countries to Combat Islamic State
text: The United Nations Security Council on Friday adopted a resolution, drafted by France, calling on countries around the world to take “all necessary measures” to fight the Islamic State.

headline: Argentina Considers Shift as Upstart Rises in Presidential Race
text: HUMAHUACA, Argentina — Winding down a presidential campaign that is upending this country’s politics, Mauricio Macri dutifully chewed on coca leaves, a symbol of the resilience of indigenous culture in this remote corner of northern Argentina. Raising his voice barely above a murmur, he asked Mother Earth for the wisdom to guide Argentina down the “righteous path.”

headline: Benjamin Clementine Wins 2015 Mercury Prize
text: Benjamin Clementine, a pianist, poet, singer-songwriter and former Paris busker, was awarded the 2015 Mercury Prize on Friday in London for the best British or Irish album of the year. The prestigious award, which calls itself “the music equivalent to the Booker Prize for literature and the Turner Prize for art,” comes with a cash prize of 20,000 pounds, or about $30,500.

headline: Syrian Family Diverted From Indiana Feels ‘Welcomed’ in Connecticut
text: NEW HAVEN — The couple from Syria arrived at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday only to face one more shock in a four-year journey of loss, anxiety and upheaval. They had no idea they had landed in a political maelstrom.

headline: F.D.A. Takes Issue With the Term ‘Non-G.M.O.’
text: Lost in the news about the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of genetically engineered salmon on Thursday was its long-awaited guidelines on labeling food with or without genetically altered plant ingredients.

headline: Administration Is Seeking Ways to Keep Prescription Drugs Affordable
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration began building a political case Friday for government actions to protect people against high pharmaceutical costs, saying millions of Americans were unable to afford lifesaving prescription drugs.

headline: John E. Zuccotti, Urbanist, Financier and Would-Be Mayor, Dies at 78
text: John E. Zuccotti, a street-smart urbanist who was an unsung hero of New York City’s fiscal crisis in the 1970s, died on Thursday in Brooklyn. He was 78.

headline: Donald Trump’s Take on de Blasio? ‘The Worst Mayor in the U.S.’
text: Donald J. Trump tore into Mayor Bill de Blasio on Twitter on Friday, accusing New York City’s top elected official of “ineptitude” and calling him “the worst Mayor in the U.S., & probably the worst Mayor in the history of #NYC.”

headline: After Unusual Stumbles, Rafael Nadal’s Year Ends in Hope
text: LONDON — On the eve of the year-end ATP World Tour Finals, Rafael Nadal mused, “In the work, always there is a solution, no?”

headline: A Plague of Bucks and Does on Staten Island
text: Last month, a stag reportedly gored a German shepherd named Sprocket, puncturing the dog’s lung with an antler. Two days later, one jumped through a window at a T.J. Maxx store, then bounded bloodied up and down the aisles of clothes.

headline: Workers Ratify U.A.W. Contracts With General Motors and Ford
text: Bringing to a close a tumultuous bargaining season with American vehicle manufacturers, the United Automobile Workers ratified contracts Friday with General Motors and Ford Motor.

headline: Groups Claiming Responsibility in Mali Attack Have History of Resilience
text: WASHINGTON — The two Islamic extremist groups that claimed responsibility for the assault on the Radisson Blu hotel in Mali on Friday are among the most dangerous and resilient in a hodgepodge of terrorist organizations in northwest Africa that have ties to nomadic tribesmen as well as Al Qaeda.

headline: Tom Buckley, Versatile and Colorful Times Reporter, Dies at 87
text: Tom Buckley, a versatile reporter for The New York Times who covered the United Nations and the war in Vietnam, wrote columns about New York City and articles for the Sunday magazine, and as a television critic panned “Hill Street Blues,” died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Lego’s Success Leads to Competitors and Spinoffs
text: When Paul Hollingsworth tried to recreate “Jurassic Park” in a video using Lego bricks, he ran into a roadblock. Lego offers plenty of T. rexes, velociraptors and other dinosaurs, but not Richard Attenborough or Jeff Goldblum, who played characters in the movie.

headline: Paris and Mali Attacks Expose Lethal Qaeda-ISIS Rivalry
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Before the hostage crisis at a Malian hotel was over, before the gunmen had even been identified, admirers of Al Qaeda and the rival Islamic State started jostling on social media over which of the jihadist organizations was more righteous and more prominent.

headline: Donald Trump Sets Off a Furor With Call to Register Muslims in the U.S.
text: Under assault from Democrats and Republicans alike, Donald J. Trump on Friday drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, trying to quell one of the ugliest controversies yet in a presidential campaign like few others.

headline: Paris Attacks Force European Union to Act on Border Controls
text: PARIS — If Europe’s system of passport-free travel was not under enough pressure after a summer of chaotic migration, then last week’s attacks in Paris have fortified doubts over how much longer that freedom of movement — one of the most cherished accomplishments of the European Union — can survive.

headline: What the Saudis Miss When They Focus on Iran
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — It doesn’t take long in Saudi Arabia to see evidence of an obsession with Iran, the Shiite foil to this Sunni country. In recent conversations, government officials, analysts and members of the royal family were quick to describe how incensed they were that President Obama hadn’t found a way to remove Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president and Iran’s close ally, from power.

headline: Iowa’s Climate-Change Wisdom
text: Iowa City — NEGOTIATORS en route to the United Nations conference on climate change in Paris, scheduled to begin later this month, should take a detour on rural roads here in Johnson County. A new climate narrative is emerging among farmers in the American heartland that transcends a lot of the old story lines of denial and cynicism, and offers an updated tale of climate hope.

headline: Jury Orders Washington to Pay Wrongfully Convicted Man $16.65 Million
text: The government of Washington, D.C., has agreed to pay $16.65 million to a man after a federal jury found that two police detectives had framed him for the 1981 rape and murder of a college student, a crime for which he was wrongly imprisoned for 27 years.

headline: Brinkmanship in the South China Sea
text: Few issues are more important to Asia than the free flow of navigation through the South China Sea, a channel for some $5 trillion in annual trade. And no threat to that trade is as grave as China’s claim to “indisputable sovereignty” over fully 90 percent of the sea. It is no surprise that President Obama and several other leaders were giving the issue high priority this week during back-to-back summit meetings in the region.

headline: The Price of Fear
text: After the attacks in Paris, the world is again challenged by fear. With every bombing, beheading and mass shooting, the dread spreads, along with the urgency of defeating this nihilism.

headline: Coalition Pushes for Memorial to the Triangle Fire
text: A block east of Washington Square, not far from the neighborhood’s boutiques and chic restaurants, was the site of one of the nation’s worst industrial disasters. Many New Yorkers might be unaware of this.

headline: Fighting Scoliosis, and Dreaming of Having Her Own Business Again
text: After her lifelong disability worsened, Carmen Gonzalez’s hard-fought professional, personal and financial successes started to crumble rapidly. To improve her health, she underwent surgery, which left her with 22 screws in her back and in perpetual pain.

headline: You Can’t Please Everyone
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I say this a lot, but if this is where you get off the weekly crossword carousel, so to speak, get back up on that horsie and ride again. You won’t be sorry.

headline: Pregnant Woman Killed in Stabbing in the Bronx
text: A baby girl, only a few minutes old, swaddled in a blanket or clothes, was breathing on the hood of a car in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. Inside a two-family home nearby, her 22-year-old mother lay on the floor in a pool of blood, fatally stabbed several times in her torso and neck, the authorities said. She had been close to nine months pregnant.

headline: Paul Laffoley, Painter Inspired by Time Travel and Aliens, Dies at 80
text: Paul Laffoley, whose annotated diagrammatic paintings, with their kaleidoscopic representations of abstruse philosophic systems, made him one of the most distinctive and cerebral of the outsider artists, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Boston. He was 80.

headline: 7 New York City Schools Will Reserve Slots for Disadvantaged Students
text: Taking a small step to address segregation in New York City schools, the Education Department announced on Friday that it would allow seven schools to reserve slots for children from low-income or non-English speaking families.

headline: U.S. Victim of Mali Attack Worked on Women’s Health
text: Anita Ashok Datar, an American public health worker from the Washington suburbs, was killed Friday when gunmen attacked a luxury hotel in Mali’s capital, Bamako, killing at least 19 people and taking as many as 100 more hostage.

headline: Skelos’s Son Wanted C.E.O. Removed in Failed Takeover Bid, Witness Says
text: It was a request that would have been extraordinary and unreasonable, no matter who had made it.

headline: Islanders Are Adjusting Faster to Their New Home Than Their Fans Are
text: The Islanders have a winning record. They are coming off a 101-point season and are playing at a level that should keep them in the playoff race all season.

headline: Knicks Win, Surviving Late Rally by Thunder
text: In their not-so-distant past, road trips were the stuff of nightmares for the Knicks. Opposing crowds loved seeing them come to town. Things have changed. The Knicks ventured to Oklahoma City on Friday and sent another message in a month full of them by defeating the Thunder, 93-90.

headline: Paris Victims, Remembered
text: At least 130 people were killed Nov. 13. They included an architect, an American college student, an Algerian violinist and many, many music fans. Here are some of their stories.

headline: Yankees Lose Whitley
text: The right-handed pitcher Chase Whitley, who is recovering from Tommy John surgery, was claimed off waivers from the Yankees by Tampa Bay. The Yankees also added pitchers Johnny Barbato and Rookie Davis, as well as outfielder Ben Gamel, to the 40-man roster, which had to be finalized by Friday.

headline: Republicans Discuss Geopolitics at Thanksgiving Table in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Seven Republican candidates sat around a mocked-up Thanksgiving table here on Friday night, gathered to discuss issues of hearth and home before an audience of more than 1,000 Christian evangelicals.

headline: Seeking Remedies From Home
text: Immigrants turn to stores known as botanicas that sell plant-based medicines and herbs for cures to what ails them.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: Get your Saturday night jollies with the turkeys, whether “Fifty Shades of Grey” or a couple of movies starring the actual bird. Then fall asleep to bittersweet lullabies from Adele.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “There was no plan. We were just hoping for the best.”

headline: Corrections: November 21, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: 9 Foreigners Killed in Mali Are Identified
text: BEIJING — Three senior executives of a Chinese state-owned rail construction company and six Russian employees of a cargo company were among the 19 victims of the gunmen who attacked a hotel in the capital of the West African nation of Mali.

headline: Cate Blanchett’s Oscars Looks
text: With “Carol,” the actress is back in the Oscar race and with it the inevitable red carpet question: “Who are you wearing?”

headline: Unilever Finds That Shrinking Its Footprint Is a Giant Task
text: Hellmann’s mayonnaise is known for many things — making egg salad delicious, being loaded with fat, that old “bring out the best” jingle. To date, however, it hasn’t been associated with sustainability. Mayo is a processed food made by huge conglomerates, not a symbol of environmentalism.

headline: The Nanny Factor in Hollywood Marriages
text: When Jennifer Schuur Herbert passes a rack of tabloid magazines in her Los Angeles neighborhood, she is often reminded of what can happen in even the most glamorous Hollywood marriages.

headline: Why Snapping Is the New Clapping
text: Christian Bailey, a 58-year-old physicist who works for a manufacturing company in Elkton, Md., was attending a conference on progressive health care issues when he began to feel self-conscious. He would look around and notice a key difference between himself and nearly everyone else in the room.

headline: The True Story of Sergeant Goosby and His 19 Dogs
text: LOS ANGELES — “If they ask you to wear the bite suit, say no.”

headline: Lee Miller’s Journey From Model to War Photographer
text: London — In 1927, a chance encounter on a New York sidewalk with the media mogul Condé Nast made the gamine beauty Lee Miller a magazine cover girl and modeling sensation. Later, as the lover and muse of the artist Man Ray, her face and body were preserved in some of the most striking solarized portraits of the Surrealist age.

headline: Cate Blanchett and Her Red Carpet Journey
text: It was shortly after 8 a.m. on Wednesday and Cate Blanchett was 15 minutes late to breakfast.

headline: Are Squirrels Able to Enjoy the Changing Colors of Fall?
text: Q. Do squirrels see the colorful fall display of red, yellow and brown leaves?

headline: Inside Raqqa, the Capital of ISIS
text: A bustling city has been transformed under the group’s brutal rule.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from scenes of mourning on the streets of Paris to the stage at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Refugees Must Not Be Turned Away, Obama Says
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Obama vowed on Saturday to keep America’s borders open to the world’s refugees “as long as I’m president,” even as he met with child migrants and refugees here and his administration refused to yield in a long-distance feud with his critics over the issue.

headline: ISIS Women and Enforcers in Syria Recount Collaboration, Anguish and Escape
text: SOUTHERN TURKEY — Dua had only been working for two months with the Khansaa Brigade, the all-female morality police of the Islamic State, when her friends were brought to the station to be whipped.

headline: Brussels Placed at Highest Alert Level; Subway Is Closed

headline: FIFA Ethics Committee Recommends New Sanctions for Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini
text: Ethics investigators for FIFA, the ruling body of world soccer, have recommended sanctions be imposed on Sepp Blatter, the organization’s longtime president, and Michel Platini, the head of soccer’s European confederation, the organization said on Saturday.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Turkeys, News and News Turkeys

headline: ‘The Knick’ Season 2, Episode 6: A Circus Sideshow
text: Early 20th-century medicine often looks like a circus sideshow on “The Knick,” but never as literally as in this week’s episode. Haunting the dime-museum arcade, John Thackery took in a not-very-convincing hypnotist and a very persuasive pair of conjoined Russian sisters. Both put ideas into his head. Hypnotism seemed like a possible answer in his search for a cure to addiction, though an experiment involving Tom Cleary didn’t go so well. The sight of the twins inspired his pure medical curiosity, and soon, with Cleary’s help, he was kidnapping them from their manager and pimp and preparing to surgically separate them, with the help of his trio of protégés, Bertie Chickering, Algernon Edwards and Everett Gallinger. (The pimp was played with understated grotesquerie by Fred Weller of “In Plain Sight,” while the sisters were played by Miranda and Rebecca Gruss and an armature of artificial flesh.)

headline: Hyundai Cars Are Recalled Over Faulty Brake Switch
text: Hyundai is recalling about 305,000 of its 2011-12 Sonata models because the automatic transmission could possibly be moved out of park without pressing the brake pedal, allowing the car to roll or drive away, according to a report from the automaker posted this week on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s website.

headline: A Cherished Custom at Penn, Any Way You Slice It
text: University of Pennsylvania fans have a peculiar way of displaying school spirit at home games. They throw toast.

headline: U.A.W. Vote at Ford and G.M. Ends Painful Process for Big Three
text: DETROIT — After five months of bargaining and divisive ratification votes, the United Automobile Workers on Friday completed new labor contracts covering more than 140,000 workers at the three largest American automakers.

headline: Variety: A Tough Cryptic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Before we get started, I wanted to take a moment to mention the passing of Rosalie Moscovitch, who contributed cryptics and other variety puzzles to The New York Times. I never had a chance to meet her in person, but we corresponded behind the scenes. Ms. Moscovitch died Nov. 10 and she will be missed. If you would like to try her last variety puzzle that she co-wrote with Joe Cabrera, you can find it here.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 2: The Devil Did
text: Control is everything in another thoughtfully character-driven, albeit tonally wonky episode of “Jessica Jones.” We are constantly reminded of the show’s thematic concern with control through dialogue that underscores the way that everyone, from supervillain Kilgrave to good guy Luke Cage, struggles to stay on top of their lives. Jones knows that struggle well, as we see when she nurses a drink while investigating Kilgrave’s case. She snaps at her upstairs neighbors for the same reason: She can’t see the world beyond her own problems, and therefore despises people she imagines can’t handle their own private lives — in private.

headline: Mali Hotel Attackers Are Tied to an Algerian Qaeda Leader
text: A member of Al Qaeda in Africa confirmed Saturday that the attack Friday on a hotel in Bamako, Mali, had been carried out by a jihadist group loyal to Mokhtar Belmokhtar, an Algerian operative for Al Qaeda.

headline: Pentagon Expands Inquiry Into Intelligence on ISIS Surge
text: WASHINGTON — When Islamic State fighters overran a string of Iraqi cities last year, analysts at United States Central Command wrote classified assessments for military intelligence officials and policy makers that documented the humiliating retreat of the Iraqi Army. But before the assessments were final, former intelligence officials said, the analysts’ superiors made significant changes.

headline: Finding Ways to Thwart the Jerk at Work
text: Most of us have days at work when we walk around with a spring in our step and perform our tasks with gusto — and other days when our feet drag and we just can’t seem to get motivated. A new study encourages employees to look more closely at the people around them as one reason for that disparity.

headline: Bored to Tears by a Do-Nothing Dream Job
text: More than a decade ago, I was in the type of job where, if I had sat down at my desk and worked for 100 hours straight, I would be only slightly less behind than when I started. I was a newspaper editor, stuck in the type of never-ending grind that caused me to begin having a regular daydream.

I have loved in Paris, had children, dreamed, wandered, gotten lost, found myself again. At every intersection there is an invitation, on every bridge a recollection. The carnage, in this city, feels like a personal matter.

headline: ‘The Statue of Liberty Must Be Crying With Shame’

headline: Ruling From the Shadows
text: WE’VE come to expect bickering from our politicians. We’re often exasperated by this state of affairs and sometimes we yearn for a quieter, gentler age, when compromise wasn’t a dirty word. But the raucous rivalry in Washington has its benefits: a political process thick with competition. By contrast, political competition in other important parts of our democracy is worrisomely thin.

headline: Why Are Student Protesters So Fearful?
text: THE message coming out of recent student protests on college campuses, from Princeton and Yale to the University of Missouri, couldn’t be clearer: Students are rightly pained by the racist and sexual abuse still shockingly common into the 21st century, and for good reason they are indignant that institutions they trust — or wish to trust — fail to stop the culprits, or even to acknowledge publicly the harm they do.

The speaker expounded his thought. “She hits a bad shot and seconds later she’s laughing. She is so relaxed.”

headline: China’s Nuclear Vision Collides With Villagers’ Fears

But here among cornfields and crumbling stone homes skirted by persimmon trees, the government intends to build a nuclear power plant.

headline: Chicago Set for Protests Over Shooting by the Police

As cities like Ferguson, Mo., Baltimore and New York have been consumed by fatal encounters involving the local police that have fueled national attention since 2014, this city managed to keep a lower profile.

headline: Kim Young-sam, South Korean President Who Opposed Military, Dies at 87
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Young-sam, the former president of South Korea who replaced the last of the country’s military leaders, purged politicized generals and introduced a landmark reform aimed at transparency in financial transactions, died on Sunday in Seoul. He was 87.

headline: Michigan State Stuns Ohio State With a Late Field Goal
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Michael Thomas and Jalin Marshall, Ohio State’s best wide receivers, both had inexplicable drops on what should have been simple throw-and-catches against Michigan State on Saturday. The drops came on two of the staggering six three-and-out drives the No. 2 Buckeyes had.

headline: Cutting Water Use, but Still Getting Soaked
text: Amid drought in California, a disparity has emerged in who gets fined for excessive water use, with many wealthier residents getting off scot-free.

headline: In California, Stingy Water Users Are Fined in Drought, While the Rich Soak
text: APPLE VALLEY, Calif. — Outside her two-story tract home in this working-class town, Debbie Alberts, a part-time food service worker, has torn out most of the lawn. She has given up daily showers and cut her family’s water use nearly in half, to just 178 gallons per person each day.

headline: Donald Trump Calls for Surveillance of ‘Certain Mosques’ and a Syrian Refugee Database
text: Donald J. Trump said Saturday that he would order surveillance of “certain mosques” to combat terrorism after the Paris attacks and claimed to have watched as “thousands and thousands of people were cheering” while the World Trade Center towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: John Bel Edwards, Democrat, Defeats David Vitter in Louisiana Governor’s Race

headline: 1915: War Hospital In Paris Becomes Prey To Flames

The upper floors of the annex, which is situated at the corner of the rue de Sèvres and at the rue du Bac, were used as a war hospital, nearly 200 wounded soldiers being tended there. Exciting scenes occurred during the rescue of these helpless heroes, and the doctors and nurses of the hospital showed remarkable devotion.

headline: 1940: Fascists Driven From Key City in Greece
text: ROME — Capture by the Greeks of Koritza, Italian base eight miles inside the Albanian frontier, was announced today [Nov. 22] by the Italian high command. It said two Fascist divisions which since the opening of hostilities with Greece had held defensive positions on the Greco-Albanian frontier near Koritza had retired, after eleven days of fighting, to a line west of the city.

headline: Barbara Taylor Bradford: An Author’s Collection
text: Ms. Bradford has a story for almost every piece of her jewelry.

headline: From Barbara Taylor Bradford: A Life Story That Dazzles
text: The best-selling novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford had 40 pieces from her jewelry collection auctioned in 2013.

headline: ‘I Want to Be a Boy Scout.’ There’s Just One Hitch.
text: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — Five girls wearing makeshift scout uniforms stood before top Boy Scout brass this month and made an announcement: We want in.

headline: With Ben Carson, the Doctor and the Politician Can Vary Sharply
text: When he was not in the operating room at Johns Hopkins Hospital, performing one of his 400 surgeries a year, Dr. Ben Carson could often be seen walking slowly through the hallways, hands behind his back, nodding, smiling and speaking softly to co-workers and students who approached.

headline: The 2015 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Simulate the End of the Season for Any Team
text: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? It’s a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated. This interactive simulator walks you through the scenarios.

headline: From Vaccines to Creationism, Ben Carson’s Views Perplex Some
text: As a surgeon for three decades, Ben Carson carefully balanced his responsibilities as a physician with his deeply religious personal philosophy.

text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

headline: Practicing the Art of Misdirection, With Unsavory Intent
text: The three Colombians worked as a team, the police said, with polished coordination and improvisation, like a criminal jazz combo. Until they aimed too high.

headline: 7 Feet, 7 Blocks: Kristaps Porzingis Looms Ever Larger
text: Kristaps Porzingis is a player who inspires many debates. The arguments include what nickname best suits him — Godzingis and Three-Six Latvia are gaining traction after he said he was not a fan of Zinger — and his potential as a player.

headline: For Auto Enthusiasts, the Right to Tinker With Cars’ Software
text: Car owners in the United States can soon play Volkswagen engineer, courtesy of the federal government.

headline: Storied Brooklyn Church to Lose Its Keeper of History
text: The woman in the lavender jacket sat carefully on a bench beneath a portrait of a 19th-century preacher with bushy sideburns. They were almost as bushy as those on the more famous preacher she would spend the next 90 minutes talking about — the one for whom “Beecher boats,” “Beecher bibles” and the “Beecherama” were named.

headline: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post Said to Be Sentenced to Prison
text: A spokesman for the Iranian judiciary announced on Sunday that the jailed Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian had been sentenced to prison, an Iranian news agency reported.

headline: Defiance and Necessity Spur Mali Back to Normal After Attack
text: BAMAKO, Mali — On a sunny weekend morning, one day after gunmen went on a murderous rampage at the Radisson Blu hotel, a local dignitary sped across town in his official government S.U.V.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: It’s Singalong Sunday, with contemporary hits at the American Music Awards, a sequel to a Disney favorite and some rock ’n’ roll classics from the women who made the men sound great. Also, Trevor Noah flaunts his worldview.

headline: Our Simulator Can Assess Your N.F.L. Team’s Playoff Chances
text: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? It’s a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated.

headline: CNN Shows Sex Assault Film Despite Legal Threat
text: LOS ANGELES — In the face of threatened legal action from the football star Jameis Winston, CNN did not back away from broadcasting “The Hunting Ground,” a documentary about sexual assault on college campuses that has stirred controversy since its January debut at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Addicted to a Fantasy
text: Josh Adams owed $30,000 to friends and family when he finally decided to face his gambling addiction. Then he discovered fantasy sports.

headline: ‘The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2’ Opens Big, but Not Big Enough
text: LOS ANGELES – It was one of those weekends when a movie opened to massive ticket sales and still disappointed: “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2,” the finale of one of the decade’s biggest film franchises, took in about $101 million at North American theaters, a 17 percent decline from initial sales for “Part 1.”

headline: Thinking About the Trumpthinkable
text: Alan Abramowitz reads the latest WaPo poll and emails:

headline: 16 Arrests in Belgium Terrorism Raids
text: BRUSSELS — After a dramatic security sweep late Sunday marked by the deployment of soldiers in the historic center of the Belgian capital, the authorities here announced early Monday that 16 people had been arrested in a joint police and military operation to try to head off what the prime minister earlier described as a “serious and imminent” threat of a Paris-style terrorist assault.

headline: VSPs and the Case of the Disappearing BPEA
text: Brad Delong has nice things to say about my old Brookings Papers on Economic Activity on the liquidity trap, and asks why central bankers still don’t seem to get some of the basic points I made way back then, especially about the desirability of a higher inflation target. I actually have a few thoughts, which are inevitably mostly — but not entirely! — self-serving.

headline: Pfizer and Allergan Reach $150 Billion Merger Deal
text: Pfizer has clinched a blockbuster merger with a fellow drug maker, one worth more than $150 billion, that can best be described in superlatives.

headline: Donald Trump Again Insists He Saw Celebrations in New Jersey on Sept. 11
text: It’s a scene that, as Donald J. Trump describes it, would seem to be seared into the American consciousness.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on the Asia Pacific Summit
text: President Obama has called on China to halt its construction on reclaimed islands in the South China Sea.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Supports Those Who ‘Roughed Up’ Protester at His Event
text: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday he was in favor of the actions of his supporters who reportedly punched and kicked a protester from the Black Lives Matter movement who interrupted Mr. Trump’s campaign rally the previous day in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Israeli Woman and 3 Palestinian Attackers Killed in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Three Palestinians who each attacked Israeli Jews in separate episodes across the occupied West Bank on Sunday, were shot dead by Israeli civilians and soldiers, officials and witnesses said. One Israeli woman was killed in the attacks.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Campaign Unveils First Television Ad
text: Marco Rubio’s campaign is hitting the airwaves, releasing its first television ad on Sunday.

headline: Five Touchdowns for Cam Newton as the Panthers Remain Undefeated
text: Cam Newton spent the week dealing with the public’s debate of his ostentatious dancing. After he threw a career-high five touchdown passes Sunday, while helping his team reach 10-0, the public should talk about his ability to play football instead.

headline: Pearson’s Big Paydays Defy the Odds Against Print Media
text: It has been tough sledding for print media. More than 150 newspapers have closed or converted to digital-only offerings in the last two years. Recently the magazine giants Condé Nast and Time Inc. have both cut employees and closed magazines.

headline: Lack of Enthusiasm From Supporters May Undermine Clinton’s Lead
text: There’s cause for concern in Hillaryland, the constellation of Democratic advisers, supporters and politicians counting on the former secretary of state to lead the party to a sweeping victory next November.

headline: Cowboys Still Alive After Tony Romo’s Return
text: Tony Romo was not exactly the cure-all that the Dallas Cowboys were hoping for, but the star quarterback did enough in his much-anticipated return from injury to get his team its first win since Week 2, beating the Miami Dolphins, 24-14.

headline: Q. and A.: Jindong Cai on ‘Beethoven in China’
text: Jindong Cai, 59, is an orchestra conductor and a professor at Stanford University. He has conducted many orchestras in China and has been a guest conductor at numerous orchestras in the United States since moving there in 1985. With his wife, the writer Sheila Melvin, he has written numerous articles on China and two books on music in China: “Rhapsody in Red: How Western Classical Music Became Chinese” and their latest, “Beethoven in China: How the Great Composer Became an Icon in the People’s Republic.”

headline: Paris Attacks and Other Assaults Seen as Evidence of a Shift by ISIS
text: WASHINGTON — The recent attacks in Paris and Beirut and the downing of a Russian airliner in Egypt were the first results of a centrally planned terrorism campaign by a wing of the Islamic State leadership that oversees “external” targets, according to American and European intelligence officials.

headline: Adele’s ‘25’ on Track to Break Sales Records
text: When Adele released her new album, “25,” on Friday, it was sure to be an instant hit. The only question was how big.

headline: Jets Drop Ball, and J. J. Watt Drops Jets
text: HOUSTON — The Jets tried holding on to their playoff aspirations Sunday, but they dropped them, like the deep balls botched by their rookie receiver. The Jets tried sustaining those aspirations, but they were depleted by every sack they allowed, every interception they threw, every dose of gadgetry that stunned them into mediocrity.

headline: Sky’s the Limit for Porzingis, and He’s Closer to It Than Most
text: When Mike Breen and Walt Frazier, announcing on television, discussed how Kristaps Porzingis had tied the Knicks’ rookie single-game mark of seven blocked shots, Butch Beard had a flashback to the player who had set it.

headline: Once Again, the Big 12 Looks to Be on the Outside Looking In
text: In the third quarter of Saturday night’s game between Texas Christian and Oklahoma, with T.C.U. trailing by a manageable 23-13, Horned Frogs quarterback Foster Sawyer heaved a throw downfield right into the arms of Sooners safety Ahmad Thomas. Trevone Boykin, who had thrown 29 touchdown passes and accounted for nearly 3,500 yards in the air in a Heisman Trophy-worthy campaign before injuring his ankle in the previous week’s victory against Kansas, might have done better.

headline: Review: In ‘Beasts,’ BalletX Explores Nature and Nurture
text: PHILADELPHIA — There are many dance styles around America that aren’t to be found in New York, from local brands of hip-hop to individual subsections of ballet — and this is good for the dance health of the whole nation. Recently, when Ballet Memphis came to the Joyce Theater in New York, the sheer non-New-York-ness of its choreography and dancing struck many observers. I like to think that around the country there are many other such companies that New York audiences never see.

headline: Review: Jeremy Denk and Stefan Jackiw’s Lessons in Ives’s Nostalgic Sonatas
text: A concert offering all four of Charles Ives’s craggy violin sonatas might seem at first more a music history lesson than an engaging program. If not quite rarities, these fiercely original works are pretty close.

headline: Review: JACK Quartet and Anthony McGill Perform a Menu of American Delicacies
text: “The Wind in High Places” is a string quartet by John Luther Adams that uses only open strings and natural harmonics. Written in 2011 in memory of a friend and hiking companion, it evokes the glassy stillness of the Alaskan wilderness that for decades was Mr. Adams’s home and inspiration.

headline: Review: Max Emanuel Cencic and Il Pomo D’Oro Bring Baroque to the Met
text: How a singer conveys the text is usually an integral part of a vocal performance, assuming the listener understands the words and story or can rely on subtitles. Deciphering unfamiliar lyrics when syllables are elongated and ornamented can be a challenge in any language: Subtitles are often provided even for English librettos.

headline: Review: In ‘Beatlebone,’ an Imagined Trip With John Lennon
text: “Beatlebone,” the strange and exhilarating new novel by the Irish writer Kevin Barry, is about John Lennon — kind of. It follows him closely for around 200 pages, through a few comically calamitous days in 1978, as he travels through western Ireland to an island off its coast, bought on a lark 11 years earlier. He’s nearing 40 here; past drugs, past scream therapy, far past the Beatles, and stripped raw emotionally, tired “but not for sleeping,” full of “large sad warmish feelings.”

headline: Nepal Police Kill 3 Protesters in Clashes Over Constitution
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Violence flared in southern Nepal when the police open fire on protesters who had been blocking the country’s main highway, an official said on Sunday. The shootings threatened to deepen a political crisis over the country’s new Constitution.

headline: Review: A Beethoven Cycle From Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic
text: Claudio Abbado. Herbert von Karajan. Wilhelm Furtwängler. You are weighed upon golden scales, if you are the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic. And for good or ill, the balance tilts hardest in what is still thought of as classical music’s core repertoire: Mahler, nowadays; Brahms, naturally; Beethoven, forever.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 23
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Dark Knight III: The Master Race’ Comic Book Prompts Reflection and a Look Ahead
text: The opening panels of “Dark Knight III: The Master Race” depict a break-in at the Batcave. A display case containing the imposing costume of Batman, the DC vigilante, is smashed open and his emblematic cape and cowl are stolen, leaving only a bare mannequin.

headline: Persistence Pays Off
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — When last we saw Parker Lewis, he had constructed two New York Times puzzles in 2011. Before, Mr. Lewis had spent a couple of years in Namibia as a member of the Peace Corps, teaching MATH to middle school “learners,” as they are called in Africa.

headline: Review: Thomas Adès Calls for Complexity at City Center
text: When did dance audiences last see and hear a composer perform his own works with the revelatory mastery shown by Thomas Adès? Because the quadruple bill of his works “Thomas Adès: Concentric Paths — Movements in Music” came over the weekend to New York City Center, the mind flew to Stravinsky.

headline: Review: In ‘Beyond Time,’ U-Theater Dances and Drums With Precision
text: A solar eclipse and a torrential downpour descended on the stage of the Howard Gilman Opera House at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. Those were among the natural phenomena digitally conjured in “Beyond Time,” a production by the Taiwanese dance and drumming company U-Theater that was having its American debut.

headline: Review: Paco Peña’s Troupe Flaunts Its Inventive Flamenco Style at Town Hall
text: The Paco Peña dance troupe, based in London, passes through New York about once every two years, usually for a one-night-only concert. For anyone with a taste for flamenco at its most exciting, that isn’t nearly enough.

headline: Heroin, Survivor of War on Drugs, Returns With New Face
text: United States military operations in Afghanistan, now in their 15th year, are routinely described as America’s longest war. For overseas combat, that is true. But nothing tops the domestic “war on drugs” that an American president declared more than four decades ago. The casualty rate has been exceedingly high.

headline: Thanksgiving, With College Students: Fantasy, Reality, and Getting It Right
text: Here is the fantasy: After months of missing our college kids we eagerly await their return for Thanksgiving. In our dreams we spend cozy hours in the kitchen listening to them recount their experiences and marveling at the newly mature teen who sits before us. Our kids have looked forward to these days of rest and reunion and are thrilled to come home to the embrace of their families. Food will be abundant and family time sacred.

headline: Panels Advise Bolstering W.H.O. for Crises Like Ebola
text: In recent months, numerous groups of health experts have gathered to debate how to prevent another crisis like the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, which jumped borders, spread fear across the globe, and directly killed more than 11,000 people. Many more died as hospitals and clinics closed for months.

headline: Petco Nears $4.7 Billion Sale to CVC and Canadian Pension Plan
text: Petco is near an agreement to be acquired by CVC Capital Partners and the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board for $4.7 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Bahrain Abuses Continue Despite King’s Pledge, Rights Group Says
text: CAIRO — Bahrain’s security forces torture detainees using electric shocks, beatings and sexual abuse, despite a public pledge by the king of Bahrain four years ago to end such practices, according to a report released on Monday by the New York-based Human Rights Watch.

headline: Saeed Jaffrey, Actor in ‘Gandhi’ and ‘The Man Who Would Be King,’ Dies at 86
text: Saeed Jaffrey, an Indian-born character actor known internationally for his work in films like “Gandhi,” “The Man Who Would Be King” and “My Beautiful Laundrette,” died on Nov. 14 in London. He was 86.

headline: On Foreign Trip, Obama Yet Again Contends With Events Elsewhere
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Obama traveled more than 12,000 miles last week to shower attention on Asia. But he spent most of the trip in grim consultations about the attacks in Paris and Mali and in a long-distance war of words with Republicans.

text: Zendaya, Selena Gomez, Gigi Hadid and more at the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles.

headline: American Music Awards 2015 Red Carpet
text: Zendaya, Selena Gomez, Gigi Hadid and more at the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles. See photos from the red carpet.

headline: Gov. Cuomo to Order Large Increase in Renewable Energy in New York by 2030
text: Frustrated by the pending shutdown of two nuclear power plants on Lake Ontario, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to order state regulators to mandate that, by 2030, half of all power consumed by New Yorkers be generated from renewable sources that emit much less carbon dioxide, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: Artist’s Death Sentence Follows a String of Harsh Punishments in Saudi Arabia
text: SANLIURFA, Turkey — For years, Ashraf Fayadh, an artist and poet, has served as an unofficial ambassador for Saudi Arabia’s small contemporary art scene, organizing shows and working to introduce Saudi art to the world.

headline: Louisiana’s John Bel Edwards Overcame Big Obstacles to Win Governor’s Race
text: NEW ORLEANS — One evening in 2013, two weary Democratic legislators sat at their desks in the State Capitol, stared across the emptying House chamber and considered another unsuccessful day of fighting the governor. “Sam,” said one of the men, Representative John Bel Edwards, “I’m not staying in the House. I’m not doing this anymore.”
