text: Updated at 10:00 a.m.

headline: Ask Well: How Many Miles a Week Should I Run?
text: Question:

headline: Pope Francis, in Nairobi Slum, Denounces ‘New Forms of Colonialism’
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The pope got a taste of Kenyan slum life on Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: A Patek Watch and a Record Price
text: Watch industry buzz has been continuing all month about the $7.3 million price — a record high for a wristwatch — achieved by the Patek Philippe Reference 5016A-010 (left) at the Only Watch auction in Geneva. The amount was 10 times the low estimate of the sale price.

headline: Statement by Chinese Rights Campaigner Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
text: Yang Maodong, a Chinese human rights campaigner better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, was sentenced on Friday to six years in prison on charges of “assembling a crowd to disrupt public order” and “picking quarrels and provoking trouble.” Prosecutors had cited his role in organizing support for journalists protesting censorship at the Guangzhou newspaper Southern Weekend and for rallies calling for China to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

headline: Six French Films That Speak to the Identity of the Nation
text: The shock of the Nov. 13 attacks in and around Paris refocused attention on debates that have convulsed French society for decades — about the marginalization of the Muslim population, about the tensions between Islam and French Republican ideology, about the identity of the nation itself.

headline: Art for the Holidays: A New York Visitors Guide
text: So you’re coming to New York City around the holidays, and you’d like to see some art?

headline: Online Polls Are Rising. So Are Concerns About Their Results.
text: Two of the most important trend lines in political campaign polling might be about to cross.

headline: Q. and A.: Lu Yang on Art, ‘Uterus Man’ and Living Life on the Web
text: While the new media artist Lu Yang was studying at the China Academy of Art in Hangzhou in the 2000s, she drew up a series of works dealing with mind control. Many were deemed too sensitive, even borderline unethical, and remain unrealized. But with the help of the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum in Japan, Ms. Lu was able to obtain dead frogs that had been used in a medical dissection to produce one of the works. The result is a six-minute video called “Reanimation!  Underwater Zombie Frog Ballet” (2011), in which frogs wired to electrodes dance in water to a funky electronic beat.

headline: Turkey Seeks to Ease Tensions Over Shooting Down of Russian Jet
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey took steps on Friday to calm relations with Russia over the shooting down of a Russian warplane this week, calling for a presidential-level meeting, possibly at the climate talks in Paris next week.

headline: 100 Notable Books of 2015
text: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review. This list represents books reviewed since Dec. 7, 2014, when we published our previous Notables list.

headline: In ‘Transparent,’ a Heroine Evolves Further Still
text: LOS ANGELES — On the set of “Transparent,” a handful of actors dressed for a flashback scene on a 1930s ocean liner — cloche hats, woolen jackets, long skirts — crowd together on benches in a large wooden container perched atop a gimbal, a device that can simulate the rolling of a ship. Sitting cross-legged on a long table a few yards away, the director Jill Soloway, who created this Amazon series, quietly throws out a few suggestions to the gently swaying actors.

headline: 1957 | When Pfizer and The Times Worked Closely
text: Our editorial board wasted no words this week in describing the planned combination of the drug companies Pfizer and Allergan as a “tax-dodging maneuver that enriches shareholders and executives while shortchanging the public and robbing the Treasury of money.”

headline: 1915: Goal of American Red Cross
text: One hundred million dollars is the financial goal of the American Red Cross Society, announced yesterday [Nov. 9] at a meeting held at the residence of Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, 451 Madison Avenue. A movement was also started to place all war relief societies organized here since the outbreak of the war under the direct control of the Red Cross. Miss Mabel Boardman, head of the Red Cross organization, said she hoped the money would be given as an endowment fund to place the society on the same basis as the Rockefeller and Carnegie funds. She urged every man, woman and child in this country to join the Red Cross and give $1.50 a year to help in this new movement for preparedness. Mr. Joseph H. Choate presided at the meeting. — The New York Herald, European Edition, November 28, 1915

headline: Student Debt in America: Lend With a Smile, Collect With a Fist
text: The American student loan crisis is often seen as a problem of profligacy and predation. Wasteful colleges raise tuition every year, we are told, even as middle-class wages stagnate and unscrupulous for-profit colleges bilk the unwary. The result is mounting unmanageable debt.

headline: 1940: Students Clash in Zagreb
text: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia — An incident that carries with it a heavy charge of political dynamite occurred in the Croatian university town of Zagreb today [Nov. 27] when extreme Croatian Nationalist students clashed with a group of ‘‘moderate’’ students supporting Dr. Vladko Matchek’s policy of co-operation with the Serbs. The fight, in which a number of students were seriously wounded, occurred on the occasion of a meeting held within the university by the extremist group, which favors independence for Croatia. The university was closed and guarded by the police so as to avoid a possible disturbance, but the ‘‘moderate’’ students — those favoring Yugoslav national unity — forced their way in through the cellar and tried to break up the meeting. The clash which ensued ended only when the police quickly restored order and made a number of arrests. The incident assumed special importance in view of Yugoslavia’s uncertain diplomatic relations with a number of her neighbors. The position of this country, nearly surrounded by potential foes, resembles that of Czecho-Slovakia in 1939. In the internal situation, too, there is a parallel. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 28, 1940

headline: Inside the List
text: Killing Santa: Every year, around the time mall stores start playing “Frosty the Snowman” and Starbucks breaks out its red cups, the best-seller list hangs its stockings by the fire and waits for a visit from Richard Paul Evans. You know Evans: He’s the one whose self-published debut, “The Christmas Box,” sold something like eight million copies in the mid-1990s and landed him a fat contract with Simon & Schuster; since then, his cozy holiday-themed books have included “Finding Noel,” “The Christmas List,” “A Winter Dream” and “The Mistletoe Promise,” among others. Now he’s back, right on cue, with “The Mistletoe Inn,” new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 9. What draws Evans so repeatedly to Christmas? Readers prone to psychoanalyzing might find a clue on his website, where Evans describes the “tsunami of misfortune” that hit his family in 1970, the year he turned 8. “My father lost his job and couldn’t find work, and my mother began to exhibit the first signs of severe depression. My Tourette’s syndrome manifested that year and I was ticking like crazy. In addition, I wet the bed every night, made worse since I shared the bed with my brother,” he writes. “During this dark time I had a soul-crushing fourth-grade teacher named Mrs. Covey. I’ll never forget two weeks before Christmas when she ridiculed those of us who still believed in Santa with the words: ‘Your parents lied to you. There is no Santa.’ Crushed, I went home and asked my mother if she had lied. My mother frowned. She said, ‘Santa is the spirit of giving.’

headline: What Is Holding Back the Economy?
text: The Great Recession began in December 2007, and ended officially in June 2009. As of October 2015, the unemployment rates in half the states in the country had fallen to or below their pre-recession levels. In the other half, unemployment rates were still higher than before the recession.

headline: Iceland, Ireland, and Devaluation Denial
text: One of the big lessons of the euro crisis has been that Milton Friedman was right — not about monetarism, but about the case for flexible exchange rates. When big adjustments in a country’s wages and prices relative to trading partners are necessary, it’s much easier to achieve these adjustments via currency depreciation than via relative deflation — which is one main reason there have been such big costs to the euro.

Its right arm, elevated at a 90-degree angle like a passer’s, and its left, lowered and tucked into the body like a runner’s, each have half of a football stitched into them.

headline: Amaranto in Bushwick Is a Family Effort

Mussels gawk from the bowl, mouths full of chorizo, cut in hunks like lardons.

headline: As Pope Francis’ Visit Nears, Central African Republic Violence Rises

headline: An Alley Entrance for a NoHo Condo
text: The New York City alley, in all its grittiness, has long been a Hollywood favorite. Yet, in reality, New York has only a handful of them, as the designers of the city’s grid left little room for such passageways. Now one of the remaining few, Great Jones Alley, between Broadway and Lafayette Street, will assume a more rarefied role when it becomes the exclusive entrance for a 12-story condominium.

headline: At Grace Farms, Encountering Art at Every Bend

From farther away, approximately 10,000 of those cubes coalesce into a flowing form stretching 61 feet across a curved wall. Wherever viewers stand, the piece changes with the weather, the season and the time of day.

headline: Lauren Bacall’s Dakota Apartment Sold for $21 Million
text: The grand apartment at the landmark Dakota that Lauren Bacall called home for more than half a century, filling its nine commodious rooms with an eclectic mix of artwork, antiques and countless mementos, many of them from her fabled Hollywood career, sold for $21,000,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: How Daniel Jacobs, Boxing World Champion, Spends His Sundays
text: Daniel Jacobs, a son of Brownsville, Brooklyn, is the World Boxing Association’s middleweight champion. Before that, he was a cancer survivor. Mr. Jacobs, 28, learned he had osteosarcoma in 2011, which could have ended his career. Instead, after surgery and radiation, he returned to the ring 19 months later and has been undefeated since. He is set to defend his title against Peter Quillin at Barclays Center next Saturday. In the months before a fight, Mr. Jacobs lives and trains on Long Island, leaving only to spend Sundays in Brooklyn with his partner, Natalie Stevens, 28, a makeup artist, and their son, Nathaniel Jacobs, 6.

headline: When Some Turn to Church, Others Go to CrossFit
text: Ali Huberlie, a 27-year-old education consultant in Boston, awakens at 4:45 every morning to go to her CrossFit “box,” or gym, where she spends two hours. When she and her boyfriend, whom she met through CrossFit, went apartment-hunting, they chose a neighborhood near their box. This year, as a student at Harvard Business School, Ms. Huberlie wrote a case study about a founder of CrossFit that was incorporated into the school’s curriculum. And when Harvard Divinity School researchers were studying spaces other than churches that function as spiritual communities, they interviewed Ms. Huberlie.

But inside, amid the cozy music room, the rehearsal was heating up as the pianist Michael Boriskin and the ensemble Music From Copland House rendered a rousing version of Charles Ives’s epic Trio for Violin, Cello and Piano.

headline: Baking Cookbooks That (Gently) Push the Limits
text: With cookbooks, those on the savory side have a lot more leeway to showcase innovative ideas and far-flung dishes. Armchair chefs are just as happy to read about smoking eels over green hay and butchering small game as they are to find a recipe for the best macaroni and cheese.

headline: 3 Are Dead in Colorado Springs Shootout at Planned Parenthood Center
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — A gun battle erupted inside a Planned Parenthood center here on Friday when a man armed with an assault-style rifle opened fire and began shooting at officers as they rushed to the scene. The authorities reported that three people were killed, a police officer and two civilians, and nine were wounded before the suspect finally surrendered more than five hours after the first shots were fired.

headline: Review: Ann Hampton Callaway Honors Her Predecessors at Feinstein’s/54 Below
text: Ann Hampton Callaway belongs to the school of gifted pop singers for whom majestic vocal display is not enough. Along with Barbra Streisand and Celine Dion, to name two obvious examples, Ms. Callaway uses pyrotechnics as a platform for conveying inspirational messages of peace and hope. And the opening-night performance of her new show at Feinstein’s/54 Below, “Feminine Persuasion: Ann Hampton Callaway Celebrates Women Songwriters,” often had a sticky undertone of sentimentality.

headline: Shooting in Planned Parenthood Clinic
text: Authorities responded to an “active shooter” near a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs.

headline: The Pain in Spain Falls Mainly Away From BBVA
text: BBVA, Spain’s second-largest bank, is often seen as more conservative than its Spanish peers. That reputation now looks deserved. The bank is the only major domestic player that does not have exposure to Abengoa, the Spanish engineering company seeking protection from its creditors.

headline: Restaurant Review: Porta Napoli Offers Pizza for Every Palate
text: In early September, Porta Napoli in Harrison took the place of Rue des Crepes, known for its theatrical Parisian décor and its neatly folded buckwheat crepes. It is Naples, not Paris, that the new proprietors hope to bring to mind. “Authenticity” is the catchword. Wood embers glow in a fire-engine-red pizza oven, which spreads cheer like a giant emoji. Menu headings are in Italian (sfizi, insalate, pizze rossi, pizze bianche). The flour in the supple pizza dough is “00” (doppio zero), as required by the Associazione Verace Pizza Napoletana. The wine list covers regions from Sicily to the Alps but never strays beyond Italy’s borders.

headline: In London, Portuguese Fare, Served With a Twist
text: Though the chef Nuno Mendes was born in Lisbon and trained mostly in the United States, it’s his London restaurants — Chiltern Firehouse, for example — that have gained attention. His latest is Taberna do Mercado in East London’s Old Spitalfields Market. The informal, tightly packed 40-seat restaurant (with additional tables and a charcoal grill outside) looks like a sleek version of a Portuguese tavern: nothing fancy, but with plenty of attention to materials and details (including seating that is all too authentic: Some of the wooden chairs are really too small for grown-ups). The atmosphere is convivial; we had fun at the tiny concrete-topped bar, drinking and watching sausages being sliced.

headline: As World Leaders Launch Paris Climate Talks Monday, Bill Gates Will Launch a Supporting Science Push
text: Here’s the White House announcement on “Mission Innovation” and Bill Gates’s explanation of the Breakthrough Energy Coalition:

headline: Permanent Punk Invasion
text: “This is Pepe,” said Denise Mercedes, pulling out another cigarette and walking past her resplendent white cockatoo. “You should see him dance. He knows more about music than half the people I’ve played with.”

headline: Review: ‘Nora,’ Ingmar Bergman’s Adaptation of Henrik Ibsen’s ‘A Doll’s House’
text: Torvald Helmer isn’t generally viewed as a likable guy, but Ingmar Bergman thought of him that way. To him, the injured party at the end of Henrik Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House” is Helmer, crushed by the “aggression and brutality” of his wife, Nora.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Atelier Florian in New Haven, Seafood Is King
text: Is there a better finish to a cold, blustery day on the New England coast than a steaming bowl of bouillabaisse? I mean the real deal: a rich, tomatoey, fish broth fragrant with saffron, fennel and garlic, and crowded with seafood that — if you’re lucky — was caught just a few miles away.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Sandbar, Familiar French Hands Behind the Menu
text: Sandbar, a sparkling new restaurant that opened in Cold Spring Harbor in late September, is a beauty. Diners enter through a bar with a soaring glass ceiling and emerge into an elegant dining room with plenty of windows, 11 chandeliers and pale, sand-colored walls. The light, bright room nonetheless has a subdued nautical look, with antique mahogany half hulls lining the walls, along with lovely paintings of the harbor by local artists.

headline: Window Onto a Butcher Shop at the Cooper Hewitt
text: When visitors walk through the big bronze doors of the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, they are issued the Pen, the institute’s remarkable Internet-accessible stylus. The 1901 Beaux-Arts building then becomes, in the words of The Atlantic magazine, “the museum of the future.”

Striking it may be, but it’s not for sale, said Mr. Betten, the 41-year-old founder of Lost Art, a leather goods company that caters pretty much exclusively to fashion and rock royalty.

headline: ‘Jaco,’ a Documentary About the Jazz Musician Jaco Pastorius
text: When Jaco Pastorius first met Joe Zawinul, the keyboardist and composer behind Weather Report, he had his introduction ready. “My name is John Francis Pastorius III,” he said, as Zawinul later remembered. “I’m the greatest bass player in the world.”

headline: New Women’s Political Party in Britain Demands Faster Equality
text: LONDON — It may seem an inopportune time to start a new party, given Britain’s crowded political scene, but Sandi Toksvig says she is tired of waiting.

headline: National Geographic Takes Travelers to the Falklands
text: Lindblad Expeditions-National Geographic is introducing Falklands 360°, its circumnavigation of the Falkland Islands. The voyage will also feature a visit to Argentina’s Isla de los Estados, a national nature preserve. Set aboard the 102-passenger National Geographic Orion, the 13-day expedition will depart twice in October next year. Rates begin at $10,850 per person based on double occupancy.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Bagatelle
text: Accessories and charms are dangling from bags and carryalls. The idea started with the Fendi Lagerfeld fur-doll charm, but Victor-John Villanueva’s portraits have enlarged the idea to the level of a child’s fantasy or the balloons in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. A favored subject of Mr. Villanueva is the late performance artist Leigh Bowery, an outrageously dressed drag provocateur from Australia who was the toast of London clubs in the 1980s.

text: “The Spymasters” begins with an act of vengeance.

headline: The Season’s Fashion Books From Cindy Crawford, Terry Richardson and More
text: There’s often an exotic quality to the massive, lushly photographed books that emerge on coffee tables every holiday season: They dazzle the eye with distant icebergs, cheetah-flecked savannas, endangered birds midflight, coral reefs and majestic mountains. But some of this year’s most striking gift books evoke the natural beauty of monuments much nearer at hand.

headline: Preparing ‘The Golden Bride’ for Its Big Day
text: Rachel Policar, a 27-year-old with a master’s degree in vocal performance, has been trained to sing German, French and Italian. Yiddish? Not so much.

headline: Kentucky, Beacon for Health Law, Now a Lab for Its Retreat
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Carolyn Bouchard, a diabetic with a slowly healing shoulder fracture, hurried to see her doctor after Matt Bevin was elected governor here this month.

headline: A Slippery Number: How Many Books Can Fit in the New York Public Library?
text: As New York mysteries go, it hardly competes with “Who’s buried in Grant’s tomb?” or “How many pigeons live in the five boroughs?” But for devotees of the New York Public Library, the question of how many books can be stored in the majestic central stacks on Fifth Avenue is far from academic. They say it goes to the heart of the library’s mission to keep as many research books as possible within arm’s reach of scholars.

headline: Gunfire at a Colorado Planned Parenthood Clinic
text: A gunman inside the clinic in Colorado Springs engaged in a shootout with the police, killing three people and wounding others.

text: Celebrating a Parisienne’s style, cultural exchange and more.

headline: Bill Gates Expected to Create Billion-Dollar Fund for Clean Energy
text: WASHINGTON — Bill Gates will announce the creation of a multibillion-dollar clean energy fund on Monday at the opening of a Paris summit meeting intended to forge a global accord to cut planet-warming emissions, according to people with knowledge of the plans.

headline: Bobs Are Back
text: Naomi Campbell, Gigi Hadid, Demi Lovato and more sport winter’s It-chop.

headline: BTG Pactual, Brazilian Bank, Seeks to Calm Investors After C.E.O.’s Arrest
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — With its chief executive in jail, BTG Pactual tried to calm investors on Friday, saying that it would cooperate with any investigation.

text: A gunman injured at least 11 people, including five police officers, at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Civil Wars, Billie Jean
text: Last week I featured The Lone Bellow reinterpreting the Rolling Stones, which was great; but by far the most revelatory cover I’ve ever heard is this one, by the oh-so-sadly broken-up Civil Wars:

headline: Black Voices Against Black Friday
text: Protesters gathered on Chicago’s main shopping streets Friday to disrupt the shopping frenzy and draw attention to what they say is police brutality.

headline: Road to Robotic Parking Is Littered With Faulty Projects
text: MIAMI BEACH — It seemed like the perfect night life accessory for the South Beach set — an automated robotic parking garage where trendy clubgoers could park their Porsches with a futuristic touch of a button.

headline: Cubans Protest Stricter Rules for Traveling to Ecuador
text: MEXICO CITY — Dozens of Cubans crowded outside Ecuador’s embassy in Havana on Friday, worried and angry about new rules that require Cubans to have a visa to enter Ecuador, which is a vital steppingstone for islanders trying to migrate to the United States.

headline: Instability in Marketplaces Draws Concern on Both Sides of Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The latest turmoil in health insurance marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act has emboldened advocates on both sides of the political spectrum, providing ammunition to conservatives who want to shrink the federal role and liberals who want to expand it.

headline: Paris Attacks Darken Tone of G.O.P. Campaign Ads
text: The terrorist attacks in Paris immediately changed the course of the presidential race as national security and foreign policy rose to the top of stump speeches and television interviews.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: M.T.A. Contract Workers Push for Higher Wages and Better Working Conditions
text: Month after month, workers from a call center in Queens arrived at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s board meetings in Lower Manhattan to complain about low wages, a hostile work environment and bedbugs in their office.

headline: With Fewer Skaters, N.H.L. Hopes for More All-Star Competitiveness
text: The N.H.L. announced last week that the All-Star Game, which had essentially become an Ice Capades, with virtually no contact and far too many goals, would be played in a three-on-three format, which has been used for the first time this season in the five-minute overtime period.

headline: Mental Illness Cited in Murder Case of Manhattan Hedge Fund Manager
text: A few years ago, Thomas Gilbert Jr. appeared to have it all: movie-star looks, wealthy parents, an Ivy League education and entree to elite social circles in Manhattan and the Hamptons.

headline: Two Sets of Twins Trace Lifetime Link to Two Teammates
text: As a rookie linebacker and long snapper with the Dallas Cowboys in 1984, Steve DeOssie assumed a mentality of being “crazy all the time.” A second-year teammate, however, made an important impression. Defensive end Jim Jeffcoat showed DeOssie that it was possible to assume a separate mentality off the field.

headline: Black Friday Shopping Shifts Online as Stores See Less Foot Traffic
text: In shops across the country, including the empty malls of Georgia and the “not too crazy” crowds at struggling J. Crew, the relative calm that accompanied Black Friday shopping this year belied a frenzy for deals — many of them on the web.

headline: The New Atomic Age We Need
text: THIS past summer, the Group of 7 nations promised “urgent and concrete action” to limit climate change. What actions exactly? Activists hope for answers from the coming United Nations climate conference in Paris, which begins Monday. They should look instead to Washington today.

headline: Affordable Housing vs. Gentrification
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio has a plan that he says will preserve economically diverse neighborhoods in New York City, significantly and permanently increase the affordable-housing supply and create a more attractive streetscape. In community meetings across the city, New Yorkers are finally having their chance to say whether they agree with him.

headline: France’s Cult of Fearlessness
text: Paris — SINCE the attacks two weeks ago, I’ve been avoiding supermarkets — which seem like potential targets — and doing most of my shopping at a minimarket. The cashier there, a young man from Mali, keeps telling me not to be afraid.

headline: President Obama’s Hypocrisy on Syria
text: IN 2008, Barack Obama won the presidency promising that he would heal our political divisions. Instead, Mr. Obama has been as polarizing as any president in the history of modern polling. The debate over the Syrian refugee crisis illustrates why.

headline: The Danger of Urban Oil Drilling
text: Many Los Angeles residents are familiar with a sight that may seem strange to outsiders: an oil pump operating mere feet from businesses or homes. A recent lawsuit claims that the city has systematically failed to address drilling’s environmental consequences, especially in lower-income neighborhoods that are majority black and Latino.

headline: Helping Others and Accepting Help
text: Marvin Grossman, who will turn 79 on Tuesday, is used to doing things on his own. He never married or had children, but his life is filled with reading, writing and classical music. He is always willing to lend a hand to an elderly neighbor by running errands or doing the laundry.

headline: Setsuko Hara, Japanese Star of Films by Ozu and Kurosawa, Is Dead at 95
text: Setsuko Hara, one of Japan’s most beloved actresses, best known for her subtle portrayals of women torn between the demands of family and their own desires in “Late Spring,” “Tokyo Story” and other films directed by Yasujiro Ozu, died on Sept. 5 in Kamakura, near Tokyo. She was 95.

headline: Eldzier Cortor, Painter of Scenes From African-American Social Life, Dies at 99
text: Eldzier Cortor, a painter and printmaker perhaps best known for his elegant paintings of nude black women created when such works were seldom seen in the mainstream art world, died on Thursday at his son’s home in Seaford, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 99.

headline: Unblinking Gazer
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — On Saturdays, you have to approach a crossword carefully, with a healthy dose of suspicion, at least as it applies to the clues. Things are definitely not what they seem, but that’s what can make solving the toughest puzzle of the week so much fun. And today, the cluing is especially thoughtful and tricky.

headline: Joan Duddy, Nurtured Dance and Joyce SoHo in Manhattan, Dies at 78
text: Joan Duddy, an influential curator and advocate for new dance as the founder and director of the dance program at the Dia Center for the Arts (now Joyce SoHo) in Manhattan for 18 years, died on Nov. 7 in Cambridge, Mass. She was 78.

headline: A Rite to Improve Karma for Man, Creature and, Now, the Environment
text: “It works better with turtles — turtles just stand there and stare at you,” Shi Benkong said as he stood near the Great Lawn in Central Park on Tuesday near several cardboard boxes containing not turtles but restless, rustling birds.

headline: With Legal Aid, Immigrant Advocates Turn Focus to Citizenship
text: This election season, Sandra Ocampo is running her own campaign.

headline: Former Rikers Inmate Who Received Settlement Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn
text: For Robert Hinton, 2015 was supposed to be a year of new beginnings. In March, he was released from prison after serving time for a parole violation. In September, he was awarded $450,000 by New York City to settle a lawsuit against several jail guards who hogtied and severely beat him in 2012 while he was incarcerated at Rikers Island.

headline: With Little Bench Relief, Knicks Run Out of Steam
text: The Knicks won 17 games last season, so the mere fact that they are no longer an unmitigated laughingstock has engendered an understandable measure of satisfaction among the team and its fans.

headline: Battling Blindness and a Family Health Crisis, but Seeing Hope
text: Impaired vision has kept Cimeron DuBose from working for nearly 20 years. The days could be tedious, but they were also filled with purpose.

headline: Garrett Swasey, Officer Killed in Colorado, Is Recalled for Courage and Faith
text: Garrett Swasey, 44, the University of Colorado Colorado Springs police officer who was shot and killed while responding to a shooting at a Planned Parenthood office, was described by his fellow church members and friends as a courageous man and loving father who drew strength and inspiration from his Christian faith.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “There are people out there for whom this may be the only record they’ve bought in five years. The last one may have been ‘21,’ and now they’re coming back in force.”

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: Take a walk on the wild side with “Tangerine,” watch the Property Brothers build edible homes and choose between a couple of spy movies — one real, one not so much.

headline: Corrections: November 28, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Addicted to Distraction
text: ONE evening early this summer, I opened a book and found myself reading the same paragraph over and over, a half dozen times before concluding that it was hopeless to continue. I simply couldn’t marshal the necessary focus.

headline: A New York Trainer to Men About Town
text: Brendan Fallis, the D.J., entrepreneur and fashion model who is engaged to Hannah Bronfman, had a conundrum that many men concerned with fitness and style can relate to.

headline: OMG! The Hyperbole of Internet-Speak
text: The text exchange was unspectacular: a friend explaining a video that had been posted by a classmate to his Snapchat feed. Jordana Narin, my 20-year-old research assistant, was half paying attention, sitting in my living room working on a project, texting between breaks.

headline: Swell of Tupperware-Type Parties Overwhelms City Dwellers
text: Nine women were gathered in the immaculate Midtown East apartment of Mallorie Corcoran, 29. Tall, svelte and long-maned, the guests and their hostess clustered around a table in the living room, picking at fruit platters and sandwiches but generously pouring themselves wine and seltzer.

headline: Elaborate Holiday Windows Dress Up New York Department Stores
text: It was 61 degrees on a recent November evening, but the scaffolds outside Lord & Taylor on Fifth Avenue were trimmed with artificial fir, and Santa Claus himself was bopping with Liz Rodbell, the store’s president, to Austin Mahone’s “Mmm Yeah.”

headline: The Return of Werner Erhard, Father of Self-Help
text: The silver-haired man dressed like a waiter (dark vest, dark slacks) paced the aisle between rows of desks in a Toronto conference room. “If you’re going to be a leader, you’re going to have to have a very loose relationship with this thing you call ‘I’ or ‘me,’” he shouted. “Maybe that whole thing in me around which the universe revolves isn’t so central!”

headline: Paris Climate Talks Avoid Scientists’ Idea of ‘Carbon Budget’
text: After two decades of talks that failed to slow the relentless pace of global warming, negotiators from almost 200 countries are widely expected to sign a deal in the next two weeks to take concrete steps to cut emissions.

headline: Tibetans Fight to Salvage Fading Culture in China
text: YUSHU, China — When officials forced an informal school run by monks near here to stop offering language classes for laypeople, Tashi Wangchuk looked for a place where his two teenage nieces could continue studying Tibetan.

headline: Tashi Wangchuk: A Tibetan’s Journey for Justice
text: Worried about the erosion of Tibetan culture and language, one man takes his concerns to Beijing, hoping media coverage and the courts can reverse what he sees as a systematic eradication.

headline: In Colorado, Bustling With Shoppers, Then Gripped by Chaos
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — The injured man staggered into the grocery store, his face and chest bloodied. Customers stopped and stared. “He lifted his shirt up, and he had holes in his chest,” said Miranda Schilter, 17, who had been waiting for a drink at an in-store coffee shop.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from Hong Kong to the Lower East Side of New York.

headline: 一名藏人的追求正义之路
text: 带着对本族语言和文化即将消亡的担忧，一名男子来到北京，希望媒体报道和法院能够改变这种在他看来是系统性灭绝的现状。

headline: A Plumbing Problem: Sludge in the Bathtub
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Roots of China’s Real Estate Rush
text: Chinese money is reshaping real estate markets, as companies and individuals snap up commercial and residential properties.

headline: Chinese Cash Floods U.S. Real Estate Market
text: Canyon Lake Ranch was once a playground for Christian day campers, and then was a corporate retreat with water-skiing, barbecues and cowboy shoot-’em-up shows. Hawks now circle above 108 sunbaked acres occupied by copperhead snakes, a few coyotes and the occasional construction truck.

headline: House-Hunting, Chinese-Style
text: Chinese families are looking for a safe place to invest their renminbi. From rural Texas to Silicon Valley, American real estate is an increasingly popular destination for their cash.

headline: Ohio State Band Shows Flair Even as It Sticks to the Script
text: As fans clad in scarlet and gray clapped along to “Le Régiment de Sambre et Meuse” on a warm September day in Columbus, members of Ohio State’s marching band and its alumni went about precisely spelling “Ohio” in script on Ohio Stadium’s field.

headline: Prominent Kurdish Lawyer Is Killed in Southeast Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — A prominent Kurdish lawyer and a Turkish police officer were killed on Saturday when clashes erupted after he spoke at a news conference in Turkey’s volatile southeast.

headline: Pope Francis Offers Mass in Uganda at Shrine for Christian Martyrs
text: NAMUGONGO, Uganda — On the very spot where some of this nation’s first Christians were burned to death for adhering to their beliefs, Pope Francis offered a Mass for hundreds of thousands of Ugandans on Saturday.

headline: Big City Book Club
text: As the year winds down, the Big City Book Club is seeking the wisdom of the crowds to help make our next selections. For our next meeting, which will convene in early January, we’re asking for your suggestions: What is the best New York-centric book you read in 2015? For those of you just joining us now, you can read about previous choices here. There were some heavy hitters set in the city published this year, like “City on Fire,” by Garth Risk Hallberg, about New York in the ’70s; “Smash Cut,” by Brad Gooch, about the ’80s; and “A Little Life,” by Hanya Yanagihara, about traumatic transitions to adulthood. But the books you propose need not have been published in 2015. One of our liveliest recent discussions was about “The Custom of the Country,” by Edith Wharton, published in 1913.

headline: Nudging the Boss for Your Performance Review
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Anh Nguy: Research Is Her Recipe
text: Anh Nguy, 41, is a culinologist at Ingredion. She works in Bridgewater, N.J.

headline: 2 Dead in Brooklyn House Fire Caused by Power Strip, Officials Say
text: Sharon Hinds, a home health attendant, was walking home from a party along a street in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn early on Saturday when she heard screams and smelled smoke coming from a two-story house.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic That Floats
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Do you have a hobby, a pastime, a passion that you find difficult to describe adequately to people who do not share your passion?

headline: Obama Says ‘Enough Is Enough’ After Colorado Shooting
text: President Obama responded angrily on Saturday to the mass shooting that took three lives, including that of a police officer, at a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado Springs over the Thanksgiving holiday, calling the country’s recurring outbreaks of gun violence “not normal.”

headline: Big Companies Put Their Money Where the Trash Is
text: The recycling industry has a dirty little secret: Much of the plastic that consumers diligently sort is never actually recycled. Instead, some of those yogurt containers, translucent takeout boxes and bottle caps are buried in landfills or incinerated.

headline: A Pitch Is Framed by Diplomacy in Cuba
text: HAVANA — A minibus of Americans rumbled through a city in transformation, past the run-down housing and round-the-clock construction, the sparsely stocked bodegas and chic new restaurants, to a reception at the residence of the American chargés d’affaires. The hint of change teased the November night.

headline: Demand, Supply, and Macroeconomic Models
text: I’m supposed to do a presentation next week about “shifts in economic models,” which has me trying to systematize my thought about what the crisis and aftermath have and haven’t changed my understanding of macroeconomics. And it seems to me that there is an important theme here: it’s the supply side, stupid.

headline: Healthier, Wiser and Back With the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Craig Dahl, an undrafted rookie safety from North Dakota State, was a long shot to make the Giants in 2007. His roommate that season, linebacker and long snapper Zak DeOssie, was another first-year player trying to make the team.

headline: With Steve Kerr Sidelined, Warriors’ Perfect Start Raises Questions of Credit
text: In a flawless start to the season, it is tempting to try to find fault amid the perfection. With the Golden State Warriors displaying no obvious issues on the court, close watchers of the team have set their sights on a rule that prevents Luke Walton, the interim coach, from getting credit for any of the victories.

headline: Marco Rubio Bets the Grand Old Party Is Ready for His Younger Face
text: There is nothing particularly flashy about the endorsements that have been rolling in for Senator Marco Rubio lately: a handful of Republican members of Congress, mostly junior and not terribly influential.

headline: A Step Forward for Contraceptive Access
text: Patients seeking birth control pills today typically have to get a prescription from a doctor, but reproductive health advocates have long argued that this process is unnecessary since the pills are safe for a vast majority of women. Now two states are about to allow patients to get them from a pharmacist without seeing a doctor first. Other states should consider similar moves.

headline: Voting and Self-Interest
text: Why do many poor people support politicians who are opposed to a generous safety net?

headline: One Governor’s Extraordinary Year
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — NEWLY bald and always blunt, Gov. Larry Hogan was wondering about his hair. When it might grow back. How it might grow back.

headline: Don’t Feel Bad About ‘Bad Sex’
text: DEAR Nominee,

headline: Another Baltimore Injustice
text: Baltimore — THE trials of the six officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, the 25-year-old black man who died after suffering a spinal injury in police custody, begin tomorrow. As a public defender here, I have watched the cases of the officers move through the Baltimore City Circuit Court.

headline: Could Your Healthy Diet Make Me Fat?
text: SOME people eat as little fat as possible to lose weight and stay healthy, while others avoid carbohydrates. A vegan diet (with no animal products) and the paleo diet (with lots) both have enthusiastic devotees. One popular diet encourages intermittent fasting, another frequent small meals. Who’s right?

headline: Notes on the China I’m Leaving Behind
text: BEIJING — I GOT together at a restaurant the other night with some Chinese and expatriate friends. While bossa nova played in the background, we sipped French merlot and snapped iPhone photos of one another making goofy faces.

headline: Frank Sinatra in Hoboken: If I Can Make It There ...
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — “How did all these people get into my room?” Frank Sinatra happily shouted in 1966, as he arrived before a cheering crowd and a swinging band eager for his concert at the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas. Backed by the Count Basie Orchestra, Sinatra recorded a virtuoso album that graying Sinatra fans still listen to for a whiff of life’s sheer exuberance and drive.

headline: What Comes Out in the Wash
text: SYDNEY, Australia — ASK most people about the problem of waste plastics in the environment and they will talk about plastic bags caught in trees and the vast slicks of plastic trash found in remote areas of the Atlantic and Pacific. But the most menacing plastic waste problem is less visible and not so well publicized.

headline: What the Paris Climate Meeting Must Do
text: In 1992, more than 150 nations agreed at a meeting in Rio de Janeiro to take steps to stabilize greenhouse gases at a level that would “prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system” — United Nations-speak for global warming.

headline: The Smartness Act of 2015
text: PUBLIC LAW 114–69 114th CONGRESS

headline: Digital Culture, Meet Analog Fever
text: IN the course of a recent move, I decided to “cut the cord” — that is, walk away from cable television and fully embrace the streamed-entertainment revolution. I felt very digital. Just a few weeks later, however, I discovered something that surprised me: Thousands of my fellow cord-cutters have taken to buying antennas, to pick up the seemingly quaint format of over-the-air television signals.

headline: Tales of a Warmer Planet
text: Paul Smiths, N.Y. — IT’S a mistake to think the climatic effects of our carbon emissions will be over within a few decades or centuries. Our intergenerational responsibilities run much deeper into the future.

headline: Contaminating Our Bodies With Everyday Products
text: IN recent weeks, two major medical organizations have issued independent warnings about toxic chemicals in products all around us. Unregulated substances, they say, are sometimes linked to breast and prostate cancer, genital deformities, obesity, diabetes and infertility.

headline: Versatile Standout Finds a Position, and a Home with Portland Timbers
text: There was never any doubt that Darlington Nagbe had talent. Talent is what made him the national player of the year in college, and it is what earned him goal of the year honors in his rookie season in Major League Soccer. It is also what drew the attention of United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann, who eagerly threw Nagbe into two games this month almost as soon as the ink on his new citizenship papers was dry.

headline: Red Bulls’ Home Edge Faces Stiff Test
text: The Red Bulls’ playoff game against the Columbus Crew on Sunday is already the biggest match at Red Bull Arena this season. The result will determine if it is also the last.

headline: Spain Yesterday, Syria Today
text: BETWEEN 1936 and 1939, the Spanish Civil War condensed the awful drama of the 1930s into one conflict. Spain was where left-wing illusions about Stalinism went to die, where Hitler’s war machine tuned up for the Blitzkrieg, where aerial bombardments of civilians and politically-motivated “cleansing” were normalized. It was a proxy war for the totalitarian powers, a magnet for volunteers from around the Western world, and an object lesson in the impotence of Europe’s liberal democracies.

headline: Short Answers to Hard Questions About Climate Change
text: The issue can be overwhelming. The science is complicated. We get it. This is your cheat sheet.

headline: The Heart Disease Conundrum
text: SOUTH ASIANS today account for more than half of the world’s cardiac patients. Heart disease is the leading cause of death in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, and rates have risen over the past several decades. South Asian immigrants to the United States, like me, develop earlier and more malignant heart disease and have higher death rates than any other major ethnic group in this country.

headline: Eric Winston
text: Eric Winston is an offensive tackle for the Cincinnati Bengals and the current president of the N.F.L. Players Association.

headline: With Poor Starts Giving Them Fits, the Jets Plan to Go Back to Basics
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The good news about the Jets is how well they tend to play after halftime. Only three teams — New England, Arizona and Houston — have outscored opponents by more points in the second half than the Jets have (49).

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Dolphins at Jets
text: 1 p.m., CBS

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Giants at Redskins
text: 1 p.m., Fox

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: With Diversity Comes Intensity in Amherst Free Speech Debate
text: AMHERST, Mass. — Hundreds of students crammed into Amherst College’s Robert Frost Library for a sit-in against racial injustice that turned into a confessional, as one black or Hispanic student after another rose to talk about feelings of alienation and invisibility on campus.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Forget About Gargling, Coach. Just Learn to Project.

headline: Obama’s Legacy at Stake in Paris Talks on Climate Accord
text: WASHINGTON — At a joint news conference here Tuesday with President François Hollande of France, President Obama veered from his focus on the terrorist attacks in Paris to bring up the huge international gathering beginning in the French capital on Monday to hammer out a global response to climate change.

headline: Ohio State and Ezekiel Elliott Run Wild Against Overmatched Michigan
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Jim Harbaugh stood near the line of scrimmage, bent over, his hands on his knees, watching intently as Ohio State lined up needing a yard to convert a fourth down. Ohio State had knifed through Harbaugh’s defense all day. He looked as if he wanted to run onto the field and tackle Ezekiel Elliott, the Buckeyes’ running back, himself.

headline: In Spain, New Political Party Makes Gains From Surprising Place — the Center
text: BARCELONA, Spain — The splintering of politics in Europe has spawned the rise of numerous upstart parties, usually on the extremes, be they left or right.

headline: Transgender Argentines Confront Continued Murder and Discrimination
text: BUENOS AIRES — Diana Sacayán was found tied up in a 13th-floor apartment in Buenos Aires in October, stabbed to death. A month earlier, Marcela Estefanía Chocobar, 26, was decapitated and her body dumped on a vacant lot in Río Gallegos, in Patagonia. Also in September, in Santa Fe, a city on Argentina’s Pampas lowlands, the corpse of Fernanda Olmos, 59, was discovered on her bedroom floor, a plastic bag pulled over her head. She had also been stabbed.

headline: Siege Highlights Security Used in Abortion Clinics
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — As the heavily armed police officers entered the Planned Parenthood clinic here to hunt down the gunman and rescue those trapped inside, they had an advantage that seemed like something out of the movies. Officers in the command center outside the clinic were able to tap into security cameras throughout the complex, watch the siege unfold and give precise instructions to officers inside.

headline: Four-Letter Words
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — What does it say about someone’s character if they are wont to throw around four-letter words? Probably nothing; I’m not sure why I even brought that up.

headline: Norman C. Pickering, Who Refined the Record Player, Dies at 99
text: Norman C. Pickering, an engineer, inventor and musician whose pursuit of audio clarity and beauty helped make phonograph records and musical instruments sound better, died on Nov. 18 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 99.

headline: Josephine Chaus, Co-Founder and Re-Inventor of Fashion Brand, Dies at 64
text: Josephine Chaus, a fashion executive who founded Bernard Chaus Inc. with her husband and later rescued it from the brink of collapse, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 64.

headline: Coping After a Shooting in Colorado Springs
text: People gathered in the city for a vigil the day after a gunman killed three people at a Planned Parenthood clinic, while investigators searched for a motive.

headline: Merkel, While Refusing to Halt Migrant Influx, Works to Limit It
text: BERLIN — With as many as one million refugees having arrived in Germany this year, Chancellor Angela Merkel has found herself increasingly isolated in Europe and markedly less popular at home than she was during the crisis over the euro this spring.

headline: Ex-Wife Says Robert Dear, Suspect in Colorado Rampage, Showed Few Signs of Obsession
text: GOOSE CREEK, S.C. — The blue eyes of Pamela Ross, 54, wince and cloud when she thinks back on the years that she spent with her ex-husband, Robert L. Dear Jr. They were together 16 years or so, and married for about a dozen of them.

headline: After a Defeat in Houston, the Fight for Gay Rights Shifts to Jacksonville
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The first major gay rights showdown since Houston’s rancorous vote to repeal its anti-discrimination ordinance is shaping up here in Jacksonville, the largest city in the nation whose leaders have never enacted civil rights protections for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: Obama’s Bookstore Haul: A Franzen, a Rushdie and a Wimpy Kid
text: It may say something about the era that even in his pleasure reading, President Obama cannot seem to get away from the dicey modern issues of security and liberty.

headline: James Prideaux, Writer for Stage and for Television, Dies at 88
text: James Prideaux, who wrote television movies that starred Katharine Hepburn and Elizabeth Taylor and a play for which Julie Harris won a Tony Award for best actress, died on Nov. 18 in West Hills, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Meetings, and Morning Workouts, With Members of Congress
text: Representative Tulsi Gabbard sometimes straddles a line between being a next generation leader for Democrats and a prominent critic of her party’s leaders.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard, Rising Democratic Star From Hawaii, Makes Mark on Party by Defying It
text: WASHINGTON — Between the chilly temperatures and the pace of the push-ups, there was plenty to complain about after eight lawmakers straggled into the park behind the Longworth House Office Building for their regular 6:30 a.m. workout.

headline: Another Loss Leaves Rangers to Face Their Flaws
text: Just seconds after he had flattened Philadelphia defenseman Nick Schultz with a ruthless check, Rangers defenseman Dylan McIlrath found himself face-to-face on Saturday with the snarling Flyers defenseman Luke Schenn, who had taken exception to the hit and flung down his gloves.

headline: Robert Dear, Suspect in Colorado Killings, ‘Preferred to Be Left Alone’
text: HARTSEL, Colo. — Robert L. Dear Jr. was a man who lived off the grid.

headline: Battling Depression, a Young Man Finds Joy in Computers
text: Moises Ramos is a great talker. When he is comfortable — and he often is nowadays — he will settle back in a chair, arms hanging loose by his sides, and he will smile and gush about his new friends, his love of computers and the art he is working on.

headline: Complexity and Contradiction
text: The painter Sam Gilliam talks to Rashid Johnson, who is known for his installation art.

headline: Painting the 20th Century
text: Eldzier Cortor (1916-2015), a painter and printmaker, was part of a generation of black artists whose work was overlooked by many institutions but is now being recognized.

headline: Two Generations
text: Talking to the sculptors Betye and Alison Saar, who live and work in Los Angeles.

headline: Black Artists and the March Into the Museum
text: The painter Norman Lewis rarely complained in public about the singular struggles of being a black artist in America. But in 1979, dying of cancer, he made a prediction to his family. “He said to us, ‘I think it’s going to take about 30 years, maybe 40, before people stop caring whether I’m black and just pay attention to the work,’ ” Lewis’s daughter, Tarin Fuller, recalled recently.

headline: Chris Christie Endorsed by Key New Hampshire Newspaper
text: Chris Christie’s long-shot presidential campaign got a lift on Saturday night with the endorsement of The New Hampshire Union Leader, an influential paper in the state where the New Jersey governor has camped out in the hopes of catching fire.

headline: ISIS’ Grip on Libyan City Gives It a Fallback Option
text: MISURATA, Libya — Iraqi commanders have been arriving from Syria, and the first public beheadings have started. The local radio stations no longer play music but instead extol the greatness of the Islamic State’s self-proclaimed caliph, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

headline: Stanford Kick Sends Notre Dame’s Playoff Hopes Reeling
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — At the moment the ball went through the uprights, the Stanford players, coaches and fans spilled onto the field.

headline: Giants Losing Linemen
text: The Giants will face the Washington Redskins on Sunday without much of their starting offensive line as both center Weston Richburg and left guard Justin Pugh did not travel to Washington with the team Saturday. Pugh is recovering from a concussion and was not expected to play, but the Giants had been hopeful about Richburg, who sprained his ankle in the Giants last game on Nov. 15. The veteran John Jerry will replace Pugh, and Dallas Reynolds, a longtime N.F.L. backup, will most likely be the center. The starting tight end Larry Donnell, who has a neck injury, has also been ruled out for Sunday’s game.

headline: Angie Canuel, Steven Kantor
text: Angie Ellen Canuel and Steven Lloyd Kantor were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Roger Ross at the Rainbow Room, an events space in New York.

Matthews, both of Tulsa, Okla., and a stepson of Barry S. Lyons. The Rev. Dr. Warren G. Blakney, ordained by the Church of Christ, officiated at Vintage Court, an events space in Covington, La.

Rubinstein and Jonathan Glick, both of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Stanley J. Savage performed the ceremony at Rodef Shalom Congregation in Pittsburgh.

text: Lynn Burnside Smith II and John Michael Durnil were married Wednesday at the Bethesda Terrace Arcade in Central Park in New York. Sarah J. Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

text: Morgan Rae Walker, a daughter of Pia R. Walker and James C. Walker of Atlanta, was married Wednesday to Nicholas Peter Mider, the son of Barbara Kolsun and Paul A. Mider of New York. The Rev. Steven P. Schulte, an Evangelical Lutheran minister, officiated in Monterey Square in Savannah, Ga.

headline: Rebecca Cleary and Elizabeth Stribling-Kivlan
text: The couple met at a mutual friend‘s home, where they ate pad thai and watched “Law and Order: SVU.”

Ruocco of Grand Island, N.Y. Peter Ruocco, the godfather of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Twentieth Century Club of Buffalo.

headline: Jaclyn Wagner, Patrick Boyle
text: Jaclyn Jean Wagner and Patrick Thomas Boyle were married Friday at the Olde Mill Inn in Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Jimmy Smith, a Celebration Community Church minister, officiated.

headline: Janie Bonacorsi, Alexander Waldman
text: Janie Iris Bonacorsi, the daughter of Fay H. Bonacorsi and Thomas A. Bonacorsi of Cedarhurst, N.Y., was married Saturday to Alexander Scott Waldman, a son of Miriam Waldman and Robert A. Waldman of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Dovi Scheiner officiated at the Battery Gardens restaurant in New York.

headline: Allison Ferrari and Stephan Panagiotakis
text: Allison Gene Ferrari, a daughter of Catherine V. Ferrari of Little Neck, N.Y., was married Friday to Stephan George Panagiotakis, the son of Frederica Sagianis and George Panagiotakis of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Vince Corso, a minister with the International Council of Community Churches, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse Ballroom.

headline: Daniella Malekan, Bradley Gershel
text: Daniella Sarah Malekan, a daughter of Mojdeh Malekan and Manny Malekan of Sands Point, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Bradley Ross Gershel, the son of Linda Gershel and Alan M. Gershel of West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi Aviad Bodner officiated at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

headline: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
text: BRIAN HILL The Wyoming sophomore rushed for 232 yards and a touchdown, setting a team record for rushing yards in a season, as the host Cowboys defeated Nevada-Las Vegas, 35-28.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “He lifted his shirt up and he had holes in his chest.”

headline: A Wealthy Governor and His Friends Are Remaking Illinois
text: The richest man in Illinois does not often give speeches. But on a warm spring day two years ago, Kenneth C. Griffin, the billionaire founder of one of the world’s largest hedge funds, rose before a black-tie dinner of the Economic Club of Chicago to deliver an urgent plea to the city’s elite.

text: LAMONI, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz, responding to a critical ad from allies of Senator Marco Rubio of about his national security record, said on Saturday that his rival’s campaign was clearly “very, very dismayed” about the direction of the race and the fact that conservatives “are uniting around our campaign.”
